description:
Pros: the coffee, the service, the pastries, holy cow a coffee shop that doesn't close at 5p in SF
Cons: SF + good coffee = overpriced 

Finding a good coffee shop in SF that stays open past sunset is more frustrating then being delayed at the airport. For some reason, it is really really hard to find ANY open coffee shop in 90% of the city after 530p. Yet another sign that SF is not really ready to be considered a primetime major city worth it's rep...but I digress. 

This all makes Ritual really stand out to me. First it's open until 8 everyday(!!). Second, the coffee is good. Really good. This is the perfect place to buy a distinctly SF gift for your F&F. I would say the coffee is usually more tasty and not as brutally strong as sightglass, and more refined than Philz. Service is friendly and quick. In true SF fashion, you can encounter long lines on weekend mornings but otherwise it's usually very reasonable. You can also expect a very reasonable selection of pastries and on a sunny day there is cool outdoor seating. Indoor seating is  plentiful and offers numerous work spaces. Like all cafes in SF, using the bathroom can be adventurous bc of the homeless problem but it is available. 

Caveats? I have no idea how WiFi works here bc I don't trust/do public WiFi (use at your own risk). Paying $5 for coffee is also frankly not sustainable for most folks. Refills? 

Overall: highly recommended (but please don't crowd me out on Sunday morning ok?)
author: Andrew C.

description:
Not a big coffee person (yet), but my friends are, and I went with them to Ritual on Saturday. 

Ritual has a nice open space with interesting art on the walls that rotate every so often. Was going to opt for a tea, but then I saw the Nibbler and figured I'd try that because of the Dandelion Chocolate incorporated.

If you're a chocolate person, I'd *highly* recommend the Nibbler while it's being offered! The coffee was super smooth and not bitter at all. You can definitely taste the chocolate, but it's not overly sweet. My one complaint is that I wish my cup was bigger and/or it contained less ice and more of the drink!

Even a few days later, I'm still thinking about the Nibbler and how good it was.

Ritual has a rewards program in the form of a physical stamp. They don't automatically give you one (at least in my experience), so definitely ask for it if you think you'll be a regular or even periodically frequent the shop.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
3.5 stars

TL;DR
1. Good coffee (iced lattes were yum!)
2. Crazy prices (two iced lattes were $10... sorry, what?!)
3. Cute interior (big, bright, airy, modern)
4. It was very cold, though (they keep the doors open on both ends of the cafe)
5. Bathroom was a mess (Like, second/triple/quadruple-guess how much you actually have to go, messy and gross.)

Gave a three as I doubt I'd return. There are too many awesome coffee shops to settle on a mediocre one - sorry!
author: Nic Z.

description:
Good hipster coffee. Came by with a group of friends after eating an early dinner to get some caffeine to explore SF. 

I got a regular drip coffee which was strong and a bit acidic. My fiance got the cold brew which was really good. Strong and bold, but not too acidic. 

Service was good. Seating available, but wouldn't recommend this place to get work done (unless you have noise canceling headphones or something) as theres lots of people coming in and out and people who were seated were mainly chatting with friends.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
San Francisco has a LOT of great coffee, and there are quite a few places in the city where you can get an amazing cup of joe. However, if you find yourself in the Mission and are craving a coffee, Ritual should be your first choice. Here's what's so awesome about it:

1) The coffee! Both their pour-over (V60) coffee and espresso are great. They have multiple options for either, meaning you can choose exactly the flavor profile you want. They roast all their own beans, and while you can find them at many different stores around town, the best selection and freshest roasts are all here. They also offer a few teas.

2) The food! They offer both regular and vegan pastries, meaning people with a dairy allergy can also grab a pastry to go with their coffee. Their vegan donuts are particularly good!

3) The service! As I said above, there is a lot of good coffee in SF, but (unfortunately) there are also quite a few snobby/pretentious baristas too. Luckily, you won't find any of them here, as every Ritual barista I've had has been super friendly and approachable about any and all questions I've had, no matter how "basic" they have been. This is super refreshing!

4) The space! A wonderful setting with lots of seating and even a cute back patio that offers a bit of quiet in a very loud city. 

All in all, Ritual is one of my favorite places to go for coffee in San Francisco, and my top choice in the Mission. Give it a try!
author: Brian S.

description:
Very nice and picture worthy coffee shop but it comes with a high price tag!

My usual go-to drink is an iced mocha so that's what I ordered. It cost $6.25 which is the most expensive iced mocha I have bought even compared to Blue Bottle or Andytown.

Customer service was ok and pretty fast even though they were very busy.

This place has such a nice interior, very hipster and nice. I love how this place offers both inside and outside sitting, which is nice and dog friendly.

Now for my drink, it was a very delicious iced mocha. However there was nothing that made it extra special compared to other coffee shops. It was good but so pricey for a cup of coffee. Espresso was very strong, not super sweet and had a strong real chocolate taste.

Overall if I was in the area I would prob try another drink because their menu is pretty interesting.
author: Michele G.

description:
Great coffee comes with a bit of a hipster vibe, and terrible coffee in a trendy neighborhood is invariably accompanied by exclusive hoards of rather annoying hipsters.  Somehow Ritual is situated in trendy Mission but brews an excellent cuppa and has a nice, mixed bag of customers.

The coffee itself is great and the ambiance is open, airy and relaxed.  Seating on a weekend is tough to come by unless you're flying solo and don't need a camping spot, but always plenty of standing bar space along the wall.

Line moves quick compared to a couple other coffee spots in the area, so if you've only got 10m and need some caffeine, just avoid the pour over and you'll be fine.
author: Nathan B.

description:
They've renovated this flagship Ritual outlet since my first review and visit here many years ago, with the result being that it's a more airy, modern-feeling space that can accommodate more seated customers at a variety of spaces, whether counters in the front and middle or small tables in the rear.

Thanks to its reasonably long hours (open until 8pm daily), it's still a dependable go-to for me while in the Valencia corridor. The coffee is as good as it's always been. While there's no wi-fi and few (if any) power outlets, there are still just as many, if not more, laptop loiterers as before. It's a productive place for a meeting, conversation, or a quick work session on your laptop.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Considering that "Ritual Coffee Roasters" ranks as one of the top five Bay Area-based coffee shops, there's no wonder why this location has a very high amount of Yelp reviews. Reason being is that this was their very first location that opened its doors back in 2005. Since then, they now have a total of 6 coffee shops; 5 in San Francisco and 1 in Napa. 

Located in the heart of the Mission District directly on Valencia St. (in between 21st and 22nd St's), many people who have never been here before may not even realize the business is here. Their trademark is a red flag resembling a star and an outline of what looks like a coffee cup. My lady and I arrived roughly around 10:30am on a beautiful Saturday morning. Since we drove here, we luckily found parking right outside the business! Do keep in mind that this is metered parking which the city charges Monday through Saturday.

Upon entering, the building itself has a long rectangular shape to it. From an aesthetics perspective, it is very spacious, inviting, and bright. And with the light earth tone colored walls throughout, it allows an abundance of natural light inside. There are a few select prints along the walls and area to purchase their coffee beans, coffee mugs, high-end espresso machines, and even books. This is an example of one of many coffee houses that almost has the look and feel of an art gallery.

Ritual offers a simplistic yet effective menu of options. Everything from basic brewed coffee to drinks that are used with the Hario V60 dripper. And of course your basic espresso drinks including cappuccinos, macchiatos, lattes, and mochas. They also offer a nice little tea selection as well as hot chocolate and Chai lattes. There is a pastry selection including croissants, muffins, and scones but the choices are quite limited.

As far as our drinks, I ended up ordering a 16 oz. Cold Brew w/cream while she opted for their 'hot' Latte w/vanilla syrup added (available at the condiment station). We also split a blueberry vanilla scone to share. Both our drinks come out within a minute of another as we both grabbed a seat inside by the window. My drink packed a nice punch as I loved the bitterness and strength of their coffee. Her latte was very creamy, frothy, and sweet while the espresso flavor was on point. 

Overall, we were both very impressed with the delicate process of making their coffee drinks at "Ritual Coffee Roasters". The reason why I am deducting a star from this place is that there is no Wi-Fi! C'mon guys, your business is one of the major tech cities in the world, at least let us connect online! Another is that their are no power outlets for charging your phone/tablet/laptop. And finally, the prices are a bit steep but keep in mind, this is San Francisco when everything is at a premium. Aside from those little negatives, I still highly recommend this place for the avid coffee drinker. My rating, four solid stars.
author: Donovan H.

description:
Good coffee, no WiFi. I was in town and came across this shop. Needing to get work done, I pulled out the laptop and realized they had no WiFi but it was too late, I already ordered. Then after realizing I needed to charge my laptop I looked around to see there was only 1 outlet for the entire back end of the shop. 

No biggie, just typed on a word document until the battery died out. Solid cup of joe tho.
author: Gabriel V.

description:
Wake up and smell the coffee!

Urban decor here and I love their smooth coffee blend as well as the aroma!

Nice seating and good to lounge over a cup.  

Hip and happening spot!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Here is what I liked:

1. I ordered some sort of savory onion cheese muffin and it was moist and delicious.
2. I liked the space.  The cafe is large, clean and open
3. Tried a sip of my friends cappuccino an that was delicious

Here is what I was not crazy about:
1. The clientele seemed like they were straight out of central casting.  "Actors needed to play Mission Tech Hipsters". 
2. Service was lackluster.  
3. It was painfully loud. We left because we couldn't hear each other and wanted to talk. 
4. The drip coffee was cold and I personally did not care for the flavor at all.
author: Laksmi V.

description:
What a fancy looking coffee shop. If I didn't search this place on yelp beforehand, I would have easily passed on by not knowing what their logo stood for. 

I ordered their hot latte with soy milk and I was surprised by the taste. I've never had coffee so smooth and creamy before. Although, I felt they could have slightly added more coffee to give off a stronger flavor but regardless, I still enjoyed my cup for the day.
author: Ester S.

description: I have been going to Ritual since early last year and this location is one of my favorites! I always order Latte with Almond Milk and their latte really tastes better than other places, seriously. I also love getting their vegan donuts there and on the weekend, they have more variety of pastries, but getting early (at least before 11am) is a must. I also love that they have a reward program: a punch card that is: buy 10 get 1 FREE so that's pretty cool.
author: Kobsupang R.

description:
This bathroom has a messy-chic aesthetic. Given its prime location in the Mission I can't say that I had very high expectations -  nevertheless I was surprised that the bathroom's aesthetic doesn't match the clean and elegant aesthetic of Ritual itself. 

Upon entering one notices a dim mood lighting that accentuates the enigmatic nature of the layered text that serves as wallpaper. It was only after minutes of squinting that my eyes adjusted to the light and I was able to read parts of the wallpaper. 

The layout of the bathroom was definitely access friendly, and the gender inclusivity of these restrooms leads to my 5/5 rating. The bathroom, while low on toilet paper laid out for customers, had a nice backup supply, and there was plenty of hand soap available for even the most dedicated of germaphobes. 

The distance between the sink and hand dryer are also optimal - not too much distance to splash all over the floor, yet not too close to blow air directly into the sink. 

The highlight of my restroom experience was definitely the door. There are not one but four hooks, so that even the busiest of shoppers can hang all of their bags on the door. Bravo, Ritual!! 

Also - there are in fact two restrooms, though I was only able to enter one in my time at this Ritual location. 

Overall, I enjoyed a dimly lit yet well stocked bathroom that gets the job done. 

P.S. I also ordered an espresso at this location - I received a dreamy and perfectly balanced shot that achieved a nice sweetness while also managing to retain a full body. Not too sour, not too bitter. In fact, while I usually return to locations based off of their bathrooms, I would honestly come back to this Ritual for the espresso alone. I also managed to snag a shot of a latte that my friend ordered, which I have included because I am impressed by the perfect micro foam needed to achieve the highly coveted latte swan.
author: Maya C.

description:
Beautiful space and, most importantly, I had a delicious latte. Definitely in the upper echelon of espresso drinks in a city filled with them. 

However, the space could definitely use more electrical outlets. It's a little odd that they don't have Wi-Fi, but a fellow customer told me that's one of the reasons she likes it here. She lives in the neighborhood so I'll give her the nod and say maybe that's not a bad thing. Maybe...
author: Ted R.

description:
I love Ritual.  The employees are kind, friendly, and go out of their way to show they appreciate us as customers!  They've given us free pastries towards the end of the day, and more than a few times, the baristas have bought us coffee!  

The coffee itself is extraordinary!!  It's so delicious that my sister gets deliriously happy every time I send her a couple of bags, and my mother-in-law actually approves (she's a total coffee snob, and drinks it black).  I'm an iced latte or quadruple-shot-of-espresso kind of girl, but the pour-over coffee is very fabulous, too.

The pastries are mostly very tasty.  I think I've only had one thing that I didn't care for, and it's probably more because I'm not really a flaky-pastry kind of person.  I'm ADDICTED to their chocolate-and-sea-salt-topped peanut-butter rice krispie treats!!!  I almost didn't want to admit that in this review, because then y'all will all go there and buy them, and I won't be able to get one when I stagger in at 7:45 pm looking for my coffee and a treat!

This store is blissfully 100% WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE, including the bathroom!!

Ritual Coffee is also clean, well-lit, and spacious, with ample seating.  It has a sparse aesthetic, so if you're looking for plush, upholstered furniture to lounge on, this won't meet your needs.  They DO have bench seating in the front part of the coffee shop, so you CAN spread out a little bit!  

There's also a parklet out front with a long bench and big table, a lovely bit of outdoor seating for a warmer day or even a chilly one, if you have the right coat and enjoy the fresh air!

Even though I love this place, if I could change two things about it, it would be for them to stay open past 8 pm, and for them to have wi-fi.  But honestly, almost all of the coffee shops in the Mission close by 8 pm and don't have wifi...So much for the days of hanging out late into the evening in coffee shops chatting or playing on your computer!!

I heartily recommend Ritual to anyone and everyone!!!
author: Amy L.

description: This is a coffee shop without WiFi. Not sure how that is possible in Silicon Valley. However the coffee was good and the music is very chill. Shame that I couldn't hang out to do some work because they don't have WiFi!!!
author: Roberto G.

description:
For coffee I went to SF knowing I was going to try this place!  

Simply said this has to be one of the highest quality of coffee being served in the bay area.  I can't say it's the best, but gotta be top 10 easy.  I'm blessed with keen sense of smell , and the aroma of the roasted coffee beans here is unbelievable.  And the taste wow.

I will be back and back some more for the coffee. Just the coffee is 5 stars.
author: Kevin O.

description:
I had only been to the Napa location before today, and I loved my experience here. First off, the interior is warm and inviting, with a good amount of seating in the back, a long standing bar if you want to stand and sip your coffee, and patio seating in front. Cute swag too lol! I ordered a soy latte and my sister got a macchiato and both drinks came out quick and were perfectly made. My latte was very smooth and wasn't overly sweet or bitter. I loved it. I'm glad we decided to come here as our last stop before leaving the city. 

Not sure if they offer gluten free or vegan treats but I will check next time I visit.
author: Mel L.

description: Great coffee ! Also tried a few pastries... the guava pastelito was good but I'd pass on the scones.  Line was out the door but staff was pretty quick.  They have a huge seating area.
author: Jolleen S.

description: This was our second stop on our self-guided coffee tour on a recent trip to SF, so we walked down here from Four Barrel right afterwards. I didn't know this was their original location from when they first opened, and after hearing that they recently renovated the space, I was eager to see it. The place is very open and bright with lots of merchandise available near the front. I don't remember my coffee unfortunately (not that it was bad), but I was too distracted people watching and noticing all the homeless bums outside. There is definitely a big homeless problem in SF, if this neighborhood that is not the tenderloin with a very successful hipster coffee shop has homeless bums sleeping right outside their doors. That being said, I would still try to stop by this place again just for their coffee.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters iced coffee was refreshing after walking in the blazing sun for more than an hour. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Great quick stop for coffee or ice tea drinks. 

Very spacious. 

Friendly staff. 

I like this place. I hope you give it a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
i just went once and it was love at first sight. 
I was taken by a friend who is a coffee lover and knows a great deal about coffees. we had cappuccinos and it was frothy and so yummmm!!

Cant' wait to go back
author: Subha J.

description:
Yet another blazing hip cafe in the city! Street parking wasn't as bad as I thought (there's also a garage within ~2min walking distance. Luckily there wasn't much of a line when we stepped in, but throughout our stay the line did get long enough to be "out the door."

I like that they have their own beans though! Grabbed one of their Kenya's to take home. Two of the three of us got teas, which were fruity and refreshing. The interior is very well kept and is plentiful in natural lighting. Seating can be tough to find as it's a good place to camp out and get some work done. They even have pastries for some light snacking depending on how long you stay!

3 seems a bit harsh (as the reviews glare at me from the threatening side bar), but my logic is this: pretty solid, easy 3.5. Bathroom was (and felt) so smelly..worse than supermarket bathrooms. Don't know if I just caught a bad day though. I just figured if they can make the exterior so pleasing, the inside should match too!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
I honestly bookmarked Ritual Coffee Roasters based on the look of the store from the photos on Yelp. I was super intrigued! I went here after my lunch at Mau restaurant down the street at 1:25pm on Tuesday. 

Large space for coffee. The layout and interior reminds me of a coffee stand within a museum. There is something interesting about the design, and I loved it. I also liked that they have cards on different brew methods and how to brew them at home. I have never seen that in any coffee shop and I appreciated the enhanced coffee knowledge for customers. 

I want to add that when I was here with my friend the store was slightly busy but also steady. When I came back at 245pm, it was PACKED!!! I was shocked, in a good way. 

Cleanliness (4/5): clean. stocked. well kept. The bathrooms were cleaned (at least the one I went into was, not sure about the second one). The only concern was the amount of flies right in front of the back door to the "garden viewing" space. I definitely would not want to sit near that space. 

Customer connection (4/5): cashier and barista were nice. normal level of friendliness. I will applaud the cashier for being honest when I asked how their chai tastes (yes, I actually remembered to ask whether it was on the sweeter or spicy side)! 

Service/Product Quality (3/5): I ordered an iced chai and my friend order the nitro cold brew. The chai was as the cashier described ... a balance between sweet and spice. Which I 100% agree. Except, the chai was a little more milky than I had anticipated. My friend's nitro cold brew was super light and I tasted a tangy aftertaste. It wasn't bad.
author: Martin N.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop so far in the city, in terms of taste; and I'm so glad that I did not miss it during my stay.

Very different from Blue Bottle, the other CA local chain. It was smooth like silk, and balanced at the same time - almost gave me a nostalgia feeling. 

Latte art was heartily made too. I wish I could just stay here and enjoy my whole day! Definitely would love to return and give a try on some of the bakeries.
author: Elaine H.

description: Coffee was just what I needed first thing in the am. Tasted rich! I got a latte and I got a shot of expression on the side
author: Nico R.

description:
Love their coffee. Nice seatings and decorations are simple and very cozy.
Has Almond milk to make latte so I loved it.
Very clean and staffs were friendly and answered some my question very politely.
I really hope they can come to LA area soon. I love their coffee more than S and P coffees.
author: Mayu H.

description:
Solid spot, consistently good. Not so hip though. 

They need to deal with the fact that animals provide emotional support. 4 barrel, haus, Philz, etc all have dog bones. Ritual needs to get to speed.
author: H K.

description: Good and trendy. We got tea and coffee and we're satisfied. I do feel like the Soviet Union symbol is an odd choice.
author: Awmber M.

description:
Rituals' is in a good location and has ample indoor seating and some outdoor seating. The interior design is sleek and the ambience is good for working or for just hanging out with friends.

I ordered a latte and sat about for a while reading my book. The coffee was decent and was reasonably priced for the quantity served.
author: Lucine O.

description: I recently returned after a year's haitus and was delighted - their almond milk cappuccino is spot on now.  The almond milk they use is amazing and the espresso shots in it perfect the drink.  I haven't tried their other offerings but I definitely endorse their cappuccinos and espressos.
author: Erika R.

description: Love the chai and mocha here, delicious! They use bittersweet chocolate for their mocha and it's perfect, not sweet like you're drinking sugary chocolate at all. The staff is friendly and the vibe of this place is great.
author: Ruchi S.

description:
Hm, boyfriend and I were in need of some coffee and decided to randomly try Ritual. I was a little disappointed by their cold brew. It was on tap and really frothy, but lacked any depth in flavor. It almost tasted like dirty water. It was also very light in color for a cold brew (looked like iced tea). 
The ambiance and decorations were very nice (totally befitting of SF, going for that "hipster vibe"). The bathrooms were gender neutral and decorated with book pages which was also cool. Friendly staff but I wouldn't go back. $5 for some frothy water wasn't worth it.
author: Anissa R.

description: One of my favorite stops in Missiom District. Great coffee, decent pastries, and prices like you'd get at any other 3rd wave coffee spot. They make really good pour overs, and the bean selection to take home is also solid. Just wish they'd had more accessories for sale
author: Vladi Z.

description:
I love me some amazing Cold Brew. 9 out of 10 times I drink my coffee black, no sugar and no creamer. Just can't afford all of those calories :-(. The cold brew is very smooth. I often worry about coffee being bitter when black, but Ritual is just perfect. Gotta love that SF vibe. 

It was very busy on this Sunday afternoon. People were coming and going. Most of the table were in use, and quiet a few people were on their laptop doing work. There's seating inside and a few out front as well. 

They have just about everything you're looking for in a coffee shop. Amazing coffee, pastries, wifi, and it's spacious. Highly recommend Ritual Coffee Roasters.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Don't get the nitro brew. It's watered down. Overpriced. And most importantly zero bowel movement after throwing back this Dixie cup. 

Lame!
author: Ian M.

description: How did I manage to find the ONLY coffee shop in the city without WIFI?  No power outlets except in the back?  They really ought to have a sign out front that says, come in, drink coffee, but don't hang around because we really don't want you.
author: Howard D.

description: Got the seasonal expresso and my friend had the latte. It's pretty good with good service. Next time I'll try their coffee. Overall 4 star. Thanks Anita for recommending.
author: Christy V.

description: Good ambiance, tasty coffee, polite baristas. Opens early, but there's no WiFi. This is a nice place to meet people for a chat. The back patio is nice.
author: Jonathan Y.

description: Ritual is a nice coffee shop with a super aesthetic interior. Tons of natural light and a decent amount of seating for you to hang out with a friend or get some work done. However, compared to other coffee shops, Ritual does fall short for me. Their coffee is decent, nothing to write home about. On my visit, I got a macchiato ($3.75). A little pricier than I'd like for such a small drink, but we're in SF...so that's kind of expected. I think my biggest gripe with Ritual is their lack of wifi and outlets. I was able to get by via my Xfinity hotspot, but I wish Ritual had their own dedicated wifi provided for their customers. Ritual is perfect for those looking for a place to sit down, relax, and have a conversation with a friend. But if you're looking for a place to work and need wifi/outlet I'd recommend heading elsewhere.
author: Steven L.

description: Honestly the worst coffee shop I've ever been to. Not only was the customer service horrible, the coffee was horrific. I ordered a chai latte with soy and it literally tasted like ginger and turmeric juice with milk and not in a good way. we also got the nibbler with almond milk and it tasted like watered down coffee. Absolutely disgusting. If I could give them a 0/5 I would.
author: Zharik S.

description:
One of the best coffee shops in town, comparable to Blue Bottle, Four Barrel, and Sightglass. 
Flat white :  good mix of coffee and milk. Medium roasted to unlock the layers of coffee bean.
author: Lily C.

description: Great location, ambiance, staff, coffee, art, and cleanliness. It was a bit crowded but that's a good thing? Also has a mini store selling related coffee and branded products.
author: Esther J.

description: The setting is lovely and spacious but I seriously never had cold brew coffee served this way especially since it was $5. the cold brew coffee came in this flimsy cup and was very watered down. This is the EXACT same kind of cup that they use as a party cup from Safeway...Super disappointed cause I heard many good things about this place.
author: Denise C.

description: This is the worst cafe in SF so far. There is NO Wifi. The face of the staff made me feel i owe her money. She was so not friendly. No smile at all. It was in the morning on Saturday. So disappointed to see her face. I really dont know why there are so many people there.
author: Qi L.

description: Nice ambiance, pigout vegans pastries are a must get and eat!!! Yummy coffee and food! Perfect 5
author: Rhea M.

description:
Very busy and hip coffee bar right in mission district. Seeing over 1700 reviews, I was curious to see what this place is all about? So my first impression is - wow so many people queuing up? It must be good. Stood in a line and having observed people around, I am not sure what was a miss but suddenly I realized it's the minimalistic design. Seems cold but people in the cafe definitely made it better. 
Small Cafe latte for $4.50 doesn't excite me to return but I will to try other stuff on their menu.

Other striking thing about this place was to see various classifieds by local artists. Not sure if they take money to display but something good to look out for.
author: Priyanka S.

description: On a Sunday afternoon, I want a carefully crafted and delicious cup of coffee. I was about to be on day TWO without coffee and if others wanted to maintain the peace..I NEEDED IT!! Upon entering the shop, it was kind of hard to find a place to order, and I accidentally cut a guy in line while looking at the menu. I moved aside and waited to be helped. Is it me, or when you're in coffee shops such as these, you feel a need to KNOW what you actually want?! Usually, I'm about it! However, on a Sunday, I want to actually treat coffee like the delicacy it is. But I rushed into a latte with almond milk and a sweet shot. The wait wasn't long at all and my Sunday wish for coffee was granted. The aesthetics of the space are beautiful and the staff were quite friendly. I like the nice touch of the free post card-like pieces that showcase the way coffee is made in the shop. Then on the flip side, it gives you instructions so that you could attempt to be your own at home barista if you have the equipment. Prices are SF typical. I would come back to this place.
author: Crystal M.

description:
Amazing coffee. They know what they are talking about. I had a Gibraltar and it was amazing!
Would highly recommend this place.
author: Stephan Z.

description: One of the pioneer hipster coffee roasters that has predominantly taken over San Francisco.  Think about it, their logo looks like some kind of socialist manifesto design that they are marketing into pure unadulterated coffee business. I actually went inside and the coffee was ok, but the people were annoying AF just like their marketing schemes. What is this a conscious lifestyle branding sugarcoating lucrative enterprise?  You'd think people are smarter than this...But a whole lot of aimless tech-designy "tribespeople" seem to feel right at home saying in all-bearded gentrified unison, "San Francisco, rise up and wake up to ritual coffee!"
author: Shoe C.

description:
Imagine this: It's a hot summer day in the Mission and I'm nearly falling asleep on Muni. I desperately needed some caffeine and saw Ritual wasn't too far via the Yelp app. I've been to the one in the Haight and knew this was the place for me. 

I walked in and ordered an iced soy latte. Staff was friendly enough, even though they looked like they were bored with life. Expected at this type of establishment. The latte was well made and it was the best pick-me-up on a super hot day. I do wish they had A/C here, though. Some wifi would also be nice.

The atmosphere is minimalist and, of course, hipster. I can see why other people make fun of it. All I had to do was put on my own headphones to tune out all the "I like this band because no one has heard of them" chatter out of my ears.

1 star off because they assaulted my ears by playing Taylor Swift. Y'all can't play some Arcade Fire or something more appropriate for your customers? Another star off because they're still not as good as Four Barrel and Blue Bottle.
author: Karen R.

description:
Wow seriously don't go here... this is the epitome of pretentious coffee shop. Their food & coffee is over priced and honestly nothing special. There are better places in the neighborhood, try Borderlands Cafe or Revolutions cafe. 

Not a good place to do work because they don't have WiFi, they have few / inconveniently places outlets, and it is very loud. 

The environment is super pretentious, from the decor and even to the customers. I never really write bad reviews but I had to for this place.
author: M P.

description:
The people and things we love are famous. They are the biggest things in our lives and, for us, they are like marquee celebrities--larger than any actor or politician. 

When I think of this place it is like being somewhere grand, like this lacquered red box at the center of San Francisco, as if I had found myself in this really rewarding episode of Twin Peaks.

And here, I walked with the woman I love, who also seemed so large. All these things so large and myself so small. What amazing espresso here, what amazing machines, so strange, so sad, so beautiful.
author: Paul A.

description: I agree with other reviewers. If your purpose is to come and get some work done, I suggest going elsewhere. No WiFi. One outlet in entire coffeeshop, towards the back. Otherwise it's a cute venue.
author: Matt N.

description:
i don't why i want to give this place a try last saturday, i have been four barrel,sight glass, verve...etc coffee place around the city every day, and my usually Cortado coffee were the same amount of milk, this place make mine like Macchiato,  and i ask the girl let me have some more milk, since i order the Latte too, she dump the milk anyway, she would not let me have it and just looking at me said this its the size we made..?
WTF ? oh well, enough coffee place hang out on Valancia street anyway, bye...ever !
author: Stenson L.

description:
Our usual Mission coffee stop (Dandelion) is closed this week so we ventured up the street to Ritual. Our party of five ordered a variety of drinks. Mine was a macchiato, which properly made is a shot of espresso with a bit of foam on top. What I got was a cup of hot milk with espresso mixed in. I'm stunned that a place like Ritual doesn't know what a macchiato is!

Second, mine was the last of the five drinks to arrive -- we'd ordered under one rather unusual name -- and when I reached for it, the barista snapped at me "that's not yours!"  She would not relent until one of the male members of our party assured her that it was indeed my drink. 

We got our drinks to go, and as soon as I left and realized that mine was almost all milk, I discarded it. Everyone else made better drink choices, hence three stars rather than one.
author: joanne g.

description: Saw it on several lists of top wifi cafes and thought id check it out. After spending about 10 bucks on a small cup of coffee and croissant I findout its so hipster they dont believe in wifi and prefer a ton of empty tables and chairs so I came here for nothing. In all fairness tho the cup of Guatemala coffee was alright and the croissant was flaky and tasty.
author: Sean G.

description:
I live a block from Ritual and an almost always here to pick up a bag of roasted beans. For obvious reasons, it's usually packed, even without free wifi!

It's spacious with plenty of seating, two gender neutral restrooms and an excellent atmosphere.

LOVE!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Ritual is primarily a hit for me, but occasionally a miss. I like their rich and dark roasted flavors, but sometimes it tastes burnt. When it is done right (which is most of the time) the espresso tastes amazing!!
author: Shizuka L.

description: Ritual Coffee Roasters was a nice surprise in San Francisco. The store is beautiful and the baristas are very knowledgeable. I personally was not a fan of the brewed coffee. I find them to be underroasted and tart. The coffee was so acidic you could not pick out any other flavors. Overall we had a great experience.
author: Tyler S.

description:
Ritual has to be one of my favorite places for coffee in SF. The space is open, has a nice decor and very bright. The back of the cafe has seating(which every time I have been here, is always full). There are two bathrooms in the back which do not need a code or are locked. 
I generally get an almond milk latte here. The coffee is not bitter or burnt and is flavorful. The prices are a little steep though. The place is clean and the staff is friendly.
author: Chet L.

description: Great chai and nice working environment but no WiFi! Frustrating when it is listed under yelp as a good place to work and a place with WiFi.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Time for a Ritual early evening brew ha ha

Ritual Coffee Roasters in the Mission District was the site for my first ever coffee cupping class.  I vividly remember the Nicaragua episode of "Bizarre Foods", where Andrew Zimmern slurped & spat his way through various coffee, noting the distinctive notes of each brew.  I now had the chance to see how loud a slurp I could make, distinguishing from various single origin coffee.  All the while, enjoying a high octane caffeine boost to power me on for the night.

Sho was our barista, and he led us through the cupping process.  Starting with South American coffee, and onward to Ethiopian grinds, Sho had us sniff the dry grinds, to envision the flavor notes in our head.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=TYxAiOEYhyHvWiRMnyM99Q

Then, after brewing for a certain amount of minutes, Sho had our group sniff the brewed grinds, to see if the flavor notes we experienced before still applied or were altered in any way.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=MZiLLvVwdf25tuzBWRbVkQ

Afterwards, came the highlight of any coffee cupping - tasting!  Sho demonstrated the artisan way of tasting.  By using a spoon & slowly lowering it into the brew, we slurped the coffee as loud and fast as possible, which we spat out.  Tasting this way sprays the coffee onto the tastebuds, allowing for maximum savoring.  In my opinion, the South American coffee had more sweet/floral profiles, whereas the Ethiopian coffee had bold/more assertive flavors.  What was on the unhygienic side, was we used a communal cup to wash our spoons before each sipping.  All I can say is, I was glad I was the second one & not further down the line.  

Upon our coffee cupping class coming to completion, we all had our choice of drink from Ritual Coffee Roasters.  Wanting some cold with a kick, I went with Ritual's nitro cold brew-
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=NVFjUQAJ8HHblOE_grqRcg

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=YsK0c7A9MYVWW4boDJPciw
Cold, slightly acidic, caffeine-laden, the nitro cold brew hit the spot.  For the uninitiated, nitro cold brew coffee is akin to coffee beer.  Frothy, slightly bubbly & having a stoutness to it, the drink is made the day before to remove most of the acidity.  By cold brewing, the nitro cold brew contains more caffeine than traditional drip coffee.  Refreshing as can be!

Service was great.  Sho was quite professional during the class, communicating in unpretentious terms about coffee and the brewing process.  Our drinks came out in a timely manner and we even received free can cozys.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=yuT_2TD6454whUeYh1NJgg

A fair amount of seating inside, with 2 communal tables (in front & in back).  A few tables for those alone or with someone.  Most available seating is al fresco, via wooden tables overlooking Valencia St.  Metered street parking is hard to come by, so try to visit during off hours when possible.

While I'm not a ritual coffee enthusiast,  I do enjoy the brew at Ritual Coffee Roasters.  All the coffee beans at Ritual are roasted in San Francisco, keeping things local.  Drinks are made one cup at a time, and customers can see the attention & care that goes into the products offered here.  I had an educational & entertaining time, participating in my first coffee cupping, and Sho was as great a teacher as any during the process.  There are many café options in the city of San Francisco, and it would behoove you to make Ritual Coffee Roasters one of them.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=T584HmKUR1Bu7ahNdcvz7A

Highly recommend!
NOMNOMNOMNOMNOMNOMNOMNOM
author: Rodney S.

description: 5 Stars for great coffee and great service. Always super friendly when I come in in the morning when I'm in town. I would highly recommend their cappuccinos or espresso. Delicious.
author: Sophie P.

description: Recently, I asked for a little top-off of my brewed coffee on the way out the door and received a rude rebuff. As someone who lives nearby and has been coming for years, tipping every time, that was a little much. I'm on a Ritual hiatus for a while.
author: Galen P.

description:
First of all, best parking situation so far similar to Philz Coffee. So I was already in a good mood. 

Husband ordered a Kenyan blend. The acidity is not too high for this blend, quite smooth.  Has a chocolatey aftertaste and feels pretty light. 

I ordered the Jackie Palmer. This was more bitter than cold brews with tonic that I've had.

Atmosphere is nice and modern. There is seating inside and outside for you to enjoy but no wifi! Still always packed.
author: Bianca C.

description:
I chose this coffee shop, because I had a friend meeting me in SF, and we wanted to find a place not too far from
a BART station. I also wanted a place that was accessible, as my friend is in a power chair. This shop fit the bill. It was big, with plenty of utilitarian seating. There were many people working, so I assume it had WiFi. We were able to sit and have a conversation and not feel like we were disturbing anyone by talking and laughing. 

Come for the coffee- that's it. The brew is delicious and I enjoyed it. I purchased a what was supposed to be a Nutella pop tart. It tasted stale, dry...and was so gross, I took it back. The barista/Manager was nice and allowed me to exchange it for a donut, which was good(not  exceptional, but it was ok). 

The staff was pleasant, and the atmosphere was busy and buzzing. The clientele was young..I'd say the majority of the patrons were in their 20's. 

If I am in the neighbourhood and need a place to work, then I would stop by, again.
author: Robin W.

description: There's no question that the coffee is excellent and the space is lovely.  However the "service" is slow, the staff ranges from ignoring you to rude, and you're expected to clean up after yourself. All that for the bargain price of $4.25 for a latte.  And don't expect wifi.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Rituals is one of those coffee shops that definitely belongs in the Mission, specifically Valencia St where the shop is located. Sleek interior, minimalist design, hipster hipster hipster. Not that I'm complaining. 

The coffee is good in the way only very neutral tasting coffee can be. I go here for the ambiance but $5 lattes definitely end up burning a hole in your pocket when you go too often. 

For anyone who isn't into coffee, the chai here is very good! You can taste the ginger and cardamom as those flavours are pretty intense. 

People have complained about the service here but I haven't had any bad experiences. The staff just seem very bored which is kind of the vibe I expect from a coffee shop like this. *shrugs* to each their own!
author: Eunah T.

description:
I find myself quite smitten with this coffee-house in The Mission.  I was enjoying a day of sightseeing and decided to visit on the strength of the reviews and hip location.  I was not disappointed!

Upon arriving, I was struck by the very clean, minimal, and attractive interior.  The color scheme was calming and the seating well arranged and comfortable. The condiments area was clean and uncluttered despite how busy the shop was during my stay.  The bathrooms were exceptionally clean and had a lovely design. 

As mentioned in other reviews, the staff are quite affable and inviting -- there is no snootiness here.  I ordered (from what I remember) a Columbian blend with notes of cherries and chocolate.  $5+ is pretty steep for a modest sized cup but I understand at a place like this you're paying for ambiance and quality (and probably decent wages for the staff) so no complaints from me. The coffee was very flavorful and stayed true to the description.  I very happily sipped on my well roasted coffee while reading and people watching.
author: Jordan W.

description: My coffee is so good! It's a "fancier" coffee place, so yes it's a little more expensive but look how beautiful my cappuccino is! The workers were very nice and the place is large and clean.
author: Abby S.

description: Their coffee is good but their vegan pastries suck the Donas have been recycled with the same oil for weeks the savory vegan  scones are,so dry and nasty
author: Gregory H.

description: I came to this coffee shop a couple of weeks back because it had very good reviews. As soon as I entered inside it felt beautiful. The decor is chic with ample space to sit comfortably. I ordered one Café Mocha and one special coffee on the menu with unusual name (It had notes of orange and cherry). Honestly Both the coffee's were very average tasting. For that price I can say I have had better ones.
author: Shatakshi G.

description:
Late night.. Early morning.. It's only 12:30pm...I'm drained.  No better place to take a pause and enjoy a great cup of coffee.  

The atmosphere is amazing inviting, but difficult to get a seat and take it all in. I've had a couple of meeting here and managed to " shadow" some people to get a good seat. 

Go for the coffee, stay for the environment.
author: Samuel C.

description: It had been seven years since my last cup at Ritual. It was good to be back and get a pour over but I wasn't blown away. There are so many great spots in sf and great coffee isn't hard to come by in the city. Stop by ritual and grab a cup, it's a safe bet as they roast their own beans and they have some great blends.
author: Brennan L.

description:
All coffee is equal, but some coffee is more equal than others.
^Animal Farm reference, though I'm not sure how many people will get it... unless you read books and think about communism... as Ritual cafe-goers might :P

Ritual is the quintessential hipster cafe, complete with artisan coffee, correspondingly high prices, a beautiful minimalist space, and a pretentious lack of wifi and outlets. This is a place where you will find idle-looking people in plaid shirts, Warby Parker glasses, and man-buns chilling casually on a weekday morning, perhaps pulling a journal out of a suave leather messenger bag. This is the typical Ritual crowd.

Enter me, sleep-deprived, looking like I rolled out of bed, RBF and antisocial af pre-caffeine, encountering the talkative barista try to start a conversation and asking me how my day was going (even though it was 6:30am)....ahaha clearly I do not fit in. 

The coffee is up there on the top tier of famous SF coffee roasters, rivaling Sightglass, Four Barrel, and Blue Bottle. Ritual's roasts are interesting because you can taste the notes in the description, like wine and fancy chocolate. I think my favorite part was the design, with an artistic use of space and a remarkably elegant abstract light sculpture. 

It's a memorable cafe experience, though the price is quite steep ranging from $3 for a cup of brewed coffee and over $5 for a mocha. Too bad Ritual doesn't actually endorse communism as its logo suggests--free bouge coffee for all would indeed be indeed be utopian.
author: Edna C.

description:
The coffee was pretty outstanding, the vibe very laid back and 'tech-y' - I wonder if the next life changing app was being produced at the table next to me...maybe? It felt like that kind of place for sure.
If I lived in this area of SF, it would be my go to coffee hang out. Good.
author: John B.

description: Coffee was good. Stopped by for a quick pick-me-up in the rain. Set up of this location is a little strange, large amount of unused space, which is striking when you walk in, but means there isn't that much seating available.
author: Winnie Y.

description: I love that this Ritual Coffee had a place to sit on a beautiful, busy Sunday afternoon. After walking around the Mission for Halloween costume shopping, I needed a pick me up in the form of a double shot over ice. Yum! Don't forget your punchcard!
author: Thomas L.

description:
I like to try out different coffee shops across the city when I need to get work done. Ritual's interior is clean, modern, and spacious with plenty of seating. Ritual does not offer wifi but you can connect to a free Xfinity hotspot if you use Xfinity's cable or TV service.

I ordered a cappuccino which was above average in price ($4.5) but below average in volume. The latte art looked nice but the flavor was bland.

On the day I went, Ritual was playing fairly loud metal for several hours. I occasionally enjoy metal and I'm not sure if this was the norm, but I do prefer softer music in a coffee shop setting.

All in all, I would not recommend making a special trip to Ritual despite the 1700+ 4-star reviews. Instead, I would recommend Réveille on 18th Street a few minutes away if you're looking for an incredible cappuccino; I would recommend a regular Starbucks/Peets if you're just looking to get some work done.
author: Hao H.

description:
Another hipster coffee shop in SF with over priced coffees that are very acidic.

I prefer a smoother coffee.
author: T K.

description: One word amazing! I'm a coffee lover and ritual coffee roasters hit the spot. The vibes of the place are spectacular. Highly recommend it.
author: Jessy V.

description: I can't understand they don't have Wifi.....I wanted to surf the internet using my laptop but i couldn't....
author: Minjae J.

description: Really really awesome! They had beans to sell as well and the latte was great too. Parking is difficult though :(
author: Megha U.

description: I ordered a simple cup of tea. The barista said "that will be six dollars". I was like holy sh*t that's an expensive cup of tea. But I thought, I'm gonna sit here for a few hours and do work, so I'll happily pay it (plus tax and tip). Once my tea was ready I asked for the WiFi. "Sorry, we don't have WiFi". Seriously? I just paid $7 for a cup of tea and no WiFi? Not impressed.
author: Erica S.

description: Line was out the door on a Saturday morning! But went by relatively quickly. I'm a big pour over drinker so I got 2 cups...just kidding me and my best friend got one each! I asked the cashier what she recommended for pour over and she suggested the one that taste like M&Ms. what was nice was that she actually gave a detailed description of where the beans originated from and how they're sustainably grown which was awesome. Cool vibe inside with great art for sale on the walls. Oh yeah, the bathroom was super cool so much that I took a photo of the decor. Make sure to enjoy your visit in there too!
author: Dimitri R.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters: where lots and lots of hipsters hang out and drink coffee.

The design of the coffee shop is modern and very clean, so I can see why people like hanging out here. There was definitely a handful of people doing work here too!

(I am on the Jon Snow level of knowing nothing about coffee, so I can't elaborate too much on the drinks...)
author: Christine S.

description: Single best cup of coffee I've ever had in my entire life. And I've always considered myself a coffee snob.. sorry Philz, Blue Bottle, Stumptown, Portola, Intelligentsia, etc etc
author: Katie S.

description:
You'll have the time of your life if you enjoy drinking deliciously small cups of pricey coffee while listening to old school Vanessa Carlton albums. This place is great for having awkward interactions with the neighbor sitting to the left of you because all of the other seats are filled up and you have to squeeze in next them ohsorryaboutthat didn't mean to touch your kneemybad

Be careful because Yelp lied about the WiFi availability. Either use your phone's hot spot or bring your portable typewriter.
author: Katherine X.

description:
Great selection of coffees and a nice location, very spacious, 
I had a capuccino with a single origin espresso and it was very good, definetly stop by if u are in the mission district.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
I really like the aesthetic of this cafe. Depends on you but I don't think I can study well here. They play loud music and a lot of talking. 

Parking: Kind of hard to find

Coffee: Not many options for coffee and my mocha isn't that sweet for my taste, but that's okay. The latte art is very pretty!

Space: Kind of hard to find seats
author: Casey Y.

description:
Stopped in for a coffee with friends and found this spot to be trendy, love the open space, but ultimately not quite the right roast for me. 

We tried a soy latte and regular coffee which were both pretty standard. The selection of different espressos is unique but I couldn't taste the subtle tones that were supposed to be imbibed. 
The atmosphere of the shop was really bright, spacious, a cool garden in the back and awesome wall paper in the bathroom. Cool outdoor seating in the front though we sat inside. 

I think the concept is really cool, super props for special roasted beans, I'd like to try more but for now didn't find the selection quite my type.
author: Angela D.

description:
Exactly what we were looking for when visiting SF.

This coffee shop has it all and it all starts with their baristas. They all seem to be very kind, patient, knowledgable and heavily invested at Ritual. They know where all of their beans are from and shared stories about their inspiration for certain brews and drinks. 

My wife and I were very fascinated and thoroughly enjoyed our single origin coffee, nitro cold brew. However, what stood out most to us was their featured drink: a cold brew, tonic water and black berry reduction cocktail. My goodness, that hit the spot on a warm summer evening in SF. We couldn't have been happier.

Thank you Ritual!
author: Naji H.

description:
Totally down for this place. 

They made me a delicious Latte, the bathrooms were excellent and wallpapered with book pages, and there was tons of space if you don't want to be close to anyone. 

I also love places who have real mugs for when you're staying, because, well, we're ruining the planet really fast with all our crap. Yay real dishwear! 

And the coffee was delicious. Yum. Yum. Yum. They overfilled it, which was lovely and foamy and beautiful and yes, I drank every drop. It was glorious. I approve. 

That's the extent of my experience there. The girls are pretty and sweet and were really nice to me, though I'd find it hard to believe if they weren't nice to anyone, to be honest. 

Great place. Great coffee. Boom.
author: Tina S.

description:
It's an oasis.
That was my initial thought when I walked in for the first time.

It's spacious.  Maybe it's as simple as the white color scheme, but it's soothing somehow.  Any space that offers a soothing refuge right smack in the middle of a major thoroughfare is a winner in my book.

Now, the coffee.  It is superb.  And their number of Yelp reviews surpassing the number of reviews for Four Barrel (down the street) speaks volumes.  

They offer soy & almond milk.  They carry Pepples Donuts & gluten/dairy free goodies.  Love, love, love.

I'm not giving 5 stars for one reason...the price.  18 bucks a pound is not exactly the nice price.  A fellow patron sitting at the neighboring table actually told me that you can get it at Whole Foods...for less.  Like 4 bucks less.  What?!  That's just silly, right?

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Came here in search of good local coffee and was not disappointed... inviting , modern place in the Valencia area .great place to take a break , hangout and grab a coffee while strolling the beautiful area . The coffee is on the pricier side , but in SF that is expected ! Mocha and Cappuccino both were good - little different from my taste though ...
author: Charvi N.

description: really great coffee and tons of places to sit down and work!  We spend about 3 hours here when we got to the city getting some work done, though there was no wifi, there was plenty of room to sit and enjoy the great coffee options.  We had an espresso w/ sparkling water, a latte, and a black coffee and all 3 were to die for.
author: Geena G.

description: Mediocre coffee, but despite that very pricey. Very loud atmosphere, not enough plugs. No wi-fi. Not very friendly staff. Would never come here!
author: Nilay D.

description:
I feel like this place has potential (I just didn't experience their greatness). I came here today and got a chai latte. It was awful. So with that I can't give more than a two stars for this review.

My chai had way, way, way too much milk, I could hardly taste the tea and at the end of my drink I finally had some flavor of cardamom. My brother who has been here before and also thought his drink had way too much milk in it as well. My partner got a caramel macchiato and he was pretty disappointed as well.

So maybe it was an off day? But bad chai is a peeve of mine and I don't forgive easy because of it. I won't be coming back if I can help it.
author: Gita r.

description:
I walked by and this place and it caught my attention so I decided to give it a try. I order a chai latte and a macchiato for orb my mother and omg it tasted so bad. 
Worst chai latte I ever had it tasted like water.
The macchiato was so bland, I was so disappointed. I really wanted to like this cool trendy place but it did not make the cut. I never felt like I wasted my money more than when you have a bad drink. I will not be back, I threw  my chai away as I walked out so sad and disappointed. I'm still currently craving a chai latte. I'll probably stop by at Philz on my way home.
author: Ella P.

description: No wifi, which is fine. What really ruined my experience was the loud, headache-inducing music (electric rock at that time). There were people who tried talking over the music (impressive), but just added to the noise. Not an enjoyable experience.
author: Ashlee B.

description:
I'm all about my 3rd wave coffee, and I was excited to give Ritual a try. The coffee didn't disappoint -- I got a pour over coffee and it was fantastic. 

I'm docking stars for the unfriendly service. I don't expect servers to smile from ear-to-ear and beam happiness at me, but it seemed like both the cashier and the barista who made the drink were making an active effort to give off pretentious, mean vibes.

It's a shame, cause the coffee is great. But in the Bay Area we're lucky to have access to a lot of great coffee. Will go somewhere more welcoming and community-minded next time.
author: Daniel S.

description: What can I NOT say about Ritual Coffee Roasters. I'm in love with the lattes. They're smoky and creamy and hot and downright delicious. I make sure I get my card stamped every time because I go that often.
author: Louise J.

description: Really yummy espresso, quick and friendly service, and cool atmosphere! They make each almond milk latte with my favorite almond milk - kalifa - and with care. They are quite pricey but, according to a posted sign in the establishment, they have done this to pay their workers more and give them benefits! I can get behind price increases for that!!
author: Annie K.

description: The history of Ritual Coffee has me intrigued. This particular location of Ritual Coffee Roasters in the Mission neighbor of San Francisco is a nice local place to people watch while chatting with friends or spending time alone.The ambience is cozy while coffee is served hot. The barristes are quick and are knowledgeable about their coffee.
author: Lorin M.

description:
Great quality. You get what you paid for. I love the mochas

I wish they had Splenda but the way I drink my coffee is blasphemous (aka lots of milk and Splenda, coffee is a suggestion hah)
author: Gloria Z.

description:
$9.75 for a latte and a mocha. Small size for the price, same as other popular cafes, like blue bottle, four barrels, sightglass etc. they all tasted better than most other coffee shops. 

This ritual is crowded and not easy for parking.
author: Jenn J.

description:
Ritual definitely seems at home on beautiful Valencia Street. The cafe is busy and designed with a sleek, minimalist, welcoming interior. While blatant lack of wifi and electric outlets make working challenging, the silver lining is that finding space to sit (or stand at the bar) is much more likely. The menu provides enough variety and niche offerings to please most coffee-aficionados. 

The cold brew was pleasant and smooth but not as strong as expected. Definitely a great spot to chit chat or do some light work.
author: Russell P.

description:
Great coffee place. Mocha was fantastic and so was the coffee. 

Good ambiance, friendly vibe, and relaxing atmosphere.
author: Rohit B.

description:
Had a great couple of cups of pour-over black coffee here as well as a very good croissant. The atmosphere was lively after 9am and the staff seemed to handle the rush pretty well. 

This isn't really a cafe or a place for hours and hours of work as much as it is a place where coffee quality is paramount. I would love to see just a few more food item options for breakfast. 

I also must report that while no one was rude, I was treated rather coldly. The staff, the two or three that I interacted with, were generally lacking in any attempt to connect with me as a customer. I noted that my "thank you"s weren't greeted by "you're welcome"s. my smiles weren't returned and attempts at small talk were absorbed and unrequited. 

Still, I'll return for the fantastic coffee and a smile would go a long way toward earning the 5th star :)
author: Daniel B.

description:
Love the coffee and the vibe.  This is our wknd ritual.

Ps: you guys should consider giving free coffee on birthdays :). Starbucks does it and it's a nice feeling.
author: V V.

description:
Nice.

Surprisingly, I didnt have any problems finding a metered parking spot on the street a block away. 

Cant get any more hipster than this. With the ink-drawing-style logo on the coffee sleeve... To the miniature garden at the back... To the wood panels.

Their Mocha and Chai drinks were great!

Plenty of tables available half full of, I kid you not, good looking hipster males with open laptops hanging out. WiFi must be fast and free.
author: Kislev A.

description:
Good coffee | Nice place
$$

Cool coffee shop on Valencia. We came here after having a food coma from Lolo's nearby. Ordered a regular plain coffee (medium roast?) on drip. Pretty good! Everything is clean and fresh-looking inside. It can get a little crowded since people crowd around the bar table against the wall, but it was fine, and we sat down towards the back. Would come back again!
author: Lauren F.

description:
Great space to work at or hang out at.  Love the long communal table in the back that provides plenty of space for everyone!  Great bright lighting that also somehow always results in it being a little too warm in the afternoon and very open and inviting atmosphere.  No wifi though.

Coffee is a bit on the expensive side and would definitely classify under the bright category.  It's not my favorite coffee, but I pay more for the experience and the real estate than the coffee itself.  I'm not a fan of bright coffees, so I tend to order their lattes and cappuccinos which help to tame the acidity for me.  Fine latte art and good foam on their espresso drinks.  I also am a fan of their Nitro Brew which is almost like a beer-like coffee.  Has a nice smooth almost head-like foam.  Refreshing and unique!
author: Jess Y.

description: Atmosphere is nice and was fairly quiet when I was there. Ordered the iced Americano (added sugar and cream) and it tasted delicious. On the popular street of Valencia so in close proximity to other great shops and restaurants.
author: Ashley E.

description:
This is where we get our daily early morning coffee & doughnut. The coffee beans are really good - I'd recommend the Ethiopia coffee. 
They also have gluten free treats!
author: Kimberley C.

description: I've been living in SF for 5 years and raised in the Bay Area; there is no better espresso coffee in the city than Ritual! Each location even has a signature drink at their locations. The only thing that's a drag is that I have to use both hands on mornings when I decide two cappuccinos are better than one!
author: Alex R.

description:
Coffee and facility are good. The 1 star is for the rude customer service. 

"You are not allowed to put milk in the glass." one guy said that to my face. 

Why can't I put milk in my coffee? It was in the glass because the coffee was full. That's why I had to put the small amount of milk on the side in the glass, so I can slowly pour it in without spilling anything. 

Would recommend people to go to other branches for better customer service.
author: Chris C.

description: Pretty decent coffee shop if you're around the area. I tried the iced separator, which was a solid drink, but didn't really blow my mind. Theres plenty of study space though, so if you're looking for somewhere to plant down and do some work, this might be just the spot.
author: Andrew T.

description:
First time at this Ritual location on Memorial Day.

It was super easy to find parking today since it seems everyone is either asleep or getting ready to BBQ later today rather than get coffee. The actual coffee shop was pretty busy when I arrived though and while there was a line, it moved very fast. 

I think the aesthetics of this location could be improved since there seemed to be too much blank space everywhere I looked. While I appreciated that the shop was not cluttered, it seemed that they could use more decorations on the walls. While the seating was functional, it was not creative.

My 12oz mocha tasted good, which I was already expecting since I have tried Ritual at the Napa location before. The latte art on my drink was sort of sloppy, but that wasn't too big of a deal.

I'm definitely a fan even though I can see areas where improvements could be made. Come check them out!
author: Regina W.

description:
Update: OMG THEY NOW HAVE NITRO COFFEE MY LIFE IS COMPLETE. 

I used to hate Ritual... That was back when I was ordering their acidic "fruity" coffees, which just ain't my thang. The thing to get are their espresso drinks - lattes, cappuccinos, macchiatos...you can't go wrong. They are perfectly executed, though I wish they came out hotter. I love that they offer califia farms almond milk!

They recently got a new pastry case, now serving Le Marais croissants, Pepples Donuts, and various sandbox pastries.  I'm pretty meh about the Sandbox but recently tried their Le Marais chocolate croissant and it pretty much blew my mind. Ok, it's kind of expensive but there were endless layers of light crispy buttery croissant and a generous portion of decadent chocolate inside. Not too chalky or hard and a perfect proportion of chocolate to pastry ($5.25 eep!). The ham and ricotta cheese croissant had the same crispy flaky buttery crust, and I enjoyed the large cubed chunks of ham on top of a layer of ricotta ($5.75) - I just prefer the chocolate croissant, despite my being more a savory person. 

Overall love ritual. Get a punch card. Bring your own cup for 25 cents off. Note: no internet available (per customer demand).
author: Jess C.

description:
I feel like I should have liked this place more.  It has a clean, modern, inviting aesthetic.  Most customers are hipsters and the staff are that type of unsmiling, but not unpleasant hipster with whom you are probably familiar if you live in or visit the Mission regularly.  The line is usually prohibitively long and after you order, it takes a while to actually get your drink too. 

The drinks, in my experience, have been hit or miss. I've found the iced coffee to be bitter, or weak, on different occasions (where it turns very light when milk is added), but have consistently enjoyed hot lattes I've gotten here. 

Also, isn't a lot of seating for the large size of the space (they do have an outdoor seating area with the parklet in front, though) and the layout is a bit uninviting as far as knowing where to wait in line, order, etc.
author: Christine G.

description:
I'm going to preface that I love sweet coffee. I could have ordered wrong, but the cold brew at Ritual was $4 (yowza!) and didn't taste sweet after I literally dumped their sugar and milk in it. C'mon man, can I be a hipster without having to drink bitter coffee? Can you offer some alternatives for the sweettooths like myself?

Overall, I didn't care for the coffee, didn't care for the prices, and didn't care for the overly minimalistic space.

Here's to praying for sweeter coffee!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Ritual is one of the local roasters, roasting all their beans in San Francisco. While I'm not a fan of their roasts (generally too sour and not robust enough for me), it's nice to see this new space that is more spacious and comfortable than their little shipping container on Octavia.

I still adore their outdoor space at their original location - but given how cold SF can get, this is a good place to hang out and not have your coffee get cold before finishing it. The only complaint I have is the space for the pick up counter -- it's got a nice bar table against the wall for people to wait for their coffee, but everyone pile up or just drink their coffee there, making the walkway really hard to get through.
author: Alice C.

description: For some reason I never heard of this place even though I get coffee just down the street, so I was intrigued. Cool atmosphere and the coffee was pretty good (but not amazing) the staff wasn't very friendly and  he restrooms did not have a pleasing odor. Overall a good v60 pour over from Kenya and a tasty scone. Mostly likely I'd walk a few blocks for my coffee
author: Darren Y.

description:
Really good location and parking really isn't that hard (by SF standards). 

The latte I got was amazing as I expected but what I really need to rave about is the chocolate croissant. The chocolate was deep and decadent and I found myself savoring every last bite. 

If you get your latte to go and walk down Valencia to Clarion Alley you'll be treating your eyes to a feast with the amazing (and meaningful) street art.
author: Summer G.

description:
The cashier treated us badly, had a nasty tone. Felt very unwelcome. You'll probably have better luck if you dress like a hipster.

The coffee itself was pretty good, comparable to stuff you'd get at the other hip coffee places.
author: Adam W.

description: I really wanted to love Ritual as I heard so many good things. The atmosphere is chill and is full of grungy hipsters. The coffee is on the medium side (according to my taste) and the food options were a little limiting. The space is quiet and good for working.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
My local coffee place... that I have never thought to review but do indeed appreciate. Solid all around. Comfortable place even when crowded and waiting. Always efficient and professional. Props.

Only request- bring back the sparkling water shot with the espresso! This seemed to stop at some point but loved the touch.
author: Grace M.

description: Came here on a Sunday morning, luckily with no line. I'm on this hype of seeing how good different mochas are at various coffee shops which is what I opted for when I came here. Street parking and this place is pretty big! Nice open space and plenty of seating. The baristas were really nice, take your order and wait for your name to be called. I thought my mocha was aight, but I will definitely come back to try the other coffees! I love the ambience!
author: Veronica A.

description: Good coffee in an amazing space.  My only complaint is that I couldn't figure out where to order, and ended up waiting near the pickup for a few minutes.  The barista was chatting up a customer so he didn't notice I was waiting.  Cappuccino was delicious.
author: Sara M.

description: Nice to come back to the ritual coffee roasters shop. While it's not part of my usual ritual, come in here does bring back a warm fuzzy feeling of happy memories. Great culture as it's on Valencia Street in San Francisco.
author: Ron L.

description: Tables are so wobbly they make you spill your coffee. Please fix your furniture. There is no WiFi. Why?
author: Jason T.

description: A favorite for 3rd wave coffee fans. If you don't know what that is then probably just walk on by. :-) Xlnt v60 with 3 small lot variety options. We always stop here when in SF.
author: Jow H.

description:
MacBooks, Moleskines, and succulents, oh my!

This place is hipster central. Stopped by a few days ago to have some coffee and work (offline) for a bit. I definitely felt mildly embarrassed of whipping out my work laptop (a Dell) here, but oh well, what can ya do.

No wifi here anymore, which is kind of nice. I think they purposely don't have a lot of outlets, either. Okay amount of seating and a communal table in the back. The bar area is huge; I don't really understand why it needs to be so big, but I suppose it makes for a pretty Instagram picture?

Service is pretty fast, and my latte was delicious. Overall a really great place take some time to relax and unplug, or just work offline :)
author: Alyssa T.

description: The vegan donuts are very good but come early to get them as they often sell out! Limited seating but plenty of standing counter space with interesting books to read.
author: Isla F.

description:
If you have trouble finding it, look for the wrecked boat (converted to a bench) out front.  The neighborhood is colorful and bike friendly, witTh more than one record store within eyeshot.  It is inviting inside: roomy, light colors, and lots of natural light for the plants in the front.  

They had a single origin Rwanda, but upon asking I was recommended the blend (Daydreamer).   Served in a white demitasse with appropriate spoon.
Smell was big strawberries, not artificial but real strawberries .  The taste was sparkly and tart, but not dry.  The bus area is well developed, wth a sign that says Hey, thanks for bussing yourself.
author: Steven S.

description: Love the vibe and coffee!! The people who work there are super down to earth and very friendly. Coffee tastes amazing and I just get there hot and ready coffee
author: Char B.

description: Love the coffee and atmosphere here. It is a relaxed and cozy place. I tried the Nitro coffee and v60 coffee. Both are nice. I also got some beans to go for my sis who loves coffee.
author: Jinny T.

description: All the coffee here was really good and fresh. Came in for a caffeine pickup before dinner. We ordered the Monte Rey which was cool cause it was poured via tap and the other drink we had was the Nelson Ramirez which was also good too. No sugar or cream added. Drank as is. We also ordered a ham and cheese pastry that I wish was toasted but it's ok. Around $16 for everything. Pricy and very hipster but the price is worth it for the fresh brewed coffee. Space is also very open and welcoming.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
You know, I'm not a coffee snob. I'm not even a regular coffee drinker. I've been to Ritual Coffee Roasters a few times now and I love the minimalist design and feel of the shop. I personally feel that I'm not hipster enough to hang out here. On my most recent visit, we took our drinks to go and strolled to Dolores Park.

I like both the latte and the mocha here. Neither are inexpensive but that's totally expected for a place like this.
author: Yi Z.

description: I live a block away from this location on Valencia and used to work in coffee for Four Barrel. This morning when I came in, I brought a thermos and the cashier asked if I'd like it filled all the way - it was 16 ounces and you typically serve 12 ounce pours. I'm all for fairness but come on, guys. Just fill the darn mug! It made me feel like I was trying to swindle you out of 4 ounces when I was really just trying to transport my coffee in a sealed, reusable container. Please don't make me feel bad for that, I'm saving you the cost of a cup.
author: Allison G.

description: Came on a rainy Sunday afternoon and the place was packed - luckily just as I was walking by, a table opened up! I tried just a regular latte based off the reviews and it was delicious. Definitely a great place to hang out.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Out-of-this-world cappuccino. Served at the perfect temperature and made with an impeccable layer of foam and a sweet and nutty shot of espresso with an acidic kick of a finish, which I like & really sets it apart from all the other (excellent!) coffee found in SF.

The interior is absolutely immaculate - airy, minimalist, bright. Standing space adjacent to red & white painted Synesso espresso machines, bar tap water taps, and for-two and communal tables provide the expected hipster coffee shop atmosphere, while the glassed-off succulent garden and gorgeous lighting fixtures exude more of an art gallery vibe.
author: Victor S.

description:
I like that this place has lots of open space to work in.  It's ideal for studying, WFH, or just to hang out.  It was a hot day (...ok fine, this is SF. It was a very warm day... ) so I wanted an iced tea.  I got the iced golden needle and it was pretty good.  There was a CC minimum so I also got a gluten free pumpkin bread, which was not too bad.  

The decor is cool, service was actually really cool and friendly, and like I said earlier theres lots of space.  The only drawback was the limited menu, but I'm down to try the coffee next time.
author: Lyn C.

description:
