Stopped in after a meeting in the area. Super nice, a wonderful surprise. Asked for a glass of ice coffee, a simple request that often elicits multiple questions, but not here... "coming right up!"

Really lovely interior environment, music at a comfortable volume, door open at back for garden breezes. Will be back to sample other coffees, teas and treats!
author: Ian M.

description: I am a coffee snob. I love the attention to detail and the exceptional quality of their cappuccino. The redesign of the space is ok (but not great). Their pastry selection is just ok but I come for the coffee.
author: Thatcher H.

description: Came to this coffee joint with 12 others and learned that they don't have electrical outlets for their customer except for one that's in a corner which was being used. Asked if I can charge my laptop for a bit behind the corner and was told that they don't allow customers to use their electricity. The female clerk was extremely rude and unprofessional. Thanks for the great Monday morning and focusing on service.
author: C B.

description: This spot has great decor and the coffee is REALLY good but my boyfriend and I waited for about 20-25 minutes for 2 cups of coffee. I think I would go somewhere else next time
author: Merica K.

description: Amazing coffees without the attitude. Love their coffees and love the people who come in. Good coffee matters, and these guys show that on a daily basis.
author: Nathan O.

description: Very nice place to chill out, plenty of seating, nice calming interior. They offer tea and vegan treats. Nice for a lactose intolerant person!
author: Dana N.

description:
Came by for coffee the other day and the coffee here was decent.

Mocha was smooth, not too sweet and the perfect drinking temperature.

Service was friendly by the staff.

The ambiance of the coffee shop is pretty neat. It's modern, open, and airy,

$5 for a mocha.
author: Derek S.

description:
TL;DR - Great for to-go orders or any activity that doesn't require an outlet or wifi.

The service is hit or miss. Sometimes I get a sweet barista and sometimes I get a sourpuss (hey, we all have bad days).

The drinks are consistent (capps and lattes are the way to go) and the baked goods hit the spot.

I love this place for the late hours; especially in this area.
author: Crystal Z.

description: This is my absolutely favourite coffee place in the bay area, have lived in Australia for 6 years definitely made me very picky about not just the coffee but the entire experience. Ritual is located on Velancia st in mission, very spacious with minimalistic interior design. They have a small menu but I successfully ordered piccolo and flat white with them before, they were all made with the right amount of milk and foam. Their latte art definitely made the coffee even more enjoyable. On a side note, their ham and cheese  croissant is delicious!! I would say it is way better than the ham and cheese croissant from Tartine near by=) if you are a coffee lover (not just the caffeine), Ritual is where you want to go.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
Ritual's coffee is consistently good, fast and high quality. I have been to a few of their different shops and each one has been well above-average. The Valencia Street location is my favorite because it has a lot of seating and feels very open. The baristas at this store are also particularly firendly. Yes, it is yuppy coffee but it is good yuppy coffee and in a city like SF where pretentious coffees hops are a dime a dozen, you are much better off spending your money at one with quality coffee. Ritual definitely competes in the top bracket of coffee in this city. Is it #1? I surely don't think so but they do churn out reliably quality coffee on a larger scale.

I almost always get a Skim Cappuccino or a Pour Over and they do both quite well. I can only imagine all of their other beverages are similarly good.  I have had the baked goods at the Valencia Street shop as well on a few occasions and they are always fresh, so I cannot complain. The WiFi situation can be a bit spotty but you can't have everything :D
author: Carrie W.

description:
Ritual is a coffee company started here in San Francisco (not China -as the logo of the company is reminiscent of the Chinese flag. You see it?!? See, my thoughts aren't that far off). They've branched out to Napa and are found in speciality shops as well.

Anyhow, it's a modern, hipsteresque vibe, very large space with only a few tables and chairs. Ritual only makes a light and medium roast, which I am fine with- just not so much of a variety for others. Milk choices are of the cow variety, soy and I chose almond for my latte. I was visually pleased with my latte art and equally pleased with the taste as well.

Latte $4.50
Lemon poppy seed frosted vegan donut $3
Coffee w/friends in SF priceless :)
author: Jules B.

description: Stylish and upscale.  They have delicious coffee and tea, and also coffee-based cocktails (non-alcoholic) that are amazing.  Great ambiance.  My whole office loves coming here.
author: Jordan K.

description:
Cons:
1. Loud rock music - bad for meetings and studying 
2. NO WIFI
3. No mirror and no toilet seat covers in the bathrooms 
4. Limited selection of overpriced pastries (and there was a fly in the case with the pastries)

Pros: 
1. Great customer service
author: Alpo P.

description:
Interior-wise there is some interesting decor. The place itself looks like a very wide hallway with some cool lights and art. There aren't too many places to sit given how large the space is which could seem frustrating when its busy. 

Got a simple cappuccino and it was golden. The barista was nice and helpful when my friend and I had questions.
author: Christine K.

description:
I didn't realize that this place was a chain and/or that it was super hipster funk popular. Their coffee is great and give discount to those who bring their own cups. Very simple decor inside. Pretty good place to work but NO WEEFEE. crycrycry 

Good coffee, okay pastries. We got the two scones and they were just okay but I kept eating it bc of false hunger. 

There's a pretty long table in the back, which is good for groups. My friend got her wallet stolen here though, so I'd just be careful of any sketchy-lookin' humans and make sure to have your bag zipped and close to you.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Ritual Coffee was by far the best coffee shop I visited in San Francisco.

I had an iced mocha both times I went, it was a bit small for the price ($5ish) - but the taste of my latte was definitely worth it. Not only is the roast of high quality, but the chocolate seemed freshly melted instead of a packaged syrup you typically find when visiting coffee shops.

The staff was very friendly and had my drink ready fairly quickly.

Finally, the design of this coffee shop is beautiful. I loved the garden in the back of the restaurant. Great aesthetics.
author: Taylor B.

description:
High quality coffee, friendly baristas, fantastic latte art... Cool place overall. 

Minimalistic aesthetic; makes for a great working environment if you can find a place to sit!
author: Noelle M.

description:
Our last stop of our restaurant hop- coffee and dessert. 

They have a very small selection of pastries, which should be fixed because they definitely have enough customers.  However, the lemon coconut tart that I thought I was settling for, ended up being amazing. Their presentations of the coffee drinks and tea are really cute. The ambiance- I have mixed feelings for. Part of it was really cold and bland, but the other part had really cool random details. I guess that's was "modern" is all about these days.   Overall good experience.
author: Tiffanie A.

description:
The coffee was great, but the wait to get it was excruciating.  

Coffee:  5 stars
Service and Wait Time:  2 stars 

It was my first visit to Ritual.  I had heard so much about it.  I heard one of my favorite baristas from Portola Coffee in Costa Mesa even worked moved up to SF and worked there (where were you Paulina?).  Last trip up north I got to try Four Barrel.  This time I tried Ritual.  

Sunday afternoon.  We ordered a cappuccino and a V60 Las Manos.  My cappuccino was ready within five minutes so I grabbed that when they called me.  I added some sugar while we waited another few minutes for the V60 pour over.  I asked the barista that was handing out the drinks if I needed to wait at her station or if I needed to go to the pour over station.  She said no, they bring them to where she was.  At least 20 order pickups passed us by, including many by people that had ordered after us.  

Cappucino - Good beans, right temperature with the right amount of milk and foam.

At 20 minutes I went over to the pour over station and asked if my order was coming up and if the pour over girl had seen it.  She said she hadn't.  She rifled through the old orders pile and there mine was.  She says, "Oh wow, I'll have this done next for you."  She had that look on her face that said, "Oh crap this order was placed 20 minutes ago!"  

I don't know who messed up.  I'm thinking it wasn't her.  Somewhere between my payment, where the orders print and the person who brings the order slips to the V60 station, something got hella lost.  Mine wasn't the only one, there was another order next to mine that got shorted.  

So 23 minutes in, we finally got our V60 pour over.  My friend was about to go ape sh*t, but didn't because she was on vacation from Canada and didn't really want it to ruin her day.  The pour over girl approached us sheepishly with the drink and also gave us a card for a complimentary drink.  So at least she was nice enough to do that.  The first girl (not pour over girl) that I asked about our order answered me with a subtle air of annoyance even though we had been standing directly in front of her forever.

The espresso here is good.  My friend enjoyed her V60 pour over.  The price is reasonable too... it was only $3 for the pour over of the beans of your choice.  Usually I'm pretty understanding about order errors, but we were doing a one day tour of San Francisco and trying to cram in as much as we could while on the go, so the delay was a lot of wasted exploring time for us.  

The new interior of Ritual is a clean design, but it's missing the warmth and charm that a coffee house should have.  If they just traded those stringy neon or LED string lights for something more homey or old school industrial, that would give the place some charm.  Or maybe it's the high bare walls?   In reading reviews from regulars here, I can understand their lament.  Philz Coffee has been opening new locations but has managed to retain some of their Philz charm, even in their newer stores.  Could Ritual have done the same?  Maybe we just haven't programmed ourselves to accept futuristic or ultramodern coffeehouses (epitomized by the red with fluorescent backlit espresso machines).  Maybe it's just me that's not ready for it yet.  Or maybe it's because a week later I'm still annoyed that it took 25 minutes to get a cup of coffee.
author: Howie C.

description:
Went to Mission District for Ritual Coffee as I was on a mission to check out all famous coffee shops while in SF. Loved the decor and service but I've had better coffee in Seattle - probably just a personal preference. While I was waiting to pay for my coffee, one customer came by to ask for wifi access but cashier told the guy that Ritual Coffee doesn't offer wifi, which surprised me. 

Overall, cute 'little' shop with above-average coffee. Loved their mugs too!
author: M K.

description:
Good coffee
Nice inside and friendly staff

A little pricey, but that's how all the places are around here

It might take a while to get your drink during the day, so it's best in the afternoon ;)
author: Jad A.

description:
THIS PLACE IS HUGE!! They have a stand up bar that takes up half the store, and just a lot of space.

I tried their "First Exit," espresso and it was a good shot. Slightly under extracted for my taste but they pulled the flavors out of it really well. This bean is more on the acidic/ citrusy side so if you prefer nutty/ chocolaty notes you might not appreciate. They also have information cards on different brewing methods by their espresso machine. Just thought that was neat and thoughtful.

Parking is street and we all know how expensive it can get in the city. I recommend parking in the neighborhood, its only an hour parking but free after 6pm.

Overall a great place to work
author: Ben L.

description: Great coffee! Absolutely delicious coffee! The atmosphere is very lovely. I will definitely go back.
author: Ronak M.

description:
The newly remodeled Ritual is beautiful! Aesthetically speaking, it now is on the same playing field as the Four Barrels, Sightglasses, and Blue Bottles in the city - spaciously, minimalistically rustic. 

I may be in the minority here, but I feel that it was a good move to do away with WiFi and the power outlets; it discourages people from hogging the tables and keeping others from being able to enjoy the space. If you want a coffee shop where you can stay immersed in your laptop screen for hours on end, there is a myriad of Starbucks within city limits you can choose from...take your pick. 

As far as the coffee is concerned, Ritual was the first place where I ordered a drip coffee and did not have to add any milk or sugar. That says a lot about this roaster's ability to produce a balanced cup with no acidity, and it speaks volumes about the baristas who work there as well. Even though I buy Ritual beans from Whole Foods, manually grind with my Hario Skerton before brewing with a Chemex, I still don't achieve the same quality from home as when I get a cup from Ritual itself. Quite possibly the best drip you'll find in the city and arguably ground zero of San Francisco's coffee culture.
author: Olivia V.

description:
Sigh, ritual coffee. Out of all the big whigs in SF, Ritual took my heart from day one. A few things here to get out of the way: yes, coffee here is expensive. yes, it borderlines on pretentiously hipster. yes, everything is delicious.

Ritual redid their interior in 2014 (if I remember correctly), which really opened up the space and bumped this review form 4 to 5 stars for me. It's well lit, open environment, and generous wifi really take the cake and make it an amazing cafe to relax with friends or do work/study.

Their drip coffees are carefully prepared to order, but depending on the roast that you order, a coffee can range anywhere from $4 to $8/9, which can probably turn off some people from trying their coffee. That being said, their beans are some of the best I've had in the city so definitely give it a try.

If you're a fan of iced coffee, go for their Nitro Cold Brew. Very cool, smooth and silky.

If you're venturing into coffee and want to channel your inner barista, they have a lot of cool coffee mugs, drippers, and sets available for sale as well! Chat up some of the staff to get some insight on how best to prepare your own drip coffee at home and take home a set as well :)
author: Jay P.

description: Nice spacious area and coffee is delicious! Great place to sit and chill. I had the latte. The space is bright and inspiring
author: Nan T.

description:
Friday, 4:45 PM.
Note: no wi-fi.

Quickie:
+ Drink/Food quality
+ Service
- Hygiene
+ Atmosphere
+ Turnaround
* Menu variety
* Layout

And then...?
Ritual provides a conducive work space if you do not need to get online. Most of its seats are at tables.

**********
Constructive comment:
*Expand food menu
author: Chuck N.

description: The staff here are awesome. They love their coffee and have the education to reach out all about its complexities a how they carefully selected the blend
author: Kelly S.

description:
Great coffee and ambiance for catching up with friends or studying! 

Came here on a Sunday afternoon and it was pretty crowded but luckily there is plenty of seating in the back at the long table.  There were a few people in line but it goes by really quickly.

The decoration is modern and rustic. Everything was clean and the entire place is very spacious. I loved that they had a nice cactus garden in the back! I would definitely come back here again especially for the ambiance!
author: Linda X.

description: My favorite coffee spot in the mission. No Wi-Fi but that isn't always the worst thing. Really good mocha and coffee and gorgeous on the inside.
author: Cameron J.

description: Helpful staff, asked about dark roast & was pointed in right direction. Had all the stuff I needed too, honey, almond milk etc. Friendly staff, courteous and listened to me talk about rock n roll. Yes the elder skatesman can still yak with the best of em.
author: Henry K.

description:
This is NOT a review of the shop (I haven't been here) but a review of the product: I've been buying Ritual brand "Seasonal Espresso" for some time now (from local Whole Foods or wherever I can find it) and it is quite simply THE BEST espresso I've ever put through my machine.  I start every day with a double-shot mocha (iced or hot depending on the season) with just a squirt of Ghirardelli Special Dark chocolate sauce. I've tried dozens of espresso brands over the years, but once I found Ritual I've never needed another brand.

I wish they had a subscription service for their beans.
author: Daniel G.

description: The coffee here is simple and gorgeous! And the ambiance inside exudes the same vibe! Ordered the cafe latte today and it was spot on. Perfectly roasted beans, flavorful, and aromatic. :)
author: Chase B.

description:
It's true.
It's all true.
I cannot tell if Ritual is any more or less awesome than the other awesome coffee roasters in town.

But I knows what I likes, and Ritual's short capp (or cortado) meets my (totally realistic but possibly slightly skewed) standards.

Moreover, to better quantify exactly why I like what I like for future reviews, I've started to outline a possible Rubric that will help accurately encapsulate what is an acceptable cappuccino that's based on the quality of the espresso itself and its relation to the temperature and foaminess of the milk.

Seriously.

I mean I wouldn't necessarily say I'm an obsessive type person . . . an obsessive type person . . . an obsessive type person . . . an obsessive type person . . .  or anything.

So besides their excellent java, the interior space is something to see.  The amalgamation of matte white walls and glossy birch wood help to create this tranquil oasis from the sights and sounds and smells of the Mission.
author: Dan B.

description: I wasn't a huge fan of the cold brew here. Heavy on that "carbonated" taste. With that said, it kept me up all night so it's definitely strong!  Also, there's no WiFi. Blah.
author: Ninette C.

description:
Love the simplicity and ambiance. 
Good coffee and friendly staff. 
The banana nut bread was yummy.
author: Debbie P.

description:
Burnt, bitter, over roasted coffee beans do not make great coffee. I think instant coffee would have tasted better than this stuff. On the positive side, it's extremely clean and the modern decor is fairly spot on for an uppity coffee shop that preaches sugarless lattes with a side of overly sweet "breakfast" food. 
At least the price was right. I am glad I didn't waste more that $11 on this place and I won't be returning.
author: Autumn L.

description: Hot chocolate is rich and tasty. The whole place has a pretty nice vibe.
author: Tariq P.

description:
Ritual serves up some mighty fine coffee in an ultra hip locale, without being overly pretentious.  I like to think that Ritual Coffee Roasters is the more mature version of the relatively new, sparsely decorated coffee shop in Berkeley, Artis.  Both shops cater to elite coffee connoisseurs and relative newbies alike.  However, Ritual feels older and, perhaps, a little more forgiving, while still maintaining its commitment to excellent coffee prepared with the utmost care.  In addition to working intimately with their coffee bean producers, they offer multiple espresso roasts to choose from for your cup o' joe.

When you first walk in, you will notice shelves of different coffee pots and tea wares on your left, much like Artis.  On the right wall of Ritual, you will see cool photo prints of Japanese city life.  My friends got a kick out of the fugu sign in one of the busy Japanese street prints, as they were fresh off the plane from their sojourn in Japan.  During their stay, they had tasted the puffer, which can cause sudden death by poison if prepared incorrectly.  But I digress... 

There are thick wooden tables throughout the shop for sipping, working, chatting, or just soaking up that ultra cool Ritual vibe that abounds.  Despite the construction, which blocked off a good portion of the space, Ritual still had a steady stream of customers during my visit.

My mocha was so smooth and well-rounded.  The semi-sweetness of chocolate punctuated the fruity undertones of the coffee so perfectly.  Of course, my boyfriend ordered his usual macchiato espresso.  He commented that it was excellent, albeit not as strong as he prefers.  (I tried the macchiato and thought it was just right for such a drink, so I would still recommend it to you :p)  Five stars for Ritual!  I'll be back next time I'm in the Mission.  Cards are accepted through Square, so you can have it emailed to you instead of printed.
author: Brittany N.

description: I just got the smallest 'large' iced coffee I've ever seen served up by a sullen cashier at a premium price.
author: John M.

description: Solid performance, pretty good cortado and cappuccino. The space is nice, really open and had a lot of natural light.
author: Amber H.

description:
Awesome cool interior
Great and friendly service
Interesting mix of people to chat with
Fun outdoor seating... Ahoy matey! 
And, of course, great coffee...
author: Greg S.

description:
Visiting from out of town, and definitely not disappointed! The location inside is bright, expansive and open- even with the overcast weather outside. Baristas were helpful and knowledgeable. 

I tried a pour over, and I'm fairly certain it is the best cup of coffee that I've ever had in my life. Light, citrusy and very aromatic. Mmmmm! 

Boyfriend ordered an iced mocha, which was unique and delicious. Most coffee shops of this caliber offer mochas that are traditionally on the bittersweet side, but Ritual mocha was slightly more sweet, with a hint of vanilla caramel. 

What I love most about coffee shops and traveling to new ones like Ritual, is that it is an experience to be enjoyed and savored.
author: Erin E.

description: I don't know how some of the other coffee joints have 5 stars with a ton of reviews and Ritual is at less than 5 stars. This place is amazing and has high quality coffee and the baristas know their coffee well. The atmosphere is great as well. I wish I lived in San Fransisco so that I could come here all the time. I will be buying pounds of coffee from them online for sure.
author: Jay B.

description: I love Rituals mocha and cappuccino - they have a aromatic smoky/floral-y note that I can't quite pinpoint. Most unique espresso in terms of flavor that I've had. Their cold brew is also pretty good, slightly acidic but bright and not bitter at all
author: Melody L.

description: Nice modern decor. Fancy machines. Their roast is a bit bright for my taste, and no wifi sucks.
author: Peter T.

description:
I had a favorite coffee shop in the bay area, and Ritual coffee roasters just beat it to be my current #1 favorite coffee shop. Everyone there is so knowledgeable about the coffee they carry and have some as projects that they try and see how customers like. The nitro had tons of caffeine and is good for a cold day, almost tastes like a stout, with a creamy head! Has a chocolaty taste! 

The santa clara was amazing too, served hot of course. They CAN ice it for you, but it has a whole different method of icing and may taste different from the hot (original) version!

They have a great selection of organic ingredients to add to the coffee such as Clover milk and a variety of soy milk.

They offer a wide variety of selections including aero pressed coffee as well!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Their coffee, for me, was very very strong - this can be a good and bad thing. For $4.something macchiato, I think it's on the pricey side but as it was strong coffee, maybe quality over quantity? In any case, I needed to put some extra sugar in mine but I saw some people drinking espresso so I guess it's doable. 

The interior, remodeled recently, is very nicely done. Very minimalistic and modern but with very nice accent decorations like their chandelier-looking thing. It gives a nice and relaxing atmosphere to the coffee shop. I saw some space in the back where everyone was studying so I think this would be a great spot to come by and study if you live nearby. 

The one minus star is for the slow service. Compared to other small stores, they take longer - maybe they had some large group order or something. In any case, I wouldn't mind coming back here :)
author: Sarah K.

description: Delicious coffee, and a hipster ambiance - to be expected in SF, of course, but they deliver. And you won't feel claustrophobic with their high ceilings, which is a bit less common!
author: Olivier L.

description:
I was trying to explain what a "hipster" is to my sweet, innocent babygirl. I couldn't come up with a definition on my own, other than "you'll know it when you see one".  I thought Ritual would be the place for me to show her what they look like in their native habitat. 

You can imagine my surprise when we stepped into the newly remodeled flagship Ritual shop. I'm not sure it's all that new but then again, I haven't been to this location for years since parking normally sucks. 

The new digs are pretty nice looking. This location is not nearly as cramped as it was previously. Then again, we made our stop in here on an early weekday evening, so perhaps we missed the crowds.  

I've been a fan of Ritual for years. Although I usually get my fix in Napa lately. Be sure to ask for a punch card as they don't always volunteer to give you one. I have now had my punch card stamped at all four Ritual locations. They are my favorite brand of coffee, even over my beloved Timeless in Oakland. Sure they don't have v3gan pastries that I know of , but their coffee is so much more smooth in taste and texture as far as the lattes go. 

They take their coffee brewing prowess seriously 'round here, yet not pretentiously so. The cold brew is high quality as is their pour over single brew selections. Not sure if it's the technique, or the roasting. Most likely both. 

If I can have one last coffee before I die, it would be Ritual. If I could afford to do this ritual everyday, I most certainly would. 

Sure there's plenty of hipster folk that frequent this place, if you're looking to get all "crikey" and spot a few, this is a much more comfortable and tasty environment to do so than say Fourbarrel down the street.
author: John B.

description:
Coffee is good. But the amount of hipster attitude is off the charts. Ordered the cheaper already-brewed coffee, which got a smug reaction from the cashier. Asked for the wifi from the barista, which caused two other employees to look up at me aghast that I would even ask that. Final straw is that they block all but one power plug in their very large cafe. 

Way too many great coffee shops around here to deal with these guys.
author: Zach K.

description: Spacious coffee shop- high ceilings, clean design, indoor and outdoor seating. They serve some unique teas, for us non-coffee drinkers. Laptop crowd and chatters alike are here. Good meeting place.
author: Joanna L.

description:
This place was pretty good! Came in wanting an art latte and that's what I got! Caffeine usually doesn't wake me up or does what it needs to but it definitely rises my body temperature up and it certainly did so. So that's how you know or I know it does its job. 

The shop is pretty cute and easy to follow with multiple seatings. Nice place to chit chat or do some work. The tables were a little dirty and I got an unknown random coffee stain on my cardigans sleeve when I sat down. I didn't see anyone coming around and wiping the tables down... & my friend said she could smell the bathroom from where she was sitting and we were a bit far from the bathroom. 

But overall, good environment for a sit down chit chat over some coffee.
author: Sandy L.

description: wow this place just brought me complete joy after my difficult breakup and like i had no energy to keep moving anymore but after i drank that 30 espresso shot coffee i have just been reenergized. god bless, pls go try this place:)))
author: Bella H.

description: This place is quite the spot if you're looking to hit your morning coffee. Lots of seating, beautiful light fixtures, and some baristas that get fancy with their coffee. These guys are chemists. There are succulents in the back but that's not the only thing that will spike you over here!
author: Tesha S.

description:
Been here a couple of times for coffee to go, it's good coffee on the expensive side.

Took down one more star for not having WiFi, on a weekday, Thursday 9am. Went down to borderlands instead.
author: Zorayr K.

description: One of the best coffee shop in San Francisco!   Mild and unique taste of strong coffee that you know they are different right the way.
author: Sapphire L.

description:
Local favorite and hotspot.

I ordered the macchiato and it was perfect. Perfect amount of foamed milk to stain the rich, dark, robust espresso. A nice little pick me up coffee for 6pm. 

Seating not as ample and no restroom for customers.

I also had to buy a $10mug with their logo on it. Why? Because I like collecting mugs from fine coffee establishments. Hopefully it does not contain lead from china.
author: Lan N.

description:
Everything about this place is decent. If I looked up decent in a dictionary it'd show a latte from here.

Very hipster / trendy design but the actual coffee is average.

I ordered a latte and it was okay at best. Nothing to write home about.

Lots of seating for the Mission District Hipsters.

The water dispenser looks like a tap which is kind of cool. Beer tap, that is. 

Parking can be a HUGE issue so I suggest taking Muni or BART to check this place out. At the end of the day, I'd go to Four Barrel just because it's better.
author: Chris W.

description:
We needed somewhere to kill time while we waited for a friend and we ended up here. I got a {cold} tea which I can't remember what the name was, but it was really good and refreshing. My friend got one of the granola bars with chocolate and nuts which were really good and totally hit the spot since we were hungry before dinner. 

Overall, it's a nice, and hipster place to hang out and chill or do some work. The space is really open and clean and they drink and food (of what I tried) is really good.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Had this bookmarked forever and finally got a chance to come here.

This place is super classy and very hipster.  Love this about SF.  When will the rest of the bay catch on?! 

Got the sweet tooth espresso ($3, tax included) and it wasn't sweet.  Turns out this is what they call their "coffee of the day".  Still, it was good.  
It evens comes with a shot of sparkling water as a chaser.  Fancy!!!

They have lots of different coffee cards that explain the different drinks and how to make them.  Very cool and fun! =)

Will be back to try their other drinks.
author: David W.

description: Found this spot during a weekend trip to SF and so glad! Only negative was they have no wifi but their coffee was great. Stayed a while and had a cappuccino and a latte and my god the bbbbbessst  jelly donut ... it also happened to be vegan! Sooo good.
author: Looloo D.

description:
I'm not a coffee freak, so I don't know the difference between Folgers Crystals and organic Arabica slow-roasted and artisanally cold-brewed in an Oji style system. Okay, that might not be true, but you get the idea.

So, apparently Ritual is for the second group of people. People who would wait 20 minutes to get coffee handmade by someone who actually thinks making coffee is an art (and I'm not talking baristas ... the real shit). They apparently have two kinds of coffees: the pre-made batch stuff, which is pretty good and comes out in 2 minutes, and the hand-made wait 20 minutes stuff. I think the pre-made stuff is just like like most other coffee shops, but I heard rave reviews of the hand-made stuff. I had the pre-made iced coffee, and while it was good, I was a little surprised by how it had a very tangy finish. Not sure if that's because I'm used to Starbucks crap and this is the taste of high quality beans. Anyway, it was a "whatever" experience for me.

On a side note, I was completely confounded by the communist theme in their color scheme and logo.
author: Akash K.

description:
A pleasant open space with some whimsical but practical outdoor seating, I came to Ritual with a friend on my recent visit to San Francisco when we were wandering around.  I perused the tea menu and found it to be short but impressive, with about five teas total and most of them were teas I would have been pleased to try.  I settled on a wild mao feng and then we stood around a while while they steeped it.

Properly.  

At the right temperature, with a timer, in a dedicated tea-steeping setup.  Good tea cannot be rushed.

Everything was wonderful, and my friend was happy with his coffee.  We sat outside at the table with the compass sunk into it, and I was curious about the contrast between the nautical theme and the communist-style logo, but mostly I was happy with the tea.
author: Penelope B.

description:
Huge space, great coffee, friendly staff, short wait.

Latte foam was on point.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
5 stars for the coffee but 3-4 stars for the price. Ritual is still one of my favorite coffee roasters in SF. Blue Bottle and Philz are really good too, but I like Ritual better than Four Barrel and Sightglass. I stopped by the store a few weeks ago and purchased a couple of beans to brew at home:

-Organic Pinabetal Whole Beans (Notes of Vanilla, Canteloupe, Rainier Cherry, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=DClsyAPtSHV1i1XJiRSExw#DClsyAPtSHV1i1XJiRSExw): I really liked the flavor notes listed on the bag, but I couldn't really detect them when drinking the coffee. Also, this ended up being a really light brew, and I prefer my coffee a little stronger. I wouldn't get this blend again.
-Siberia Whole Beans (Notes of Sweet Citrus, Cherry, Caramel): This was Processing Experiment #1 w/Traditional Fermentation, and I loved the flavors! The caramel flavor really rounded out the medium bodied coffee. I would definitely purchase this again. 

Ritual has never been cheap, but I think they might have raised their prices recently since they won that coffee challenge. In any case, although each bag of beans was pricey(between $18-$19 for a 12 oz bag), you are paying for the quality. I don't know if I could justify purchasing Ritual beans for everyday drinking since the bf usually drinks 3 cups/day, but I will definitely be back to try out additional blends and hopefully purchase the Siberia again. Note that it takes them a while to prepare your coffee since they use a drip method, and the line can get long at times. However, there are plenty of tables to sit at inside and hang out. Parking in the Mission can be difficult, but street parking spots are available.
author: Amy D.

description:
Bomb coffee in a cute space! 

Finally got to try Ritual coffee after hearing such great things about it during my last trip to SF. 

Got the cold brew and it didn't disappoint. Cool thing is that you can purchase an engraved mason jar to get your cold drink in and the next time you bring it in you can use it to purchase your drink in it too!

Definitely come here.
author: Vicki L.

description: Very slow service. Coffee was not distinct from other iced Americano that I have ordered from other places
author: Kitty D.

description:
Delicious, smooth cold brew coffee ($4), fast wifi, minimal outlets from what I could see. 

Hipster central -- minimalistic decor with a very spacious, airy feel right up my alley. It was much larger from what I expected when initially walking in.

Tables are small, so might not be the place for you if you need a lot of room to work.
author: Justine H.

description:
Every espresso I've ever tried has been concentrated sour-awful...my palate's not mature enough to be a coffee connoisseur.

However, I will testify that, 
sour, sweet, or bitter,
SWEET TOOTH ESPRESSO creates a magical optimal state of mind I have not achieved from any other coffee drink.

I predict it will take its place on those lists of habits of successful people: 
"My morning routine begins with a light jog on the beach of my private island and a sweet tooth espresso."

Food coma? Gone. Headache? Gone. Pain, stress and heavy burdens are lifted away after one sip. 

This is the Universe's blessing of clarity, productivity, and positivity in a tiny cup.
author: Mary L.

description: Very good coffee! Just the right amount of mix between flavor and strength. Interior is spacious and easy to maneuver for parents with strollers. Which is a lot for most places in Mission that seem to have space restrictions. Opens at 7am! Which works for us, before the morning run. 6am would be even better!
author: Sridevi K.

description: This is a good place to grab a coffee socially, but not to work. The staff and layout of the space make it very clear laptops are not welcome. There is no wifi and a single electrical outlet in the entire shop... and there are outlets that have been purposely closed. In a packed city like San Francisco, this is a serious let-down.
author: Chris H.

description: Hipsteriffic tasty coffee - not cheap. Strange "parklet" (I never will understand the appeal) in front of a shipwreck.  Clean and sterile inside.  Detached customer service (ie, did they  hear me? are they really letting the toddler over there break her fingers in the hinge of the front door? etc).
author: Jenn C.

description:
I'd heard about this place and while bike-shopping in the Mission I finally came across it. I didn't need a coffee, but I needed one since I was here. Straightforward menu, great baristas.

I got a mocha, and walking down the street, I took a sip, sighed, and thought "DAMN that's a good mocha. LIFE IS GOOD."

It's a pretty big cafe, with lots of seating. They take credit, but they also over-charged my card. Yes, I actually look at my bill, guys.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Great coffee shop with modern vibe. Plenty of space and the line moves fast. 
I tend to like my coffee bitter with an extra kick, if this is your style asked for an extra shot.
author: K M.

description:
Yum. As a newly minted coffee fan, I approve.

Drip coffees, black:

El Angel, Costa Rica (raspberry, vanilla, chocolate orange notes. $3)
Slightly sweet flavor, more earthy than the El Silencio.

El Silencio, Colombia (mandarin, butterscotch, vanilla notes. $4)
Had a bit of a sour, fruity note to it. My bf kind of regretted getting this one and liked mine better.

Bran muffin - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=CV3u-TrJnDkU1WIOEoU34g#CV3u-TrJnDkU1WIOEoU34g
This was soft, slightly crumbly, yet moist and grainy. It could've used more flavor, though the bits of cranberry/raisin were good pockets of more intense flavor. It was also pretty oily.

Coffee menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco?select=CV3u-TrJnDkU1WIOEoU34g#sZnqaRxlHTevCVrK3gvAbw
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Strong espresso here--I had the mocha at 9PM, and I was still awake at 2AM!  

The ambiance is minimalist and spacious.  When I walked in, the place was packed with people with laptops.  The bathroom has a Dyson hand dryer, which is always a plus.  My only complaint is that nonfat milk is not available--the default is whole milk.
author: Matt R.

description:
Very solid coffee. In any other city this would be the #1 coffee spot. This is SF though, so I still prefer blue bottle or Philz. But that's all just personal preference.

If you're in the neighborhood definitely check ritual out. The space is beautiful and airy. Lots of tables for work space, cactus garden out back, and clean bathrooms. 

So, even if I like the coffee slightly better at the other 2, this is a much cleaner work space. Matches my vibe better than Philz personally...

Plus this stretch of Valencia has some cool shops. Come check out the area.
author: Quyen V.

description:
I can't believe I never wrote a review for this Ritual. That's crazy cause I particularly love this location, even more now since they reopened. 

No free wifi, but I think that's the great part of this spot. 
And it's the future so people BYOB (bring your own broadband) and just hang out. 

I will always get a iced soy latte here, because it's delicious. 
It's the spot that between two 16th and 24th Bart Stations, so it isn't overly crowded. 

I use it as a meeting point on the weekends when I'm in the mission because you can usually find a place to sit and it's central to a lot of restaurants/bars.
author: Theresa D.

description: This place seems to suffer from some undeserved hype.
author: Andrew N.

description: My son asked me to go to Ritual and get him a mug...he heard about Ritual from Adam Savage of MythBusters (me: who's he?). The place is cool...along with a mug (!) I bought a pound of the Sweet Tooth expresso for my son, and he said it's the best coffee he's had yet. I agree...reminds me of the coffee that is the norm at the cafés in Italy.
author: Shannon S.

description:
This place is beautiful! I love the interior - very spacious, minimal, and clean. I love the window in the back showcasing all the plants. Their branding is great as well. There is no wifi which I appreciate because it encourages you to sit down and have a conversation with the person next to you. It's also a great place for you to sit down and enjoy a good book, write, or sketch. 

I wasn't sure what to order, but the barista told me that they were known for their cappucinos because thats what the owner of Ritual likes to drink. Although I'm not an avid coffee drinker (I'm a coffee noob), I enjoyed my beautiful cup.
author: Annie L.

description:
Ritual is legit and have been exemplary roasters since they began in 2005, roughly. I used to work at a cafe that tried to go above and beyond, and Ritual was a name we looked up to and referenced often, and for good reason.

The crema on their espresso drinks, if you're a crema/espresso drink fan, will likely put you in a blissful, buzzing, warm state of mind. It's delicious. Their espresso never tastes burnt, and I don't know what type of roast they use most often (medium/full city?) but it is delightful and doesn't feel like you just drank oil, or as though it is eating a hole in your stomach. The crema is creamy, aromatic and fluffy, and I love when baristas don't make their drinks so dang hot that it singes your fingertips to hold the cup. That's not how it's done. 

Ritual has got it going on, and they have a few locations in SF, as well as a number of cafes around the bay area which carry their beans and use their beans in their coffee/espresso drinks. 

If I had to compare them to something else, I'd say (and this is my opinion and may not necessarily be shared by all, as we all have different taste buds) they taste similar to Four Barrel, who are also badass supremes of the roasting world, if you ask me. 

I don't believe you'll be let down by Ritual, at all. They're solid.
author: Stacy N.

description:
CAN I SAY I LOVE THIS PLACE IN ALL CAPS!!! Most delicious, soothing, tasty latte I've ever had. Staff is super friendly too! 

Parking isn't bad if yr there at 6:30am like me :)
author: luis m.

description:
I have been going to ritual coffee since around 2005. I've had both good and bad experiences, but the coffee is always amazing.

The redesign of the cafe makes it seem a bit bigger, but possibly less inviting. I miss the art on the walls. In general, though, the baristas are legit, the staff is generally kind and will be fun if you smile and are engaging.
author: Jay S.

description: Pretty long line. It went by quick. In less than 10 mins I had ordered, received my drink, and was out the door. The only thing I did not like was how they didn't have any sugar packs. This made me eyeball on how much sugar to pour into my drink. Anyhow, it was a good but expensive cup of latte.
author: Ann L.

description: Ultimately, I am writing this for folks that like strong, rich, coffee. Ritual serves a roast that is similar to tea. If you like very light, watery coffee. This is your spot. To each his own. The baristas are very nice and helpful but I found this out after I purchased the coffee. I even tried another cup thinking that they had forgotten to add fresh grounds to the pot, maybe accidentally used old grounds. Nope, they nicely "schooled" me about how they pride themselves on a very light roast that has the essence of tea. Super sweet folks...super weak coffee.
author: Birdie M.

description:
It's a beautiful space with a lovely cactus garden at the end of the shop. The staff's friendly and the atmosphere's very light and relaxing. But compared with four barrel and sight glass coffee I felt this coffee wasn't as robust. And they don't roast their beans in this location.

My usual drink is an almond milk latte and I've found that the type of almond milk makes a huge difference too.
author: Cara G.

description: I went here to grab a coffee with my 9 month old. And listen, I get that we're in the Mission and that there is a certain level of empathy for the homeless in the area, but I was disappointed to see their staff do absolutely nothing when a homeless man came barreling through the doors with an old Ritual cup and charged straight for the milk counter. He clearly had very prominent fecal stains on his pants and seriously grimy hands. He proceeded to block the counter area and chug every carafe of milk available, all of the sugar water and then took a seat in the back of the shop. Instead of cleaning the carafes... the staff went and filled them back up to which he came straight back and started chugging all the milk again. He then left after drinking 4 carafes of milk at the counter. And the staff did not go and replace the carafes or clean them- the next customers just unknowingly grabbed them, started filling up their expensive coffees and eating their vegan pastries (which don't get me wrong- are delicious). At the end of the day I know that it's a hipster spot- but it's also a food establishment and a certain level of obvious hygiene should be maintained. I'm now going to be forever wary of what I'm putting in my $5 coffee when I pour the milk at Ritual.
author: Kim C.

description: I can easily see why this is an sf favorite! Great coffee. Really nice space. Lots of tables. Lots of light. There is even a little garden in the back!
author: Jen G.

description: Yet another of the SF cafe scene that has an undeniably sexy layout and design. You have to specify you want ceramic, otherwise you'll get paper - so be sure to do that, because ceramic is the door to flavour town. I had an americano & cap, both were bold and flavoursome with the milk textured nicely. Come here and fuel up before a big day exploring Valencia St.
author: Chris K.

description:
Beautify open space with decent amount of tables and seatings. I feel like they can have more tables though. It feels a bit empty. There also a backyard outdoor seating area. 

I got my per usual Almond Latte and my friend got the Ethiopian Pour Over. The almond latte is just their house blend espresso with steamed almond milk. It was okay-- kind of lukewarm and latte art (the BEST part) was very disappointing. I was hoping for a turkey but I got a wilting leaf of some sort. I felt so rushed to snap a picture real fast before it disappear on me completely. But that's not the point, for $4.50, I expected a better cup of almond latte. One that is actually HOT since I requested "extra hot."  The Ethiopian blend pour over was very bold and dark. Definitively the kind of coffee that would keep me jittery for the rest of the day.    

I'm disappointed to say that Ritual didn't live up to the hype. Service was okay, neither good or bad. On the same token, an almond latte can only go right or wrong in so many ways and they all usually taste the same -- regardless of where I get them. I was just craving an extra hot latte on a chilly Saturday morning! 

Ritual definitely has a beautiful clean ambience to it. Great place to for a coffee date, but I think I would try out the many other coffee spots in the area next time.
author: Ellen W.

description:
Thank you Patty for letting me film you doing your latte art! 6 years of hard work and dedication for sure makes everyone's day every time they receive those cup of coffee! Because my girlfriend and I sure did when we received our lattes! 
It was both of our first time here, and I am definitely coming back the ambient of this place is extremely open and modern. No wifi unfortunately, but I could see why it gets better reviews without! Lovely place. Definitely recommended for coffee lovers!

Thanks again Patty!
author: Joey K.

description: Some very, very good coffee (of all varieties).  Don't mind the modern decor or the hipster location, they serve up a mean brew regardless!  The service was also very friendly and not a bit pretentious.
author: David C.

description:
The thought of a delicious latte drew me like a moth to a flame on this rainy day. 

Their bright space was buzzing with the usual darkly-clad hipsters, some with Mac laptops, others with books, and some simply enjoying each other's company over iPhones and lattes.

I contemplated whether I should purchase branded Klean Kanteen while in line under the carefully crafted light installation, then placed my order for a latte to go. 

After a quick trip to the bathroom to wash my hands while perusing the beautifully illustrated dictionary pages papering the wall, I only had to stand for a moment before my carefully crafted concoction was proclaimed ready by a smiling barista. 

After snapping a photo of the beautiful design, I carefully placed a compostable lid and sleeve on the similarly compostable cup and made my way back into the rain with a happily moistened smile.

Although the latte didn't last too long, I look forward to the bag of magic beans I also bought infusing my coming mornings with pour-over goodness.
author: Jessica H.

description: Went in on a chill Monday afternoon and had a cup of extra hot lattee. I personally love how it is decorated in here and the amazing coffee Ritual brew. Lost 1 star due to the horrible music That was playing that day.... Wasn't so sure if it was a radio tech problem or its just.. Bad music. I was so annoyed by the music that I didn't stay as long as I wanted.... Humm
author: Melissa H.

description:
Place inside is sleek with modern chic flare. Lovely street outdoor seating-perfect for people watching (Valencia St. is very colorful) & afternoon sunshine bathing. Service is great-fast & very friendly. 
Coffee is strong & tasty, but pricy and my latter cup size was very small...may be 5 oz or so? :/ 
It was Saturday afternoon & there were not too many "sweet" healthy choices available. 
But overall, good coffee place :)
author: Ellie J.

description: I was really let down on my visit here. I've gone here before and thought their lattes were pretty good, so we decided to stop by for a quick caffeine fix after brunch. I ordered a latte and they really went overboard with the amount of milk they used. My sister ordered a chai latte and was also disappointed with the overpowering taste of milk that diluted her chai. Not sure if anything has changed or if the barista just went a little pour heavy, but I'm not sure if I'd come back.
author: Jay R.

description: Service was friendly and swift. There is usually a line, but it moves quickly. The atmosphere is warm and there is ample seating, although today is a holiday and it's a little crowded. I ordered a cappuccino and it is excellent. Being from Portland, I am a coffee snob and I can taste the difference between a good cap and a not-so-good one. The coffee is bold and temperature was perfect. There are pastries available but the supply was a little low. Mostly a great place to drink coffee or tea and meet up with a friend, group or have some personal time. I live supporting local businesses especially when they are serving excellent coffee!
author: Mary R.

description:
I've been a frequent customer at ritual for 7 years . Today I went in and noticed the nice barista stocking shelves with pounds of coffee priced at a shocking 20$ per pound .. Wow ...I then proceeded to order my usual pour over coffee to-go and was very flabbergasted when the barista informed me that the price has now gone up to 4$ for the least expensive option with the most expensive option set at a whopping 5$ dollars for a cup ...

Really? FIVE DOLLARS? 
You've got to be kidding me .


I mean , I know there's a lot of rich folks now spending a ton of money in there every day 
but shouldn't that mean you can afford to be reasonable ? ??? ?? and show some gratitude to the few middle class locals that still want to grab a cup  of coffee in the neighborhood?

Ritual , I'm sad to say , it's been a great run . So many memories ...

we laughed,  we cried , we shared the sacred chalice of black gold .. But I'm afraid I must take my leave .

Take it easy ... Hold on to yourself 

Sincerely ,

JG
author: James G.

description:
One of my best friends loves the coffee here, so I have a frequent drinking card. 

But like a dog is with their owner, I'm really just tagging along for the friendship, and not the coffee.

I've tried their beans, from sweet to light, etc...but they all taste like I've just licked an ashtray or kissed a smoker. It all tastes bitter and awful.

And that's just there latte I'm talking about. 

Goodness forbid I try their regular coffee, I'd probably knock me over due to it's strength.

But, since they don't kick us out when we're there for over an hour catching up, like cars taking up a parking space, I'm going to give this place 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description:
I love the new layout of Ritual Coffee! It definitely creates a creative space for all individuals. 

I haven't had their drip coffee, which many people have recommended, but I did try their espresso. It was too bitter for my liking but nonetheless I will be back to try other things on their menu.
author: Sarin P.

description: This is a nice coffee shop to meet someone at. They re-did the interior and now it looks like a museum or art gallery. It's a little over-the-top for another coffee shop in SF. They need a more interesting menu with more food.
author: Denise C.

description: Very nice coffee shop with a quiet space and comfortable seating in their adjacent parklet. they have a few types of espresso beans, coffees and cold brews. my GF and I had an espresso and cold brew, both were on suitable quality. their interior is quiet modern. they have a nice selection of GF and vegan pastries although none were tempting enough to try.
author: Mario C.

description: Decaf latte (1%) needed to be hotter else delicious. No wifi. Strange vibe post remodel as though RCR can't decide between new-wave hipster or NYC proto-yuppie.
author: David S.

description:
Came here on a chill Saturday night, came here with my bf, we were going to plan our agenda for our upcoming summer trip. He got a latte, I got the Jasmine Pearl tea. My tea came in a little pouch stuffed with Jasmine, which really enhanced the flavor of the tea. It was so good! After I finished one cup, they gave me more water free of charge.

I asked for their internet password. "Actually, we don't have wifi." I was a bit confused since there were several people inside that were on their laptops. After observing the clientele, my boyfriend and I noticed they were all developers, as in, computer programmers that don't require internet access on a Saturday night. He was disgusted, as this is more evidence that techies have taken over the Mission District.

Anyway, no internet was disappointing. But I guess it was nice to have a regular face-to-face conversation with someone. And tea was great. If I wanted to feel hipster again, I would come here.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
To the point: some of the best coffee you can find in a city known for great coffee.

This place has the most hipster vibe I've ever seen. They even sell mason jars to go. Their coffee really is delicious, though. I've had an iced mocha and a cold brew so far and the cold brew was exceptional.
author: David R.

description:
Coffee, atmosphere: pretty good. 

Service: Not bad.

But why is the pastry case left open? Doing so leaves the content of the case susceptible to flies and other stuff. This is gross and unsanitary. 

And check out the lights overhead: they're covered with webs and dust. Yuck factor: higher than average. The lights are located above the coffee machines. 

If I ever go back, I hope my next Ritual coffee doesn't catch any of the yuck hanging from above.
author: bad b.

description:
My goal of sampling every single coffee place in SF has stagnated.  Why?  After sipping some delicious Ritual Coffee Roasters coffee, I've returned again, and again, and again.  Hipster, spacious, and, most importantly, delicious coffee. 

Tip #1:  There's a decent amount of outdoor and indoor seating, but it's usually pretty crowded--might be hard to get a seat. 

Tip #2: Cold brew coffee on a (rare) SF hot day, hits the spot. 

Overall:  "I need coffee" is slowly transitioning to "I need Ritual Coffee Roasters"
author: Sarah W.

description:
I wanted to like this place so badly that I gave it a second chance. Maybe it's the ex-Seattleite in me. Maybe it was 2 off days weeks apart for them. Who knows? At any rate I tried this place because I had heard great things from the interwebz and friends alike. 

Nope.

I had the cold brew the first time - awful. Maybe the worst cold brew I've had in a long time. It was watered down, almost fruity tasting. But I decided to give it another go a few weeks later. That time I got an iced latte. The taste is fine, but that's it. It's nothing special. Sorry Ritual - the Mission kids love you but I have yet to figure out why.
author: Sonia M.

description:
I know this review isn't going to be too popular with some people, but I've never been one to go along with the masses; besides a good dogfight is good for the soul. 

Ritual Coffee on Valencia was one of my go-to places for coffee and some writing time. The space was warm and inviting, the coffee always perfect, and the staff friendly. It was a community spot for folks to come in out of the chilly San Francisco weather, sit down with friends over a cup of coffee, or with a notebook and pen, or computer. It's what a coffee shop should be.

Fast forward to 2015. Ritual Coffee underwent a massive remodel in 2014. This was my first time back since. Whoever designed the interior space or thought this was a good idea should be taken out and shot.

The new Ritual is cold and sterile. The design makes you feel miniscule and dwarfed immediately making you feel unwelcome. Most of the tables are gone though with the chilly atmosphere, one doesn't want to linger, and my guess is that is exactly what they want. They want their customers to come in grab a cup and go. No more lingering, no more community feel. The customers are no longer welcome to sit and be a part of what made Ritual Coffee great. The redesign is a concept to get the customer in and out as quickly as possible, to serve more is to, afford the increasing rents of the Mission. 

The pastry and baked goods were terrible. Either they were days old or the baker doesn't know what they are doing. The croissant literally crumbled when I touched it. Whatever happened to moist, flaky, pastries? I couldn't even eat it as it just kept crumbling. Oh, and let's talk about the price. Two pastries and two coffees came to twenty-two dollars, yes twenty-two dollars! No thank you, never again.

Simply put the design doesn't fit. It has nothing to do with the neighborhood it once supported. It's as if Ritual Coffee has turned it's back on the community and the people who supported it, all for a quick buck.

I will not return.

My rating...1 Paw

With love from my dog bowl to yours....Happy eating.
Shatasdogbowl.
author: DJ S.

description:
Wasn't working for me---my cup of pour-over Sao Benedito was so weak and held no promise of the notes mentioned in its description. Really let-down, as it was my first time trying.

La Libertad didn't deliver either. How can two cups of pour over be so full of promise, and yet so flavorless? Perhaps the barista undermeasured the amount of beans for the filter? Shockingly bad and after $7 wasted, reluctant to give them another try. 

Sorry guys---can't add you to my methylxanthine list, and I was planning to too!
author: Jana C.

description: okay coffee and okay everything. everything is just okay about this cafe but not great. They also don't have wifi which sucks but not that inusual in this area. what is not fair tthough is that they are pricy as hell but still don't provide wifi.
author: Helia S.

description:
People will always have a difference in opinion when it comes to our tastes. I admit that my opinion of Ritual Coffee has changed since my last review, so an update is in order. 

I met up with friends at Ritual and noticed almost no line for coffee. Nice. I headed over to the barista making drinks and asked for the Sweet Tooth Espresso. He mentioned that it was tiny (showed the little espresso cup) and so I ordered another coffee beverage to balance my coffee fix. 

So I order one Sweet Tooth Espresso made with Altos del Abejonal, Costa Rican beans. I assumed this was *sweet* and drank it right away. It was not sweet, but good and really strong. 

My other beverage, the decaf Cappuchino was up next. Perfectly decorated with a heart, it was adorable. I didn't want to be over caffeinated, so the balance worked perfectly. 

Loved both coffee drinks and the heavy metal music selection. \m/ Yeah!
author: Rebekah T.

description:
5 star cafe! They are not your usually coffee peeps. Low key love ritual. I worked right down the street for a year and that nitro cold brew is like that stuff transporting alcohol to my muscles and brain some days.

Service is friendly enough.
Always Johnny on the spot with the coffee even if your an army of my one in this little coffee hacienda.

I would say tho, this coffee takes getting used to. It seems sour at first but overtime you will say, "Why is my coffee not sour? Is something wrong with it"

/
author: Nathan B.

description: Simply superlative coffee every time I come here! I always get the cappuccino. Wish I lived closer so I could come here more often.
author: Flavia U.

description:
With all the coffee joints in the city, it's often difficult to know where to go. But Ritual is, without a doubt, one of the best of them. For starters, there is a lot of natural light in the place, making it a great place to hang out and read, or work, or talk with friends. The inside is pretty minimalistic and clean, but it's still got a welcoming vibe.

There is also WiFi, which a lot of the places with good coffee tend to not have, since there's a big push to get rid of the anti-social aspect of coffee places. I get that, but sometimes you just need to get out of your house/office and do some work elsewhere. Ritual is one such place.

The drinks themselves are top-notch, and the coffees and tea selections are not only pretty good, but relatively affordable (for San Francisco). Service is a bit slower here, as drinks are brewed individually, but it's completely worth it.
author: Natalye R.

description: Coffee was terrible and the milk was bad! $4.50 for a small cold brew that went into the garbage a block down from their store!!!
author: Joe I.

description:
There was a time when I considered ritual my go to place in the mission for a few things:

1. Coffee - I like it - I like trying various shops and when I find one I usually frequent it regularly
2. A decent chance of a table
3. Plenty of high ceilings to let the creative out
4. WiFi that wasn't God awful like much of SF despite being the high tech capital of the world 
5. Some random people to talk to on occasion

This time has now passed...
1. The coffee is good bean-wise but after going thru the espresso machine - it's a bit more bitter than in the past - implying that it's being steamed maybe a little too hot...
2. No real change in the table status and honestly it's certainly nicer after the renovation
3. The ceilings are still high and the quality of the interior design has improved greatly
4. Not just God awful wifi - no wifi at all - this is a make or break for me at a coffee shop - I have meetings at coffee shop sometimes but 90% of my coffeeshop experiences involve a need to be online
5. Random people - still an option

So if it's not clear from what I wrote - you've removed any possibility of my return - wifi is a must have for me.  I'm not angry about it - it's your business - but the anti wifi move goes against my business needs.

Either before or now - I would suggest dropping the decibels a little - as one yelper said prior to myself - if you intend to focus on people hanging out and talking - make that actually possible.

Congrats on the renovation but I will - somewhat sadly - not be back.  The business no longer meets my needs when I can get ritual coffee elsewhere in a more laptop friendly environment.
author: John-Michael S.

description:
I used to really like this place.  Perhaps I liked their old decor better, before their renovation.  Now it feels like I'm in a tech company's office rather than a coffee shop.  I seem to remember liking their coffee better back then too.  The beans used in their pourovers are roasted on the light side.  This makes for a nice caffeine kick, but it frankly just doesn't taste great to me.  Their lattes are fine, but nothing special.  I prefer the lattes from Blue Bottle and the pourovers from Philz.

Their lemon poppyseed scones are pretty disappointing.  The lemon flavor barely registered on my palate, and the texture was really rather dry, even for a scone.

The cactus garden is cool, but too bad they don't let customers go back there.

I liked the staff too.
author: Lucullus L.

description: A hipster coffee place that is so hipster that it doesn't even have wifi. Nice logo though that seems to be a combination btw turkish flag and sovjet union.
author: Wolfgang G.

description:
Everyone has their opinion about coffee in this city, so I'll keep my brief. 
Great flavor, top baristas, multiple locations, consistent top quality.
author: J S.

description: This is such a lovely and open space to get some great coffee and also work done in! I got a cold brew and my friend got an iced mocha. The mocha was very rich, but also good because the richness did not take away from the coffee. The cold brew was a little bland for me. Light body and a little too acidic for me, but maybe it was just an off day? I've had their teas (mostly chai and some others), and they're also great.
author: Steph V.

description: This is where you drop by for a mighty fine, high-quality cup of coffee. Well done every time, guys.
author: Kalong W.

description: OK,  I'm a big metalhead myself, but I really do NOT want to listen a full album of loud metal music with brutal vocals while sipping my latte.
author: Tina B.

description:
I left San Francisco in 2006 and a short time later, this coffee shop opened up, and a short time after that, Valencia Street became Melrose of San Francisco, but a short time before that, this coffee shop seemed to represent the street before it disappeared. 

There is a saying that the crowd defines the shop, and wholeheartedly I believe everyone escaped Valencia Street to crowd this shop. I like finding my old neighborhood within the crowd here. It's the only remnant of Valencia that hasn't changed. Just seeing one person I have known eight years ago meandering in here made my day in San Francisco complete.

I come in a couple of weeks ago and it's the closest vibe to what I remembered of the neighborhood from the days of yore. It's like everyone escaped the glass walled facade of the horrible high-end retail shops that killed 14th to 22nd streets to duck into the encampment.

Perhaps this is a high-end coffee shop but places like this haven't obliterated the street with glass walls and isolated displays. The shop blended the outside with the inside and became a community gathering.

The coffee is good. The atmosphere is good. The bathrooms are unlocked.
author: Chris G.

description: Great experience and all the baristas really know their coffee. I suggest the latte but there are some amazing pour over coffees.
author: Steve M.

description: Decent amount of seating, no wifi (which I suppose is how the popular places do it), and a good cold brew.
author: Victoria C.

description: Wow.  Totally worth going out of your way for.  I ordered an almond milk macchiato and it was the best, most perfectly balanced cup of coffee I've ever drank.  Love the vibe, love that it's not a synthetic wework, and awesome staff.  5.5 stars
author: Jeff R.

description:
The atmosphere is GREAT to get work done.  I know that it's pretty hipster and whatever, but there are plenty of outlets and places to sit, which is much more than I can say for cafes in North Beach. As much as I love cafes in North Beach, they really do whatever they can to keep from staying there for hours, like closing up all the electrical sockets. At Ritual, this is not a problem at all!

The lattes here are also muy bueno if that's your thing. One of my favourites in the city. Donuts are also really yummy here. I'm pretty sure they're the vegan donuts from Pepples (also sold at Philz and at the Ferry Building) that are heavier than normal donuts and thus,  more filling.

And lastly, it's open relatively late for SF standards! So many cafes in North Beach, SoMa and FiDi close at 6 or 7, but Ritual is open until 9. Yay!
author: Jennifer L.

description: I love their coffee but if there are 2-3 people in line in front of you in the morning you'd better have 15 min to wait or forget about it.
author: Hanna L.

description:
The Mission has some really popular coffee shops that serve as great meeting places and lounge area if you just want to read a book.  Spending the day at a local coworking space, I figured I'd drop into Ritual for a cup of their famous brew before getting started.

I ordered the mocha which was kinda pricey at $3.60 for an 8 ounce cup, at least compared to Starbucks.  However, it was much better quality and the bold flavors weren't overpowered by the chocolate.  The vibe inside is great and it doesn't feel too crowded, making it a perfect place to get some startup work done.

I'm no coffee connoisseur, but Ritual brewed a pretty good mocha.  Service was friendly but I did spend some time in line since there was only one barista working.  This place can get really packed!  Otherwise it's a great way to kick off the day and I'm looking forward to coming back.

Food: 8/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Popped in one day for a latte. Service was meh- guy that was making the coffee could barely crack a smile. 
Ended up a with a lukewarm cup o' joe. 
Meh-
author: Kinjal N.

description: In the past I've enjoyed Ritual Coffee drinks and beans at Oxbow in Napa and independent coffee shops like GGET in LA, and only recently was able to partake in its splendor in one of their namesake shops. This shop is located in the Mission just a stone's throw from various Baking Temples I'm duty bound to visit as well as in the vicinity of cut-throat coffee competition all within a few blocks, and all great in their own way. Choices galore.... but all things considered, if I happened to be riding my bike in the Mission and get clipped or doored by a stoned Californian driver and I'm bleeding out and an ambulance comes to save me, the EMT might as well skip the Type O negative and give me a transfusion of whatever espresso of the day Ritual is serving, b/c there's a high probability that that's what's flowing through my veins anyway. Who needs blood when there's caffeine? not I, but the EMT may recommend taking those life saving espresso drinks to go, b/c there's no wifi.
author: Alma C.

description: The coffee was okay. I believe they had a nitro brewed coffee which was what we ordered. The person who took order was kind enough to let us taste the coffee before putting in our order. The nitro coffee did take some time to adjust to the taste but not my cup of 'coffee'. Nice spot to chill/study though.
author: Lily M.

description:
Free 2 hour street parking is pretty easy around here. 

It's very spacious and has lots of natural lighting, and they have lots of tables, but it gets pretty packed in here.  There's also a nice (but small) outdoor space in front.

Beans are always roasted fresh. Usually they have the ones roasted from the day before available by the afternoon. The staff is super helpful and friendly. 

My only complaint: like most of the 3rd wave coffee places in SF, no wifi. Also, the beans are fresher but are more expensive than at some grocery stores that carry Ritual.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Hipster-y vibe without the space constraints one would expect from a hipster-y coffee joint.  Really nice decor.

I got the One & One -- one shot of espresso and a single shot macchiato to taste.  The espresso is a little sweeter than I'm used to, and a little more citrusy.  Definitely pretty tasty though.  

As for cups of coffee, they do a really good job describing the tastes.  I forget what my friend got, but it was described as "Meyer Lemon, graham cracker, and vanilla" ... AND IT TOTALLY WAS.  Admittedly, I don't know the difference between normal lemon and Meyer Lemon, but it was very tasty nonetheless.  

I would normally give them 4 stars because their coffee is pretty pricey ($3 - $3.75), but their merch is sooooooo sexy that I can't help but bump them the extra star.  But seriously, they could use a frequent member program or something so I don't feel so guilty dropping so much cash on coffee.
author: Mike P.

description: I love the coffee, staff and atmosphere. I've been coming here for 2 whole weeks and every time is a great experience. I don't get any of the hipster attitude ppl say...everyone is super cool and chill and super attentive. 5 stars it more!
author: Patricia H.

description: After its awesome interior update Ritual Coffee Roaster is an even more beautiful place to enjoy a drink, read a book at, meet up with a friend. I really appreciate the garden in the back and the general open space feeling. Only thing is tea is too small a pot and no free wifi, though if you're an xinfinity customer then you can reach the wifi hotspot from here.
author: Christina H.

description:
I was with a friend (who lives in SF) and we were walking around on Valencia because I hadn't explored this part of the city yet. I was complaining about a headache since I'd only just gotten off a plane about an hour before. 

He suggested Ritual and said perhaps I needed caffeine since I'd been up since 3am (CST). 

He ordered expresso and I ordered a mocha. I like when I don't have to add anything to my coffee, but that it's perfectly sweet and creamy. The mocha was lovely. Not too sweet and not too bitter. The foam on the top was nice and it has been one of the better cups of coffee I've had.
author: Melissa A.

description: I know I'm going to disappoint people here with this low review. Ritual used to be cozy, a place you could work with others and drink expensive coffee. Now after remodel there is no wifi, ONE outlet for the whole place, indirect lighting and bad pastries. It feels more like McDonalds - get people in-n-out. The two stars are for the "normal" coffee you can get now...instead of the Russian roulette question "what brew do you want to try?"
author: Cate R.

description:
I will go completely out of my way for a great cup of coffee. After hearing so much positive things about this place, I decided that a BART-scursion with necessary.

The croissant was buttery, flaky, and the best I've ever had. I normally just go for a simple cup of joe. Usually a drip or a few shots of espresso but not today. I wanted coffee art so I went with a cappuccino. I made a great choice, not only did it look great, it tasted great too.

I loved relaxing on a couch sipping on a delectable cappuccino.
author: Justin C.

description:
Love Love Love this place. Every time i am in San Francisco and i find myself in the Mission District, Ritual Coffee Roasters is a must stop along my day's journey. They even make delicious vegan Mochas and Hot Chocolate. Hmmmmm!

Their coffee is rich and flavorful. Their lattes are thick like warm coffee milkshakes. I usually order the soy Latte  or cappuccino and they are consistently smooth and comforting to drink.

The staff is very knowledgeable and excited to describe their different coffees to you. Given the traffic of patrons, the Baristas concoct your drinks fast without compromising on quality. 

Oftentimes it is hard to find a place to sit down and enjoy your drink, though other customers are friendly (it is San Francisco!) and when tables are full i have had no problem sharing a table with a handsome stranger.
author: Gabriela G.

description:
Ritual Coffee has a nice, roomy, wi-fi friendly environment here. lots of space, tables, art pics on the walls. rock music..

pour: drip pour over coffee(3)
-above average smooth coffee, 
-coffee pales compared with blue bottle, sightglass, la paz et al.
-3 stars at best.

drips:
-5 minutes to drip, short line.
-3 stars for the coffee, 4 stars for the wi-fi/ambience
author: Victor G.

description: If you don't come here for the coffee which is delightful you should definitely come here for the beautiful big windows, cactus garden, modern furnishings or incomparable hipster people watching! The Baristas know their stuff and do great Cuppings( tastings) to help you better understand coffee so be sure to check that out.
author: Sandeep C.

description:
Oh yay! I'm a fan.
Thanks for organizing daily demonstration on knowledge of coffee!
I attended one of the cupping demonstration and had fun learning with others.
I wish I live closer and can attend often with a group of coffee enthusiastic community!
author: Pokemon P.

description:
This place is absolutely so good. I had at least an hour wait for an appointment and was kind of still sleepy from the night before. I had heard of this place an had to try it out.

It's so good. There seems to always be a line, but it moves quickly. I cannot decide if I like this place better or Four Barrel. Both are pretty up there for me.
