They have a pretty big place and it looks like there is quite a bit of seating. I didn't grab a seat myself, but it didn't look too hard to find a seat. I could see how it could be difficult though. The espresso taste in my drink was so good. It was very potent, which is something you do not get at a Starbucks. Highly recommend this place if you're in the area. Way too good.
author: Julie L.

description: I was getting tired and needed a good pick me up, and after a fellow friend told me about Ritual I migrated to the place and boy I wasn't disappointed! I had such a great cup of coffee and it kept me up for hours. I haven't had such good coffee in a while. It was funny sitting there in a wave of MacBook Pros and Airs...
author: Vanessa S.

description: Disclaimer- I am not a coffee lover. I am a tea lover. Went in hoping to get a chai latte. Asked the woman at the counter if their chai was spicy, she said 'oh yes, quite spicy'.  That's what I prefer, so I ordered it. Sadly their chai is not spicy. Not even close. In fact you barely taste the chai at all. It was basically slightly flavored steamed milk.  Not even worth drinking.  Just figured it was worth a review for other chai lovers.
author: joshua h.

description: its a very cute place. great for studying since you are in the middle of a big garden surrounded by succulents everywhere.
author: Anuran C.

description:
I literally have dreams about this place.

Last night I was on the line for a drip and was whisked back into the machine room-like roasting area to inhale the dreamy coffee blends. I opened all my jacket pockets and filled them with warm toasty beans. I awoke in a warm, caffeinated sweat.

One of the many boutique coffees I have sampled on my stays in this fair (hrm, foggy) city, I have to rate this comrade of mine up in the leagues of BB and 4Barrel, for sure. If this ritual is part of the coffee uprising, I say: vive la revolution !
author: Claire F.

description:
1. Ordered an espresso ristretto: so acidic, it was undrinkable. 
2. Ambiance: the lighting makes you feel like you are in an animal dissection lab, how the lighting is. Corpse complexion, anyone? Also the deco is cold and uninviting.
3. Playing music so loud you can't talk to the person you are with.

Overrated hype, disgusting coffee.
author: Jackie P.

description: The inside is nice, large and confortable. The espresso was alright, but when you give me a cappuccino looking like this and have the impertinence of not providing a wifi connection, at least 2 stars should drop...
author: Andrei M.

description:
I stopped by after going to the SF Street Food Fest. The place is spacious and everyone and their mama had a Macbook Pro. Then some guy busted out his Dell. I guess he didn't get the memo.

At times, the line can be out the door. But when I got there, I barely had to wait. I ordered a latte and at $4, it was on the expensive side. The lattes are good but not as bold as I would like. The design on top actually looked like a heart but finished off with their symbol. I thought that was pretty creative. 

I also order some grounds to take home. The barista recommended the Monte Copey. I am currently sipping it while writing this review. It does pack a bunch of fruit notes which I am not use to. Maybe after a few more cups, I can appreciate Ritual Coffee more.
author: Kien M.

description: It was not the very best I ever had but I would go again. I am impressed by their marketing. Great packaging too.
author: may a.

description:
Absolutely excellent coffee. Cold brew, pour over, and the standards.  I'm particularly picky about mochas - they're usually too sweet, cheap chocolate or not well blended.  This is top 5 in the city, easily.
Small selection of artisan baked goods (more than one bakery represented, which, for some reason, I think is cool).
Only thing is that it borders on pretentious (or maybe just not my personal aesthetic).
Also, $5 for a mocha - unfortunately getting to be normal price.
author: Rachel M.

description: One of my favorite SF roasters. The coffee is consistently good. I love stopping by whenever I'm in the Mission. Good amount of seating. They have some nice merch on sale too.
author: Shu J.

description:
Cool cafe with a good vibe and great coffee. Service is quick and friendly (if you happen to come when there's no line). One thing that stood out to me was I completely forgot to order my drink with soy milk and rushed to tell the barista. Luckily he hadn't started on my drink and changed it no problem. No additude, nothing. And as a barista I know how hard that can be. I guess it's the little things?

Only reason for four stars is that they don't have WiFi and the cafe can get a bit toasty to the point where it's a little uncomfortable.
author: Trevor C.

description: Delicious coffee, place is enormous and modern. I should've asked them to make my mocha extra hot because they made it warm. I like mine piping hot. Overall, flavor is delicious.
author: Denise A.

description:
I'll probably edit this review after I go here a few more times. My first impression of the shop is that it's clean, spacious and a cool place to hang out and spend some time.  Other than the decor, the v60 that I got was prepared unskillfully. The cup was sour and gamey.

Update: Went a couple more time's and the brew was better, I'd come here as a solid spot off the reputation of Ritual and their roasting, my first experience could have been an extreme side of the spectrum, but I think that they should train their new hires more to live to the expectation of Rituals brand. I'm in no way qualified to criticize them though and they'll always have a solid reputation. Moved to 3 stars. Decor is also really nice since the reconstruction, I'd tap that white paint job and pourover counter.
author: Nick F.

description:
First reaction: Hipster central..haha.

This review is based on the drink my friend ordered for me. Got a soy latte and didn't think that it was anything out of the ordinary. The actual soy overpowered the taste of the coffee. So I really didn't get to experience any of the flavors people spoke highly of from this place. Willing to try it again, but will probably go for a straight up black coffee, my usual item of choice.
author: Vincent L.

description: Tis OK I suppose. Preferred the previous (warmer decor); kind of sterile white-cafe style. Pastries are so-so; would add a star if they offered Neighbor Bakehouse goodies, like Sightglass or FourBarrel. Espresso is .25 more than FourBarrel. Like the early hours.
author: iko o.

description: Conveniently ended up at the Sunday Streets on Valencia event today after having brunch at Tartine.  The sun was shining, there were a ton of people of walking around, and the only thing missing was a nice iced coffee to go along with the walk.  We saw a number of people lining up at the Ritual Coffee Roasters stop, and saw a nice lady selling iced coffee outside the shop.  Greg and I both had a nice cold coffee for our walk and loved the chocolately/citrusy (like those adjectives?!) coffee from Ritual Coffee Roasters.  So delicious! I would definitely like to come back here for a hot cuppa coffee :)
author: Lisa I.

description:
Oh man. Today was my first time at Ritual since the remodel. I hate it. Call me old-fashioned or just old. Or maybe I'm out of touch with what others find to be a pleasant experience. But I don't like the new decor and atmosphere. Before it had character, vibe and a sense of uniqueness and belonging. Now it is cold and sterile. Rather than feeling like a Mission institution that was here before the neighborhood was ritzy, it now feels like a nouveau riche new kid that's trying too hard to be trendy and make a splash. 

The coffee is still good. And there's a nice cactus garden out the back window. 

Sigh. I miss you, Ritual. R.I.P.
author: Matt E.

description:
Very lovely architecture.  The coffee is in my opinion better than Blue Bottle but not as good as Four Barrel and I confess, after years of fancy hipster coffee drinking, my new favorite is good old Mr Espresso from Oakland. 

No wifi.  Really, I am not joking, they don't have wifi.
author: aynne v.

description:
Such a cool unassuming gem in this part of the neighborhood!  I walked into a awesomely cool establishment to get tea on New Years Day. There was not much of a queue when I walked in but it seemed very busy with plenty of people sitting in the back and front.  They also have a standing wall shelf where you can enjoy your drink or wait for them.  The interior is modernized but not as impressive as Four Barrel in the Mission or Sightglass in SOMA.  

The cashier was very nice when helping me choose which tea to order of the six they had to offer.  The teas are all signature flavors you won't find easily anywhere else.  I decided on the Peach something or rather.... it had a super long name I can't remember LOL.  There are some Baristas here that are seriously attractive.  Not to mention the patrons who were here the time I came in were mighty fine as well.  Most everyone else complete in their Mission hipster clothing as well.  

Overall the tea around lunchtime helped wake me up and stave off lunch for a while longer.  I love visiting these boutique artisan coffee houses; I really think they are a wave of the future.  I despise the commonality of Starbucks, if you ever see me check-in there I am probably not ordering a drink.  Although I am guilty of doing that every once in a while.  We need a Four Barrel, Sightglass, or place like this somewhere in the South Bay!  Although we probably won't be able to match the hipster following they have up here.  If I ever came here early enough I would give the coffee a try, it looks delicious as well.  When in the Mission do as the locals do; Ritual Coffee Roast ya'll!
author: Kenny P.

description: Definitely different than your typical coffee experience. This coffee experience felt like a red wine tasting. Different options had taste descriptions and each one was to a tee! Full bodied coffee with obvious hints and flavors.   Not an everyday place but a good one to stop into
author: Sarah G.

description:
Came here last week on my trip to San Francisco! Really cool and hip atmosphere - can totally see myself doing work here. They are trying a new no-WiFi thing, so don't go if you need internet. They have a beautiful greenhouse in the back which gives the place a unique and refreshing atmosphere. 

I got their latte, which was creamy heaven and I love creamy lattes. The only thing is that it got cold pretty quickly since it wasn't that hot when it came out. So drink fast.
author: Sally A.

description:
The renovated space is a masterpiece of douchery, and the baristas need to get over themselves. There's always been something off about Ritual, and this makeover seals the deal. On the plus side, the architect and interior decorator will have nice portfolio pieces showing them to be right on trend. 

"Well, show me the way 
To the next [coffee] bar"
author: Jay B.

description:
Too hipster for me, but cool spot
usually too crowded 
but that's life

cool hood
author: Alanna F.

description: I'm big on caffeine and a fan of ritual -my favorite out of the third wave coffee roasters in the bay. They offer solid, high quality hand dripped coffee. LOVE their lattes and cappuccinos, it's definitely quite strong but delicious and aromatic.
author: Jasmin H.

description: My wife and I are visiting SF. Our city has some great shops and a love for coffee. We had friends who gave us suggestions for some shops to check out. Ritual was fantastic. Great coffee and great environment. It isn't a work spot but more of a share life with other spot. If you are looking to hangout with friends & family this is a great place for you.
author: Bernard E.

description:
I've been dreaming of a place like Ritual since I moved to the mission. Hi, I'm Mandy and I'm a coffee-aholic. I'm sure many of you can relate. We all have our desperate moments, but I am a little stingy about my coffee shops. I've been trying out places throughout the Mission and so far nothing has really impressed me until I came here. 

Right off the bat it's adorable and modern. The first time I came here was actually for a date on a Saturday afternoon and I felt the environment and overall vibes were perfect for that setting. Not to mention the adorable little cactus garden out back, how cool! Secondly, the coffee is great. If you are just ordering regular black coffee they make it fresh to order by pour over - YUM! I've been back many times since and have loved all the coffee I've ordered. 

The only reason it gets four stars and not five is no wi-fi. They got rid of wi-fi temporarily during a renovation and so many people loved it they decided to not to get it back. I think it is very cool in a way - but I also would really love to hangout there and do some work that just isn't possible without internet!
author: Mandy A.

description:
Hello, Ritual. At last, we meet!

The interior is really aesthetically pleasing: red walls, lots of wooden tables, soft lighting. For a Thursday night, it was packed. Lots of IT nerds and hipster eye candy. 

I ordered a soy latte ($4.50) and later, a soy mocha ($4.89, I think). The prices are a little steep, but the staff is friendly and they have several plugs to charge your various electronic devices. 

My battery was completely dead before I could get a photo of the latte, but the mocha had beautiful art on top. Too bad it wasn't hot enough. 

Despite these little nit-picky details, I would come back... it was nearly perfect, but still not the blissful coffee experience that I'm so desperately on the lookout for.

P.S. Tip your barista! Their tip jar was looking very sad when I went in.
author: Brandi W.

description:
Very good coffee but would say is slightly over rated
Single origin beans, nice staff, nice vibe...
Recommended overall
author: Nadim T.

description:
Oh so sad.  This review is for the newly remodeled Valencia St location. Another nail in the coffin.

I've frequented Ritual off and on since they first opened. The coffee has always been of above average and often great quality. The cafe space itself was always somewhere I could go, find a seat and either talk with friends, study (back when I was in school) or read a book.  They had chairs, bar seating, love-seats and couches. I could sit for a few minutes or for hours and see the diverse folks of the Mission roll in and out. There were hipsters, tweakers, young preppy kids, older activists and artists, family folks with kids in strollers, students, and of course tech people. 

Today I walked in and...wow. Whiteness and tech everywhere.  The decor fits this description, but the clientele even more so. Young white people with laptops and expensive clothes and haircuts.  That was it. Oh sure, there was some diversity -- there was both young white dudes with blazers and also some young white dudes with plaid shirts (oh so carefully unbuttoned at the top to show that they've been spending time at the gym). 

Less seating; much less seating. No couches or love-seats. Just stark white tables and stark white people.

Dear owners of Ritual, I hope you are reveling in butt-loads of investor cash and cocaine right now, because you've really gutted a place that used to reflect a diverse neighborhood. Yuck.
author: David L.

description:
Loved it.
Best cappucino ever !!! Cappucino at many coffee shop tend to be bland and taste burnt but Ritual's cappucino tasted just fabulous with the right amount of foam.
author: Alan T.

description: I had a soy ole and the coffee was excellent.  I had a large and the cup I received would be a small in almost every other coffee shop.  A bit too hip and cold to have good coffee shop ambiance.
author: Trey C.

description:
1321 reviews! ooohh la la let's make 1322. I thought I had died and gone to heaven whilst partaking of my decaf mocha at Ritual the other night. 

The staff was sweet and welcoming to a one, and my coffee had a purty picture drawn on it and it was AWESOME.

Also the establishment was super nice and clean. I don't know how they keep it so spiffy as it was packed on a Monday night at around 8pm, but it was much appreciated as we are over the grunge atmo of many coffee emporiums.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Exceptionally good coffee. Creamy and awesome. Worth every penny of it. 

The premises are as cool as it gets. Worth a visit. Even their logo is phenomenal!!

But, but, but... As good as it was, it did not beat Storyville's coffee in Seattle.
author: R P.

description: Yes! Staff is always rocking sick band tees. Coffee is always constant, ambience... rather avoid- techies have moved in to stay
author: Jane D.

description:
Sorry, Ritual. I used to love you, but no more.

Apparently San Francisco couldn't wait for the new MOMA to open their coffee shop (which will probably have Blue Bottle), so Ritual went ahead and did it for them. It's like walking into a high-end gallery in Lower Manhattan or something.

Walked in apparently just after closing, which we were brusquely informed of by the barista (the door was wide open, and people were there), so perhaps I can charitably assume that they jacked the lights up to 200% of their normal brightness to drive people away - because dang! It was blindingly bright in there! That alone was enough to wake a person up, no coffee required.

Seriously, it seems like they wanted to make it as uninviting as possible - between the white cube aesthetic and the elimination of wifi & electrical outlets, they've probably solved the problem of people 'hogging the tables' that another reviewer claimed Ritual used to have. I never really had trouble getting a table there before, and I probably won't be trying to anymore. 

I like GOING TO New York. I don't want it to come to me.
author: Steven B.

description: A better cup of tea than the usual SF cafe.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Remodel just finished ... So I've been looking forward to going back since it was my favourite work spot. Now, not only do they no longer have plugs but they also don't have wifi. Not only do they not have wifi but they have a sign saying they won't add wifi because they had such good feedback from customers from their wifi being gone during the remodel.

When I tried to give them feedback that I wanted wifi they gave me a hipster scoff. Liked it better before.
author: Paul H.

description:
Well crafted coffee drinks.  Staff is friendly and the lofted ceilings give a great open feel.  

Why no WI-FI?   There are still lots of guests on laptops using hotspot other forms of internet connections.  If the lack of WI-FI was intended to design a "distraction free" zone, then it has been unsuccessful in changing normal human behavior.  Please bring in accessibility to the Internet to make Ritual a better experience.
author: Justin H.

description:
Yummmm, ordered the soy macchiato! Delicious, but Sightglass still has my heart and soul. Ritual and Tartine make an excellent pair :)

I came on a late Saturday morning, so tables were a bit competitive.
author: Caroline W.

description: Mocha was good and strong.  I wanted to find a cozy spot to sit at and enjoy my cup of coffee and catch up with a friend, unfortunately, it didn't seem too comfy and cozy, it was chic and not inviting.
author: Veronica A.

description: I would say this is one of my favorite coffee shops in the US. They're one of the few coffee shops that make a fantastic Nitro Cold Brew coffee. Every time I go, I get an amazing cup every time. They're super consistent. Not just with their nitro brew but also with their other drinks. If you're a fan of the cappuccino, they know what they're doing here. Milk texture is always perfect and is done just right. I can't recommend them enough. Do yourself a favor and come give it a visit.
author: J P.

description: $3 for an unspecial cup of skunky  coffee. Save your money and move on. Unfortunately Starbucks and McDonald's are better
author: Stan S.

description:
This review is specific for the nitro cold brew coffee.

The first time I had nitro cold brew and regular cold brew was at Stumptown Coffee in Portland, OR in 2015.  Ever since I tried it the first time, I fell in love with it.  Since then, I haven't found a place that even carries such item or if they do, it is not comparable.   Reccently, cold brew has been popularized in SF Bay Area,  I am so excited to try every possible one out there.  

Two weeks ago, I was so excited to see nitro cold brew on Ritual's menu.  Knowing it would cost me $5 for it, I didn't hesitate to order because I knew Ritual would not disappoint me.  When it came out, my bf and I were shocked on the size of it.  It was served in a plastic beer sample looking cup and there was probably only 6oz of coffee in it.  WTH!  It was almost like liquid gold price!   As I recalled at Stumptown Coffee, it was less than 5 bucks for 12 oz of nitro.
I'm sorry to say that I will not buy this item again due to its ridiculous price.

Despite this "liquid gold" pricing of nitro cold brew, we were very happy with the other items we ordered.  We will definitely come back to Ritual for other items but Nitro Cold Brew
author: Avril C.

description:
One of the most famous coffee brands in SF, Ritual Coffee Roasters, I was brought there by my local friend after Four Barrel Coffee(she supposes to be another coffee junkie...). Before Ritual Coffee, we still stopped by Tartine Bakery & Cafe for making it as a connection, though Tartine unthinkably has over 4,000 reviews. 
High ceiling, spacious room, lots drinkers but not feeling crowded at all, that's how I feel about Ritual Coffee in Guerrero St. No matter which, Four Barrel, Ritual or Sightglass, they all come as factories with wide space to tuck in roasters, baristas and drinkers(and bikes for Sightglass...). How about the tastes? A big question, my preference would be Four Barrel though this post is talking about Ritual. It's a great shop and supports some coffee bars in NY as roasters. I'm just giving my personal choice within these 3.
author: Wei-Hsiang H.

description: Excellent service, even better coffee. Had the La Folie: Caturra and the citrus jumped out of the cup, and left a delightful aftertaste. Highly recommend.
author: Brett B.

description:
I visited the new Ritual for the first time the other day. Sure it's pretty, but it definitely lost a lot of the charm it used to have. I found myself wanting to like it, but on the other hand, it just didn't feel very homey.

It's kind of emblematic of the New Mission - the one dominated by "hipster" tech employees rather than crackheads. A lot cleaner and more sterile, but something was lost in translation. The Mission was supposed to feel a bit well-worn and kind of used up. I guess that times really are changing...
author: Dana L.

description:
Drinking coffee at ritual is like driving a Ferrari.  It goes fast and you'll probably crap your pants by the end of it.

Seriously though, I love ritual.  I drink the espresso every day of my life.  They have a much better espresso than Blue Bottle, no one is even arguing about that.  GO HERE EVERY DAY.  You must.
author: Alex H.

description:
As first timers here, the barista took the time to explain their different espressos and we both decided to go with the house mocha and latte. They were both delicious, rich, satisfying drinks and were a perfect pick me up in the early evening after work. 

The cafe is spacious, bright, and perfect for studying. Interior design is minimalistic and simple and I'll definitely be coming back in the near future.
author: Shirley N.

description: Super hip, large space. Was my first time at Ritual. The barista informed me they don't offer any dark roast coffees which automatically loses a star. I'm a huge dark roast, black, strong coffee fan. I ordered a light roast coffee $5 for pour over. It was tasty. Not the best ever, but not the worst. Also ordered a cheddar scone which was dry and crumbling. If you bring your own jar you get a discount on your order. Personally feel it's overpriced for what you get.
author: Tallestbird R.

description: Stumbled upon Ritual Coffee in the Mission while taking a stroll and decided to give it a try.  Pretty trendy/modern spot.  The line was surprisingly not that long.  I've heard from a friend it can be pretty lengthy so I guess I was lucky that day.  I ordered a mocha and since it's drip coffee (drip = made with love) it took a little awhile until it was ready.  Pretty good....I'd probably return if in the area.
author: Christine D.

description:
Nice ambiance with tables good for reading and studying.  People were nice.
Pastries come from a variety of vendors and looked rustic and delicious.  
Hand crafted coffee same as blue bottle, sightglass, and other hip and popular coffee places in sf.  I would have to say, for myself, that blue bottle wins; but ritual coffee roasters still makes a good cup of coffee!
author: Linda T.

description: Coffee is good, not great. Prices are through the roof. Harsh white interior.  And... NO WIFI!  At these prices? And NO sign saying so either.
author: Jeff L.

description: Best coffee in the city. They've managed to instill a depth of flavor I have never encountered elsewhere. Just the smell of the beans is incredible. Darkhorse- espresso roast is my favorite. The beans are smaller and lighter than the store bought variety, but they have twice the intensity. The baristas are always friendly and they make a mean cappuccino. The vibe is cool. I'm natively from Portland, and I feel perfectly at home here. Powell's might even benefit from a Ritual coffeehouse next door.
author: Megan M.

description: Wanted to enjoy the taste so went with black coffee. I felt the coffee tasted a little sour toward the end of it, but it was still a great cup. I also enjoyed the ambiance of the place which makes for a hangout place in the morning or afternoon.
author: Aaron C.

description:
A Sunday morning stroll in the area and a recommendation from one of the people working at a local bicycle shop lead us here for espresso to enjoy with our home-baked goods while we waited for another shop in the area to open.

It was busy, alright, with a line of people waiting to order.  
Like so many places, they do not practice the art of serving "hot" espresso.  They may have shot a quick burst of steam to semi-heat the cup, but not enough to keep the coffee hot for several minutes to enable one to find a table and get situated.
The coffee was rich, sharp, and chocolatey-tasting.  It went well with our Brasilian baked goods.
Interesting music played and people ambled around for tables and the bathroom, of which there is only one - unisex.  I had to wait in line at length to use it.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Walking down Valencia on a Sunday when the street is closed, we chance upon the line outside. Got to be good right? Friend walking with us also recommends it. Of course, I had to try it. 

You wait in line that leads to the barista who takes your order and then you pay after. Wait a few more minutes to get your coffee. 

I get the single origin Sweet Tooth (forget where it came from). They take a while to pull the shot. A good sign since single origin coffee takes some effort to pull correctly for a good cup. 

True enough, this is good stuff. On par with Blue Bottle's single origin. Flavor is a bit different as it's milder, sweeter initial notes, acidic in the middle and clean finish. Beautiful stuff.

Now I know where to find fantastic coffee in the Mission.
author: Norman S.

description: The coffee didn't live up to the hype. The space inside is roomy as some reviewers have noted but there's something about the acoustics here that seems to make seemingly quiet conversations all add up to a lot of noise. Not the place for a quiet chat or for reading a book.
author: S G.

description:
Not my cup of tea. (lol)

Id like to think i am very open minded when it comes 
to coffee and have tried tons of different ones.. trust me.

It was my first time here. . the place is modern 
looks like a good place to sit down and chat with a friend
or just read a book.. (if you find a seat )

the coffee. bleh"  not what i expected..
author: T. C.

description: too expensive. the counter was rude. does not smile. the place was ok. outside of store has a lot of rubbish. not a good place to chill.
author: Karlo G.

description:
It's hard for me to give a coffee spot in the US 5 stars as I can't help but compare it to the cafes at home in Melbourne, where not only do we get fabulous coffee but table service and an environment conducive to catching up with friends. I still can't get over the whole lining up to order and then milling around waiting for your coffee to be made thing... 

BUT seeing as this is "just the way it is" in the US I'll readjust my scoring system and say that Ritual deserves the highest praise. The coffee is excellent - from the pour overs to the espresso, everything is made carefully and with beautifully roasted beans.

If you want to sit around for hours on our laptop then this looks to be the place to do it. The place is seriously packed with people nicking the wifi.
author: Tresna L.

description: Really friendly staff, lots of great coffee options, and nice vibe. I got one of the daily selections on the V60 and it wasn't my favorite coffee ever, but it was damn good. Would definitely recommend this spot for anyone who's into coffee
author: Anand S.

description: It's like if Apple opened a coffee shop, but without the Genius Bar where you can reserve a spot online so it's always packed and has a long line.
author: Isaac R.

description:
Came here pretty late at night for a post dinner coffee before hitting the bars in the mission. I'm a big fan of some of the other coffee shops which are popular in San Francisco. Many of my friends love Ritual, and hence I figured I should try it. I thought the staff was fast and friendly. 

The quality of the coffee and the drink were decent, but I like other places in SF better. If this shop was in almost any other city it would be a 4 or 5 star, but SF is very competitive and the bar is high!
author: Jonah K.

description:
Definitely the hipster coffee spot in the mission. Awesome coffee, more awesome tea.  Vibe is very cool and staff is really great.  Really is a must go to if you're in the Mission - maybe even in SF. 

Any business meeting or anytime someone wants to get together this is always my go to spot.  Oh and pastries are just as awesome as everything else.  Love it.
author: Josh V.

description:
I have a massive backlog of places I still need to review, probably dating back about four months. Yet I just had to write a quickie on Ritual Coffee Roasters.

I'll start off by saying that the double 8 oz latte I had was delicious. Ritual's espresso has a really distinctive, overtly nutty quality to it that I really enjoy. Almost like unsalted almonds. The latte was creamy and perfectly proportioned.

But dear god, the obnoxious EDM music they were blaring in this cavernous cafe was such an assault on my ears that it drove me out the doors as soon as I finished my drink. It's bad enough that the interior of this cafe is soul-suckingly spartan and cold, but the awful sound of Transformers fucking just put it over the top. No, not every cafe has to do the Bohemian thing, with comfy couches and warm tones of brown and turquoise. Other reviewers have mentioned that this is a good place to study due to the large amount of seats and outlets. I suppose if you crammed earphones in and blasted your own music to drown out the cacophonous dretch coming from the speakers, then you could get some decent studying done.

For a passerby like me, who simply wanted a brief respite from a day of hauling it around town, I was pretty bummed out. I definitely will be back to give this place the benefit of a doubt, but a part of me also just wants to stick to the sweet coziness of Philz.
author: Eric F.

description:
Gave Ritual another shot of steering clear of their burnt tasting coffee and burning man art for a few years. Coffee still tastes burnt and now there's a tiny cursive handwritten sign conveniently placed after you pay saying that there is no longer wifi. 

Suggestion: place a visible sign on the counter so customers can make the decision before they buy stuff. If you need help, visit Borderlands. They are quite good at communicating this part of their "experience."

Ritual so wants to be like Four Barrel/Blue Bottle but they never, ever will.
author: Kate R.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters in the mission is where all the hipsters are! i admit to having some hipster tendencies but walking into this large coffee shop i noticed this line (out the door btw) and the baristas were so very SF. Hilarious! Plenty of tables but i still had to stalk a couple of people leaving to snag one.

A cappuccino and a soy latte put me at almost $8 for coffee. I didn't expect anything less. I splurge at Coffee Bar and Blue Bottle. Ritual is no different! My latte was buttery and so smooth. I could sit in here all day..
author: Samantha L.

description: I swing by this place this afternoon. Easy parking if you can find a spot. Maybe it's hard to find the spot in the weekend. I got a latte here and satisfied with my drink. Nice art. I tasted some baked sweet potatoes, sweet &burnt flavor...lol It's probably because I'm used to the dark espresso? I will hit this place again if I was near by.
author: Nora J.

description:
I love the new remodel. Ritual looks sleek and chic now. I am SO OVER reclaimed wood, Edison bulbs and gray paint! Give me fresh and clean and interesting. The greenery in the back is stunning.

The person who claimed that removing wifi causes more techie programmers to frequent the place sounds misguided to me. When I go in now, I notice more people talking face-to-face and fewer eyes glazing over in front of glowing screens. 

Oh, and their lattes are fantastic and beautiful, as always!
author: Carla C.

description:
Going to Ritual Coffee Roasters for a cup of their Sweet Tooth Mocha may now become a SF ritual of mine.

My wife and I had been walking around the Mission on a cold, drizzling SF night when we decided we needed something to warm us up.
Ritual was the perfect place. It's big, cozy, and they had lots of available seating even though the place was pretty busy. They also were playing some relaxing music throughout the big dining room. 
 
Their menu is fairly small but one item caught both our eyes right away and that was their Sweet Tooth Mocha. At almost $5 bucks for a large I was hesitant to purchase this drink but since I saw Ritual has over 1200 reviews on Yelp with an overall 4 star rating, I knew it would be good. 

And it was. It was not too sweet and not too strong. It was actually perfect. I loved the chocolaty aftertaste I got in my mouth after ever sip. If I lived in SF I may not go here daily because of the high prices but I would definitely come often.

Check this place out if you're in the area. It's really worth a try if you're into gourmet coffee.
author: Craig R.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters definitely takes coffee seriously. Not only do they have multiple flavors of drip on tap, they also cost more than the flavored drinks! I never thought I'd be charged $5 for a cup of plain ol' joe.

Well, I take that back - each of these blends packs a lot of subtle flavors. Their method of preparation allows for a smooth brew, and most of their blends (La Folie in particular) have a more fruity taste to them. It's definitely one of the better cups I've had, but darker roasts are still my favorite way of waking up.
author: Casey S.

description:
Ritual. Need i say more.
Really love their coffee, service and the interior space. Great place to drink your coffee!
author: C A.

description:
I really wanted to like this place seeing as how my LBS was down the street but the EDM blaring in the background and crappy service just wasn't for me. As a first timer, I asked where their lids, sugar, etc. was located... I was given the death stare and a pointed finger in the right direction (sheesh, sorry for asking....) 
Their house coffee & lychee iced tea was great and their open, airy space was too... lots of tables and chairs for customers.
author: Catalina F.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters has some of the best sound systems I have ever heard inside a cafe. The speakers are really amazing and I enjoyed the nostalgic Biggie Smalls and Tupac they were playing. The Cappuccino I ordered was really good. I liked watching the cashier pour a leaf design of foam milk on top of the espresso before handing it over to me. 

As a whole, I liked hanging out here for an hour and a half reading a book and getting my day started. The clientele are in the 20's and 20's so their's a good level of energy there. I recommend Ritual Coffee for anyone who wants to kick back and relax over some caffeine.
author: Maximilian R.

description:
i went to many shops in the bay and ritual was my fave! this location is open, bright and comfortable. the baristas were nice and were willing/able to chat about the coffee they were serving. 

i started with a shot of espresso - the presentation was beautiful, the shot was even better! lots of florals and fruits, they definitely know what they're doing. my girlfriend, not a caffeine drinker, ordered a hot chocolate with almond milk. she said it was the best she's ever had and i agreed. while we were enjoying our drinks we recognized photos above us taken by vivian fu, a sf local woman of color. we were happy to see her work displayed here! 

on my way out, i ordered a pour over to go. it had to have been the cleanest cup of ethiopian coffee i've ever had. can't wait to live closer to the bay and make my visits to ritual more frequent!
author: Mashkawizi I.

description:
Don't be mistaken, Ritual is one scalding fartbag but it's perfected the art of being the textbook coffee shop that appeals to all of the self-serving crappers who give them their business and ratings.  For that sole reason, I have to give credit where credit is due.  What I ordered here is beside the point, as it tasted like a hot cup of failure, because it's insignificant compared to the debacle I saw.  

Ritual is more of the antisocial social gathering spot and coffee just happens to be there.  

We were here only for the sake of getting directions and needed Internet due to unfortunate housing circumstances.  More than half of the people there that day were set up neatly on their Apple MacBooks, all contaminating the free WiFi by broadcasting their unimaginative and uneventful lives on display via all mediums of social media as though they are worthy of everyone's attention, time, and envy. 

In a sad attempt to paint their lives into a Picasso of marvel and wonder because they have nothing better to do than to tell everyone else worthless details about themselves that amount to the sweat off a donkey's ass.  As if people want to know exactly what type of muffins you ate for breakfast and how it felt going down.  Or what funny color your stool was that you laid out in your significant other's toilet.  

These people are paralyzed by their frivolous existence and a lack of purpose that they need to desperately fill the gaping holes in their lives, as large as the ones they find in their dank skinny jeans that strangle their decrepit nut-sacks, with photos and tweets that stroke their egos.  This place could use fewer lemmings who insist on spewing inane bullshit out of every pore in their faces.

You know a place fucking sucks when its definition of good coffee music is Wiz Khalifa.  If that scene is going to happen, I had better be seeing free drugs laid out in front of me.  I wasn't even high and I couldn't tell where to put my dirty cups or silverware and where to grab clean silverware.  I am fed up with places like Ritual whose primary focuses are out of alignment.  Let's face it, their coffee and chai here taste diluted and caters to sad-loner-douches. 

I'm not hating because this place is all swag, hot, and in the developing district of Mission.  I'm hating because Ritual seduces miserly sacks of crap and essentially sucks both my big toes simultaneously.  It succeeds at being the watering hole for losery tools who are encumbered by all of the aforementioned shortcomings.
author: Whitney B.

description: Love the cappuccinos...old school quality espressos. I just love it
author: Kevin F.

description:
Great place to get coffee on Mission. 
They have art exhibits on the walls and the ambience is bright and neat. You can choose seating indoor or outside on the sidewalk.
author: Luiza P.

description: Coffee has a unique tang to it, drinkable and full bodied but I imagine it'll appeal to only a few. Atmosphere can get crowded and noisy but the interior design is very calming. You can checkout some of the paintings as you wait for your coffee.  The wait time can be long if there were a bunch of people ahead of you.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Coffee was wonderfully smooth, moderate strength.  Great atmosphere. 

I just got a coffee to go, but I did notice a sign next to the register that said they are trialing turning their wifi off; so just an FYI.
author: Kristine B.

description: Decided to get a cold brew here. I actually enjoyed it and I'm usually very picky. Looks like it recently got a makeover and is actually very nice inside. It was a bit pricey but worth it in my opinion.
author: Jessica A.

description:
I really dig the sleek yet playful look of this coffee brand. (You can tell in the awesome logo alone.) And they take their coffee seriously! 

One major thing I would have changed is a much more visible menu. Customers [standing in the long line] were waiting so people in front of them could move away from the table-level menu. It was an unnecessary struggle.

However, the coffee more than made up for this hardship. I bought the Sao Paulo beans to bring back to NYC!
author: Jess L.

description: Just waited 25 mins for a cup of coffee. They apparently missed our order and didn't say anything about it
author: Ye X.

description:
Consistently some of the best coffee in the Bay. I've never had their drip coffee, but their capuccinos and hot chocolate are fantastic.

There's usually a line, so be prepared to wait at least five full minutes. If there are at least two of you, one should go ferret out a seat. 

Some of the cleanest bathrooms in the Mission, to boot.

The good: awesome coffee.
The bad: full of hipsters talking about fair trade coffee. When in Rome.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Not only do I find this spot convenient to go to due to the fact that my school is literally a block away, but their coffee and space is nothing short of amazing.

Having been back to CCSF after two years, I've definitely felt as if I've missed out on some really great coffee shops. Luckily, I was able to find this gem as I was walking aimlessly trying to find the campus. Since then, it's become a habit going to this specific space before class, after class and just when I need a little boost of energy or a place to work on assignments.

They have a great set of employees and the ambiance is always inviting. And though they do not provide free wifi for customers, which may turn away a few, I personally don't have a problem with it at all. It definitely makes it a lot easier to catch up on a few readings and other assignments.

In addition to being a naturally great coffee shop, they have recently installed a public parklet right out front! Thus creating more of a reason to pay them a visit, if you haven't already!
author: Armando A.

description:
Ritual not only has great coffee, but a chill spot for hanging out and catching up with an old college friend. It's my go to spot for a coffee date in the Mission/Valencia area, besides Philz.   

It was recently remodeled and I don't feel like it has as much seating space (maybe it's just me), but I'll take away a star for that. Nonetheless, it still has tables for people to study and drink their coffee. Also, they recently added an outdoor bench in the front. I like Ritual's space because it's trendy and open, which is welcoming. 

After going so many times, I found myself sitting next to a famous writer/blogger/feminist Anita Sarkeesian. I thought it was a cool minor celebrity sighting.

Overall, I love their coffee and love the people that work there. The employees are easygoing and friendly. So far I haven't encountered any issues with the people there. 

I usually get a chai latte, but I definitely recommend their coffee.
author: Steve S.

description:
Delicious coffee. Try their nitro, which is new!

Note--after the remodel, there is no wifi, so this is a great place to talk but not necessarily to work.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I'm definitely not a coffee connoisseur (or snob, ha) by any means, but hopefully this will be helpful to those who stick to that fine line between bitter and sweet coffees - also known as your average latte. They make 'em pretty good here. The only problem I've had so far is that my latte was kind of between lukewarm and hot once, but I prefer my drinks and my food just really freaking steaming hot in general, so I wouldn't take it as too much of a problem. 

It's definitely really full in the afternoons on any given weekday or on the weekends, but it's not all too difficult to get a table if you just hang around and wait for a bit (or stare someone down until they notice you and start packing up to get you to stop being creepy). Just kidding, don't do that... 

But yeah, I tend to gravitate towards Ritual when I'm in the area just because they have more seating than some of the other ones I've been to. And, they have pretty cool cups - the logo kinda looks like it's been stamped onto each individual cup. Not sure if that's actually the case, but it makes for a good picture!
author: Emily H.

description: Great drip coffee; a powerful caffeine-packed coffee, just like I like it.
author: Rachael S.

description: Wow shittiest espresso of my life. I nearly choked on it. The vibe made me want to puke it was so fucking pretentious. I don't know, it was just incredibly cringeworthy. It wasnt a welcoming warm place either, felt like a museum shop. And the coffee machines look like they cost a million dollars. Yeah they're beautiful but it wasnt a homey atmosphere. It's like when you see a modern beautiful home in a architecture magazine, yeah it's beautiful but not warm or inviting. Patrick Bateman would love this joint. The cashier seemed like she hated her life. Would not return. 2 stars instead of 1 because the bathroom was clean and nice.
author: Ellie B.

description:
I'm the first to admit that I don't have much of a developed palate. I can't taste the woody fruitiness or hints of leather in wine, and I certainly can't taste the creme brulee undertones in beer. However, I do know what I like and I do like - no, LOVE - coffee from Ritual. 

I went with the lightest of their brews one evening and I was so impressed with its rich, creamy flavor - as a cream and sugar type of girl I barely needed anything to enjoy this cup! I also appreciated that it wasn't scalding hot so I could start  drinking it right away. The girl (wo)manning the cash register gave great recommendations and the guy making my cup seemed to really enjoy educating us about the coffee and just chatting it up in general, which I find to be rare at these coffee-snob type places. 

My only hesitation in giving it a full five stars is that it really did take a LONG time to get my cup... I'd say  nearly 10 minutes when there wasn't anyone ahead of us. Perhaps this was because the dude enjoyed talking to us so he was taking his time, or perhaps we were distracting him with our dumb questions about his coffee, but in any case I definitely wouldn't be able to wait 10 minutes for a cuppa joe when I'm running to work in the morning. 

Other than that, I'm pretty in love with this place - lots of space to work and show off your latest Apple gadgets, a cool aesthetic, a frequent drinker coupon card... pretty amazing all around!
author: Christina P.

description:
A coffee shop without friendly baristas and good service is nothing to me. The poor service was such a turn off- Their casing of numerous pastries did not have any labels and the girl who was helping me looked like she was having the most terrible time when I asked her for the name of ONE pastry. I'm sorry, are you too hipster to help me? 

One thing I did appreciate was the atmosphere for doing work/studying- So it's good if you're looking to grab some coffee and get work done.
author: Min S.

description: Great coffee at a great location on Valencia Street in the mission district. Great place to enjoy your coffee and get a little work done on your laptop.
author: Nicholas F.

description: Really liked this place! The coffee was delicious and they have a lot of tables to work at. There's no Wifi and not a lot of outlets though so not really a good place to work if you're planning on staying for a long time. The music was also decent but then I guess the playlist was changed and it became really heavy-metal which kind of sucked but not really any fault of the cafe itself.
author: Linda Z.

description:
Not all that and we asked for extra hot...but he cared more about his Thor hair than our cup
Or was it the lady with the frizzy hair
author: Betty H.

description: Is the remodel like the coffee shop version of normcore? Like, we're so hot, we purposefully try to dress as ugly as possible? Nothing says cozy cuppa like, "Welcome to Terminal 3. Your flight will be boarding in 23 minutes." Coffee's still good, but I'm almost embarrassed to bring anyone here now. Might as well take them to a Starbucks built into a 90s era hotel with this vibe. And not cool, grunge nostalgia 90s. Putty wood bland 90s.
author: Veronica L.

description:
This is one of the very few places in SF that has everything you could want in a coffee shop...

1. great coffee (their chai is awesome too)
2. good workspace (wi-fi & outlets)
3. longer hours

Unfortunately, it is kind of far from my house- but it is great.
author: Christy L.

description: Nitro iced coffee and cold brew coffee were both amazing. Neat clean space indoors, and street side benches great for watching the world go by.
author: Dorcas C.

description:
Let's just get this out of the way--I've had WAY better coffee at other places in San Francisco. 

I don't get why there is a hype over this place. I have gotten coffee here a few times as well as whole coffee beans. Neither impressed me or any of the people who I've taken here to have coffee. Everyone in here is just too cool for themselves, it's a little ridiculous. 


My latte or mocha has always been lukewarm and weak here. Yes, they did a lovely job on the foam art, but I need it to taste good, too. I'm guessing this is why people are so star struck with this place, because in reality, the coffee just isn't all that good. The prices are decent. 

Their pastries are amazing and I will drop in to buy their baked goods.  This is the only reason I've given it 3 stars instead of two. There really isn't any excuse for continually being served weak and tepid coffee.
author: Bianca U.

description:
I have always enjoyed Ritual Coffee Roasters! My first experience with their coffee was at the Oxbow Public Market in Napa, CA. I've also seen their roasts in a few coffee shops around Downtown Los Angeles, CA. After realizing they are San Francisco locals, I just had to drop by for their coffee, made by Ritual baristas!

The place is pretty spacious, with lots of seating and free wifi. The baristas are pretty friendly, and they [willingly] give pretty good advice on their roasts. Around the time I visited the place, they had an experimental "micro-lot" out on pour-over that was pretty good. Great to see that this pour-over was only $3 - the cheapest of all their choices, but definitely worth every penny!

Quality coffee, completely satisfying, and never over-priced! I'm a fan for life!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Been to their location before they remodeled. Love their flag for the exotic feel-Feel as if I just entered a soviet institution. Love their coffee apparatuses too. Good hardworking man's coffee.

Want to visit it soon.
author: Rahul V.

description:
I just can't see what all the hype is for here. Yes, the ambiance is kind of cool with lots of tables and couches. Yes, the logo is all retro vintage sexy. But what about the coffee and the people behind the counter?? 

I had a latte made by a hipster looking fella with a major hipster attitude. I think he probably spent all this time learning how to make beautiful flower patterns in the coffee instead of making great coffee. My latte was extremely bland and barely lukewarm. At least the workers at Philz can back up their attitudes. =)
author: Henry W.

description: I have been a fan of ritual coffee ever since we arrived in SF 4 years ago. It's not pretentious, it cranks out great, perfect, always delicious & beautiful coffee each & every time. I love the new fit-out & again we weren't disappointed with the coffee. Another standout was the hot chocolate made with local rechiuti chocolate...yum!
author: Nicole E.

description:
You can expect: 
- hipsters who judge
- a line that moves slowly
- unfriendly haughty baristas and who yell at you "WE DONT LIKE PICTURES, OK?" 
- yummy lattes (i admit to org-ing out loud after my first sip) 
- a decent cup of drip 
- fun and sometimes custom coffee items (aeropress, hario stuff, scale, cups, mugs, tumblers) 

It's worth a try because it kind of perfectly exemplifies this part of the mission. 
BUT, would I become a regular here? nah. It's just over the top. Is there really a need for the staff to be so unfriendly and judgy? If you want people to buy your coffee, shouldn't you have excellent customer service. I have purchased bags of ritual beans at local grocery stores, but I dont think their beans are anything super special and given how I've been treated at this location, I'm less inclined to purchase again. 
(oh, i also saw a maggot or some similar type bug walking on their pastries inside their enclosed case. barf) 

Go to four barrel - better beans, better service, and beautiful space.
author: Tim B.

description:
Ritual is one of the best coffee joints I have been to! I would say that Ritual and Blue Bottle are neck to neck. Personally, I like them both for different reasons.

Ritual's coffee is more bold and flavorful. It's definitely stronger than Blue Bottles. They make some delicious espressos, macchiatos, cappuccinos, & lattes! I like their lattes here better than Blue Bottle.

They also sell some pastries/donuts. The free wifi is definitely a big PLUS! Oh...and their espresso will run you only $1.25 ;)
author: Veronica S.

description: One of the most famous coffee shop in town, latte is really good, very smooth, very light.
author: Sunny J.

description: Open, contemporary decor. The coffee was fantastic. Watching the staff work was like watching artists at work. Very friendly and welcoming.
author: Ron C.

description:
I came to Ritual with my wife and friend after lunch on sunday. Despite its large size and ample seating, the cafe was packed, and every other person that was sitting at a table had a laptop open.

I bought several things from Ritual as I had set forth to try to visit as many coffee shops as I could on my trip.  I got a bag of whole bean coffee, Sweet Espresso, a mug (I love the soviet-like logo), a tumbler (for my wife), and a latte.  The person at the till was also very friendly and funny.  Service was also fast and kept the line moving, but I didn't feel rushed.

The latte was smooth and excellent at the cafe.  I made my sweet espresso in both my coffee press and my moka pot at home.  Both brews were very good and tops.

I am very impressed by Ritual Coffee, and will definitely hit this spot up again, and get another bag of beans!
author: Katherine L.

description:
A dozen-or-so years ago, I used to run my business from this place on my white plastic Mac iBook along with a packed house full of laptop-wifi-gypsy freelancers. They've updated the place, and it looks great. It's not the wifi palace it once was, and that's probably a good thing.
Used to be, you might feel strange crowding into this place if you weren't tapping away on a laptop, but the energy is more laid-back now.
The layout is more spacious, and there's still a friendly community table plus a new back-window terrarium garden for your viewing pleasure.
The same old sense of coffee fetishism dominates, but they offer a great tea selection: Song tea, a spin-off company, the barista tells me, from my beloved Chinatown tea source, Red Blossom.
It is a little mean of them to serve that $4 tea without the actual tea leaves so you can't get free hot water refills, but I guess a cafe has got to make a buck somehow. I still love writing here and have heard that owner Eileen Hassi Rinaldi considers it her personal mission to fuel us--the writers of San Francisco.
author: Kristy L.

description: We loved this place. The coffee selection was great and the ambiance was beautiful. I am a connoisseur of great coffee and loved my experience. The staff was friendly, knowledgeable,  and cute.  Great job I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting the mission area.
author: Eric A.

description:
If you're looking for good coffee in the Mission, Ritual is a good bet, on par with anyone else in the hood. 

No surprises here - they do the things any decent coffee shop does these days (single brew pour-over, cold brew iced coffee, etc.). One nice thing is they offer drip coffee as well, in case you don't have time for the pour-over. 

A little less attitude than 4-Barrel, and a lot cleaner inside. In fact, they just remodeled and have a shiny new space. 

Expect to wait if you're going during peak hours. Getting people through the line quicker must not have been a goal with the remodel.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Guaranteed caffeine fix. Nuff said. I'm impressed, good quality cup of mocha. The doode warned us they were closing in 20 minutes and sure enough they were playing the super annoying "get the @#$^ out music" as they wrapped up the cleaning and shutting down of the place. It's a typical coffee joint, couches looked comfy, tables industrial, laptop abound, clean spacious bathroom in back.
My first ritual experience was actually infused in a Speakeasy porter. Now that was to die for. Beer and coffee together. Delicious! Too bad you can't pick that up at the coffee shop...
author: Naomi K.

description:
Ridiculously delightful coffee and a bastion of coffee culture in San Francisco. But you really don't need a review to tell you to go--- just pass by if you're in the neighborhood and check out the line. 

Pick the cheapest beans they offer that day, it'll be more expensive than any other pour-over in the vicinity but taste amazing. 

Their pastry selection is quite good, I recommend the coconut macaroons!
author: Lisa Q.

description:
Disclaimer: I don't do coffee. Don't drink it, don't like it, can function without it (knock on wood).

Still, I couldn't say no to Ritual Coffee Roasters. I saw and heard the name at different cafes around the city and felt the hype. It'd be like going to Istanbul and not trying out a tiny cup of Turkish coffee!

So there I was, ordering a "third wave" coffee with a long name. I stood around while my coffee was poured over, and was handed a big mug filled to the brim. 

I took a seat in the under-decorated space and took a sip. And wow, the coffee tasted nothing like the few cups of "first-" or "second wave" coffee I've had in the past. It was very full of flavor and wasn't bitter at all. It was like drinking Natty light at frat parties, then tasting a really good craft beer. Makes you see the beverage in a whole new light.
author: Janet B.

description:
Of all the hipster in all of San Francisco, I had to walk into this one.

Despite all the horn-rimmed technorati clicking away at their laptops at 3pm on a Saturday (seriously, what are you all working on?), and the angst-ridden dude scribbling away on his Moleskine next to me, my friends and I were able to enjoy our coffee here. The place is spacious, well-lit, and clean. But on to the coffee.....

The coffee, oh, the coffee. If you see the El Angel on the menu, casually make your way ahead of your friend in line and order this coffee. Try to be cool, don't spaz out in front of the coffee, you want it to think you're cool and not trying to hard. The El Angel is quite possibly the best cup of coffee I've had here in SF. The taste and body are unparalleled, and I didn't vibrate home afterwards like I usually do after Blue Bottle, nor did my stomach start doing summersaults like a Romanian gymnast like it usually does after Four Barrel. Though I'll probably take the coffee to-go next time.
author: Craig P.

description:
I love Ritual and I love the one in the Mission especially. 

There's never much of a line when you go but there's always people in the shop. 
It's a really open and really modern shop. They kept everything simple and streamlined, unlike their coffee. 

I don't quite remember the coffee I got when I went but it had hints of cherry, vanilla, chocolate and some type of flower. It was a really smooth and really good cup of coffee. 

One issue I had was with the staff, if I'm being honest. They were curt, kind of rude and that came complete with an eye roll when I asked which was their most popular drink. Maybe he was having a bad day. But other than that, Ritual is great.
author: Tammy L.

description: The set up is really nice, and the brand is what really compelled me to try their coffee. Got the V60 Brew and was not a fan. Tasted like water down coffee, not sure if that was what it was suppose to taste like. Other than that, service was good. Looks like a cool place to work.
author: Amanda H.

description:
This place is excellent because they have:

--- amazing speedy wifi
--- ample seating (and high turnover generally)
--- power outlets
--- great unique roasted beans 
--- good location (heart of Mission)
--- two bathrooms

The line often appear long at the coffee stand, but it always goes through in about 5 min. I'm usually a tea drinker, but their drip is quite amazing. They often carry 1-2 unique varieties. I'm not a coffee connoisseur but their drip is very smooth, fragrant,  and not acidic, definitely worth a try.

I often camp here for a very long time, working on my laptop for 3-4 hours straight. It may be noisy around, but that doesn't generally bother me. If you come on weekend afternoons, it gets very crowded (FYI, if you really can't find a table and need to work, you can go to Blue Fig which is a block away that often has tables). If you come on weekday afternoons it's easy to get a table. 

Being in the heart of mission, parking is not always easy. BART and muni stops are nearby, so I highly recommend walking to it. There's plenty of nearby boutiques, food shops, and other cafes to visit.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I know it's 7 in the morning, but must the staff be so unfriendly?!? Their lack of warmth makes you almost feel a bit awkward ordering from them. I felt almost as if I was bothering them! 

Anyways, besides the attitude, the baristas do make a mean latte. I am certainly no expert on coffee, but I can taste the difference between their lattes and the ones made at my local diner.  The best way I can describe the difference is that Ritual's lattes are richer and creamy when compared to others, which tastes watered down.  I'm also in love with their ham and cheese croissant...sooooo flaky and delicious.
author: Anna Y.

description:
I went to this cafe every day while I was in SF. It is really close to the music school I was using to practice. It is a great place to spend a few hours reading, catching up on email, working or writing Yelp reviews :) 
I tried the coffee, the lattes and the herbal teas (the Elderberry was really interesting). All were smooth and delicious. They create pretty latte art, even with soy and almond milk orders :) 
I wish more DC/Northern Virginia coffee shops offered almond milk in their coffee drinks.
It is not inexpensive, but this IS the Mission D. The trend-factor is like, a million. You will not be much worse off than if you had gone to Starbucks, and their products and quality are infinitely superior. 
They have long opening hours and if you wait around long enough you can get a table or workstation with a plug for your computer or phone. They will leave you to read or work unmolested at your table which is nice- I could have stayed in there all day without being bothered. 
The music is slightly loud for my taste, but I guess that is due to the younger crowd?
ps: They have "pepples" vegan doughnuts you can order to accompany your coffee. I am surprised this did not set me off on a binge. Frugality and practicality prevented me from ordering one of every flavor after consuming the blueberry. It was that good.
pps. free wifi  /love
author: Simplehiccup D.

description:
OK so I bought beans here at Ritual, I know I didn't get a cup of coffee at the shop, but I always like mine I make best at home! Long story short if I didn't like the espresso at home I would have hated it at the shop... Anyways So I have my own Rocket Espresso Machine and I drink quit a bit of espresso (at home) I'm always on the hunt for great beans when I go different places. I could not get their espresso bean...  (Seersucker) to pull a nice shot, it was runny and watery, where I like the shot to come out slow and  syrupy! Now I know that it wasn't me, because I got it come out slow, but it was only watery consistence! I have more then half a bag left if anyone wants it!! 

P.S. Went to Sight Glass and got their espresso blend, Owl's Howl and pulled a shot on my machine! Perfecto! Very nice!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
It's official: this is simply my favorite cup of coffee in the entire city! They're not cheap (very much the opposite, as a matter of fact), but for a special occasion where you feel like splurging on caffeinated wonderment, you can't go wrong with any of their offerings. 

Most of their selections start at $2.25 per cup and range as high as $4.00 for a single ceramic mug of steamy java. My grandma would slap me across the head for dropping 400 pennies on a single cup of coffee, but hey - it is what it is.

There aren't any outlets for laptops, which is a good thing and a bad thing. On one hand, you don't have to worry about people lounging all day long mooching the free wifi, but on the other hand, when you're laptop runs out of juice, your working-from-the-cafe day is donezo. Make sure you have a full charge before settling in.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
The first time I ever experienced pourover was in the hallowed halls of Ritual coffee. I was a doe-eyed Canadian, and somewhat agog that people would wait four minutes to watch coffee drip through a paper filter. Ritual changed me. 

Updating my review to reiterate that I like this spot. The have clear descriptions of what's on brew, and their espresso drinks are equally solid. It's an airy space with plenty of seating and large tables. The two things that differentiate this spot for me:

- you can pay with plastic
- Wi-Fi is free and password-less and works

Also: pick up one of their very smartly designed Brew Guides!
author: Vivek S.

description:
Love the coffee, love the service (everyone is always extremely knowledgeable and sweet), and it is comfortable. 

Why 3 stars - what's up with the music?! I am not sure who really likes to work (the majority of the clientele is working not chatting) to metal, but be forewarned - they blast some really un-friendly working music. Its kinda to the point where I just might not come back if I really want to get something done. A shame really.
author: Alex M.

description: I miss Ritual so much.  They really do have the best beans, to the point that my mom occasionally orders them for us as a special treat (she's in the Midwest, I'm now in the Southeast).
author: Helen V.

description:
Great place to grab a beverage and settle down to work for an hour or two if you're like me and can't seem to get motivated when at home.

I'm not a coffee drinker, so can't comment on that, but their peppermint rose loose-leaf tea is divine.  I went back to the counter twice to get a hot water refill....and may have ended up with two (delicious) chocolate chip cookies as a result.  It's not my fault; they looked at me.

One minor nitpick: the "fresh squeezed orange juice" advertised on the sign was just poured from a jug that looked suspiciously similar to something you'd buy at a supermarket.  Not sure they're actually doing any orange-squeezing on site...stick to the hot beverages.

Music is pretty loud, so recommend bringing your own headphones if you want to zone out!
author: Joëlle M.

description:
I love this place and when it comes to coffee in the city, I know everyone is always like "THIS PLACE IS DA BOMB" and I'm not about to do that, although I think this place is most excellent.

What I will say is that if you like strong, bold flavor profiles that kick to you in the teeth, while simultaneously caressing your tongue - then you need to try this place.

My primary reason for going is for their unique seasonal espressos - you should seriously try them and experiment with what you get, I promise you will not be disappointed. 

If you are not so much of a hardcore espresso person, their mocha latte's are simply DIVINE. Especially if you enjoy dark chocolate and nothing too sweet (which is right up my alley)

You should totally go, you will not regret it.
author: Lauren B.

description: Got an iced latte here... and while the lighting and ambience is nice, nothing here is too special. I like their coffee -- it's refined and smooth which is a plus in my book for not giving me diarrhea. It's a little out of the way for BART so if you're ever in the area,  it might not be the easiest to get to.
author: Davinci L.

description:
Places like Ritual make me want to move into San Francisco! The line wasn't long and neither is their drink list, I love a place that does a few things beautifully. They have fresh pastries and I just had to have a fresh croissant with my cappuccino. 

There is a lot of seating along the front wall and in the back, if your looking for a quiet area to work or just chill. My boyfriend and I sat in the back on the black couch which was so comfy and there was a cute coffee table in front of it. It was like have coffee at home and we were able to relax a bit and enjoy of coffees. 

I'll return next time I'm in the area.
author: Constance D.

description: Great hipster coffee spot, with friendly wait staff, a nice warm ambiance, tasty coffee, lots of sitting areas, and fast wifi. Great place for having a casual sit down
author: Henry L.

description: The coffee is good, but one outlet and no Wifi is a deal breaker for me. I probably won't be back.
author: Laura A.

description:
Consistently consistent. 
Cute guys behind the counter.
Amazing coffee.
Delicious pastries.
Best cappuccino in town.
Love to sit in the back and take it all in.
author: Katie S.

description: On vacation in SF, someone recommended this coffee shop. Walked in and saw a long line but waited anyways. It went fast and ended up being well worth the wait. My drink was brewed right in front of me which made the experience more fun. It was probably the best latte I have ever drank and I'm a huge coffee fan.
author: Lisa P.

description: Good- even great- coffee that is overshadowed by the overwhelming pretentiousness of the place. Please if you are going to be so obnoxious as to cover every single one of your outlets so that people can not utilize electronics- make this more obvious so that I do not wait in line for ten minutes just to receive my 'cup of caffeinated art' and then realize that I can not do anything other than drink my coffee in this minimalistic den of hipster witchery. And given that wi-fi in a coffee shop is now part of the standard model of cafe in 2015, I would also appreciate a sign that states  'No wi-fi (at all)' Thank you very much.
author: sharon t.

description: One of the regular places I visit to just sit and write. They have good coffee and the atmosphere itself is mellow. I've never encountered a rude barista and everyone of them are super friendly. People who complain about hipsters are just jealous of all the cool tattoos they sport! ;)
author: Ravi T.

description: Not a bad spot at all for a cup of coffee...lot's of choices for single-cup coffees, and reasonably priced.  I paid $3 for a really well done Guatemalan coffee (considering Starbucks costs about $2 for something that tastes pretty awful to me, this is a huge value).  The staff was friendly, and there was plenty of space in the shop to sit and enjoy my coffee.  Between all the choices for coffee in the Mission, I would say this is a fine place to stop at!
author: Eric N.

description:
The drink was spectular. I had a cappuccino and just was so smooth and perfect. The coffee flavor itself wasn't one of my favorites...more medium roast than I like.

The place is filled with hipsters working at the tables or reading or hanging out. So, note that even though they have a ton of places to sit, not one may be available.
author: Amy O.

description: This has to have been by far the best ever tasting pourover coffee I've ever had. As I'm becoming a coffee connoisseur , I can taste the notes of flavor in the cup, no cream sugar NOTHING! You don't need it if it tastes like this! When I'm back up in NoCal I'll be back to get another cup. Thanks! Worth every drop!
author: Dennis F.

description: Cappuccino-To Go (Double) and V60-To Go (Decaf).Great stuff.
author: Priyanka L.

description:
One of my favorite coffee spots in the city. A good roast and a solid brew makes for a smoooth cup of coffee that does not lose any of its flavors. 

Also, they make a mean latte. As in the milk is just the perfect temperature and made with JUST the right amount of froth. Did you know if you steam milk right its actually sort of sweet? 

If you like four barrel, you'll like ritual.
author: Fion L.

description:
First of all, I have to say that there is good coffee here.  I'm not a coffee fan (I just came here because I had to meet a client somewhere in the Mission and it looked like they had ample seating) yet I really enjoyed my mocha.  Such beautiful presentation and tasted great too.  There is much more seating than Four Barrel and lots of plugs for laptops too.

That being said, the service wasn't the friendliest.  When I walked up to the counter to place my order, the guy took almost a minute just to acknowledge me- no "hold on a sec", not even a glance at me.  And the cashier was so bleh with me and seemed annoyed that I was trying to pay her for my mocha.  Not exactly service with a smile.  And all of the artwork (photos) aren't so tasteful in my opinion, I was a little embarrassed to meet my client with the pictures up.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Had an iced coffee one time. Weak, flavorless, no depth.

Second visit, ordered a cappuccino, once again espresso was bleh- weak and almost not present.

Both visits customer service sucked, baristas didnt make much eye contact. Come'on guys, you're in the customer svc business- smile once in a while.
author: Mario M.

description: Macchiato espresso was absolutely divine. The coffee had a strong flavor, and wasn't bitter at all.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Forgetting Sarah Marshall, try Ritual coffee. It is the cure!  My first time, I had the Buena Vista, and it felt like someone turned on the light switch in my brain: "Get yourself together, and find someone better...You are now smarter than a 5th grader!" 
YUP! THE COFFEE IS THAT GOOD!!
Other than the line and the price for one size coffee, I must warn you that sometimes they don't serve the same coffee bean/bran...it's seasonal. 
This place is also my favorite spot to meet up with friends, especially those who are always late. I get to enjoy my cup of coffee while waiting...
Btw, their vegan pastries are good too!
author: Po S.

description: Pretty strong Brazilian coffee at Ritual. It takes awhile before you get your cup of coffee as the barista is slowly doing some drip coffee action
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
Awesome place to chill to music and get some work done. Coffee is amazing and looks like art. I was able to get a ton of work done here. The place is a little louder than your usual coffee shop, but it adds to it's feel. After you order, you can watch your brew drip or can choose from a variety of pastries. 

Only gripe is I couldn't find any electrical outlets near me at the front tables, but thankfully I came with a full charge. Another cool thing was that there was an independent feature film being shot right around the corner.
author: Chris E.

description: Good espresso drinks with below-average service.  Perhaps it's a function of the quantity of patrons that they need to serve, but on two occasions, the staff have been unnecessarily glib/terse.  As others have noted, you'll have to wait a while for your drink.
author: Chris F.

description:
Sigh ... oh Ritual. How I miss thee. It 's crazy that this location only started perhaps a few months ago and has already gotten over 1000 reviews!

I first visited Ritual in Napa when I was at the Oxbow Market and thought they had some amazing coffee. I wasn't so used to the type of coffee they served (i.e. coming from the syrupy Starbucks world) but soon I discovered that it was exactly what I liked! I love the creamy texture of their lattes and the whole place is filled with the student, study, internet cafe atmosphere.

I stopped by here a few weeks ago to grab some to-go and their line / ordering process was a bit confusing, but the coffee was delightful as it has always been.

If you're in the city for coffee, this is a must stop!
author: Lorrie M.

description: First time coming here and thankfully I beat the rush. This place is a bit pricey compared to some coffee shops as my 8oz single shot mocha was $4, but was well worth the price. Mocha was smooth and well balanced, the art was on point, and the place has a cozy vibe to it. What more can you ask for?
author: Garrick Y.

description:
I have been coming to ritual for a while and have been a specialty coffee drinker for 3 or so years. There are some awesome things and some not as awesome things. Overall I love the place and still come here most days. Here is a breakdown of what I like and don't like.

Awesome:
Coffee is really consistently great  
The batistas are nice and remembered my drink after 10 or so visits
There are several comfy couches

Not as Awesome:
There are only outlets at one big community table. 
The music is fairly loud and usually pretty bad (too hardcore)
The place is usually pretty busy
author: Graham H.

description:
If you ever misplace your hipster, you'd find him/her here. I do like their wedgey fat-bottomed ceramic mugs though. And the coffee wasn't half-bad, though I'm confused why anything that isn't going to fill me up is going to run into the $3-4 range. I got the Serra Negra since they're featuring Brazilian beans at the moment.
