No outlets, so a strange place to work, though it means turnover for tables is much faster.
author: Kevin L.

description: The ambiance was cool, latte was excellent, clean and friendly staff. Strongly recommend if you are in the area. They have benches outside to hangout.
author: Lorlie C.

description:
Coffee is pretty good. The service is awful. It takes forever to get a cup of coffee and baristas' attitude is horrible. They act like they all hate to be there and the customer is an inconvenience to them.
Thanks, but I prefer a friendly environment, like Philz. Not going back. One star for coffee only.
author: Patricia L.

description:
The latte is amazing and the espresso slapped me in the face---literally, I had a pseudo face lift for about 30 minutes.

*I made the mistake of asking for espresso con panna (like in Italy), and was given a look, kinda like the one you give your friend who's always slow on the upkeep. Yea, that look. I bounced back quick though...woo, thankfully I like espresso in the raw.
author: Shira O.

description: Nothing crazy here - just some straghtforward, choice coffee. Order an espresso, macchiato, latte, capuccino, mocha, or coffee at the first counter. I personally liked the more roasted, astringent bitterness (apt given the hipster vibe of the place...) of the seasonal espresso in my latte, but others may want to try the sweet tooth instead. Pay at the second counter, then take your drink and mingle amongst the busy crowd of hipsters on their macs enjoying the free (but unfortunately sort of spotty) wifi.
author: Clarice W.

description:
I had the honor of working on the street in front of Ritual Coffee two weeks ago and constantly had to borrow their bathroom despite not having bought anything. Most establishments would have turned me away the second time, but the baristas were very understanding and kind. I did end up getting a coffee and coconut pastry at the end of the day.

The drip coffee wasn't anything special. It was good but did not stand out to me. The same goes for the coconut pastry - a little burnt but still pretty good. Maybe I just need to go again and try something new, but my first experience wasn't so good. Honestly, I think people go there for the atmosphere.

The place was full of people the whole day - people chatting, reading, or working on their laptops. The atmosphere was comfortable, and the noise was perfect for working. It was mostly a 20-30's crowd, a bit trendy and hipster-ish. I didn't get to actually sit down and enjoy my coffee, but it seemed like everyone else was enjoying the delightful ambiance. I will come back someday with a good book.
author: Yolanta S.

description: Seems like I'm not the only one that really hates the new space. No character at all, just another recycled riff of an apple store design and shittttty music. I will say that the cappuccino was still great but it's not enough for me to come back. Sorry Ritual, I liked the original flavor you had, this new shit just isn't up my ally.
author: Stevie K.

description:
Exchange with barista:

The song playing right now keeps repeating the words "blowjob" and "bitch."

          Hmm.

I prefer not to hear those words when I'm drinking my coffee.

          We play all kinds of music here.  

I really don't like hearing women referred to as "bitches" in a place of business.  

          We play all kinds of music here, rock, punk, rap...

I like rap as much as the next person, just not the kind that refers to women as "bitches."  You're describing genres of music.  I'm talking about misogyny.  

          I'll change the song because you asked, 
          but we don't limit our choice of music here.

Well, then I'll choose to buy my coffee elsewhere.
author: Charlie P.

description:
Heard a lot of great things about Ritual Coffee.  Glad I came up to SF to check it out.  

Plenty of seating, nice pastry selection, however the coffee, while it had nice flavor, could have been prepared a little cooler.   If they lowered the temperature of the coffee by 2-3 degrees, it would greatly help reduce the bitterness I experienced.  

I under the "hand crafting" of a third wave coffee, however I was slightly bugged to see someone using their bare hands on the portafilter for so long to massage my coffee before tamping.  I'm ok with the north-south-east-west finger leveling, but full on filter groping?  My grounds felt violated! :)

I don't want to compare this place to other coffee locations because I feel that everyone's tastebuds are unique.  Happy to try them again, or get some beans to prepare at home.

Friendly staff, great latte art.

Thanks!
author: Todd A.

description:
I'm really just reviewing this place because I need another place to add to my HIPSTER WATCHING (http://www.yelp.com/list/hipster-watching-san-francisco) list.  

This makes one of the top places to hipster-watch.

1. Incredibly expensive coffee: CHECK ($3-5/each)
2. In the Mission-- specifically on Valencia: CHECK
3. Lines out the door for excellent, hand-dripped coffee: CHECK
4. Hipsters coming out of its pores (I mean, doors...): CHECK CHECK CHECK CHECK CHECK...

Yeah.  All of the above.  It's good.  A little bit intimidating, especially when I went in Moustache Mo'vember and my face did not sport a huge moustachio like every other hipster in the place.  (Well, I suppose the reason for that is because I'm an Asian female...)  Luckily, I was with C., who has a moustache/beard in his own right.  SCORE.  I wasn't so out of place after all.

Anyway, HIPSTER WATCHED.  Did it here.  Yeah, y'all.
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
Great coffee, good atmosphere, and plenty of seating. Ritual Coffee is in the heart of the Mission so have your hipster outfit on to blend in a little bit. 

I love pour over coffee and they do it justice here. I like drinking my coffee in ceramic cups but all the seats were occupied today by people Facebooking/blogging/working/ordering random shit on Amazon(I didnt look but I'm just assuming).
author: Harry T.

description:
A moment of silence, please, as I mourn the loss of my favorite coffee spot in San Francisco. The coffee has always been wonderful and no doubt still is but I hate the new interior.  It screams "you are not welcome to stay" and "that coffee is to-go, right?" So sad... 

With Craftsman and Wolves close enough, I can opt for equally good coffee and a place to sit.  Last night I walked a bit further and went to Four Barrel... What an amazing place and equally inviting as C&W. And the service was impeccable and the roaster was humming in the back... Fun!

Others have mentioned the loss of wifi and power outlets but I never went to Ritual for that... I went for coffee and a cozy conversation with friends... Our "ritual" at Ritual.  No more. With tears, goodbye Ritual.
author: Beth W.

description: I never thought I would find myself in a place like this, but hipsters do know where all the good coffee places are (after all, they found it first). The latte was very well made and not too expensive at $3.35. I know it's dumb, but I still like it when they make that perfect rosette design into the latte. The perfect blend of espresso and steamed milk makes me never want to step into another Starbucks again.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
The coffee is excellent. Excellent I say!

The venue has a "modern Scandinavian feel", which is the same as saying "bare, cold and with raw light wood" - not a fan of those, but it's probably because I grew up with that stuff... The noise level is quite high and the bare walls and open area makes every clink of cups and saucers behind the counter echo through out the room.

Looking at the clientele around me I am clearly not hip enough to be here, but I loved great coffee before these kids could even spell "mom" so I don't care. ;-)

The coffee makes me come back, the noise makes me leave. It's a bit of a love-hate relationship...
author: Roberth K.

description:
This is probably the best coffee shop I've been to in the city terms of the service/people/coffee/neighborhood. On top of that, and most importantly, it was an ideal environment to study in.

I'm not the biggest coffee drinker so the beans being served on the day I came was pretty strong--I couldn't even make a dent in my second coffee.

I'd come back here for sure. If you're looking for a place to study or just meet up with someone for a drink, this place is legit.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Do you like $4, mediocre iced coffee? Do you enjoy waiting in long lines in a loud, un-airconditioned room? Does working in a packed coffee shop with no internet access appeal to you? 

Try Ritual. It's really that bad.
author: Katherine O.

description: It's open late and has a nice atmosphere. We ordered a latte and an americano. The latte was great, not too bitter and had pretty art :) I am assured the americano was good too. Will be back!
author: Pooja S.

description:
Beware, all ye who enter here. Be not the fool who is spat on and parted with his or her money.

I used to come here two to three times a week, until the remodel. Then I arrived at the opening to find what used to be a warm, funky, inviting space has turned into a sterile Starbucks environment where service is at a minimum and taste is of no concern. I hoped to spend an hour with a cup of coffee and finish a quick homework assignment, but then I learned that the once-previously free wifi is now gone. So are all the outlets to charge your computer or phones. Instead, when I asked politely, I was told with venomous glee that "All our regulars..." were so much happier without wifi, and were having so much more FUN! I looked around the shop, NO ONE WAS INTERACTING. I'm not sure where all the "fun" was hiding, but it wasn't here anymore. The barista smiled sarcastically with a condescending attitude. I felt attacked and insulted. I tried sipping my coffee. It tasted like muddled Folgers. I felt like a fool. Thankfully, with so many options here in SF, I won't need to come back.

Dear Ritual, next time, when I'm patronizing your establishment, try to be more polite. Less service (including WiFi) doesn't mean more value. For all others, I'd suggest the Blue Fig up the street. Better coffee, more options, free WiFi, and best of all, they treat you like a human being!
author: Andy D.

description: Not a fan of the new decor. I liked the old dark and woodsy colors. And they got rid of the wifi. And they were out of two teas. And my tea cost $5. I won't be going back...
author: Stu M.

description:
Is it bad that I sometimes go to Ritual Coffee to see if my coffee boyfriend is working? You know who I'm talking about: the blond boy with the eyes and barista skills, the one who once asked me if I wanted him to remake my macchiato because he thought he saw an errant grind in the foam? I hear he's an award winner. 

Of course, he's not the only reason to go; the coffee *is* excellent, and this location has a good amount of sitting space and a slightly caffeinated ambiance. The music... excited, let's just put it that way. Busy during rush hours and on the weekends, but the line moves quick enough, and it's a great spot on this side of the Mission. 

Also, if you stop by and they have any of their Sweet Tooth beans available, drink something made with those. It's worth the extra couple of cents.
author: Allison S.

description:
Ritual was one of the two coffee spots we definitely wanted to hit while visiting San Francisco. The shop was spacious and decorated with cool artwork on the walls. My husband and I arrived late at night, and enjoyed two cappuccinos, two macchiatos, and an iced Americano. They were tasty!

The barista was quiet (but friendly,) and skilled. It was casual, laid back, and chill. I really enjoyed my visit.
author: Yiching P.

description:
This place is sooo SF - from the hipster baristas to the quirky decor to the two guys making out in the corner.

I've been dying to try Ritual, and I finally had an opportunity to go back to SF and visit it. It was a Sunday morning, and we had to wait in line for a good 15 minutes. I ordered a mocha, and my boyfriend ordered a latte (no, they do not have flavors like vanilla or hazelnut :( ) The price was actually reasonable considering that it's SF and that their drinks are of high quality. 

I enjoyed my mocha, but it was far from the best that I've had. My boyfriend seemed to like his latte. I liked their latte art probably more than I liked the actual drink. I did enjoy watching them make drip coffee for other people. They make each cup by hand, which I think is pretty awesome.

I like that they have a lot of seating space in there. Even though it's kind of loud, this would be a good place to come and work/study. It's an even better place to meet up with friends. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to come here in the future, but if you love coffee, you should definitely try this place at least once.
author: Kelly H.

description: Decided to stop by the Hayes location for a latte. Was not bad but was not great. I personally thought it was watered down and more milk than anything. Willing to go back and try another (maybe the barista had an off day). I am more of a Blue Bottle fan myself. My gal pal does love this place though.
author: Bri R.

description:
I stopped into this SF landmark while visiting this summer. I decided to buy a cup of house coffee to see what the big deal is, and to compare it to the Philz coffee I had in my hand. I'm not a Philz coffee fan, but it was close to the house. Too many choices and the coffee often tastes watery and burnt. But Ritual took disappointment to a whole new level. As I watched the barrista carefully and slowly pour the water over the cone filter, I waited, hoping that light color would soon change to a deep, velvet rich brown. After all, there's always a line. So it must be good...right?

Nope. My coffee tasted like lemon zinger tea brewed in a used Folgers paper cup. Awful. I  had to throw it out. I'm sticking to Peet's. They are simply the best.
author: arusha b.

description: Saw a girl with the same Rene Magritte macbook decal as mine. This is clearly where great minds come to congregate.
author: Tiffany V.

description: I liked the old Ritual. It was darker and warmer and had wifi. I'm not crazy about the remodel. It feels washed out and overly modern. And then there's the no-wifi policy. I can't argue with them because it's their choice, but it's going to keep me from coming over terribly often.
author: Allison L.

description: The remodel of Ritual completely killed it for me.  This place used to have character, good music, and was a great place to feel like you were having a coffee in the Mission.  Now it feels cold and sterile.  Ill be sticking to Borderlands just down the street from now on.
author: C H.

description:
When with a group of friends, and love it! The coffee was great. I was abled to drink my espresso without any added sugar. The barista was fast and friendly. He made an espresso and latte in under 2 mins. The atmosphere was good. Lots of seats, tables, outlets, and a really comfortable couch in the backs. Also the bathroom are super clean! 

Take a star away for all the non native (aka hipsters) Franciscans who don't know it's not polite to stare at the locals. (Not in the cafe's control)
author: Krystle S.

description: Not bad. The line wasn't too long, but then again it was around 7AM in the morning when I got coffee. I saw they have a $3 drip coffee from the Guatemala region so I chose that. I usually don't put anything in my coffee and this didn't taste as bitter as it normally would if I got my coffee from another place. I also didn't have the usual caffeine crash.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Sometimes, all it takes to turn a terrible day around can be some polite and polished interaction with gracious strangers. The City has more than its fair share of dorky cool (or just plain ole dorky). The crew at this location have transcended trying to be someone/something to just being themselves -elegantly. For those of us who have left the City, a trip to places like Ritual is a clear reminder that it's the people, the amazingly diverse and interesting people (the unpretentious ones) that we miss the most. Special thank you to my barista who hooked me UP with a gift!! Wow.
author: John K.

description:
Solid cup of medium roast coffee. Although it's medium roast and not the intense, dark roasty flavor of Peet's that I know and love, Ritual is not lacking in flavor or complexity.

Comparing the espresso blends at Four Barrel, I prefer those Four Barrel over Ritual. Personal preference (and maybe it even varies by coffee lot). The espresso I ordered at Ritual was more acidic than I'm used to. Perhpas it was just the daily selection and maybe the other espresso blends are better. The blend served as drip was much tastier, smooth and not tart at all, unlike the highly acidic drip I sipped at Four Barrel.
author: Kel S.

description:
I live in the Mish...really ... so you can just imagine that I am surrounded by coffee shops...I was told once that Coffee nowadays is an experience...and boy is it really???? so if you want to get experience...come here...seat down at the couch, bring your macs, sit down and enjoy.

this is bourgeois...and I meant this in a good way...I appreciate the effort they put into the one cup at a time thing.... but coffee will only be great if you have good beans...that's what it all boils down too...

if I have friends coming over and have time to sit down to chitchat, ill take them here, but if I want coffee and real good mocha...ill take them to Café Venice...

staff are nice, pleasant and they give good service.
author: Malou C.

description:
I came here for their single-origin espresso--their current "Sweet Tooth", the El Alto.  There is something weird about their unique origin espresso, as my macchiato was very one-dimensional in my opinion.  Overall, the espresso is good, but it was just lacking the subtle nuances and balance of the more conventional espresso blend.  Don't get me wrong--at the hands of a good barista, I have experienced excellent single-origin espresso.  I might just need a few more tries on this one.  

Rows and rows of 12oz bags of coffee beans that were almost a week past roast date. Disappointing. I ended up leaving with a bag of Hacienda Carmona, Guatemala that was roasted a few days prior.  

I wore my square glasses in a veiled attempt to "fit in" at this place.  But I think everyone just looked at me thinking, "Look at that dumb girl wearing square glasses in a veiled attempt to fit in with us."  Then they crossed their legs in another fashion in order to readjust their nutsacks in their tight jeans.

The logo scares me just a little... which makes it awesome.
author: Gail S.

description:
- No wifi (they used to have it)
- Not much place to sit
- Music too laud
- Good coffee, though

I can just buy a bag of coffee and make it at home.  This is not a comfortable place.
author: Daniel G.

description:
This place already lost the coffee war a few years back when it was a color war between red and blue. However, it is a significant player in the modern Bay Area coffee scene. They sure have gotten a lot if mileage out if their clever logo design. 

Here are some highlights of their history:
- when I first started going to Ritual, they were serving delicious Stumptown coffee from Portland and co-owned by Four Barrel's Jeremy Tooker. They were pretty good back then. Lots of French press coffee. 
- quality dropped when they started roasting their own beans. Hard to be as good as Stumptown starting out. 
- Jeremy Tooker left, taking hipness with him, leaving the shop full of more regular people or SF state faculty types. 
- later they focused on brewing coffee with the Clover brewer, the ultra-expensive robot French press (later bought out by Starbucks). The benefit of this was a menu of drip coffee options. 
- they later switched to making drip coffee using a Hario V60 pour-over station. At first, they didn't know how to do it right, quickly dumping a pitcher of water into the cone and and calling it a "90 second extraction." Thankfully they've gotten better at it. 

Ritual specializes in light roasted single origin coffee beans and a changing "seasonal" espresso

Seems like they have gotten better more recently. I appreciate that they stay open later than most modern coffee roaster shops in town.  I've had a few good cups at the Valencia St and Napa locations. 

Their beans are hit or miss though. I once got a bag so bland I had to dump it halfway through because there are just too many great local coffee roasters to waste time.
author: RK W.

description:
The quality of the coffee is great. 

Everything else about this place I pretty much hate. The disinterested, unnecessarily slow service, the long wait, the noise... In general it's an awful experience. 

If you can get through the gauntlet of hipsters and wait long enough, you'll get a great cup of coffee. 

Personally, I'd rather go anywhere else.
author: Eric M.

description: I went here to study, paid $4 for a burned-tasting latte only to discover (via a tiny handwritten sign) that they are no longer offering wifi to preserve the sense of community or whatever. I felt bamboozled and could only listen to the two artists next to me talking about "realness"for a few, dragging minutes before I left underwhelmed.
author: Nan H.

description:
As an everyday coffee drinker, Ritual Coffee so far has been my favorite coffee in the city, out ranking both Blue Bottle (http://www.yelp.com/biz/EFefgQdk_19WxQXvVtwEog) and Cafe Algiers (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ythBjfjRTJflsLIHXfF0Rw).  Unfortunately, I don't live or work near this place, so my visits here will be limited.  For some reason (guy tells me it's the way they roast their beans), their coffee was smoother and less bitter without being watery or diluted.  

Coffeeratings.com (as of June 2006) had Ritual Coffee #2 just below now long-time mysteriously closed Cafe Organica (http://www.yelp.com/biz/t3w1ZJGnAX8c1AhAYQqDrw).

SF Weekly 2007 Best Coffee.
author: トモ T.

description: Really really good almond milk cappuccino in minimalist pretty designed space and a great location.
author: Joe M.

description: Exquisite lattes - galettes to die for - great atmosphere - such a happening place. We returned several times during our short stay in the Bay area, even when we really didn't "need" coffee - just because it was sooo good! The David Bowie day was especially memorable, with all staff members dressing as different David Bowie personas.
author: Kathy S.

description: No more wifi! Whats the point of that. The remodel turned it into the same old stuffy cafe thats all over sf.
author: Joe P.

description: Tired of the standard trendy coffee places such as Starbucks, Peet's, and CBT, I decided to see what San Francisco had to offer and found Ritual on Yelp. Deciding to follow the advice of fellow yelpers I trekked over to Ritual and found myself staring at the coffee makers (should I call them baristas?) delicately making coffee through paper cone filters using flasks and then pouring them into 12oz coffee cups. It seemed more like art than anything else I've experienced at the national chains.  The gentleman making the coffee was very helpful as I explained I was a newbie and was looking at specific tastes. He recommended several coffees including Sweet Tooth and Organic Hama.  The coffees were spot on, not too acidic and not overly strong.  Each coffee on the menu had a description of what it taste like such as: peaches and watermelon, or lilac and lavender.  The coffees I had a sweet note to them, but I wasn't sure if it tasted like the description. Nonetheless I was hooked and decided to buy 1lb each of the coffees I sampled. At $20 a pound it can be a bit pricey, but since I was on vacation I decided to splurge.
author: William T.

description:
Great Coffee

Daughter and I went coffee crawling in the City after I came up for a conference. They had this  "Siberia Processing Experiment Coffee #3" from El Salvador. We tried it and it was pretty good. Had a slightly different taste, but that was okay. I also tried their Sweet Tooth espresso. It was pretty awesome. Second best I've ever had.

Comfortable surroundings too. They didn't make you feel like you had to drink and run, like some places do.

Definitely worth a SHOT when in the City.
author: Susan J.

description:
Pretty good mocha.

Pretty busy in here typically--could be hard to find a table if you're planning on doing work.
author: Thuan N.

description: I am amazed at how friendly the staff here is. I just moved to San Francisco and am so impressed by this place. There is often a line but they are so fast and efficient that it never takes much time. I just get a regular coffee and it never disappoints.
author: Anna M.

description:
New decor is sterile and has lost the warmth and mystery of the old Ritual, once an institution. The coffee is good, but the environment feels like an IKEA cafe. Sharp corners and hard surfaces create a deafening echoes of chatter. Really unfortunate "update" to chic and modern aesthetics. 

Without the woody, welcoming character I don't have much reason to return. RIP Ritual.
author: Alex N.

description: Their coffee is delicious and the ambience is soo typical of Valencia/Mission/SF.  You just stepped into Hipster central and did not even know it until you look around.  It's hilarious since it's real life.  But still, their coffee is delicious especially their latte.   I love how their pour the foam into a pretty flower.  They are serious about their coffee and it's obvious.  Have come here in the past to do work and there is a lot of space for it.  Seems pretentious but I love it anyways.
author: Vivian T.

description:
(See pic)

Came here craving for their Clover coffee and to my disappointment they sold the machine. The good news is they started using V-60 single drip coffee. The coffee was still very good and while it's not as smooth, the taste was actually quite good.
author: T L.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I'm coming back, but next time I'm going for the espresso drinks.  Sometimes I have to be careful whenever I get those since many of the good spots like Blue Bottle, Four Barrel and such can really get you wired.  

I came here on a Sunday afternoon to get a small pick me up with the Cepris drip coffee.  Although there a few bits of fruity notes, it's just not great to me.  Plus it was on the acidic side which I absolutely hate when it comes to coffee.  I prefer a Blue Bottle Bella Donovan and Three Africans Drip or a Tesora and Philharmonic from Philz.  With that said, scratch off drip coffee here, but room for trying out the espresso drinks.

Aside from that, the line gets pretty ridiculous, but the place seems to offer a nice vibe for a cafe.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Came here 1 night with the bf & his friend for a bit of catch up time.  This is the guys' usual spot but it was  my first time.  Since it was getting close to my old lady bed time, I opted for the Rose mint tea.  It was very menthol'y @ first but it became very soothing & calming as I got used to the taste.  I wish I had asked where I can get some of this tea because it would be perfect for sick days or after a long & stressful day of office politics.

I had a great time & I really enjoyed the vibe of this place.  Next time we come back, I am going to try their coffee - even with the early bed time.
author: Karen S.

description:
My bf saw their coffee menu and was confused, like hold on,  I just want a plain old cup of coffee, why are there 3 of them and is that one really 4 bucks? You sure you wanna go here, I mean I want my coffee to taste like, you know, coffee, not like gooseberries and plums. what the hell is a gooseberry anyway? 

Then he has his coffee and we're walking down the street, and he's like, okay, this is pretty damn good coffee. I still don't know what a gooseberry is, but this is good.

I think that just about sums up the Ritual Grounds experience. You wait in a long line, spend three times as much as you would for a cup of coffee, ogle at the hipsters a little, wonder why some people in there are so rude and snooty, can't quite understand how you can describe coffee like wine, then you have the coffee and you kinda get it. 

I don't know if I could ever make this my regular coffee place because the ambiance is just a little too hipster for me, though I must say, those robot and donut paintings totally make up for it, because, well, they're just awesome. That said, if I'm in the area and the line isn't too long and annoying, I will definitely get a cup. I did buy a bag of their sweet tooth espresso that I'm excited to try at home, hoping for the same good coffee minus the line of hipsters.

Not like I'm a hipster-hater, I'm in an MFA program in SF, so I have a few hipster friends and the hipster stereotype is far too narrow (hipsters are people too. There's a person behind those thick rimmed glasses and skinny jeans drinking PBR) It's only the  "I'm too cool for cool" thing I can't stand. Lighten up, have a cup of coffee and smile once in awhile. 

In short, the coffee is good.
author: Charlene D.

description:
Went back a second time and Brin was my barista. He was quite knowledgeable and happy to discuss espresso technique/philosophy with me - very personable.

This time, the shot pulled was much better and the drink was overall quite good. 

I went late at night so there was no line, so I'm not sure if the disorganization I experienced before was normal or not.

Overall it was good, but not good enough for me to pass up Four Barrel which is about 8 blocks down Valencia St.
author: Bernard F.

description:
Cool place with tons of seating. I ordered a cappuccino and really enjoyed it. When I'm in the area I will definitely be stopping here again.

And the barista gave my cappuccino a foam heart! *squee*
author: Jennifer P.

description: I was really disappointed by my experience here. I had a latte and my friend had a macchiato. The latte tasted like straight up milk because I was barely able to taste any coffee. It wasn't even hot so I felt like I had paid for a cup of lukewarm fatty milk (yuck!). The macchiato had a very displeasing dry and bitter aftertaste. My friend added some of my latte (or should I say milk?) to her macchiato to try to make it better, but it didn't help. We couldn't even finish half of our drinks and left the place wishing we had gone to Philz or Blue Bottle instead. I will admit that the designs they put on their drinks are a nice touch tho.
author: Stacey H.

description:
I have to say that, since my last post, my opinion has changed.  Partially because I've been back again and had positive experiences but also because the owner contacted me herself to apologize for my negative experience.

I can't say how nice and sincere her apology was ... just goes to show that they didn't really deserve the two stars I gave them earlier (maybe that employee just deserved the two stars).  

Looking forward to going back again soon for some great coffee :)
author: Banana S.

description:
I guess I work best when I'm slightly annoyed by my atmosphere because despite my deep seeded hatered for all that is hipster I choose "The Hipster Haven" in one of the most gentrified neighborhoods of SF to study. Great job Jade! 

Skinny jeans, ironic fashion choices, psuedo-political grandstanding  and attempts at street cred aside I like their caps. Actually I like the fact that their caps make me jittery and my heart beat faster than a hummingbirds and that by the end of the day I'm going through my caffiene withdrawls and get stabby with strangers. It's my crack... I only wish they would give me a really dry cap. And when I ordered an iced latte it was a bit watery maybe one more shot? More outlets in front of house where it's nice and bright too.

 In the end my caffiene fueled hipster annoyance really helps get my writing done.
author: Jade W.

description:
If art is as much about the process as it is about the product, then Ritual Coffee Roasters is a studio and its cups are its galleries.

Yes, the menu can be pricey (like its neighboring real estate) and the place is full of hipsters (whatever that means), but the brews are solid and the baristas are meticulous.  Anyone that can appreciate a solid cup of coffee MUST watch these baristas at work.  The space is noisy, comfortable (but not cozy), and often crowded.  There is also free wifi but limited electrical outlets.
author: Diane N.

description:
The remodeled Ritual is beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. It feels open and airy, while remaining comfortable and inviting. This kind of design runs the risk of feeling cold or sterile, but in this case the simplicity of the lines lets the materials shine -- wood, metal, neon, and a burst of greenery in the back.

You can see their years of cafe experience in the new flow, which allows plenty of space for a line and a large standing bar across from the counter. And, a decade after becoming one of the first SF coffee shops to offer free WiFi, they've made the welcome move of switching it off completely. This will certainly generate criticism from the exact people I'm looking to avoid.

Excellent work.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
cute modern coffee shop on valencia.
3 stars because the cappuccino wasnt that great.
i bought the glass jars they have as an option as well instead of paper cups. glass jars r cute and reusable.. 

overall kind of pricey.. 

i'll try another coffee there next time. but.. cute place to study/hang/kill time
author: Catherine Y.

description:
I'm pretty sure I've written a review of my favorite coffee roasters in the City.   It's okay though, I'll rewrite over and over if I have to!

Let me preface by saying that I love Blue Bottle Coffee and that I will not do a disservice to Ritual or Blue Bottle by comparing them to Philz.  don't get me wrong, I like Philz too but THEY ARE DIFFERENT STYLES OF ROASTERS!  Sorry for the caps but I still don't understand why people try to compare them.

Ritual happens to be my favorite for the seasonal Blends.  The Hibernator is like Hall of Fame beans.  I'm a sucker for espressos and if you are too, then you must try their seasonals.  Right now, I think it's called the Poor Baby which I think is lacking in flavor and is high in acidity/tartness.  I know a lot of people like that combination for the summer but I miss the richness and cleanness of their past seasonals.

The Sweet Tooth is a nice consistent blend.  I usually only get this when I'm not too fond of the seasonal blend.  This one is mild yet satisfying with a mild citrus and a bit of creamy aftertaste.

Still my favorite after all these years!
author: Anthony L.

description: Update: 5 stars for customer service. The business got back to me and let me know it was a mistake oversight that YELP did not get updated with construction hours and extended an offer to make it right. Have been visiting their kiosk off Hayes for the best single origin coffee around, and stoked to know that their original location does indeed open at 6AM for those early morning call times. Thanks again, RITUAL!
author: Molly K.

description: I'm totally a coffee snob. I had the best americano at Ritual. It was the perfect temperature, didn't leave a lingering after taste. I'm counting down to the next time I'm in the mission.
author: Lexi M.

description:
What can I say about Ritual that hasn't already been said in their (mostly glowing) 1,200-plus reviews?!

OK, if you get your sorry, hungover self there before 8 AM on a weekend morning, it's not terribly busy. Well, at least it isn't the morning after St. Patrick's Day...which was when I went. I even had a place to sit and read for a while. 

Awesome coffee--even though I had hot coffee and I normally have iced. 

It's tough for me to decide whether I like it better than Blue Bottle. I know I know...#firstworldproblems
author: Zulu Q.

description: Quintessentially hipster Ritual knows their coffee. Baristas are a good set of folks. Lack of WiFi and poor cell signal in the Mission makes this joint, unfortunately, brutally unworkable.
author: Valentin B.

description: No wifi. Coffee was bitter and the service not very welcomming! Too bad because the place is well designed!
author: Chantal B.

description:
Nothing like getting my hipster bike fixed at Valencia Cyclery, then getting my hipster coffee at Ritual.

So much hipster, it bleeds vermillion.

Still. It is good coffee.
author: Adrianna T.

description: The coffee was okay but the line was too long. The seating outside is sort of neat.
author: Tiff W.

description:
This place rocks.

The coffee is locally sourced. The music is awesome. Only negative is that it is always packed because of how cool this place is.

It's full of Mac computers and developers programming away. I guess what do you expect in an SF coffee shop?
author: Braden B.

description:
Pretty typical specialty coffee roaster/shop with great coffee options, lots of seating (though often full) and a hip location in the Mission.  Drinks are ordered at the first counter, you pay at the second, and pick up your drinks at the third.  Excellent quality, knowledgeable staff, and great vibe.  

Only complaint: the music, though I appreciated their taste, was so loud it made almost any communication/productivity impossible.  On the other hand, this may be their technique to keep people from staying too long.  Clever.
author: Dan R.

description:
I love a barista who can make an espresso drink with some panache. I'm a sucker for that, it's true. Look like you know your shit when you're pulling a shot and frothing up some milk and you get three stars right off the bat. The drinks are all made with tons of style at Ritual. Despite this, though, the latte was average, with a hint of bitterness. I'm sure I'd go back, because anything can be "off" on any given day, from the beans to the espresso machine, hell, human error, whatever. 

If you expect the typical coffeehouse environment, you'll get that here, complete with derivatives of an archetype: the Young Coffeehouse Dwellers. Their styles of dress and hair may change, but their "collective soul" (ugh, I can't believe I just used that expression) lives on across the globe.
author: Joi B.

description:
I've noticed a recent uptick in the number of Ma & Pa shops beginning to serve Ritual these days. This isn't  a problem by any stretch, in fact their caffeine offering is usually much improved by this decision, but I was becoming more and more anxious that I hadn't been to their flagship store on Valencia. Ritual continues to increase their stranglehold on the fine city of San Francisco and I knew nothing about their inner sanctum. Unacceptable!

I ventured into the Mission on a - well, a mission - to discover what made Ritual tick. With so many independent cells all over the city I figured I've got something to learn, right? It's like Megalomaniacal Dictator 101.

I WAS a bit disappointed. Blue Bottle's got bubbling beakers and such, and I would model my secret lair after Four Barrel in a heartbeat, but Ritual doesn't have much flair. The space is nice, don't get me wrong - it's pleasant even - but it lacks that attitude and panache. The accent walls were nice, the old school lightbulbs were charming, and it's a good place to crack open a laptop, but as THE Ritual, it fell a bit short. And why were there no robot minions making coffee? 

As I mentioned, I do enjoy a cup of Ritual Roast from time to time. So, I decided to square up and order the drink on which I judge all other coffee shops: double shot americano - or as I like to call it "the firing squad". Perhaps while soaking in the ambiance I might find some hidden passageway to their insidious inner workings.  I regret to say that I've had MUCH better americano. It was... weak. And it felt small in my iron fist.

HOWEVER! The homemade "oreo" cookie was to kill for! If nothing else, they will make it onto my Chosen list just for this. It was the perfect compliment to my drink, and I dare say it would go well with ANY coffee-based drink. 

Overall, the experience was good, and I'll definitely go back. 3 stars! And I hold out hope that the creepy stairs in the back lead to some kind of torture chamber.
author: Dan W.

description:
I really enjoy the atmosphere and the coffee. 

They have great seasonal blends and excellent service.  The baristas are really friendly and add a nice personal touch to the great coffee.  You might have to wait a little longer for you coffee but it's well worth the wait.

I also enjoyed the music selection, but I can understand why some people wouldn't.  

Every time I go to the mission this is one of my first stops.
author: Jason S.

description:
Oh god. I went here for the first time this morning just to try it out and immediately got a very unpleasant pretentious vibe from the place. The line was long, but the barista who took my order was very nice, so I had hope and sat down to wait for my coffee.

The girl who eventually plopped it on the counter barely even mumbled the order, so it was a miracle I even knew it was there - I just happened to be looking at her when she did it. I went over and asked her if it was whateveritwascalled, and she looked at me with a surly expression and nodded as if she were having a pretty terrible morning. Maybe she was. But jeez.

Took a sip of the coffee...and was in shock. It was by far the worst cup of coffee I'd ever had from a public place, even worse than the stuff brewed by the 72 cup monster that gets dusted off in my old school's library at finals time. I still drank that. This stuff was watery and strangely sour. I found myself wondering if someone had spit vinegar into it.

I finished it only because it cost so much and I wanted the caffeine.

The Blue Fig, where I got a delicious cup yesterday morning, gave me great and smiling service and a comfortable and cozy unpretentious atmosphere. It's just a block or so away. Do yourself a favor and go there instead.
author: Carly G.

description:
Ritual in mission has a nice big interior for the laptop crowd and the chit-chat crowd.  They also make lovely lattes.  REALLY lovely, like a smaller cute cup with a heart shape latte art.  Sweet!  

But it still doesn't top over my beloved Blue Bottle..... yet.
author: Carina N.

description: Nice artisan coffee, although I much preferred the Ritual coffee I had at La Stazione (http://www.lastazionesf.com) over in Portrero HIll more! My $2.50 espresso was nice, and paired well with the $1.50 caramel wafer sold at the counter, bitter meets sweet. However, my experience was dampened by the very, very loud foreground music; slow moving line (although the counter service was quite pleasant); tables that were both too large  and too small, all at once; slow WIFI; paltry, hipster baked goods section (lots of large Black Jet cookies, which are also available at the Ferry Building) with no vegan options; and lack of outlets for laptops. Plus I felt that my small black glasses were neither large enough nor black enough for me to fit in, and drinking coffee while feeling left out is no fun.
author: Debora L.

description: They are increasing their price. I don't think I can afford to come here everyday. Will be decreasing to maybe once a week.
author: J C.

description: Kind of looks like an Apple Store. Tasty coffee, overpriced but still tasty. your friends will cease to respect you for going here, by the way.
author: Maxx B.

description: Very smooth nitro cold brew!! The service can be improve, but do give them a break since there are many customers most of the time
author: Don F.

description: I like this place. Good coffee and they're open late on the weekends. There are usually tables in the back to work on, separate from the service bustle at the front. No outlets to plug into and no wifi so it doesn't end up a laptop graveyard. Looking forward to spending a lot of Saturday evenings here.
author: Natalie P.

description:
I don't get it.  I just don't.  I had the pricey ($5) drip coffee and it tasted like sinigang.  SInigang is a Filipino dish with a tamarind broth--sour.

Is this what hipsters taste like?
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Exactly what I want in a coffee house: 
- great coffee made by people who know what they're doing
- plenty of space to sit and work
- free wifi
- lots of hipsters and people that at least dress cooler than me
- interesting food options
- reasonable price (for a GREAT coffee)

No brainer: 5 stars.
author: Gary C.

description: A really cool place to chill and enjoy a cup of coffee.  I definitely recommend this place.
author: Vira P.

description:
REALLY great coffee, free wi-fi, friendly service.  

You could come here to really educate yourself in regards to your coffee drinking.  Great tasting notes accompany almost all selections.   

Highly Recommend.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Seriously, no turbinado sugar? What's up with that?

Good thing I donned my skinny jeans and scarf with my Mac in one hand and iPhone in the other so I could fit right in, but more importantly so I could receive halfway decent service that actually involves the use of one's voice and not just mental telepathy or a silent nod. 

Next time I'll bring my own turbinado sugar for my mediocre (but pretty) decaf cappuccino.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
On my trip to SF, I had cappacino at several top coffee houses, including (not naming names, but hinting) the glass container of RGB=(0,0,255) and the one with four wild boar heads on the wall.  Of the two cappas here, one was perfect, and if not the best I've ever tasted, then certainly tied.  To give you a comparison with the other top places' cappacinos (which I also found to be excellent), this one, relative to a Russian MiG weight, was a KiloGram Better (KGB) than the other places. i.e. not much, but enough to be the best.

There was a small line to take my order, but the staff were concentrating on quality, neither rushin' nor stallin'.  I make one revolution looking around for a seat, and all but one of the tables were taken with hipsters with their laptops.  Note:  napkins are paper, not Lenin.  When finished, the customers practice collectivism (i.e. taking cups and trash to the back counter).

My tongue was not Left with any unpleasant bitter aftertaste, and yet the flavor sequence with each sip was all there to enjoy.

For the uninitiated:  I like cappacino, because the steamed milk (from Ma's cow) in espresso avoids an otherwise cold war.  For great cappacino, there is no need to add sweetener.

The red flag outside is suggestive of USSR Communist flag, even though the owner is allegedly not a communist.  It's retro, according to some folks.  The red flag coupled with the two classes of people outside on the sidewalk (hipsters walking by the homeless) brought back memories of the Indian Coffee House in Kolkata.  (see http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g304558-d1196423-r116323509-Indian_Coffee_House-Kolkata_Calcutta_West_Bengal.html#REVIEWS)

This Party of the first part deserves top Marx and their winning award articles belong on Reddit.

I will be back.  Congrats, Ritual, on serving me the best ever.
author: Larry B.

description:
Let it be known that I am serious about my coffee. I love it black and dark and this place delivers. They have about 3 different coffees on tap (well, on drip) and they are absolutely delicious. As for the place itself, it gets crowded... very crowded. I don't know if it's because the coffee is so good or because the hipsters are so... well I can't think of a good adjective for them. If you're here to work, then the best of luck to you. The internet isn't bad however finding a table, let alone an outlet, is very difficult. That doesn't seem to stop people though. Tables aside, the music can be a problem. Depending on who's there it can range from loud crap to semi-loud not-quite-crap. That being said, I love coming here. Nothing can scare me away from coffee as good as this and the hipster-watching is as good as it gets.

Oh, one last thing. Whatever you do, don't get their mochas. Just... don't.
author: Dylan T.

description:
Not being a disaffected hipster, I wasn't sure if I was legally allowed into Ritual, but once I slipped past the guards, I found a damn good cup of coffee in a space which seems to be a pseudo-ode to the defunct Soviet empire.  But then, who doesn't like a good sickle-esque emblem?

I dig the location right on Valencia, and was simply meeting a friend here, so had no problems either finding a table or a plug for my laptop. 

Had the Guatemalan drip, and was impressed with the complexity and sweetness for a mass brew.  Falls a tad short of Blue Bottle's individual drips, but if Ritual keeps this up, I just may go ex-pat and fill out my communist party documents....right after I grab some ice cream from Bi-Rite.
author: Ethan R.

description:
I get that most people think this place is too pretentious and "hip" -- and they're right -- but who cares? You'll be judged no matter where you go, and you're not exactly going to a cafe to try and fit in. Unless you are. Then no one can help you. At least in my experience, the baristas here were nothing but friendly. Unfortunately, I must agree with certain previous posters who say Ritual's air of snobbery isn't backed up by its coffee. I had a perfectly good espresso, but what killed it for me was the Miraflores pour-over they served me -- it had no discernible flavor, leaving me feeling like I'd paid $5 for a cup of black water.

I will give this place another chance soon, though.
author: Eddy P.

description:
Ritual Coffee Roasters is a pretty unique coffee place with unique coffee flavors. Their coffee flavors seem to rotate depending on what beans they get. The coffee are made individually dripped! A big bonus! It comes out really fresh. There's a long line out the door, but it was definitely worth it.

The shop is a really interesting place to be at. There's quite a unique mix of people here from people reading newspaper to people with their laptops. The crowd seems to be the the younger type of people who are still in college or just finished college.
author: Steven B.

description: Tried Ritual for the first time recently and it did not disappoint. I got a drip coffee from Guatemala and had it black. It had a fairly acidic flavor to it with some fruity undertones, quite good. The decor is hip and modern and I loved all the art installs they had around the shop. Got my coffee to go this time but it looks like a great place to spend an afternoon catching up with a friend or working on your laptop. I'll be back when in the area to try more of their offerings.
author: Kevin N.

description:
I'm screwed.

I paid these guys a visit today in the Mission. God, I hate hipsters.

Had a double ristretto of their High Striker. Bought a 12oz bag of their beans. As a graphic designer, I decided I liked their logo, so I bought one of their attractive mugs.

$30.

Ouch.

But damn, that espresso was absolutely phenomenal. So now I'm ruined. Now I sip my watery stuff at home, and have realized several things...

a) I need to learn to pull a shot properly.
b) The beans I thought were good enough... aren't.
c) Mixing milk with a quality espresso - even a well made latte or capp - is tantamount to blasphemy.

Their espresso is worth four stars. But the sheer volume of hipsters - we're talking an infestation that would require a phone call to the Orkin man - shears another star off the rating. Which I'm sure the patrons of Ritual will blog about after riding home from their job at the vintage clothing store on their fixie...
author: Gary E.

description: A really nice open space.  The baristas took great care in making a good soy latte, and yet the line moved along at a decent pace so that was nice.   It didn't feel as pretentious as Four Barrel.  You had people working on laptops, or there to meet work collaborators or friends, so it was a good mix.   There were some sofas as well as regular tables and chairs.
author: Vivian W.

description: They don't quite match four barrel in ambiance but make up for it with flavor. If they are not hands down the number one craft coffee shop in SF, I don't know who is!
author: Hunter S.

description:
I'm not really a coffee drinker, but I think Ritual is tops for tea. It seems difficult to find coffee shops in this city that serve tea properly or tea shops in this city that aren't too twee. 

Ritual does it right using loose leaf tea from red blossom and cups with strainers and lids (no tea bags! Coffee Bar :| ). The water is also a decent temperature. I'd say it's slightly too hot for green and slightly too cold for black so it works for both if you pay attention to the steeping time.  Some places (I'm looking at you Coffee Bar!) use water that is way too hot. Price seems about right for tea too considering that they'll continue to give you hot water to re-steep.

As for the space, my only quibble is that the areas near the plugs aren't as well lit as the areas without them. I like their taste in music too although it can be a little difficult to study to some times. And it might just be me, but my connection to their wifi is pretty weak, which is both a blessing and a curse. Otherwise, the fact that they have multiple bathrooms and let me sit there all day is great.
author: Andrea L.

description:
The other day I branched out from my usual coffee shop to check out this overly-hyped place. While I was pleased with my latte, I'm not entirely sure what all the fuss is about here.  BUT, I find the place a bit cold and industrial, with its minimalist decor and warehouse feel. But hey - maybe minimalism is in, and if that's your thing, you'll definitely dig this place. I just happen to prefer smaller, more intimate and colorful places to work. 

That said, the place itself is indeed very spacious and offers ample seating for people like me who like to camp out typing away all day fueled by caffeine and coffee cake. But because this place is so trendy, the size of the place doesn't seem to make finding a seat any easier, given that it is just ALWAYS busy. 

One nice touch though is their wireless network doesn't require a password, which saved me my usually inevitable trip back up to the counter to ask for the password. (I know, I know. I'm revealing my laziness here.) But hey! In a place as busy as this, it can take several minutes to get a barista's attention if you want to pay them the courtesy of waiting for a natural breaking point in their work to ask.

Otherwise another positive thing about Ritual is the music they play is ideal background music. I find many places are so self-conscious about NOT playing Top 40 tunes or anything that is even remotely popular that the music tends to be experimental and consequently distracting. 

So, though this place is probably too busy and big for my taste, I'd have no problem joining a friend there again or even attempting to find a spot to work. Not a favorite, but definitely more than A-OK. (If there were half star options in Yelp, it'd definitely deserve three and a half.)
author: Anne D.

description: Huge place with a very open feel. Solid coffee but inconsistent with the pricing of a flat white some days it is the cost of a cap and others a latte... expensive coffee but in a trendy and convenient location. Made better with the outdoor 'boat' seating area.
author: Livia M.

description:
I've only ever ordered espresso, or straight coffee at Ritual, so I, personally, don't have a beef with these folk.  However, my European pal had a bit of a problem while at Ritual with me.  He'd wanted a long-pull espresso, and they don't do that, I guess, EVER.  My euro pal was aghast, and kept repeating what it was that he wanted.  The response was just same each time: "No, we only pull ristretto."  

To show you the rube I am, I didn't know at the time that "ristretto" meant short-pulled espresso.  I mean, I sorta sussed it out based on context, so I was cool.  I do think, however, that homeboy behind the counter, who, btw, wasn't from Italy, could have made the effort a bit and just told us in plain in English what it was that they only do there at Ritual.

Euro friend, deflated from his repeated attempts at trying to get what he wanted, finally just ordered an espresso.  With cup of coffee in hand, I took a seat.  From my vantage point I could see the European, en route to sitting down, putting tap water in his espresso, and the look of horror on the barista's face as he did so.  The barista, lacking any sense of decorum, mouthed to we-only-pull-ristretto-guy, "that's disgusting!"  Even if you do find it "disgusting," coffee dude, could you, at least, keep it to yourself, or whisper that shit to your co-worker?  Thanks.
author: Bea B.

description: I had coffee here one time and although it was good and non acidic but 5 minute wait for a cup. Also, I hear it is expensive.  I wonder if they grab your cup away if you arent' waiting for a google bus or living in a $3K per month Mission studio.
author: Dan L.

description:
I LOVE coffee, but this place serves the nectar of the gods!!!

My mind is officially blown that coffee can be this friggin' good!!
author: Leesa S.

description:
This is one of my favorite coffee shops in the mission area! Yea it is definitely not a cheap cup of coffee but it is most definitely worth it. It is definitely a great splurge on coffee!

This spot is definitely a hipster spot....in my opinion, but that's because it has very good coffee!
author: Rae R.

description:
One of the coffee heavyweights in San Francisco. They don't fuck around. Handcrafted coffee is the best item to get, they have an ever-changing rotation of roasts. I've gotten the Libertad the last few times I've gone and it's been solid.

Unlike many other coffee shops, they have a good selection of pastries as well. I had an apricot vegan bread last time that was quite good.

This place is usually packed, but turnover is high enough that you'll be able to find a seat if you wait long enough. Great location for meeting up with a friend since it's not too loud, but it's not so quiet that the entire place can hear your conversation.

I rank this up there with Philz and Blue Bottle for Bay Area chains. Definitely check it out for your caffeine fix.
author: Rishi G.

description:
J and I headed into the city via BART for our own little caffeine crawl. Besides Ritual, we were going to try Fourbarrel and Sight Glass as well. This Ritual is conveniently located within walking distance from the 24th and Mission station, which is key if you're going into the city to try this place out.

The entire Mission/Valencia area is so eclectic; you could probably spend a whole day going in and out of the various stores laden with local flavor. Plus there are a ton of cute eateries up and down these streets as well. 

The place itself is quintessential Mission district - urban decor and branding, beards, chrome packs, and good looking persons - you'll hear no complaints from me! The baristas were also very kind. There is plenty of seating by the window/bar plus lots of tables in the back (though don't be surprised if it's packed). Coming from the cramped cafes of Berkeley, the spacious interior was a welcome sight!

We only tried the lattes, but they were very yummy. They went down smooth and were gone in no time. I'll definitely come back to give their coffee a try, but I'm already in love with the Fourbarrel roasts!
author: Jen L.

description:
Downgraded. So it's good coffee definitely not great, sorry to disappoint all the faithfuls.  I was one.

Of all the times I've gone here, down to my stupid red 'heavy drinker' frequent buyer card, I've got to say, today set me off.  Last attempt to find personality past the ONE nice guy at the counter who earned star #2.

The female barista is dry and a flat out rude c word.   Get over yourself already and button your g'dam shirt, your saggy tits make me want to spit out my coffee.
author: Athena S.

description:
I don't like this place but I keep going back. 

The coffee is just too intense! I prefer Blue Bottle, Philz and Roger's which have smoother mellower & darker blends available. 

The staff is usually a little rude & pretentious. I like to be able to ask questions about what I'm ordering without being scowled at. Granted the last time I went in the barrista was friendlier. 

It's really dark inside. Some more sunlight always makes my coffee shop experience more appealing. 

But, sometimes I want to feel hip and hang out with the hipsters so I go here anyway.
author: Julia H.

description: Loved the soy latte and social atmosphere. No wifi is actually pretty awesome. So much happy buzz!
author: Madeline A.

description:
This is my favorite coffee place in San Francisco both because of the design and the coffee. They offer a rotating menu of delicious coffees that show a variety of flavors and the selection is tied with a brief description of the specific roast they are doing so there really is something for everyone. The baristas really know what they're doing and feature cool designs in the lattés.

The café is also really cool, they have a great music selection. The tables and the decor are bare wood and it makes the inside seem very stripped down, but also natural. It's sort of a natural interpretation on an industrial theme. It can get a bit crowded, but it's a really cool place to read or talk. The one shortcoming is the lack of good pastries, but other than that, Ritual really hits it out of the park!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
In terms of a coffee place... this is a very good place.

The actual coffee house itself is pretty standard.  Good music and ambiance.  Space for people to work.  Trendy lighting and an overall nice presentation and feel.  They even have WiFi (which I used to write this review :P).  But that isn't what gets this place 5 starts.

This place gets its 5 stars for the coffee they made.  It was fantastic; well balanced and smooth with subtle but strong hints of flavor that offset one-another very well.  This is only the first time I was here but I never give out 5 stars unless the place deserves it.  The coffee at this place deserves it.

I wish they had a better system for telling you your coffee was ready though.  But that is a small complaint at best.  I hope to come back again and be just as impressed with the coffee; and I will be back, no doubt there.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Delicious coffee and I usually order it at other cafes in the city...and unfortunately it's going to stay that way....

 I decided to stop by this location the other day to get myself a soy latte (which was very tasty) but the girl who worked there was just plain rude! I told my sister to get my change and instead of handing it to her, the chick puts it in the tip jar...WHO DOES THAT?!? It's the customer's decision whether or not they want to tip... Sorry Ritual on Valencia, I'm going to have to take my business elsewhere...
author: Christiana R.

description:
I think the appeal of these "cool" and "hip" and "trendy" and organic/fair trade/etc coffee places escapes me.

Just give me a bag of decent coffee beans and I'll make it myself and enjoy it without having to deal with the almost neurotic-ness of the Mission.

I did have an expresso here. Don't remember its name. It burned on its way down. Fairly decent.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place scares me.  Lots of hip automatons with laptops looking cool and important, sipping $5 cups of coffee. I asked the "barista" what the ritual was, the gave me a vague answer that sounded like cult-speak.  The ritual is... they pry $5 out of you pocket for a cup of joe without you feeling it.

Philz gets a pass because his coffee is unique and he has created an aura that has captured real caffeine junkies attention.  Hipsters, burning men, police, firepersons etc.
author: Gregory L.

description: Of the plentitude of third wave coffee roasters in the area, this one is not one I consider among the best. Each to their own, but I don't enjoy the single drips from here or any other place that serves it. The best cup I had was a Concepcion Buena Vista from this location, but it still was not that great. What I do like, are the lattes and mochas. I actually like the mocha here because it's just like a latte, unlike those sugary desserts topped with a mountain of whipped cream that you get elsewhere. It's just foamy and smooth down the throat. Aside from the drinks, I like the story, the branding, the idea. I like the water spray mechanism they have built in to the counter. I also like the free wi-fi are this location and the 2 restrooms.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Hard to find much to complain about here.  I am as cold-blooded a coffee snob as you'll ever meet:  I roast/grind my own beans and vacuum brew them.  Ritual is not far off on that count: They're doing a sort of chemex-style brew that involves a glass funnel.  Yummy stuff.  Coffee snobs rejoice!

WiFi is free, no codes required.  Music a little loud in the back, which is the only place you can work if your laptop needs to be plugged in.  They keep the line moving relatively quickly despite having a necessarily slow brewing process.  If I lived in the Mission, this would be a frequent hang-- and I'd just have to get a spare battery...

The aesthetic is a bit cold/barren/impersonal, but the service is friendly.
author: Darren F.

description:
The owners handling of artist is offensive and mean spirited!!! Don't show your art here it's not worth the trouble. 
I myself have only gone in to see my friends art, I wasn't cool enough for the people behind the counter  to take my order.
 Maybe when I become a hipster I can come back? 
Your a Barista, Really douchebags!!!!
author: WildBill C.

description:
This place has the best lattes I've ever had. I am not a hard core coffee drinker so I love that I can get a latte and it doesn't need any sugar and it tastes so good. That helps with my diet :). I think smooth is the best way to describe it.

I've been here a gazillion times and only once was my latte not perfect. I don't love the atmosphere here as it's dark and noisy, but the lattes are truly perfection.
author: Pari S.

description:
Too-cool-for-school hipsters working there? Check.
So-so, over-roasted coffee? Check.
Spotty wireless that rarely works? Check.
High prices? CHECK!
Lack of seating? Check.
author: Will M.

description:
I arrive at approx. 8:15am on Friday.

I browse their coffee beans wall, intent on purchasing some. After reading about each of them from the signs and their coffee menu I pick one up and get in line.

When I get to the front, I ask the barista, "Which of these offerings are the boldest?"

Barista: "I think between X and Y (points to menu)."

Me: "What are the basic differences between the two?" (Yes, I read ALL of the written literature around, but I wanted a spoken, human opinion)

Barista: "(Pause)...Are you going to order anything to drink?"

Me: "No." (My intent here was to purchase beans)

Barista: (Looks and me, looks away) "....."

Me: "If it's a tossup between the two, I'll just get this one (the one already in my hand."

Barista: "(looks at me, and goes back to making drinks)....."


Serious? I don't care how good your product is, you're still in the business of RETAIL CUSTOMER SERVICE. Ritual has failed miserably in this regard. You could have told me to hold on...referred me to another barista...anything! But, simply ignoring my question? I'm sorry, that's just rude.

Their only saving grace was that the cashier that rung me up was cordial and friendly.
author: Ellis A.

description:
I'm a bit of a coffee snob. I  don't drink Starbucks or Peet's because their coffee is yucky.

Ritual is a treat for me on the weekends. When my bf says, "It's out of the way," I respond, "Ritual is always along the way." Knowing the caffeine addict I am, he nods his head in agreement. ;)

Ritual makes the best chai latte ever. I have not found a coffee shop that can make as good of a chai latte. I like Four Barrel as well, but they don't make chai lattes. What makes Ritual's chai latte special is that the chai they use is so organic and real that the latte actually tastes like chai. It's not cloyingly sweet like every other coffee shop. 

My bf always gets the pour over which is amazing as well. 

The baristas here always greet me with a smile. If you're a frequent drinker like me, don't forget to ask for their frequent buyer card where you get 1 free after 10 drinks!
author: Aggie Z.

description:
Great coffee! 

Impressed my VERY picky French and Italian bosses with this pick.
author: Caro D.

description:
1. Not enough room... It looked more like an office instead of a coffee hang out. Everyone had their own table with a computer open... It was like everyone was working from the cafe.  FUN and INVITING right?

2. The cashier didn't ask me which milk I wanted for my coffee, which I guess at some point in the pretentious world became my duty to clarify.
I like it when people who work in customer service ask which I prefer. 

3. The latte wasn't even warm(I should have asked for extra hot, once again my fault but I mean, really?)

4. I don't think I'm cool enough to be a regular here... I think I am a Peets's coffee drinker and that's it. Everyone here looks like they know what's up and maybe I really don't get it but..... That just wasn't my scene. When I go to get coffee, I don't associate it with working at a cafe for hours on end.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Great coffee, well trained baristas, beautiful cafe, but damn...the music they play here is so LOUD. I cannot stress it enough... SO-FREAKING-LOUD.

I feel like im in a punk rock concert every time I go in. Dammit, I just want a peaceful coffee shop experience.

If you guys insist on playing that noise, at least don't play it too loud. I can hardly hear myself talk in my head. 
Thank you!

P.s. I enjoy the coffee!
author: Nica M.

description:
The latte art seems to be getting better and better. the art is always fun and it's not too loud in there. I have been trying other places recently but am glad to return to ritual and see the coffee is still top notch and the baristas are smiling.

I wish they had more snacks but the homemade oreo was really tasty and chocolaty.
author: ari s.

description:
Vibe: Chill, relaxed and a plethora of computers and books out. If you're looking for a place to work with good coffee, Ritual's a good place to land.

Coffee: Superb. I've only had lattes, but their drip is supposedly also very good.

Service: Speedy and friendly. Not much time for chit-chat, but they are friendly.

Value: Can't complain. It's pretty fairly-priced when compared to Four Barrel and Blue Bottle, and considering the free wifi, you can't complain.
author: Luke B.

description:
This is a review for their coffee, solely.  I am an addict...and Ritual has made me realize I am a total coffee snob.  I go there once a week, buy a bag of beans, have them grind it to perfection, then drink the most delicious cup of coffee every morning.  What did I do before I had Ritual beans?!  How was it even possible that I tasted coffee before?  

Addict...they made me that way.
author: Wen S.

description: I'm a sucker for aesthetics. First time being here and Ritual has risen atop my fav coffee joints beside Blue Bottle and Philz. The only downside to this place is probably that they don't really indulge in the whole iced anything deal, which is fine by me. The place is narrow but has tons of seating, and even more towards the back -- perfect for dates and or study/work sessions.
author: Av A.

description:
You can cut the hipster vibe with a dull knife in here. It was almost enough for me to turn around and walk out the door in my suburban looking rugby shirt and khaki Dockers with the stretch band. However, advance word on Ritual was so good I had to try one of their minuscule cups of cappuccino. It wasn't quite heavenly, but the flavor was definitely bounding in that direction with a smoothness that I found comforting. 

I'm too spoiled by Blue Bottle and Philz to notice how impeccably handmade my cup was prepared, but the artisan approach at Ritual certainly makes the idea of nursing a cup more palatable. Laptoppers dominate most of the tables, but if you can snag a seat, it's a nice place for a quiet chat amid the piled burlap bags of coffee beans. BTW, have you seen this time-lapsed video of a typical day at Ritual? It's way cool ...http://www.flickr.com/photos/tonx/2684046303/in/set-72157606276846353/ 

COFFEE - 4 stars...a smooth cup of joe 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...relaxing vibe for all the hipsters looking to cool down before a night of clubbing, I'm supposing 
SERVICE - 4 stars...meticulous preparation is priority, smiles are secondary 
TOTAL - 4 stars...if I can't get to Blue Bottle, this may do well as my back-up plan
author: Ed U.

description: Not too impressed with the setting. The coffee is good. They do a good pour over. The espresso is average. The attitude is a bit much. The place is the main issue. No wifi, not enough seats, no place to plug a laptop in. The whole place is unwelcoming. What do you expect? Go in, get a $4 coffee, sit and compose Walden? Please!
author: John N.

description: I absolutely LOVE the new remodel. Ritual has been innovative and at the forefront of the industry for years - the new look truly reflects where they have been and aim to be. Its wifi free environment is a welcome break from our internet & screen centric world. Look up and see the beautiful garden in the back and enjoy a conversation over the perfect cup of coffee. Cannot wait to go back.
author: Sarah S.

description:
There are three options if you want Local coffee, there are probably more but if you are young and cool there are the big three: blue bottle, ritual and four barrel.

I personally think ritual has the most neutral roast, both blue bottle and four barrel impart too much character in their coffees through the roast and have more of a brand appeal, ritual does the best job at bringing out the natural quality of the beans.

Pursuing the goal of being an instant classic like coca cola is probably one of the hardest angles to take in a creative pursuit but ritual has the quality to back that claim.
author: Josh L.

description: This is my 2nd go to place for coffee, other than four barrel. I don't necessarily come here for the pour over coffee, but I get them anyways after I buy a bag of beans from them. As any pour over coffee place of course a cup of that would be more expensive than your usual plain black cup of coffee, which is fine by me since I only get 'em once in a while. But learn how to make pour over coffee yourself and their beans will not disappoint. I like my coffee plain so fresh and quality beans are very important to me. I go here for that.
author: Pam Y.

description:
Seriously....?

Taste's like the coffee I brew at home.

Dude at the counter was kinda rude.

Secret tip:  There is an uncovered plug next to the sofa in the middle of the room, facing the front door.
author: Kevin O.

description:
So, The coffee is outstanding, and I really enjoy the hipster atmosphere.

Be prepared to wait a little bit of time before you get your cup of really good coffee, though.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place is as "Mission" as you can get; I felt like an outsider with my lack of MacBook & oxfords.
Regardless,
-amazing espresso
-large space, lots of tables & couches
-pastries from Black Jet Bakery (hello, sea salt choco chip cookies & homemade poptarts!)
-good (not top40) music
If I weren't always fearful of the SF parking enforcement/meter maids stalking my car, I'd probably make the trip out here more often.
author: Jen T.

description:
VERY GOOD COFFEE! 
a couple nights ago we were down the street from this place, and after dinner I needed my bestie, yep Coffee!! 
they don't offer much of the fancy shmancy flavors such as creme brule, gingerbread, hazelnut etc... Just plain ole'  lattes, which in this case I didn't mind trying.. because it was almost 10pm and they were still opened ( I really wanted a something caramel) .. but I got a sweetened Latte ( since they didnt have a caramel coffee drink avail) . and OOOHH la la.. it was the greatest cup of latte I've had in a while.. 

simple good lattes, and open late! - happy tummy.. happy me!
author: sharlyn g.

description: Fair warning, I'm not a coffee snob, so this review is not for people who know the difference between a red eye and an americano without googling it, which is what I did to even get such terminology ;) I ordered a mocha, not really knowing what to expect because the last time I had one was years ago at a Starbucks that traumatized my desire for mocha anything anymore, but I decided to give it a try because they didn't have my usual go-to drink, a vanilla latte. Verdict? It was surprisingly tasty, and extremely balanced. With my ever-so-sophisticated palette, I tasted the right amount of coffee, milk, and cocoa (all three ingredients are in a mocha, right?) and there was no weird after taste that I get from other places that I go to. Because of this place, I am willing to give mocha another try. And hopefully when I come back I know a bit more about coffee so I'm not staring at the menu and having it look like a foreign language.
author: Christine C.

description:
Real coffee lovers, who like to explore new hip coffee spots, Those who like real coffee with no funny business (sweeteners), retro decor and loud energetic music...
The Mission area's Ritual coffee roaster is the spot.

I ordered straight espresso and added a little brown sugar and half and half.  Superb
The Bf ordered something but i can't remember what it is... :(

Both were good, Every thing was individually hand made..dripped in its own cup.


Sure wish I lived closer to this place.  :)
I docked a star off because parking was tough. I had to circle about 2-3 times to find a spot close enough to walk. :/
author: Trang K.

description: BOMB.COM yup I said it. This coffee is perfect, just the way I like it back home in Seattle. I love foam. If you dont like foam then go to Starbucks. Enjoy the taste of the coffee and the delicious velvet foam. I had the mocha and it was delicious.
author: Kayla H.

description:
I went here for the fist time last night since my friend for some reason is determined that we will hang out in the mission even though half the street parking has been eliminated with road construction. 

What is this pretension everyone complains about? We showed up half an hour before closing AND I ordered a tea drink (I know who orders tea in a place known for coffee roasting... but I seriously don't drink coffee ever). I found the staff to be polite and friendly and yes they took five minutes to make my friend's single cap, but I think it's all about quality over speediness. My barista asked how my day was going and had a real conversation with me while making my friend's cappuccino.

My tea by the way was delicious. I ordered the Golden Monkey apparently they get their tea from a family-owned Chinatown tea company. I might have to hunt down their store so I can get some for home.

I liked the space, very open and bright with different seating options from big tables to bar tables to sleek couches and coffee table groupings. If I lived in the Mission, I could see myself spending an afternoon reading here or drawing.
