author: Dani D.

description:
In a world were everyone seems to be roasting coffee and have there own unique twist, Ritual stands apart. There wasnt anything particularly spectacular about this place, but that's what made this place so awesome. The coffee wasn't under roasted or over roasted. The crowd/workers weren't particularly hip. Just good coffee, and real people, which is all too hard to find in popular shops these days.

I more than anything love to chat up barista's about the origins of there beans, and the intimacies of the roasting operation, but a good barista also knows when to let the coffee speak for itself.

Walked in on a beautiful sunday morning with a medium and very manageable line. Ordered a Latte. Enjoyed it blissfully on a open, car less Valencia. So simple, yet so awesome!

There are many great roasters in SF including 4 barrel, sightglass, and blue bottle, but Ritual has been one of my favorite. Definitely check them out.

Philz is next! Watch out!
author: John S.

description: The decaf coffee tastes bad, prices are too high, DC outlet in the wall does not work, internet incredibly slow and the background music is really annoying.
author: Lucio K.

description:
The line was out the door when we arrived on a cold Saturday afternoon. At first, I thought everyone just wanted a drink to warm up from the breeziness that day, but apparently, it's just always that crowded. That's a good sign to me. One step in the door and all you can smell is freshly brewed coffee...mmmm.

Way better than Starbuck's or Peet's, but still doesn't beat Blue Bottle. I'll give it some love for the cool ambiance inside, especially the huge coffee roaster in the back. It's got a really chill vibe and the baristas are so talented with their foam art skills. I got a kick out of watching them pour on apples and leaves.

I ordered a small latte, which was really milky, but woke me up after a few sips. Next time, I'll probably try the macchiato or the French press. Coffee doesn't hit me as hard as it used to, but that's probably because I usually order the sugary and syrupy mixed drinks from the local Starbuck's. I need to live in SF where real coffee is made...
author: Michelle W.

description:
I went again after they remodeled everything.
It looks very raw, like an hospital or airport terminal.  The music was pretty heavy and loud, so may stay was not agreable and I left after just a few minutes.  It's not welcoming.
The coffee was not that good and they don't have wifi.
author: Alex M.

description: The coffee and the space is great as always, but I am really sad to see the wifi go away. I understand the desire to attract a clientele that does not work for hours there, but most people seem to do that at any rate through tethering or otherwise. For me it is just a bit of a pain.
author: Andreas S.

description: LA LIBERTAD!!! Can I have everyday please? :) it's so good, I highly recommend it. Pretty big space, small tables to have conversations around. Great service :) highly-highly recommend if you're looking for a quality cup of joe
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Beginning my trip to SF with the coffees and having already experienced much on my previous visit and via mail order from Blue Bottle, this trip would instead target some of San Francisco's newer or less publicized locations - the first being Ritual Roasters not once, not twice, but thrice; In the Mission, at Bi-Rite, and then via The Yountville Coffee Caboose - each featuring a different blend, each a different brewing style, but each invariably impressive.

Starting with the Mission flagship, a fantastic store with an ever present line, stripped down décor, and a stereo blaring Queens of the Stoneage as hipsters tapped away on the MacBooks my first taste of Ritual would be La Soledad Sacatepequez via single cup drip and with prominent notes of vanilla, peach, and caramel this slightly acidic blend would prove the worst of the three, yet still a great cup of coffee with a clean smoky finish and hints of apple.

Moving next to the Coffee Caboose - this time prepared by Press Pot as I wandered the streets of Younville - Ritual Monte Rey Bambu from El Salvador would be a bold take on traditional Central American flavors and with a nearly syrupy mouth feel I enjoyed the sweet top notes of vanilla and chocolate so much that it ended up warranting a second cup that hinted at deeper notes of wood and citrus when enjoyed with a Red Velvet cupcake from Bouchon Bakery; a truly diverse cup of coffee my only disappointment was that the Caboose did not sell it by the bag.

My final sampling of Ritual would prove to be the best of the bunch and after a simple cup from a multi-brew pot at Bi-Rite Bakery and Creamery I progressed to the Bi-Rite store to pick up two bags of Hacienda Carmona Guatemala, a lovely single origin blend that tasted good from the pot but vastly better from my home French Press with a tongue-coating satin texture and top notes of vanilla and almond plus fruity flavors reminiscent of figs and quince lingering on the palate.
author: Michael U.

description:
From Napa to SF, I am always seeking out Ritual. The coffee ain't cheap, but good lawd, it is the very best. The Mission loc seriously looks like an apple store, or some kind of Urban Outfitters commercial. 

I tend to think of indulging in Ritual as a bit of a treat, not an everyday coffee per say, but like your favorite pair of underwear, this coffee just gives you that extra kick to make you feel "all that".

You can quote me on that, go ahead...I'm not gonna judge you. We are homies like that.
author: Alison D.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed the cozy, albeit loud atmosphere of this place. I loved that almost everyone was either hanging out with friends or clicking away at their Macbooks. The chamomile tea was great. The tea was in a cloth bag and my friend's coffee drinks were visually appealing. The coffee was rich and frothy just like we liked it. 
I opted for a vegan donut and it was so moist and fresh I ended up ordering another. Delicious!
author: Dawn C.

description: Pretty good. Kind of over-hyped. I've bought Ritual beans in the past too, and compared to other roasters theirs seem particularly unremarkable. I grabbed a cappuccino when we were staying the Mission recently and it was okay. The flavor was pretty good, foam a bit thin (nothing left in my cup after I drank it). I think their branding is stronger than their product.
author: Green T.

description:
They do a good job and it tastes great but too much of everything else -
cost, one person per one big table, trendoid attitude, volume...
author: Dizzy L.

description:
Great spot. 
The baristas care about the coffee they're making, and it shows.  
Large seating area, but it's always crowded.
author: Julian P.

description:
Ritual makes great coffee.  It takes a little while for them to make it, but it's realllly good coffee.  The couple of times that I have been there I felt like someone was going to ask me to join a cult, but alas I made it out safely.

If you have the time, try it out.  If you are in a hurry I would advise against it.
author: Laura P.

description:
4.5 Stars 

FINALLY, I can truly appreciate Ritual Coffee Roasters. It had been a while since I have been up to the bay to have Ritual Coffee so I couldn't formulate an accurate opinion of it. A place here in Los Angeles called Bru serves Ritual coffee, but their baristas are lacking and do not bring out the amazing complexities of this tasty, tasty espresso. 

Walking through the Mission, I knew I needed to buckle down and spend some time here so that I could get the full experience. The interior of the place is very similar to the slew of new coffee shops sprouting across the country-- sleek, modern, slightly industrial. It actually looked a lot like the Pasadena Intelligentsia, but without the long beer/wine bar. Prices were average, service was quick and efficient (by boutique coffee standards). 

Ordered a mocha (well balanced, not too sweet, with perfectly pulled espresso shots) and a regular coffee (strong, complex, but low in acidity). I am definitely a fan, but I think the winner of the Mission coffee war for me is Four Barrel who offered just a slightly better coffee drinking experience.
author: Frances L.

description:
Big fan of Ritual Coffee and Blue Bottle coffee.  

Blue Bottle invloves a little more flare in the prep, but both coffees are great. Just wish there was one of these places closer to my house (castro area...hint hint)

Thick foam and rich espresso in a latte are my favorite!!

Lemon oreo cookie was DEEEEElish!
author: Matt V.

description:
I'm a big fan of coffee and these guys sure know their stuff. Service was alright. The atmosphere is very hipster like. Dark, a bit run down, and very urban. I like it. 

I definitely love the coffee there. This place would be 5 stars if it wasn't so expensive. $4 for a cup of coffee? It's good and all, but damn, that's expensive. I'd much rather buy their beans and just make it at home instead. I had the negra beans and had a nice citrus touch to it. I think I'd like the serrado more though. I took a sip of my friend's and it sure was tasty. It's a bit sweeter. Both went down smoothly. Would definitely try this place again.
author: robin w.

description:
I tried drinking this EVERY day and I learned that I still don't like their coffee, it tastes over roasted and bitter. 
If you want your coffee with a side of high snobbery, and served by a Hipster-ista then go for it. Oh and expect to pay $5 for the privilege.

I prefer Blue Bottle. It actually TASTES good!
author: Sarah H.

description: We've made this a MUST STOP place during our weekend city bike rides.  Even though the lines can be extremely long, it is worth the wait.  Also, check out Lost Weekend Video store (close by) while you sip on your drink.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Ritual Coffee reminds me more of Stumptown coffee (Portland) than any place I've been to in the Bay Area. Their roast is so freaking strong, it will put hair on your chest. The flavor is more robust than what you'll get anywhere else in the area. They are definitely on the opposite end of the spectrum from Four Barrel (weak, flowery coffee).

If you need quality, artisan coffee and are taking your caffeine consumption really seriously, Ritual has got you covered.

Bonus: they take cards and have a huge seating area!
author: K M.

description: This is absolutely my favorite coffee! I go here and Floral Grub to get Ritual coffee. This place was recently renovated and it looks hip, fresh and clean! You really can't go wrong with the coffee!
author: Gilberto M.

description:
Their coffee is good and strong. I remember coming here with my gfs after dinner because we were looking for a late night spot where we can continue on with our long conversations. All three of us are coffee fanatics so caffeine usually doesn't do much to us at night, but somehow we all stayed up (separately at home) until 3-4am on a weeknight! 

Great customer service. They're very knowledgeable and can suggest a good coffee roast for you to try. There seems to be different coffees each time I've gone, but I'm not a regular due to the fact that I'm not a SF resident. I've bought the coffee there a couple times to drink at home. Good place to catch up with friends or study.
author: Vi L.

description: Almost directly across the street from Philz, Ritual is a strong competitor.  They serve drip coffee, with yummy pastries, and minimal attitude.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I was going to write a ho-hum review because i like the coffee here, but it's not my neighborhood and i'm not here often.

But then i read some of the reviews by people who rated it 1 star saying the coffee tastes sour. I have to wonder if these people know how to read signs, or if they just walked in and ordered a plain "coffee". There are descriptions of the types of beans and roasts you can get, so don't complain when you can't figure out if you want an acidic medium roast or a toasty dark roast.

I'm not a pretentious coffee snob who sniffs out expensive coffee because a cat shat it out, but i do know my coffee roast levels. Saying you didn't like your coffee because it was sour is like saying you expected a car that drives like a Benz when you blindly rented a Kia.
author: Phuong M.

description:
Some people can't sleep well after drinking coffee.  After a purchase of beans at Ritual, anticipation of the coffee that I'd make the next morning made me a light sleeper!  I dropped in yesterday evening while walking down Valencia and bought a half-pound of the coffee that was recommended to me by the fellow behind the counter.  I paid $9.25 for that half-pound and was a bit jolted by the price.  (Bluebottle half-pounds go for $7.50 or $8 these days.)  Well, this was going to have to be very, very special!

I ground some of the beans this morning and made some coffee(s) in my French press.  I was struck by the light roast.  Everyone in the industry makes fun of the charred beans at *$ and Peet's.  Bluebottle roasts much lighter than those guys, but Ritual is lighter still.  Their roast reminds me of coffees that I used to buy in Manhattan (at Empire Coffee and Tea on 9th Avenue, http://www.yelp.com/biz/empire-coffee-and-tea-company-new-york) before everybody started roasting the hell out of their beans.  The light roast at Ritual allows the quality of the primary product to shine through.  Well, yes, this is subtle stuff, and you can drudge up your wine vocabulary to start describing what's in your cup (notes of this and that).  With all said and done, I'll stick with Bluebottle, but these guys get at least an honorable mention.
author: Kenneth R.

description: I've been walking the extra blocks to Ritual since they first opened.  They are no longer deserving of the hype.  Setting aside the loss of atmospheric neighborhood retro-hip with their corporate-look make-over a couple of years ago, their signature roasts and barista- expertise has gone with the wind of Missiongreedsters.  They've lost their edge.  My last attempt at redemption was another disappointment. I'm patient about the long line, but after spending $$ for a capuchino and getting a room temperature espresso topped by a poorly steamed, lackluster thin milk, I had to ask for a redo (which I've never done before and is embarrassing when so many people wait) only to be given a curt reply about how they "always make them cooler temperature" (since when?) And the make-over was even colder? Too strange for words.  Visiters to Valencia:  Try Faye's Video for better coffees, better price, better service, and the right temperature with no attitude.  In fact, there are now many better choices.  A ritual no more.
author: Litli C.

description: Hot chocolate for my kids tasted like brown water and my fiance said the coffe was ok nothing spectacular .I would go back
author: Sal L.

description:
Excellent coffee, but the prices are insane and the people behind the counter drive me insane.  Every time I come here it takes like 20 minutes longer than it should.
Last time I popped in to buy a "pound" of beans (really 10 oz, but still $13+)..  I'm standing in line and it gets to my turn and the guy's like "just the beans, ok let me start this guy's drink" (the guy behind me..)  then they get started on his f*ing star trek shirt, and leaving me watching this budding geek bromantic comedy..  the other chic behind the counter starts helping the person behind him, and I get stuck in the Bermuda Triangle just trying to buy some beans..
author: Clarke D.

description:
I love this place one of my favorite coffee shop in san francisco 
amazing coffee and service.

Thank you so much.  :)
author: Yossi B.

description:
I just had the best Americano of my life. Of my LIFE. 

I'm not one for lines, but time passed with ease chit chatting with Ritual devotees, browsing the beans and taking in the tempting treats. On a Saturday afternoon there were few perches to be had so I took my "Hibernation" seasonal roast in a Ritual stamped cup to go. Out the door, I gingerly tested my jolt and low and behold it was drinking temperature. It took a few sips to realize that I was almost skipping down the street with a smirk on my lips. It took a few more sips to realize I was savouring the best coffee of my life and as my drink neared the bottom, a moment of remorse. The smoothest beverage I have ever experienced would soon be finished. But I brightened when I realized I had just created my own SF coffee ritual. See you soon, on some sunny spring Saturday.
author: Crystal H.

description:
Ritual Roasters.....How dare you charge $3.00 for a cup of tea?? REALLY, $3.00!!!! I'm Asian and I know my teas, and for $3.00 your tea better have some type of healing remedies that will make me look 5 years younger.

This place is pretty chill...music was alright for my taste and wasn't too loud since I was able to still have a conversation with my friend.

Chocolate crossaint was just okay. Flakey, buttery, sweet but overpriced..

I wouldn't come here again since I can find better baked goods and tea somewhere else..
author: Nancy Y.

description: Best coffee in the city. Yes, I think it's better than the uber-trendy Sightglass in Soma and just slightly better than it's sister roaster up the block (Four Barrel). It lacks the spectacle of Sightgalss and Blue Bottle, but I prefer the laid-back atmosphere of this Mission stalwart. But ultimately what really matters is what's in the cup, and Ritual remains my favorite.
author: Randy N.

description: I'd sooner never drink coffee than set foot in this hipster nuthouse again.
author: O. Reli-yah S.

description:
This is my favorite latte in San Francisco. Simply Heavenly.

I'm currently pregnant and gave up caffeine. I really miss Ritual :(
author: Tina F.

description:
is place is great for hanging with friends, surfing the webs, and studying. It's a bit noisey during peak times, so if you get distracted easily, you may want to go else where. 

The coffee is BOMB!! So worth $4 bucks a cup. I feel bad to even putting cream in it. It isn't Blue Bottle, but it equally yummy. 

NOTE: There is only ONE outlet in the whole place, so be sure to charge your laptop before hand.
author: Charliena B.

description:
New neighborhood. New star.

No idea why the Costa Rican Monte Copey was better here than at the Hayes Valley location (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ritual-coffee-roasters-san-francisco-5#hrid:ia8Bm5zUi3p3klhLzlJRdw). Vanilla and peach flavors were stronger making the cup less dark. Price was two quarters less. Process was just as good.

Plus at this location you can linger in their spacious cafe, enjoy the free WiFi and watch life go by on Valencia. 

The Mission for the win again. Same with Ritual.
author: Jason B.

description: Very tasty coffee. If you're a fan of Sightglass or Four Barrel, you'll like it. Slightly different aesthetic--more modern, less "vintage supply"--but the coffee will not disappoint.
author: Nick M.

description:
I am very split on Ritual.  I can't stand their baristas (pretension doesn't even begin to describe it -- an example of this below), but I do enjoy their roasts.  I got a killer Colombian the last time I was there.  However, I've had mixed experiences at their coffee shops.  My espressos have ranged from great to way over extracted, so I usually back-off and order Gibraltars or Cappuccinos.  Those are hard to mess up for 'upper tier' coffee houses.

Let me elaborate on the pretension I mentioned above.  I have visited a lot of coffee shops across this country.  Los Angeles (where I live now), New York City (where I'm from), San Francisco, Portland, etc.  Pretentious hipsters are part of the American coffee scene and as long as the coffee speaks for itself, I don't care who is serving it.  That said, it's over the top at Ritual.  The first time I walked into Ritual's Mission location I was met (read: ignored) by a sneering gargoyle perched at the cash register.  I waited patiently, standing at the cash register by myself (no line), for him to finish bullshitting with his equally aloof co-worker for about three minutes.  I eventually had to interrupt to ask a few questions about the espresso they were using that day.  Generic one. word. answers. followed by a sneer after every unsatisfactory response.  I placed my order and... the espresso was TERRIBLE.  Over extracted, totally bitter.  I don't believe in judging any coffee shop by one drink, especially one as well regarded as Ritual, so I followed the espresso up with a Gibraltar, which was good, but not remarkable.  I left very disappointed.

I have since visited Ritual a few more times and my experiences with the coffee have been all over the place.  I've had good and bad Gibraltars/Cappuccinos, but the baristas are just beyond aloof (though not as bad as the stooge on my first visit).  They appear totally uninterested and generally pissed off at the customer.  For a company that seems to exude a love of coffee, it's almost as if the baristas undergo "Don't Give a Fuck 101" training when they are brought on.

In a city filled with so many options (Four Barrel, Blue Bottle, and Sightglass to name a few), I don't see how this shop can remain viable with such terrible customer service.

Too Long; Didn't Read:

Very good roasts
Average espresso/espresso-based drinks
Petulant baristas
author: Lee R.

description: The coffee is good, the atmosphere is trendy, I like that they take the trouble to make pretty designs in the foam on top of their espresso drinks. It's not really anything special though. Just good, and a little spendy for a cup of coffee. Typical for the neighborhood, however.
author: Sam Z.

description: Few places anymore, remind me of true coffee shops where you can get a pastry and a coffee; where you can people watch and daydream, read, study, or talk with your friend for hours.  This is one that does.  I like to come here and turn off all my electronics and open up a book.  Not only because everyone else is on a computer and it seems like some awful illness has moved through the human population rendering us unable to connect with each other, but because I can actually read here.  Yes it is pricey, yes lots of trendy/indy/hipster 20 and 30 somethings, but it is hard to get away from that on Valencia.
author: Sirama B.

description: I love drip coffee, so when I was finally in the neighborhood (earlier this year) I was super excited to try the coffee here. When I visited, I informed the barista that it was my first time and if she could suggest something for me after giving her my preferences in coffee (slightly sweet nutty flavors in a medium roast). It was a seasonal roast that she suggested (can't remember the name unfortunately) but didn't end up liking the cup. What a disappointment. Oh wells. I'll stick to Philz or Four Barrel
author: Kitty K.

description:
I been there couple times, really nice environment. 
Coffee smell really good and I'm loving it, but they move the roaster to the warehouse... T^T
author: Yoyo T.

description: Really really good coffee and pastries.  Possibly my favorite coffee joint in sf.  Staff is very nice, if a little spacey at times.  I much prefer here to four barrel down the road.  Calmer atmosphere.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
Ever since I came back from Spain, I've been in search of some amazing coffee. When Keane L. told me Ritual Coffee Roasters was one of his favorite coffee places, I had to find out how it compared to the delicious cafe con leche I had on my trip.

This place has over a half ton of reviews and I read quite a few before stopping by. I was expecting a long wait, a crowded space full of people and pretentious egos. In a way, I'm glad that was my expectation. It's like when I meet a new person and I think they're going to be a jerk and they turn out to be really cool. It makes me like them even more.

I showed up on Tuesday night around 7:00 PM. There was no wait and only a handful of patrons hanging out inside. I ordered a soy latte and while I waited for my drink, a enjoyed a nice little chat with the barista about being vegan. I had asked him about the vegan donuts (they had sold out for the night) and explained how I am trying out being vegan. He told me about how he was vegan for about three years and now just believes in moderation. I asked him to recommend another vegan pastry/dessert and he suggested the vegan chocolate cake. 

I took my drink and my cake and headed toward BART. The latte was the PERFECT TEMPERATURE to be enjoyed immediately. I'm not a fan of scalding hot beverages because I hate waiting and usually end up burning my tongue. Not this time. It was smooth and slightly sweet. 

The vegan chocolate cake was delicious and moist. It was lightly dusted with what I guess was confectioners sugar but it could have been cocaine. Coke is vegan too, right?

MmMmmmMMmmmMMmmmmmmmm............

I will definitely be coming back here. 

If you love coffee, please don't avoid going here just because of what people say regarding the hipsters. They're just people like everyone else and if they love coffee and you love coffee then you already have something in common. Besides, some of them are kind of cute ;)
author: Daisy S.

description:
The kids enjoyed the hot cocoa from Ritual. So earlier in the morning, we came here after my daughter's doctor's appointment. 

As expected, every visit to Ritual, the kids wants the tasty and crafty Hot Cocoa and I got two 12 oz cups each for $3.00 for them to enjoy. Unfortunately with dad's busy schedule, we were forced to take the drinks to go. They usually like to drink the hot beverage indoors with their red mug and enjoy the heart shape foam-topping presented by the shop's artistic baristas. Oh yeah, going to Rituals has made their day!

I bought a large 16 oz. Café Latte. Yes, that is one damn tasty espresso drink for $4.00. I also bought a bag of whole bean coffee from Yemen for wife and I to enjoy for the next few days. The blend is Moka San'ani blend. The $12.50 bagged coffee is weighed 3/4 of a pound and is one of the coffee shop's milder and comforting blends. The fresh batch was freshly grounded on July 1 (with the date imprinted on the red bag). 

I used my Visa for this morning's visit. And to nobody's surprise, this morning was crowded at one of Yelp's and my favorite coffee shop.
author: Matt G.

description: Coffee are better than any regular ol' joe's coffee but their lattes are really good -- smooth and perfect. Pastries are from SandBox bakery in Bernal Heights -- best scones I have ever had in my life. No Exaggeration.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I made a point to visit this place on my first trip to San Francisco, because I've heard of it all the way down in Southern California.  What I found was honest and intriguing, but less than legendary.  They had three tiers of coffee, priced at $3/4/5.  They roast their own coffee, which is evident from the flavor and texture.  I love custom roasted coffee!  I admire that they only serve pour-over style.  All that aside, the coffee just didn't blow me away.   It was a little bland.

For better fresh-roasted coffee, check out Augie's if you're ever in Redlands, CA.  It's the best I've ever had--and I hear they were inspired by Ritual.  I just wasn't all that impressed by Ritual.  It looked like a fun independent scene, but strictly on the coffee it didn't live up to the reputation.  It doesn't mean it's bad.  Far from it.  Just not the best.

You might also check out Winter Blend from the It's A Grind chain.  It's truly my favorite coffee ever.
author: Jeff R.

description: Really awesome coffee but I'm over the whole pretentious "we don't do internet" line that so many coffee shops in the mission, like this one, subscribe to.  When 90% of your clients in the shop are on devices, it hardly makes people any less likely to get off their devices if you have internet.
author: Erin W.

description: I buy Ritual coffee beans in NYC from a local coffee spot so I was aware of its' San Francisco roots.  Since I was visiting I thought I check the place out as I was passing through the Mission.  The line was out the door and I was considering passing it up.  I'm glad I didn't though.  It appears that ALL the coffee was brewed by pour over, which must have made all the difference.  It was great...and I took home a souvenir mug to commemorate!  And yes I paid for it!!
author: Shawn P.

description: Good coffee and mocha. Pastries are on the sweet side but nice. A good amount of seating inside, with free WiFi. Feels spacious. Only negative is the darkness.
author: Nico D.

description:
Rarely do I make it to Valencia and the Mission.  Parking can be a nightmare.  However, I was determined to try Ritual Coffee Roasters and I arrived early enough on a Sunday to score an all day free parking spot on Valencia.  They also had plenty of tables and some sofas (the power outlets are towards the back) and it seemed like a great spot to plug in the old laptop (free wi-fi!) and get some work done.  

The pastry case mainly had cake slices, scones, croissants, and some bagels.  I tried the pumpkin cake which was decent; the slice was small and it didn't have nuts (a good thing) but I prefer a spicier cake.  Anyway, the reason I came was for the coffee, not the cake.  

The latte was smooth and mellow with lots of foam.  In that regard, I liked very much.  I did expect (and hoped) that the coffee would be considerably stronger though.  

As far as getting work done is concerned, the room was HOT and stuffy.  I was sitting by the coffee roasting machine (maybe if I moved, it wouldn't be so hot) and the guy was roasting coffee the entire time I was there.  If you love the smell of freshly roasted coffee, this is the place for you.

The crowds came around 10:30 AM.  Combined with the heat and the noise, the atmosphere became stifling.  I did see hipsters but not interesting characters - if you want to see those, go to Coffee to the People.  They seriously attract several regulars who talk to themselves, sometimes very loudly.  Or there's this one guy who changes tables all the time and leaves his belongings on various tables that he's not sitting at.  Those are characters.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Ok I get it, this whole coffee craze of lets be better than starbucks and less expensive with better coffee. Cool I'm all for that.

But Ritual coffee is one of those places that TRIES soooooo damn hard to be cool. My goodness get over yourselves. I walked in and was pleased with the cool chill vibe. I'm a tea drinker and a picky one, I'm not for all the green tea, bean tea, lean tea, fads, just give me a good cup of tea that is straight forward with no mish-mosh in between.  

Anyway like I said when I walked in it was nice, then I asked the guy at the counter a few questions (to get my type of tea) and he just seemed so annoyed by me. Why bc I'm smiling? Not too emo for you? Bc I giggled before it was my turn? Bc I actually admired your "money of the world wall", was I supposed to instead sulk and think ignore the money wall and pretend I've seen more unique and better ideas? ... didn't know there were rules prohibiting these compliments of actually having a good time in your coffee shop. 

I got my cup of tea ... then it came to getting sugar and a straw for it, the girl down the other end of the "barista" area, ignored my asking for a spoon and just nodded her head towards the straws. Rude, what was her job anyways just to stand there with greasy bad euro-cut hair and give bitchy looks?

Its like giving up one form of snobbiness at the fufooli coffee shops for another form of snobbiness here at ritual! Which is even worse bc they're in denial of their attitudes and think they're sooo down to earth. GET A GRIP YOUR JUST A COFFEE SHOP.

annoying.
author: Sunny D.

description:
The drip coffee is very tasty, but I've always been disappointed that by the time it's served, it's barely warm.  I know that it takes a while to drip through those cones, but I'm not a fan of barely warm coffee that's cold within minutes.

The large space is great though and the service is always friendly.
author: Vicente G.

description:
A nice cafe in the Mission.  There's lot of space inside and the tables aren't crowded together, which is nice.  They have free wifi as well, but unfortunately there aren't any plugs around.

The coffee itself was pretty good.  They have solid beans and they serve the coffee in single serving french press drips.  The main problem that a lot of people seem to have is that the coffee can be expensive.  I tried their cheapest cup ($2.25) as well as some of their other options.  Some coffees are $4+ which can get pricey fast.

Overall, a nice place to get coffee when you're in the neighborhood.
author: Josh W.

description: I came here on recommendation of a couple of friends, and decided to come back. It was pretty close to Candlestick Park, which made it convenient. They were pretty busy the first day, and not so busy the second, but they were quick in getting people served. I had two excellent cups of coffee and enjoyed the espresso.
author: Jacob M.

description: As a visitor to Mission District, I was told I had to visit Ritual. I loved the place, decor, atmosphere. It was awesome to hang out in and the staff was really knowledgeable and helpful. The hot coffee, both at the shop and at home when I made it with their beans (thank you Ritual for having fancy decaf blends!) was great. However, the iced coffee from the shop was super acidic and undrinkable to me, my boyfriend and the rest of our group. I thought we'd gotten a bad batch, but I had the same problem drinking home-brewed on ice. Strange.
author: Ana R.

description: Killer espresso - can be way too busy and trendy (Valencia loc) - a place to be seen? it's fun :)
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Ritual has great, great coffee. But the place itself would be so much better if the music was a little quieter. Trying to hang out and read, work, or even hold a conversation is really difficult with the volume of the music so high.
author: sina k.

description: Ritual on Valencia really deserves 5 stars since they consistently serve the best espressos in the Bay Area.  All places sometimes do a bad pull, but this Ritual has the fewest off days.  The one star knock-down is due to the loud, usually very odd music that normally plays.  The word that comes to mind is "atonal", but I'm not really sure what it is.  Whatever the word, it usually grates on me.  I guess that's what makes a horse race though.  Other customers must enjoy it, because seats are always full.  I also find the space a tad disjointed.  Something just didn't come together correctly with the interior design.  But the amazing espresso far outweighs the negatives.
author: Tom J.

description:
I live in the Southbay so I don't frequent the coffee houses in the city nearly as much as my Southbay favorites (Barefoot, Bellano, DSRC, etc) however I have been to Ritual on a number of occasions and always found it to be consistently high quality.

First the technical specs:

- Locally roasted, fresh coffee beans: Check. Ritual roasts their own beans.
- Baristas with proper training on pulling espresso & steaming milk: Check 
- High quality Milk: Check. I am pretty sure they use Clover but can't remember if they use the Organic version or not.
- Latte Art: Check

I like comparing Ritual and Four Barrel with one another. Both are walking distance from each other on Valencia street and both are highly representative of San Francisco Third Wave Coffee movement (see tech specs above and my Four Barrel review).  While both have much in common they also are in some ways opposites. Opposites, not in quality but in style. Ritual is more of your modern coffee house that attracts people with laptops. Not a lot of conversations going on from what I was able to tell. The Baristas, while friendly are a little more all about getting the job done efficiently and making sure the long line gets attended to quickly. 

You really can't go wrong with anything you order there. I've had several lattes and cappuccinos. All were done with excellent skill and quality.
author: Fouzi H.

description:
A Few of my Favorite Things

Sun
Ocean
Relaxing at Pt. Isabel with my dog
Other dogs
Golf
A hug from W
A good book that wants to be purchased
An email from someone I've not heard from in years
Hanging out with a good friend
Sharing French Fries

And last but not least, a good strong cup of coffee.

One unfavorite thing:

Being cockblocked from obtaining an outlet.  Apparently, they've blocked if not all, most of the outlets that prevent anyone from plugging in.  WTF.

Not sure what it is, but lately, things have been changing in my life.  Changing in the way that if I have not experienced it before, then the proclivities associated with the sudden appearance causes silly attempts on my part to recover and react accordingly.  These sorts of situations do not act well if I have not had my decent caffeine.  Especially when a day (like today) is somewhat vindictive, filled with mirth and hormonal idiosyncrasies (the moon, the weather, the sporadic shifts in pressure when it becomes dark and Grey outside) that can make any sweet person begin to sprout little nubs of horns on their head.  A true competition of personalities, one who wants to remain in a dormant state of continual sleep or the other, ready to cast a line out over the Pacifica Pier.

Sunday found me looking and relaying this desire for caffeine to W as we drove about on Valencia looking for a good place.  

Ritual Coffee Roasters

Nice.  I had never been.

I was immediately taken back as if on the dreamride to the past.  A retrospective of when I was in Seattle and I took up residence for several days at the local haunt (Victrola Coffee Roasters http://www.victrolacoffee.com/) by ordering several huge white porcelain cups of their latte accompanied by the occasional large cranberry nut muffin.  

The difference is this in SF:

Hipster galore.  I'm talking about neat colors of the rainbow decorating the hair, multiple piercings, tattoos...creatives, techies, artists and actors.  I'm not complaining, I'm a musician.  I recall a man from my past that came with such interesting trappings and despite that experience adding itself to my failed barrel of relationships, it was a nice memory spiked with differences and the occasional trips to the tattoo parlor to watch them finesse away at his back, one large work of art.

The mood of the place is still, yet vibrant and humming with energy.  An excellent set-up with a large communal table as well as single areas with easy plug-ins along the wall.  I also requested an orange scone slathered with glaze and the delightful quirk of citrus flavor echoed smoothly throughout the starchy respite from having no breakfast.  Equally inviting, were the large gunny sacks lying about in Roman gluttonous splendor.........were these to be used as chairs, backdrops or a separation barrier?  I wonder..

I felt equally at home as I was up in the Pacific Northwest....  Except that the men here were not wearing North Face fleece zip-ups and neat black frames.  The feeling was, a bit more candid...simply said.

When we entered the cafe, we were about 5 people deep.  Nothing bad and nothing that would seem thwarting to our coffee search.  By the time we left, the line had gone out the door.  My large cap was warming my hands and the sun was equally so outside.  

My advice, is to either arrive early or be ready to wait in patient ardor for your caffeine god or goddess, whichever you prefer, and to accept the perfect delivery of liquid prophecies.
author: Miika M.

description:
Tepid, bitter, overpriced... and that's just the customers!
Seriously, my mocha was small and came out at room temperature. I needed a palatte cleanser before heading off for food.
The music is distracting and loud.
author: Bob R.

description:
If you are looking for a place to work, this is not the place. It's semi loud and the seats are always taken. Its super crowded so I would go here if you are meeting a friend or someone. 

Also, the coffee is decent but nothing that's wow-worthy.
author: Sophie S.

description:
I've been meaning to update my review for a while.  There seems to be a fresh group of baristas at Ritual who are friendly and accessible, and it's really changed the vibe.  So now Ritual offers great coffee, a fun, groovy environment (but dynamic and often high-volume, so don't come here to absorb yourself in a novel or think deep thoughts if you need peace and quiet to do so), and cheerful service.  

Still minus one star because somehow they still manage to have the longest wait-per-customer in town.  Maybe the process could use a tune-up.
author: Katy M.

description:
I've been to Ritual twice in a month and have gotten rude service from two separate baristas. One gave me attitude when I ordered a large cappuccino (apparently they don't make large cappuccinos) and the barista today gave me a dirty look for telling him my order without asking him how he was doing first. I'm sorry, but if you're a barista and give a customer attitude for ordering a drink, don't work in food service.  

Save yourself the wait and the attitude--go to Four Barrel instead.
author: Kayla C.

description:
We arrived here bright and early Sunday morning and found parking right outside.  Not sure if it was the time change or the Sunday morning part, but it wasn't too busy inside.  We ordered our coffees (latte for me, cappuccino for her) and baked goods (vegan donut for me, donut muffin for her) and found a table.

The music that was blaring when we first sat down was a little loud for my slightly achy morning-after-margaritas head, but they soon switched it to a more soothing Iron and Wine album.

When I ordered my vegan donut I just asked for "a sprinkly one" and was a little disappointed when I looked in my little bag that it was chocolate instead of white.  But after one taste I had no more regrets. Holy moly.  Delish.  Went perfectly with the delish latte.

I'm glad my ladyfriend likes good coffee and knows where to get it.  And I'm also glad that she bought a pound of it to take home so that it filled the car with the lovely Ritual coffee aroma the entire six hour drive back to LA.  Yum!
author: Andrea D.

description:
Dropped by to pick up a bag o coffee...

They had way too many selection of beans... the coffee dude was very helpful in helping me select the beans.

I quite enjoyed the beans I got... if parking was any easier in the hood, I definitely consider hanging out there.
author: Victor C.

description:
Wonderful soy cappuccino (my drink of choice). Recently, as the weather starts to get a bit warmer, which isn't much warmer at all, I've been ordering iced coffee. Unlike the Ritual in hayes valley, they have pre brewed iced coffee, which I was skeptical to try. It was actually wonderful. They must brew it a bit stronger so the ice doesn't water it down, which is how iced coffee should be made. I enjoyed it very much. 

I really enjoy the Monte Rey: Carrizal, El Salvador beans. I get this as an iced coffee when they do not have pre brewed coffee.
author: Brittany M.

description: I love Ritual, their coffee is strong but doesn't upset my stomach. Their lattes are really creamy and cappuccinos are done with just the right amount of foam. The espresso is intense.
author: Sandy A.

description:
I only had hot chocolate, what a loser.

But it was really good. It was not cloyingly sweet which is how I like it, and it had that fancy swirl foam thing going at the top. I'm visual so I like drinkable art. 

I made a special trip out here after work just because someone told me they had the best coffee. But after having a cup of crappy work coffee and blue bottle, I was already feeling the acid burn hole in my stomach so I'll have to come back another time.

The space is a cool place to chill in. Modern-looking with just enough minimalist art hanging on the walls. Sexy lighting. Clean and spacious with a lot of outlets along the walls. Different kinds of seating options from standard tables, bar stools, large library table in the back, and couches. Free WiFi. I studied a little, and the majority seemed to be doing the same or working on their laptops, but there were also people just enjoying their conversations, playing some intense chess game like in the movies, or just playing cards.

I dig the vibe here.
author: May C.

description: Coffee: 3. Remodel: -10 - Soul sucking. Bringing Palo Alto to the Mission one block at a time.
author: Visit T.

description: Pretty dang tasty.  Ranks up there amongst SF's best coffee.  On weekends the line is usually out the door, but the short wait is worth the excellent coffee.  I like getting my single nonfat latte, and there is usually ample seating inside.  If not, Dolores Park is just a short walk away!
author: Mel G.

description: What a coffee shop. Visiting SF and staying a few blocks away. We tried this place yesterday as my brother-in-law lead us through a torrential downpour.  I got a soy latte accidentally and loved it (asked for skim milk, but a great alternative!) I went back this morning and got an Americano, which I topped with soy. Every coffee should taste that good.
author: Clare F.

description: Screw this wobbly table. Spilled my $3 coffee everywhere. Ham & cheese given instead of chocolate croissant. No wifi? 1 star cuz the coffee tastes good. 1 cuz I'm feeling piggish and the cashier is, well, you know.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Not a bad place, but all of the reviews here seem to be from coffee lovers/snobs. I come here because the wi-fi is extremely good: and by looking around me, a lot of others agree. This is a good place to get some work done - except for one thing. The staff seem to insist that they play their music at really high levels. Sometimes, I just want to hear my own music off of my computer, or want a bit of quiet. I realize that this is a cafe and by walking in, I am making an implicit agreement to accept a certain level of ambient noise. So if I want to listen to my own music, I turn it up a bit; if I want 'quiet' I deal. But the volume at which they play music here is insane. 

Come for the coffee; come if you like the music selection; but if you have other ideas, you may want to reconsider. I was tempted to deduct only one star, but this is a huge inconvenience.
author: Sandeep C.

description:
Best latte I've had so far in SF (I haven't been to the famous Blue Bottle). Great coffee, very rich, with just the right amount of milk. It came in a fancy large blue ceramic cup, and they make pretty patterns with the milk on top. There was a line for their coffee for the whole two-plus hours I was there, so apparently they're pretty popular!

There are lots of tables and some comfy couches in the back. Colorful art adorns the walls. It's definitely a very relaxed atmosphere. 

One warning though - they were blasting rock-ish and trance music most of the time, so it's not the ideal place to study or concentrate on work. I'd rather go here to chill with friends or surf the web over a cup of coffee.

(See accompanying photo!)
author: Lisa M.

description: Amazing Latte! I love it its so smooth and creamy! Its like no other.
author: THe real TrUth D.

description: Met a friend here for the first time. Got a chocolate mocha for I believe $4.35 and enjoyed the free wifi. Had to sit on the bar stools since all the tables were taken. Great vibe though. Music was loud enough to not hear other peoples conversation but not too loud where I couldn't hear my friend. Had a great time!
author: Erica L.

description:
Is it pricey? yes

Is it slow? yes

Is there a line? yes

Is every table taken? yes

Is there free wireless? yes

Are there plugs for your laptop? try finding one that works

Is the coffee and pasteries good? oh yeah!

Despite the downsides, I can't but help coming back. 

Also, it has a blend called Double Rainbow.... whoa! all the way!!
author: Boris C.

description:
Summary: Good coffee, ok but not amazing for chilling. Open late though.

Stopped by for my second time to try some of the coffee. They had a selection of a few (5-6?) types of coffee - I tried a drip filter regular coffee, which was good.

Lighting in the place was a bit dim, so some of the tables were not great for reading or working on laptops.

They're open pretty late, which is great for a late coffee run or meeting.
author: Gary Y.

description:
SERVICE:
Credit card minimum :T Free wifi

ATMOSPHERE:
Lots of little tables. It's basic, nice, kinda dark dingy, some interesting urban decor with random hanging lightbulbs, and urban artwork hung up. Lacking in outets as they block a lot of them off. Bathroom in back.
author: Angela L.

description:
Five stars for the double macchiato Jeremy made for me last week. I've been going there since they opened (any regular from there will tell you I'm a total shill), but my hand to god, this macchiato made me a better person FOR THE REST OF THE DAY. Euphoric, pure lightning in a demitasse. Just espresso with a jot of foam and yet it tasted of raspberries and dark chocolate. Then the next damn day Gabe made me another macchiato that was as good if not better. 

If you require 16 ounces of highly sweetened milk per 4 oz. or less of espresso, then we recommend you EASE into Ritual. Start with their large (12 oz, thank you very much) mocha and work your way down. And don't take it personally that they don't have Torani's. You'll have to search elsewhere for your Ultimate Pomegranite Italian Soda.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Oh how I've heard about this place. Oh how I wanted to like this place. Oh how I didn't.

There was one thing to like about it... and many things to not like about it. But I found a way to get my fix of the good without the bad...

The good: yummy coffee.

The bad: 
-- pretentious and surly staff, acting like they are some sort of elite for working here and doing YOU a favor by serving you. (I've got news: you're a barista, working for someone else who makes money from your effort, and you're in a service industry... lose the attitude.)  
-- serious lack of electrical outlets
-- the stinkeye from 40 macbook users when I opened my Windows laptop. The snobbery was THICK here.
-- high prices... yes the coffee is yummy, but not in proportion to the price.

I wanted to love this place. I REALLY wanted to love it. But when it came down to it, I felt seriously UNWELCOME here. The vibe of the place (and everyone in it) is unwelcoming unless you are One Of Them. I'm sort of one of them... but not exactly One Of Them. Hence, the vibe was UNWELCOMING.

And when I go to a coffee shop... I want to feel welcomed. Call me crazy.

So... how to get the advantage (yummy coffee) without all the negatives?  I came down to Wicked Grounds... much more welcoming, cheaper prices, they serve Ritual coffee, have an actual food selection, and despite the wacky nature of the place-- a refreshing lack of pretension.

Or you could just go to Philz, or down the block to The Marsh, which is open/airy and welcoming, has friendly staff, good music, and electrical plugs.

Disappointed.
author: Em-eye-gee P.

description:
Again with the "hype". Someone will label a plain ol' coffee shop "cool" and the sheep will follow. Bottom line it's coffee...You can go down the street to Muddy Waters and get the same thing for a lot less, and with a normal wait. 

This place is great if...

...you own a fixed gear
...own the newest i-pad 
...enjoy wearing sunglasses inside

Stop being chumps...it's COFFEE!
author: Mel D.

description:
I would like to teach the baristas of Ritual 5 words. "I'll be right with you."

That's all I want you to say while I stand at the front of the line for 2-3 minutes. 

I am not going to stop coming here because the coffee is very good and I am holding out for the day I get a barista with manners, but god damn.
author: Tom M.

description:
A jetlagger's best friend:  they open eeearly!

Impressive cappucino: nice & fancy & tasty!

Good-looking customers & convenient wifi empowered locale. 

Can we just adjust the price a tad bit: I can't afford a daily stop.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Ritual, I've been looking for you, and I finally found you. Deadly sharp coffee served up in a beautiful setting - exactly what I was looking for. 

The blond barista that works here is like a glistening Adonis of a man. I am totally warm for his form and the way he makes my Sweet Tooth (single origin) cappuccino. It's worth the extra dollar ($4 total) to Sweet Tooth-icize your drink order here. 

Wifi is free and without hassles or limits. There's ample seating for singletons or groups, but don't come here with an uncharged device because plugs are somewhat scarce.

The hot chocolate needs work - I expected it to taste better but it was very watery and not bitter or rich enough. Will be back for another Sweet Tooth capp!
author: Kat F.

description:
Delicious espresso and coffee that's made RIGHT in the Mission. So sick of cafes on upper Valencia screwing up my cappuccinos. Too bad the staff lack personality  (except maybe 2 employees) and the back smells like dog piss all the time.

This place has definitely got its own vibe going on. Great working environment, with decent art work, and its open until 10pm!
author: Nicole G.

description:
They get my taste in coffee right on. I'm ruined, my day is not off to a good start unless I get my coffee here. It's a problem. I don't want coffee at home, I don't want coffee at a friend's house, I don't want coffee any place near where I work or on a walk at Chrissy Field with a friend. If I haven't had it in the morning I'll try to make an excuse to go with my boyfriend in the afternoon ("No, we should definitely not drive down Guerrero, it'll take forever. Use Valencia instead, oh look, there happens to be parking in front of Ritual, must be a sign, haha"). 

I've started bringing their coffee as a 'present' when I go out of town to visit my parents. I think they are starting to get that I don't bring it for them as much as for myself.
author: Naomi M.

description: I was excited to check out this place today but so disappointed with the service. Grumpy server and did not apologize when they gave me the wrong drink.
author: Elsa K.

description:
Good coffee! Good cappuccino! Great baked goods (many vegan options if that's what you're into).  

Can be a long wait... lots of people doing "work" or "reading" in here, but they do move pretty quickly.  Definitely the best coffee on Valencia Street and it is open late which is nice for post-meal drink.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I have been back a few times since my review. I get now that this a is a light roast coffee place and that is just not my thing. That alone is not worth the one star, that is just a difference in taste. However, the snottiness and general attitude of the staff here is my biggest problem. There is little to no excuse for being rude, especially when people are greeting you with a smile.
author: Eric M.

description:
Ok now that I have had the coffee, I gotta say, it's not that good. The staff is nice and the atmosphere (laptop land) is alright, but my husband's mocha was really bland and my hot cocoa was luke warm and not really drinkable. I've since had the coffee a few more times and maybe it's just too strong for me, but I think it's lackluster. I'm a much bigger fan of Philz.

Still loving on those mini cupcakes though!
author: Nikki M.

description:
Another of SF's great "designer" coffee places, as my friend from the Mission refers to them.  I like this place, though somehow it can't compete with the cool and taste of blue bottle.  Also now it has four barrels of competition across the street.  Ritual is a roaster, so you can checkout the machinery in the back and probably learn a thing or two besides.  Uberhip, as in so hip it hurts, but hey I go for the espresso!

Writing about this is making me long for my trip in a few weeks which will include SF and burning man, can't wait.
author: Sean S.

description:
Amazing hand poured, individually ground, amazing cups of  hot perfect coffee. Definitely on the pricey side, but you absolutely get what you pay for here, which is a top notch cup of coffee or coffee beans.
Ritual Coffee roasts amazing coffee. I have taken home beans and also purchased beans at Rainbow and Whole Foods. 
The cafe itself is large and has a lot of seating and Tables. 
I have to agree about the tie for first with Blue Bottle, although I appreciate the variety of roasts offered at Ritual Coffee.
Bonus points for Ritual because I always seem to find metered street parking right in front.
author: Kelle K.

description:
Caveat: Everyone here is cooler than I am. If you are cooler than I am, this could be your favorite cafe.

Decent tea and hot chocolate (I'm not a coffee-drinker), friendly service, and they hosted LitQuake events. They're open later than some of the cafes nearby, but not as late as The Summit (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-summit-san-francisco-2). It is LOUD in here more often than not, and I always see exactly one free table (but hey, that's all I need).

All of these things combine to make Ritual my favorite place to go with people I'm not interested in dating. It's nice enough, but not conducive to personal conversations.
author: Renee T.

description:
You know why they act like they're better than us?  

Because they are.  At least at making espresso.  

I sort of inherited a Pasquini Livia 90 espresso machine, which is a great, respectable machine in the prosumer market, filling the gap between home use and professional use.  

The problem is, that's not enough.  You can't make good espresso with just a good machine.  You need a good grinder, too.

So I got a fancy, 54mm ceramic flat burr grinder, with infinitesimal adjustments.  Great machine, but even that's not enough.  

After burning through a couple dozen of pounds of top quality espresso beans, many many hours of self-training, youtube videos, and hundreds of "sink shots" (espresso so bad you just have to pour it down the drain)...

I am still NOWHERE near as good as these guys.

There is a lot that goes into a good espresso.  The most important are the grind, the dose, the distribution, the water temperature, and the espresso blend.  

And the guys at Ritual have a very good handle on all of this, not to mention latte art skills. 

Latte art is important.  Why?  Because you cannot make latte art unless the milk is the perfect consistency.  And you cannot make a good latte without good microfoam.  

My only problem with "third wave" coffee shops like Ritual, Intelligentsia, etc. is the hipsters who like the scenery more than the coffee.  If you are a true coffee lover, my hat's off to you, no matter what you look like.
author: Michael K.

description: Their espresso is nearly undrinkable. Bitter, way too acidic and devoid of any body. The baristas obviously don't know how to make a good espresso, let me help them right here: http://www.home-barista.com/espresso-guide-diagnose-extraction-problems.html
author: Luca C.

description:
Espresso, over ice, with a touch of soymilk. 

It smells amazing in here.  Cozy black leather chairs for working.  The music and ambiance are perfect for a late Sunday afternoon.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: "Assembly Line" would be more appropriate than "Ritual."  I had been going to Ritual frequently before the remodel - thought the coffee good, the ambience ok - the service acceptable - but not of the par of other coffee houses in San Francisco.  With the newly remodeled space - the area is spacious - it looks good in an Architectural Digest way - but it lacks all character.  And though their coffee is good, their staff, possibly with one exception has to be the most unwelcoming staff of any coffee house that I've ever frequented - from SF to NYC to Vienna to Berln.  The staff are as welcoming as any automaton could be and generally seem to lack interest in customer service.  And with the increased space, they seem to regularly run out of most edibles by 4 PM.  I live close by and had been there many many times before the remodel - but now, after about 7 visits to the remodeled space - so wanting to give it another chance and another chance and another chance - I'll go to other coffee houses that are welcoming and human-oriented.  I had friends from LA visiting and they said "coffee" to their smartphone and it said "Ritual" - and probably a computer might feel at home in the cold unwelcoming spaces of Ritual, but not me.
author: Wolf B.

description:
I was hoping Ritual will set the bar for good coffee so high that it turns me into a coffee snob and ends me the history of tolerating crappy coffee. That didn't happen, though. The double shot cappuccino and latte only tasted so-so and they were far from taking my breath away.  I guess I will have to look elsewhere for my cure.

On the plus side, the coffee shop itself has a lot of personality and character. It's definitely a fun place to chill and people watch.
author: Tingting H.

description:
Bought some Ritual Coffee beans the other day (some Costa-Rican kind).  Roasted only 3 days ago, too.

Despite the alleged freshness, the beans smelled like a trash fire.

After running some through my moka pot, I couldn't tell if the coffee tasted more like battery acid, or more like bong water.

I think the reason they have that Soviet-quality design for their logo and packaging is because the beans that they're farmers are selling to them taste like they're from 1989.

Another realization: they use the communist star as a multi-faceted metaphor-- communism always sounds like a good idea at first, but then it just ends up being terribly overrated... sort of like Ritual's coffee.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Get the vegan donuts. Holy hell.

Great coffee, awesome environment, and great baristas. Love chatting with them about beans, music, life in general. I usually don't have a problem trying to find a table, the wifi connection is fast, and things seem to run really efficiently and smoothly. I see some people complaining about the price and the line, but really, it's worth it. 

Would you rather have one cup of amazing, strong, complex coffee and wait a few extra minutes, or get a cup of chain-store coffee that, while it takes 2 minutes to pour, leaves you wanting more/coming back a few hours later?
author: Colleen F.

description: Have to agree with my buddy Ed U about the hipster vibe. It can be hard to find a seat here and coming here as a first timer I was a little intimidated since I didn't know what to order. I decided to go with the mocha. The coffee was nice and smooth, and no bitter aftertaste. May have to try a hand poured one next time I'm here.
author: Veronica C.

description: Something I love more than good coffee, is good coffee and space to sit! I came here on a Tuesday evening and there was plenty of space. The coffee is delicious for being a drip a coffee and would definitely recommend it to anyone. People are also super friendly - there is a good mixture of start-up people, hipsters, and one-offers. I would recommend you stop here if you are between 20th - 26th street and Mission.
author: Pablo P.

description:
Ritual Coffee stood out immediately, literally, due to the giant line sticking out of it, 20 people deep.

My first thought was, "damn, that must be some really good coffee."  My second thought was, "do I really want to wait 20 minutes for coffee?"  

But what really turned me on about this place wasn't the coffee, but the whole shop really has something for everyone.  Couches for reading? Small tables for two?  Bar seating for chatters?   Communal tables for laptop parties? Check, check, check.

Needless to say, a clean coffee shop in the mission is a diamond in the rough on it's own.
author: Boris C.

description:
By all accounts A-OK if it didn't take so insufferably long.  Hyped pure and simple.  

Busted up old couch and minimal decor don't make for a great spot to chill, and it's time to update the "exposed light bulbs hanging like rain drops" thing!  Get with the times, Ritual! We're all about LED and energy efficient compact fluorescents now. Sheesh! 

Don't go out of your way.
author: Luke M.

description: Best Ethiopian coffee ever, period. Sure $4 is little high for a cup of coffee but it worth it. You might end up waiting 10 minutes, but it worth it.  Forget about Philz, Blue Bottle, Starbucks, etc.  if you love coffee (not espresso or latte), this is the place!
author: Miho Y.

description: I think I just had the best decaf coffee ever, there is a pretty good vibe to that place, did I mention hipster central ... ,  ah well you live in the mission you become one ... no seriously awesome space to chat with a friend and enjoy a cup of coffee.,
author: NAEL K.

description: basically a really hipster coffee spot in the mission. two stars for the people watching bc it was probably the best ive ever seen in the city. i can't speak for the quality of the coffee because my friend and i ordered chai lattes. they were pretty unimpressive and the menu appeared very limited to me. the pastries seemed average as well. the decor is cool and its definitely a neat place but I probably wont be back.
author: Ava S.

description:
When I find myself around Valencia and 21st, my feet automatically make their way towards Ritual Coffee. The place has got me seeing red - literally. After you place your order, the space opens up and it's pretty roomy with red walls and changing art installments/exhibitions.
I've only had the lattes here, but they're darn great. That and their lemon poppy bread. Yum! I've never had a problem with their service. It starts out a little slow when they first open, but it picks up, just like the crowd. I don't come in with my laptop, but the back side of the space is always crowded with the laptop crowd and free Wi-fi. The place doesn't get too crowded the few times I've been there, and I like that the music is not blasting and can have a conversation.  I see a lot of people order their drip coffee. I'll have to try it again next time.
author: Dee D.

description: Definitely one of my favorite places to work remotely. Friendly staff and customers. Expect it to be crowded and that you may have to table share but that's part of the working remotely experience, especially here.
author: Rich S.

description:
Dear Ritual, 
Again, I write a review of you-this being the last time as I will no longer frequent your establishment. 
I have tattoos - a lot of them. When I show them, you're nice to me. When I cover them with a tasteful sweater, you aren't very nice to me. Your hipster vibe is  old, and it'll get older. It'll bite you in the ass eventually. I write this cos I care about my hood, and hate to see businesses fail. I also hate to be served by grouchy staff. Ciao, Ritual. Nice knowing you - not.
author: David L.

description: Three bucks for a cup of coffee is a little steep, but when you consider the many hours of free Internet you'll be sucking up, I'd say that's a bargain. Good coffee, too.
author: Max R.

description: No plugs, no wifi, and overpriced coffee. This place thinks it's WAY cooler than it is. How about trying to be a coffee shop?
author: bill l.

description:
Pretentious, pricey and flipping tasty. Great atmosphere for working if you don't mind a little noise/commotion. 

Except paying $3 for a tea bag in a mug of hot water. Come on, folks.
author: Andrew V.

description:
As good as it gets.  The most care for the entire coffee process you can find.  

Great staff (over the top hipster at times) and the best latte I've ever had.  

Wifi is super fast, but it is very crowded so get used to sharing your table and meeting other coffee lovers.
author: Andrew H.

description: Great drink options: pourovers, tastings, spicy chai. Fresh pastries as well. The place to go for some laptop work sessions!
author: Benji M.

description: Coffee that stings the throat--- it's so bitter even with whole milk.  Place is stuffy and super loud.
author: Jorge D.

description: Updated from 4 to 5 stars. Great coffee, amazing staff. Seriously, they are awesome.
author: Zachary K.

description:
I've been enjoying Ritual for quite some time now since it is our "house" coffee.  The only problem is that I don't wake up early enough so don't have enough time to french press the stuff.  Ugghh!  I'm working on that.

I got to finally visit this holy land called Ritual and I was pleased with what I saw and the service.  Upbeat employees passionate about brewing the perfect cup of coffee.  My gentleman friend got a nice Ritual 101 and learned a few things and we are definately getting some of them drip things... you know what I'm talking about with the etchings in the inside so the hot water can flow better to maximize something or another but hey I wasn't the one getting the lesson.  I got the gist.

We picked up half pound each of Miraflores (Colombia), Yara (Colombia) and Hunapu (Guatemala)...hmmm... all these fun names sound like they could be code names for drugs... something white in color (most of the time) in particular.  Como Sr. Flores in Traffic...  

The coffee is not cheap but it's worth every bean.  But how would you like to spend $88 on your first visit?  Me not so much but yes... $8 for 2 cups of coffee and a vegan donut ( I asked the cashier to choose for me and he picked the blueberry one aka dark pink looking one which was lovely )... $20 for QYT. 3 of 1/2 LBS of coffee and a $50 parking ticket for not completely turning the wheels when parking on a 3% grade.

"WHEELS WRONG WAY WHEELS WRONG WAY WHEELS WRONG WAY NO BLOCKS NO BLOCKS NO BLOCKS"  Ummm in English that is called repitition... oh well.. I guess he or she was trying to make a point.  Officer J.U.... F.U.!!!  

Still this ridiculous hill parking episode did not hinder my experience at Ritual.  It was that good.
author: Shiho F.

description:
Simple goodness is how I define Ritual coffee.

I love the dark coffee house feel of the one on Valencia St. The baristas take their time and make every cup a work of art. Literally. In each cup you will find a little "foam picture" swirled on top. Each time they set one in front of me, I peer at the little art, smile and thank them. It just makes me happy. Then it makes me sad to put the lid on. I swear I walk more gingerly to the car in hopes of preserving the foamy art. I think it's the best coffee around. It's smooth, rich, deep and just damn tasty! 

Things I don't like: St cleaning is every M,W,F up and down both sides of the street and it makes it difficult for a quick pop in during the early morning hours. I'm also not a fan of their select pastries selection. They always look over baked to me. And based on the couple I have tasted, that's how they taste. I like my pastries flaky and soft! 

My 5 stars is for Ritual's coffee only.
author: Shannon K.

description:
BITTER NO MORE!  They changed their offerings. They moved their roasting elsewhere.. at least its not on the main floor close to the customers, it use to be very potent and got me a bit woozy   Been coming back to Ritualz lately and finally after many years I got a couple bags of Brazilian Fazanda's.  Using my V60 pour over and French Press, I was very impress with the results.  I can remember their beans being a bit "bitter".. not sure what part of the roasting method made it that way.  
but it made me look elsewhere.   RR has the widest selection of Fazenda's.  I also do did notice some African offerings.  RR is now back on my monthly list of beans to get.  

People comparing this to Philz... have no clue about good rich coffee.  I can garauntee you Philz beans are pretty old. They rely on roasting the crap out of it with other flavors to mask the staleness of the bean.  I spent 7 bucks on a JAMAICAN BM at Philz....their ghetto baristas hinted I put more cream n some sugar.     YUP they were right... the coffee needed it badly....they knew off the bat when I told them I wanted very little cream n no sugar that I was in for a surprise!!!!   I just found the trash and went across the street to HAUS.
author: Demanding T.

description: 3.5 stars. The mocha was smooth but didn't have the dark richness that I like. At first, it just tasted like a good latte, so I had to ask for more chocolate. The chocolate just made it a bit sweeter but didn't really make it a great mocha. Was fine but not as good as other spots in the city.
author: Catherine N.

description: The best in SF. I go to the Mission just for my fix. The creamiest mellowest bold capuccino in town.  Scrumptious.
author: John S.

description:
I don't drink coffee, but friend who does swears by their lattes with the little fern leaf designs in the steamed milk foam.  Freshly roasted coffee.

I favor the blueberry rooibois tea, a huge bag of leaves that steep cup after giant red cup.

The breakfast pastries are also good, but the best are the chocolate covered, dulce du leche alafajores.  Smuggled from argentina.

Also we like the stuffed animals that have been turned inside out and resewn, often displayed here.

Plus, the staff occassionally dresses in costume. We showed up one day and they were all wearing jumpsuits.  We asked why, and they said:  We're from the future.

I saw the server with the mustache (the skinny little guy) at the whole foods across the street once. It's kind of like seeing a celebrity.  Weird to see them out of context. He probably is recognized by more people than he recognizes
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Ritual is Mission hipster to the max and yet somehow I stil find it more than tolerable.  Employees are always friendly to me and everyone else does their own thing.  

The boyfriend likes their coffee (second only to Blue Bottle) and I love that they have a good selection of Red Blossom teas.  Even with the crowds it seems to only take a few minutes for a table to open up.   Free wifi, and nice mini cupcakes too.
author: Joanne G.

description:
This is where I come when I want to creep people out with my death stare trying to find a seat. Cause that's seriously what you have to do 90% of the time.

Coffee to go is fine. Nice and heavy bodied from the french press. Although if I'm gonna do that, I'll walk a few blocks down to four barrel. 

I had the worst espresso of my life here. Ridiculously sour and bitter. I believe it was an Ethiopian blend.  It made Starbucks espresso look heavenly. Yikes. But I've also had some damn good lattés.
author: Monica C.

description: Three stars for the coffee, but damn the service sucks. When there is a line, all hands on deck.... Only one person was serving while the other three where just standing in the back looking......a hipsters paradise.......
author: Troy H.

description:
Bay area coffee lovers take note.  THIS is how coffee is SUPPOSED to be made, served, and enjoyed.  No flavored syrups.  No blenders.  Just really really good coffee, made by people who CARE about good coffee, and have fun making and serving it.  Ok, I'm a bit biased because I know these guys, and they serve the same great beans I serve in my Portland shop, but still, they even knocked my socks off (not in a dirty-sock-ripping-off kind of way).  They love coffee, and they're brewing some of the best beans money can buy.  Finally a city that's all about good food has a good coffee place to match.  All Hail Ritual!

People are actually complaining that there is not enough seating?  Or that the coffee isn't "all that"?  Give me a freaking break.  Where in SF can you get better coffee?  And what do you want them to do, take reservations?  Share a table, or sit at the bar, or get over it.  These people know what they are doing, and if you don't like your drink, ask them to remake it, cuz they will.  This isn't "Italy" and don't walk in there with your "I've been to Italy" or "I was a barista" comments.  They don't need to hear it, and they know more about coffee than you do.
author: Brent F.

description:
I *love* it but want to visit a few more times before I go all the way (*****). 

I recognized my barista from the Western Regional Barista Championships in LA a few weeks ago and true to form, she made a beautiful and delicious macchiato -- semi-sweet and milky chocolate.  The cafe was packed and dirty dishes lined tables and the counter.  It was busy, it happens, I know.  The coffee selections are tops and I walked away with  a 1/2 pound of Fazenda Esperança Yellow Icatu, Brasil.  I *can't* wait to Clover it up after I fly home tomorrow evening.  I also enjoyed a vegan blueberry coffee cake, which was, surprisingly delicious and a nice complement to my macchiato.  I hope to be back soon, perhaps when it's not so crowded (if it ever clears out!) so I can enjoy a few more drinks without the wait!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Good coffee.

Lots of plugs for your laptop.

Lots of seating.
author: Mae B.

description: The coffee is still far above-average, the barista nice, the machines impressive  but after they renovated Valencia Ritual Coffee is not the same anymore! I am missing the real staff, the nice and uncomplicated 70s ambience, the crowd - and the roasters, but they are long gone.
author: Desiree M.

description: I used to spend a lot of money/time at Rituals but the new no-Wifi and no power outlets will stop me from going back again. I am sure their economics make sense with out wifi and power outlet but I wont be going back.
author: Srikanth D.

description:
I am very disappointed with the last two 12 ounce bags I have bought of Ritual Coffee. The beans were very dry and brittle. The coffee had a stale taste to it. I tried to contact customer service and got no response. 
I would not recommend this coffee to anyone especially for the price. I am now happy with Blue bottle coffee.
author: Dianne R.

description: By far my favorite spot in the city for a soy latte. I order it with illimani to sweeten up the crew and grab a cup of glass to refresh after every sip. Pure bliss. I'm here at least a handful of times a month.
author: Eric A.

description: Why is the coffee here always just a tiny touch sour?  Too citrus-y for me these days.
author: Maisie G.

description: wow.  If you are cruising down Valencia, you must stop and at least smell inside Ritual Coffee.  I took a sip from my girlfriend's cup of java and wished I hadn't had 2 cups of coffee at Boogaloo's an hour prior.  There was a line out the door so you'll have to be patient for this cup of coffee.
author: H H.

description:
Damn there is a line that's longer than Starbucks. Luckily, you get real deal coffee. They make it fresh, and.....they have a nice flower/leaf design on each cup of coffee. 
Plenty of seats for all the hipsters in the world to sit and chat about their business.
author: Michael W.

description:
A little bit overrated. Don't get me wrong, their coffee is good but not as great as I've been told. This shop is located in the city where the hipsters hang, a place where you'll see more bicycles than cars and yet, parking is still a pain in the butt. 

It's a fun coffee shop to come to on the weekends, but don't get caught in the line. 

My last experience was quite disappointing, I ordered an iced americano and it came out looking like an iced tea. The lady behind me thought it was her iced tea and went to grab for it but was stopped by the barista.
