When he handed her the iced tea, I was able to take a quick glance to see that even her drink looked darker than my iced americano. It was way diluted with water and it had no taste of espresso all...
author: Jenny K.

description:
This place has the best chai in town!

Lots of space, a friendly chill crowd--a perfect place to sip on a little somethin somethin.  It gets pretty crowded, but it is a very cool spot if you can work, read, or do what you gotta do with a lot of activity and chatter going on in the background.

My only missing star is due to a little bit of dirtiness I've seen around the cafe.  The bathrooms aren't the best either.  Other than that, it's all good.
author: Angella S.

description:
The coffee, whether pour-over or espresso, is always excellent.  And there's usually a ton of space to chill with your laptop or a book and get some work done.

However, the customer service is truly hit-or-miss.  Most of the time, you get a barista who's friendly or at least pleasant.  But a significant minority of the time, you get someone who acts like you're not cool enough to buy coffee from them.

For example, when my sister was visiting town, one of the baristas made fun of her to her face for taking an iPhone photo of the menu.  To be sure, she was totally being a cheesy tourist.  But that doesn't mean we need to hear mean-spirited comments when we're just trying to buy coffee.

I still come here all the time, and I buy their coffee to make at home.  I just expect that there's a good opportunity someone's going to be unnecessarily rude to me each time I come in to buy something.
author: Ross G.

description:
Gah, it is such a SCENE up in here. I know, I know, if I'm so sick of hipsters, why do I keep coming back to the Mission? Because I was here first. I was here before you guys & I will be here long after you & your skinny jeans & weird frames have gone the hell away. I am embarrassed that my old neighborhood has turned into this. 

What were we talking about? Oh, coffee...so, Sunday, it's raining cats & dogs & the best friend & I stop in for a cup of something warm. We ordered 2 mochas ($7.50); the friendly brunette recommended the sweet tooth of the month, Chapadao de Ferro from Brasil. Not bad at all. Much better than the regular drip we had last week, which was bitter & too acidic & pretty much undrinkable. 

We found an empty table & inhaled our drinks (perfect temperature for immediate drinking, no blowing required.) Like I said, not a bad mocha at all, but I am sticking to Philz & Blue Bottle because their regular drip coffee tastes so much better & that's usually what I prefer over a fancyass mocha anyday. 

I don't think I will make a ritual of hitting up Ritual Coffee Roasters every Sunday. However, I *will* continue my Sunday ritual of: sleeping in, getting a short but intense workout in, paying bills, reading a magazine cover-to-cover (this week was my latest copy of "Everyday with Rachael Ray") & watching my favorite reality show "Keeping Up With The Kardashians." 

What's your Sunday ritual? Do tell.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
You've never had coffee if you haven't had ritual coffee. 

This particular mission area one is so so cute, a nice street to walk around with your morning cup of joe. The bathroom is always empty. There is parking most days. And very attractive ppl go there. Just cannot get better.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Definitely a great cafe in the Mission.  Residing now in the east coast where all the coffee shops are packed tight like crowds pushing through the doors at Target on Black Friday, it was nice to come to a place where the tables aren't all pushed together.  The cafe definitely had a nice west coast relaxed vibe to it where you can sit and relax on your Macbook (or for the non-trendies or those who can't afford it like me, your Dell) and relax with a cup of coffee while listening to Girl Talk.  

It seems like they serve several brews and you can choose your cup which they make as you order.  The problem is that the coffee can get pricey as their cheapest option was $2.25 and that the tables weren't cleaned off.  My group and I sat at a table with two mugs of coffee that had gone cold from the people who left them there.  One of my friends who didn't order a drink grabbed a mug thinking it was ours and took a sip, complained about how cold it was and derided the coffee.  Little did he know, he swapped fluids with a mysterious wo/man.
author: Christopher T.

description: This place was busy when I visited on a Sunday afternoon. It's expected of course. I had my latte and it earns its spot with the local coffee roasters. It's a tiny bit milder then what I've been used to, but still a great cup of coffee. It beats the chains any day!
author: Stephanie K.

description: just ok. there are better places for coffee, for cheaper.
author: Roy N.

description:
The coffee tastes amazing, no doubt about it.
My only complaint is the price (high) and the staff. (After all 3 of us asked at separate times to shut the door, it was about 50 degrees in there, staff told us "No.")
Oh well.
author: Amy Grace C.

description:
I had heard many good things about Ritual Roasters before going inside. I heard the espresso was some of the best one would ever have in San Francisco, I heard they made amazing artisan cappuccinos and I heard it was a great place to people-watch when having a cup of coffee in the Mission.

All of the above are true statements, however, I was not a fan of Ritual. Their cappuccino was perfectly made and the gingerbread cake was soft and spicy, but I was not a fan of the atmosphere. There were not enough sofas, too many tables and too many hipsters on their laptops. With sofas, you can justify sitting next to people you don't know but it gets very awkward to sit down at a table across from someone you've never met.

I had someone sit across from me and we chatted before going back to our books and our work. It was the sort of interaction I never would have had at a normal coffee shop, but when I go out sometimes I just want to be by myself and not have to sit in close quarters with everyone else.
author: Stephanie H.

description: There's no WiFi after the remodel.  Totally useless as a place to work now.
author: Frank B.

description:
Definitely a good cup of coffee, flavorful, robust, aromatic.
Just had me wanting more for a hand dripped coffee priced at nearly $4.
I get decent flavor from a french press at home, and i wish they offered me that option. Definitely a good cup, but it can be very slow coming (especially if there's a line). Philz is a good alternative.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
So I'm hangin in the Mission today.. 
Doing  Mission things-- Peruvian lunch, Colombian spices, Mexican randoms and then I wanted to get a Cuban Coffee.
Actually, the coffee was first on my list of to do's, but somehow ended up last on my list.
I initially went to Radio Habana Social Club, but they were closed.
So then I did a search and found the "Ritual Coffee Roasters" made a short Cuban.
I must say the place is cool-- the layout, atmosphere, interesting mix of people.  
The Barista made me a muy excellente triple shot latte.  It was bomb, and it was made with their special Colombian roast of the day.
The only reason I am giving them 4 stars --that all over the web, it states that they make a Cuban and they don't.

I will return.  :)
author: Stacy C.

description:
Argh. This place is so damn frustrating!

First, to get things straight, as far as the products are concerned, this place is beyond amazing. Anything that I have ever had, be it cappuccino, latte or just plain old coffee, has always been delectable - a great delight for my taste buds and my caffeine starved brain. 

Now, the reason for a meager 3 stars: the obnoxiously loud music! Not from one outlier experience but rather the norm.  Music at a cafe should accentuate the atmosphere, not dominate it, especially at a place where people are sitting on their laptops trying to get work done. 

I have been here for an hour and I haven't gotten any work done because
1) I can't focus and,
2) My brain hurts from this deafening nonsense.
author: Ankur S.

description:
I love the location, the aesthetics & most importantly...the COFFEE!!

You really can't go wrong at Ritual! 

Highly recommend you bring your laptop or a good book because the atmosphere is conducive to productivity or lounging!

The "heavy drinker" card keeps me coming back for more
author: Daniela G.

description:
This places pricing is so strange.
2.5 for espresso
2.75 for a latte?!?! or something like that.
3.1 for hot chocolate
I have nothing against paying for good coffee and I am not complaining that it's overpriced, I am just saying that it doesn't make sense that the jump from espresso to latte is only a quarter.  This makes me not want to get espresso and get a latte or a capp.  If the milk is only worth a quarter why is a a hot chocolate $3.10????

OK, so I'm anal about math and having this make sense.  This pricing definitely fails logic. Oh another thing that fails is there layout, the line is outside the door yet there is all this free space in the middle?!? wtf planner.

Anyway their soy latte was AMAZING but their hot chocolate was lukewarm at best.  Had to get it re-made.  3 stars for being kind of a weak duck.
author: Skye W.

description:
I wish I could give this place only 2 stars because I find Ritual so irritatingly pretentious and "hip" that I want to shake the people lining up outside everytime I walk past.  The problem for me is the Ritual folk are coffee snobs without truly having the goods to back it up.
But.  The coffee is honestly pretty decent, if a bit acidic (heard through the grapevine that they prefer acidic roasts because their palates are so coffee fried already - fine, but mine isn't) and the baristas are friendly and nice.
The space is okay, lacking in outlets which makes it hard to work, which some people probably like.  It's just totally, utterly overrated.
author: Jane F.

description: Although Philz minto mojito is so refreshing and makes me very happy, sometimes I just want a plain o latte. I was just passing by and decided to get a latte. Wow, each cup is made to order in front of you and it tasted amazingly smooth. I loved every sip of it.
author: Cindy T.

description:
FANTASTIC COFFEE IN A MINIMAL SETTING

I am always in search of great coffee and I found another location.  I love the minimal interior of this space; it feels like an oasis on 24th street.

Caffe Latte
I ordered a café latte and it was perfectly made with a rosette pattern on top.  I enjoyed the drinking the latte as I sat on the comfortable black couch and surfed on the complimentary Wi-Fi.

As I sat on the couch, I noticed the barista was making coffee to order in a French press.  What a great find, I will be returning.
author: Rob L.

description:
Something terrible has happened at Ritual. 

In the past, when I ordered a Ritual coffee (just the normal coffee, not that clover stuff) that coffee was french pressed. What that means is my coffee has a certain thickness to it. It had a weight. It lingered in my mouth, on my tastebuds. It wasn't just coffee water like so many other places. No, no. The coffee not only tasted and smelled awesome, it really felt like something. 

But  now Ritual has made a huge huge huge mistake. Now, in the vein of blue bottle, they are making all of their coffee single drip style. 

1) This makes the lines INCREDIBLY longer. Why? Because it takes INCREDIBLY longer to do. And, 9 times out of 10 they've only got one person making the coffee! 

2) The new coffee, while being way more $$$, has no thickness whatsoever. It lost what I loved so much about Ritual. 

So now my heart is broken. Do I still love all their little baked goods? Por supesto. Are their lattes still the best I've ever had (minus when I'm in the specific mood for Philz)? Yes. But if you want a regular coffee, I'd recommend you go someplace else. For the sake of your pocketbook, tastebuds, and patience. 

:(
author: Heather W.

description:
Waaaay overrated. I went twice simply because I could not fathom it being that poor.

The good ... Crazy fast wi-fi. Decent espresso drinks. 

The bad ... $4.50/ cup of single cup drip coffee that is outclassed by the vile, freeze dried, Folgers stuff my mother drinks.

The ugly ... According to my buddy who's lived in the neighborhood for a while, this place went down hill recently after some changes.
author: Ariel J.

description: Love the iced americano - the barista and the cashier seemed nice enough.  I'll have to knock off a couple stars for the ambiance and the fact that there was no seating whatsoever...nothing but people on laptops.  I was forced to have my drink to go.
author: Will C.

description:
Methinks not, indeed!

Are you a hipster who likes looking ironic while standing in line? Then this place is for you!  The line out the door seems to be its biggest feature, as everyone looks delighted to be standing around in it waiting for crap coffee and rude service.

You guys do know there's about 20 other coffee shops within two blocks of Ritual, right?  I think people must just love THE IDEA of drinking at such a hip place as ritual, what with its Communist theme and bitchy attitude, more than the actual idea of good coffee.

Sarcasm aside, the coffee is crap, the service is rude, and the wait is terrible.
author: Brian L.

description:
Was some of the tastiest coffee I've had. Very hipstery vibe, everyone was on their laptops. Line looked horrible but moved really fast

Luckily BrunchBox was in front for lunch, it was a great breakfast.
author: Kym T.

description: Guided by my friend to come here for coffee, I'm glad that I followed her.  Nice waitstaff who make good and pretty lattes.  With a scone to go with the latte and a casual environment, I felt quite at ease.  If there was a cafe like this near me, I would go there frequently to read/study/hang out.
author: Judy C.

description:
Hipster heaven, thankfully the H-sters are to busy being aloof and ironically cool to bother anyone.

That wasn't a criticism by the way, the clientele and feel of the place was kind of what I have been looking for since moving here.

Good loose leaf tea reasonably priced, served by the pot with an infuser.  The Golden Monkey is just plain great.  The problem is they don't time how long the tea has steeped or provide the customer a way to time it.  And the infusers clearly weren't meant for people who don't care for over steeped tea.  They sit flush in the pot and have no place to grab and no insulation making it a pain to remove.  Not talking climbing Everest hard, a spoon or finger nails can get the infuser, which is now hot, out.  Along with not providing a timer they don't provide anything to put the removed infuser on.  No surprise since the infuser apparently wasn't intended to be removed.  I just leave the infuser on the counter, I figure if they get tired of wiping up the mess that makes(not a big mess) they might figure out it is time to learn how actual tea is brewed.

Decent internet, plenty of seats, plenty of outlets.  Gets a little busy.  Not a huge fan of their music.

I'll certainly be back.
author: Max Jonathan S.

description:
First of all, I love Ritual's coffee. We buy it and grind it at home, and make it with the same set-up they do in the store.

But, I was trying to buy coffee last Saturday and they made me wait in line JUST TO PURCHASE BEANS. Now, if I were actually ordering something, I may be willing to wait in line for 30 minutes, but I just needed a simple cash register transaction, because I had the beans in-hand. I even went up and asked "Do I need to wait in line even though I'm just purchasing these beans?". This is a ridiculous policy. 

Oh, and the people who work there, for the most part, take their sweet time and have personal conversations when they should be paying attention to customers. But that's been a problem for a long time, and I don't expect it to change.

Oh, yes, it is a swirling cesspool of more-irony-than-thou, but I think other reveiwers have covered that.

However, the coffee is amazing.
author: Wendy J.

description: I am sorry, but $5 drip coffee is just not my thing. This is one of those hipster coffee spots where what you look like is more important than the quality of coffee served. The descriptions for coffee flavors are all wrong. I was expecting cantaloupe-raspberry and was served burnt toast instead. Never again.
author: Evan W.

description: The coffee is very good. But the service not so much. The main problem is that they are pretty slow. Even when there are just a few people ordering coffee, it takes quite a while. And I'm comparing to similar high-end roasteries in the areas who seem to be able to do this a lot faster.
author: Roy F.

description: Lukewarm coffee and gross soy milk. Not worth it.
author: Claire K.

description:
My friend was referring to this place as the "communist coffee shop" because she had just moved into the area and thought the sign out front was reminiscent of the defunct USSR flag. I pointed out that it was actually the outline of a coffee cup tilted, but  yes, it does have a remarkable resemblance to the old Soviet hammer and sickle.

We went here to try and digest the huge meal we had over at Blue Plate. I didn't really feel like coffee so I got an iced chai instead. The chai had a really nice flavor but maybe there was a little too much melted ice, because it was slightly watered down. Still good nonetheless. My friend had a cocoa with an ornately designed leaf patter on the milk and I'm assuming it was pretty good because she downed it in like 5 minutes. 

The broad layout of the room, with local art and knick-knacks hanging on the walls, creates a nice space, reminiscent of the early days of Equator down in Pasadena. The clientele reminded me of my art school/TA days, so I'll have to say there was some nostalgia even though I hadn't been here before. Although it was a Saturday night, it didn't seem that crowded and I figured out why when they started turning off the lights at 11pm. Wish it was open at least another hour so I could get a better feel for the ambiance. So far so good but I'll have to spend more time here one of these days to get a really good idea of it.
author: Kim N.

description:
Love love loved this coffee. Just the simple French Press Drip was a tall cup of love. The F.P. blend changes weekly --- nice for variety. I especially liked the guy with the kooky curly long black mustache taking orders. Cool guy. Oh yeah, they also have "frequent flier" punch cards, which I didn't see until my second visit, but look for them by the register.

Yes, many laptops. Yes, lots of folks staring at you from behind those laptops, not smiling. Bah, whatever. Its not a kumbaya type of place. We're in the cold big city just picking up some good joe. If anyone is anything more than slightly pleasant, that's a win. (But the funky-mustache-guy makes it just a little more fun).

NOTE: Do not purchase any of the Hario cone drippers they feature there in the store. The grounds fall directly through the big hole into your cup of coffee below because there is no support for the filter/grounds. Its a flawed design.
author: Carolyn F.

description: LLOYD DOBBLER sighting yesterday. Came back for a double-take.
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
This review is for the sumatra coffee --

For christmas, I received a bag of local SF goodies from my two sisters-in-law who live there.  The gift bag included one pound of ritual coffee beans.  my husband is the coffee drinker in the family, so i wasn't overly psyched about the red sack of beans.

As I mentioned, I do not drink coffee.  The strongest caffeine I ingest comes in the form of chocolate and tea.  Any more than that and i get the shakes.  After tasting ritual coffee, however, the coffee ban might be lifted.  

My husband brewed the sumatra this past weekend and it was on point.  No sugar, just a hint of cream.  It was smooth and had none of the bitterness that I often taste in coffee.

I feel bad writing such a glowing review.  The go-to coffee here in Philly for true fans is la colombe.  In liking ritual's coffee so much, i feel like i am cheating.

But you know what, the coffee better be this good for $20 per pound.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Yum! Delicious coffee!  I love this place.  It is big and open, with lots of people there working just about any time.

They really just do coffee (plus a few bakery items), and they do it well.
author: Cara M.

description:
Great coffee but there are a couple of places here that bother the hell out of me.

EXTREMELY long lines just for coffee, especially when I only get the cone drip.  I wish they had two lines, espresso bar and drip coffee, the line would move a lot faster.

They have one barista taking the orders and making the espresso drinks, which is what holds up the line so much.  There is then another person that is working on only the drip coffees and one at the cashier.

Although the coffee is good, its also EXTREMELY expensive just for a cup of drip.  I usually go for the cheapest one cause I can't find myself spending $5 for a cup of drip coffee.  Compared to Blue bottle or even starbucks, its highly expensive.

Other than that, at least they take credit card and there is plenty of seating.
author: Kameron K.

description:
I dig. After having coffee enlightenment at Intelligentsia in Los Angeles with my coffee connoissuer friend, I never thought I'd find a place to close to have good coffee.

But alas, San Fran has a good mecca in its vast stores to satisfy those coffee cravings, and Ritual is definitely on top. Staff is friendly and helpful. My friend's mocha was beautiful, as the pictures show, and my peppermint and rose tea soothed my achey throat from my troublesome cold. 

I love how there are bags of coffee beans sprawled out on crates in the back. Overall a nice setting, where tons of people come to study or have small talk. A little out of my way, but if you're ever in the Mish and want a good coffee shop, definitely is one to check out.
author: Alita M.

description:
Like a lot of Mission businesses, this place has that gritty hipster vibe, starting with their brand, which is a play on the communist hammer and sickle.  

Coffee was very good (extremely smooth), although definitely not the best I've ever had (I reserve that for Intelligentsia in Venice).  I'm not a true coffee purist/elitist, going for lattes rather than shots or something else that allows for better judgment of the coffee. After all, we go to retail establishments for the experience and atmosphere right?   And to that extent, a bit more food would be nice...

The decor...It's an open space with high ceilings that's got a mix of industrial and hipster decor.  There's ample seating in the place, even when there is a line out the door.

Service seemed curt rather than obnoxious as some other reviewers stated.  Also, the line out the door was a by product of a rather poorly organized process of taking and filling orders rather than high demand.

Overall, it's good -- and the coffee was enjoyable -- but it's probably not a place that I'd go out of my way for.
author: JOHN C.

description:
Too...

many...

hipsters!

And coffee that tastes burned.  I'm a coffee snob.  I know good coffee.  I just don't get the appeal of this place.
author: Paul S.

description:
This coffee was fair.

But what was cool is that everyone here knew each other. It was like Cheers, except Ritual serves coffee instead of pints of oat soda.

"Hi Jean, here's your double espresso with a hint of cinnamon" or "Wow, Mike, your baby has gotten so big! Your wife Sally sure is a lucky woman. Remember when we dated? Ahh, that was fun. Here's your double-decaf with half-and-half and a mint leaf." This is the type of banter you hear on a Saturday morning at Ritual.

Of course, they didn't know me, so instead of being like Sam Malone, they were more like Rhea Pearlman's character in Cheers when addressing me: sassy and curt.

That's kind of what you hope for in a neighborhood coffee shop-- even one that acquires Yelp accolades like "second best cup of coffee in San Francisco" which is totally false. You'd like to feel like this is YOUR coffee shop, and if you do, you're willing to overlook the fact that they do nothing to resist the trend in SF to not serve non-fat milk (they say it ruins the coffee's taste... gimme a break).

On the other hand, the line out the door would imply that I'm wrong and everyone else is right. Unless, of course, you're used to Starbucks, in which case Ritual's java is like God's love served piping hot from hands of angels.

I disagree, of course.
author: Ross S.

description:
Note to self: when the time between cups of coffee is measured in years, be prepared for a ruffie like crash from the caffeine high.  I admit it, I don't really ever drink coffee or any serious forms of caffeine.  I have some green tea and since it isn't that trash meth infused stuff from starbucks, the caffeine content isn't nearly the same as actual coffee.  I got some Brazilian coffee from Ritual, partly out of boredom and partly cuz this place seemed like a pretty cool spot.  I let it cool way more than any respectable coffee drinker would and then drank it way too fast.  The crash came shortly after.  

Despite all of this, I would still probably go back if I am ever in the neighborhood.  I would probably try a milder blend or even see if there was tea somewhere on the menu, but this place just has a positive vibe about it.
author: Jason P.

description:
Ok, they have some of the best coffee around (I have not been to Blue Bottle or to 4 Barrel, but...). When the french press coffee for a pretty good sized cup cost $1.50, what a deal! And free wifi. Sweet.

I just went back 30 minutes ago to have some coffee and work on a research proposal, blah blah... NO MORE FRENCH PRESS COFFEE. Right, OK, I like other preparations of coffee. But not when the cheapest one is 2.50 and an espresso. Or you can get specially made drip coffee for 3.50 or some ridiculous figure like that. If you make a lot of money, whatever, I'm happy for you. But if you are a grad student or not rolling in the green, go down the street to the Marsh (where I am now). I know I'm never going back unless someone else is paying or they bring back under $2 coffee.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Really nice , chill environment. Delicious coffee. Very similar to blue bottle coffee. The expresso tastes a bit more fruity and light in comparison. Lovely, simple latte. 

#beenmosteverywhere #i'veeaten/dinedinover40statesand20countries
author: Seemewrite C.

description:
1070 reviews is adequate proof that this place is good.

All I'm going to say is that this is the only place I've found, so far, in SF, that has made a legit ass cup of flat white without my having to explain what it was, all owing to one spectacular barista whom I have yet to find again. But I will find you.

I'm gon find you.
author: Chieh T.

description:
I am a coffee fetishist. I roast my own beans (see Sweet Maria's review). I was the first to review Blue Bottle, Oakland in 2005. So I am not shocked to pay a little more for really good coffee. But as much as I think Ritual does a excellent job sourcing and roasting coffee, I can not get into a $3.75 cent mug of coffee. Even if it is custom ground and poured for me.

I have some other complaints, that range from the basic to the trivial. On the basic side, I am not a fan of the 12oz bag of copy. Sell me a pound, or a half pound. Or whatever I ask for. But try to fool me with the 12 oz bag. That's too much like the 1.5 qt or 14oz ice cream package scam. On the trivial side, the Ritual logo is too f-ing precious. A cross between like the islamic symbol and the CCCP. It's just too cool for me. Perhaps they are trying to justify there inflated prices. So, though the beans deserve a 4.5, I am deducting a point and a half for Rituals neo-corporate logo driven sales persona.

Lastly, and I admit, I am being  a nit-picking asshole here: For each cup, they measure a standard amount of beans and water. This is better than no standardization, but really, not all beans are created equal. Each batch of beans requires an adjustment to the water/coffee ratio in order to optimize the brew. If they were completely serious, I think they would work that out. I'm just saying...
author: Bruce K.

description:
Okay, I live a half a block away and probably only go here about twice a year. Yes the coffee is okay and very pretty-love those leaf designs! But a. I don't want to wait a half hour to get my coffee b. there is lack of places to sit and actually enjoy my espresso or pretty latte c. the staff seem somewhat impatient if I ask questions about things coffee
Sorry, I love coffee so I walk the extra 8 blocks or so and go to Philz on 24th or 18th. Where I get my coffee in a timely manner (yes, it's not as pretty), I can relax and drink my coffee and the staff is always ready to make recommendations about which coffee I should choose--all yummy!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Ritual is a mixed bag for me. They are clearly good roasters of coffee and have good technique, but I don't care for the space and the service is not that good.

The space feels a bit disjointed to me and it has been disemboweled. Someone took out the roaster! They left the raised platform and the old exhaust duct, but the heart of the place has gone somewhere else.

The staff is not particularly friendly, nor fond of giving anything more than a passing nod to your presence. They can make a decent cappuccino, true, but the overall experience is lacking. I do like their packaging, though.
author: Joe J.

description:
The coffee was good. I had an Americano. I have nothing but good things to say about the pastry I had, and the selection from which it was plucked. A very rich chocolate muffin. Yum.

The crowd was a pretty cool one ... I gotta say ... Lots of skinny tight jeans and black hoodies. People all around me were discussing bands I had never heard of. I took my coffee to go and was pleased with the counter arrangement for sugar, cream, etc.
author: Wes T.

description:
If I still drank coffee on a regular basis, this would be one of my go-to places. Their coffee is fantastic, right up there with Blue Bottle in terms of quality.

But they're sloooow. And expensive. So it's probably a good thing that I don't drink that much coffee anymore, because otherwise these people would have a lot more of my money.
author: Sam K.

description:
Coolest looking brand identity...  like some vintage communist imagery with a modern graphic minimalism...  yeah, dig it.

I'm guessing that's why people choose to hang out here - because it makes them seem cool, vintage, yet modern (let's not forget minimal) at the same time.  Well, I didn't get a chance to hang out, because there were no available tables for me to sit down for 2 mins to sip my espresso...  maybe if I'd brought my laptop and camped out for a couple of hours I'd be able to stake out my little niche of this coffee shop.  Alas, I didn't bring my laptop, and even if I had, I don't have any cool friends that I could have facebooked to let them know to meet me here.

The espresso shot was decent though - actually, downright tasty...  the Evil Twin, or something...  not sure.
author: erik w.

description:
We did not like the flavor of this espresso at all, even when I made some at home with a longer pull than their few drops of acid in a cup.

The young guy making our shots was very unfriendly and I didn't see one smile behind that counter.  How can anyone enjoy coming in here?  Why does someone making my coffee treat me like a lesser being?  I have a real job, a cool one, with a salary, and yet I don't treat people like crap, even those making my coffee.  So WTF?  Never coming back here
author: Martha B.

description:
I'd go negative if I could. 

Rude service (hipsters who are "too cool for you" work here). 

Mediocre coffee. I love the fact they are trying to be green, but who cares about that if the people working suck. 

I'd go to Starbucks any day over this crap.
author: Zeke A.

description:
Last Sunday at 4:00 pm, I waited TWENTY MINUTES for my soy latte.  This excludes line waiting time  -- it is actual coffee prep time between ordering and receipt of my latte!   So wrong.  The baristas were chatting and taking their sweet time, and I had a bunch of friends waiting for me outside.  Had i known it was going to take that long, I would've passed.

Coffee quality is still good but I can't say I'll be back.  Four Barrels is closer to my house anyway.
author: Sid D.

description: I usually like to people watch while enjoying my hand dripped cup of caffeine goodness. The coffee at Ritual is great, however, this place is not conducive for people watching. All you'll see is plaid, beards, skinny jeans, and thick rimmed glasses.
author: Sue L.

description:
Dear Ritual,

I want to take this opportunity to thank you for mini chocolate creamcheese frosted cupcakes, coffee strong enough to walk on its own, and comfy couches in the back. I also want to curse you for the big chocolate creamcheese frosted cupcakes and for being so good that a place to sit is hard to come by. I forgive you for these transgressions, however, since the people behind your counter are usually super friendly. I miss living in SF and strolling into your loving arms on weekend mornings and weekday evenings. And big ups for the cool logo.

Love,

Ghada
author: GHADA Y.

description: First time here. Friendly barista. I had the El Renacer single origin espresso. Description said it had a marzipan finish and I could actually taste it. Delicious.
author: Jeremiah H.

description: I love Ritual Coffee Roasters. I've been going to this place for several years and although the place is totally different from what is was at the beginning, the coffee is still as good. Now is the brand and place for young and trendy people to hang out, but in the good old days it was the neighborhood place where one just went to get fresh, high-quality coffee and read the newspaper while enjoying a cup of authentic espresso.
author: Mary R.

description:
I honestly never thought I'd say it, but I love coffee and as the years have gone by, I have come to only like the best. I grew up only liking the smell of coffee and of course making my Mom's coffee in the morning, but now, it's one of my rituals, and excuse me for being cliche, but I've definitely come to make Ritual one of my rituals. 

Ritual has come to be the most consistent across the board from barista to barista, at least when it comes to my order, the large latte, para llevar. The shots are always smooth, never burnt, and the drink temperature is always warm, which means I can guzzle it down the second it's served. I LOVE that all the baristas fill the milk to the very top of the cup, almost to the overflow point. Truly the mark of a talented barista. Coffee flavor is another great area that Ritual's got down and I love the complexity of the espresso as well as the drip blends. Though it is gone, Double Rainbow espresso will always have a special place in my heart. 

I don't mind driving a few minutes in the opposite direction for a great latte in the morning. The varying tunes (Snoop D-O- Double G, to alternative, to punk, to African tribal) always keep me guessing, the tattoos of all the baristas always inspire me for new ink, and the consistent drinks always kickstart my day and have become my ritual. 

P.S. One of the only good quality coffee places that still run a "Buy 10, Get 1 Free" stamp card. Take advantage. (What can I say, it's the Asian in me)
author: Christina N.

description:
Yes, the hipster vibe is STRONG here. It's a little pricier than my usual coffee shop in Walnut Creek. But the baristas here are nice, approachable and they make the mundane task of brewing espresso an art form - I kid you not. I'm not a coffee snob by any stretch of the imagination but it's one of the best I've had so far, it isn't bitter or overly roasted and I notice that it's brewed with care and love - well, let's just say my latte had a little milk art on it, a carefully poured leaf. I've never seen coffee brewed with care, not just brewed, poured into a paper cup and slid onto the counter. 

If I lived in San Francisco, I'd come here as my usual establishment.
author: Navi T.

description:
I found out about this place through a friend of mind. Actually said friend works for Timbuk2 and said company had a party there. So my first visit was more about mingling and drinking free PBRs not sampling the coffee. 

However, the second time I was there I brought a very sweet girl named Mo. We had dinner and we're craving an apres-meal caffeine jolt. I order a macchiato and grabbed a couple of the mini cup cakes.

I'm going to upload a picture of the beautifully prepared macchiato. I was taken aback, seriously, and then I tasted it and my eyes rolled back into my head...mmm, yes that good. 

Ritual has stolen the title of "best macchiato" from Cafe Reverie and upped the ante 'cause it was so beautifully presented!

CheerS!
author: isaias J.

description:
I don't really know that much about good coffee. However, my body definitely knows a bit more than I do. Because, usually, I get mad squidgy poo poo if I drink coffee from a donut store or from the office coffee pot. 

Ritual Coffee Roasters has never done this to me. Also, the caffeine high I get from their coffee is so great that I almost feel as if I can see through things. Definitely worth the money!

Oh yeah, if you decide to use their restrooms, make sure you put some weight on the door to ensure that it locks. I swear I made some hipster guy's face turn into a Picasso when he walked in on me pulling my chones up.
author: aiza g.

description:
Good, strong, flavorful coffee.  Lots of seating and plus, free WiFi.  Great location.  I try to stop here on my visits to SF and I'll be back!

Edit: I see some people have mentioned that the baristas are not "chit-chatty"?  Well that's because they are focusing on getting quickly and efficiently through the often long lines; they are trying to make the customers happy by getting them their coffee accurately and in good time!  I respect that.
author: Emily S.

description:
Very very quality coffee - but it's going to cost you.  

Also, they have a wall of foreign dollars behind the cash register.  I just tried to pay them in Guyanese dollars and they turned me down - dirty hipsters.

I should also mention they're playing dragonforce.  what. the. ****  moreso - why do I know who this is?
author: Pete R.

description: I dont know a lot of things. I don't know one roast from another. I don't even know how to pronounce the coffee names. But I do know what I like. I like coffee. And as of today I like ritual.
author: Trevor T.

description:
To date this is the BEST coffee I have EVER had in my life. I was completely sober, not otherwise altered or enhanced or even hung over. Plain and simple. Brilliant. It were expensive too. But who the hell cares when it is that good. Dripped, not brewed. Not bitter in the least. No heavy acidic anything. Simply amazingly good coffee. Well worth the 8 block walk. And by god I will do it again. Liked the roomy, bright interior. Plenty of seating at tables and couches. I managed too get a drawing done in my sketchbook while enjoying the coffee and the great tunes playing. Starfucks can't hold a candle to Ritual. 

Nuff Said.
author: Nichole S.

description:
{{{2007 flashback???}}}


I had no cash so i came to Ritual. 
I made it clear to the cashier I was there to get work done. I spend $15 bucks on a pound of beans and a large cup of coffee because they have a $5 minimum for credit card purchases. 
I proceeded to the back of the cafe, no more couches! Haven't been here in over 2 years, everything rearranged. 
Tried to find a seat. The back of the cafe wreaked of body odor. Everyone looked like bad impersonations of people i knew in '07.
Struggled to get comfortable along the wall in a small table. Opened my computer. Prepared for an evening of narrative storytelling revisions. 
Computer battery going dead.  Walked around Ritual to find a plug. All outlets in the building blocked off from access. Got up and left.
author: Sunny Joy B.

description:
I had a latte. It was....just okay. I was expecting way better based on the reviews, but honestly I've had better at Martha Bros. Hell, I"ve had better at Peets.  Muddy Waters, anyone?

The music is very off-putting. Don't get me wrong. I love me some flo-rida and apple bottom jeans, and I can get down with Coolio, but in a cafe? When I'm trying to get some work done? 

And what's up with having no electrical outlets. 

Nothing to write home about. Wouldn't think of it when I crave a good cup of coffee or espresso.
author: Nao D.

description:
I am averaging my experiences here.

First time, got a soy cap.  Waited in line/at the counter for 20-30 minutes for a beautiful foam-art cappuccino.  I loved it.  It was summer and it was cold in SF.  I held on tight to my almost-scalding cup to stay warm and let the yummy soy cap heat up my esophagus.  I vowed I would come back.

So I did.

My second visit was much more brief.  A Friday afternoon, a short wait.  Kind of.  Short line, long wait for an Americano.  Iono what it was... but it was just not that good.  Kinda bitter, kinda acidic, kinda sour.  I drank like 85% of it but I didn't enjoy ~60% of my drinking experience.  Was it my bad to not add any cream or sugar to an americano?  I don't know.  Was it my bad to order an americano at Ritual?  Apparently the French Press Coffee has nothing on Cole Coffee in Berkeley.  

I think I'll stick with the lattes/cappuccinos if I meander over here again...
author: Lydia W.

description: so cute! they listened to my last review :) :)  There is now a parklet going in outside! 5 stars!
author: Best M.

description:
This coffee place is my second favorite (you can only serve one master) after Blue Bottle.  But here are the reasons I frequent it more...
Better Parking, More room to relax and enjoy that good coffee,  Better people watching and they have free cuppings on Fridays!
author: Mick H.

description: Love these fools!  My favorite coffee now...better than blue bottle, philz, 4 barrel, farley's.  Just got a phat saeco espresso maker too and their beans are just as good at home.  Even their decaf's good!!
author: Ramon L.

description:
super cute place
if i were a hipster, i would bring my laptop here and enjoy coffee culture
author: Christopher L.

description:
I am a Blue Bottle regular which I love! I come here once in awhile for friends who want to meet here. 

Ritual Coffee is good but I do not like their variable price on different coffees which is anywhere from 3.50 to 5.00 or more.  Not why I have given them three stars. 

Service is confusing at times and a bit disorganized. Twice my coffee got passed on to someone else while I was waiting. They have no efficient system of distribution of coffees. That was a major turn off on Ritual hence 3 stars. Lines are long here too so be prepared for a wait to get your cup o joe!
author: Sharif R.

description: If you like overpriced coffee that's not worth the hype, pretentious douche-y baristas that act like they're curing cancer as they make drip coffees while treating you like you're a bother, then you're in luck. Go to Ritual coffee. Otherwise, take your money to Philz where the coffee is consistently great and the people are welcoming and friendly. This coffee hipster bullshit has gotten way out of hand, San Francisco.
author: Sophie P.

description: Ritual is my go-to for a high-end cup of coffee.  They have good options, plenty of seating inside, and WiFi if you need it.  The line often runs out the door, but they work through it pretty quickly.
author: Dan W.

description:
I've been back to Ritual many times since my review from Oct 2009. I am compelled to write an update today because of poor customer service today.  I've read in other reviews that the staff, at times, tend to be standoffish and service, in general, can be spotty.  Is this expected of coffee Nazi's?

I come in this morning and wait for my turn.  There seemed to be a changing of the cash-register guard as I waited and it took quite some time since the one already manning it seemed either spaced out or was already imagining her impending break. I had 20 dollar bill in hand ready to give her my order and she just stood there, partly chatting to a coworker and partly fiddling with cash.  She did not even look at me or tell me that someone was going to be with me in a moment. She just walked away. So, that's rudeness Number One.

Rudeness Number Two was when the replacement, who was just as distracted and space out asked me "so, you have money for your order?"  Are you serious?  I stood there patiently waiting to give you my order and hand you my payment and YOU ask me if I have money for your order?  

Your staff's arrogance can only go on so long with people who are not that addicted to your coffee, really. Management should have a pep talk with these people as regards customer service. Really? Really.
author: Jun Q.

description:
Ok, I couldn't take it, I had to go back and give it another shot.  I was absolutely shocked to find the sweet girl behind the counter (who seemed to be more of a geek than a hipster) actually *smiled* at me and said "thank you".  Whaddya know.  I left her a $1.50 tip because I was so tickled at the thought that perhaps the folks at Ritual might be listening to their *gasp* customers!  

But the funniest thing happened.  I got my12oz soy latte.  It was lukewarm.  Nay, it was cold.  And it tasted like poo.  Muddy and cold.  I was really disappointed.  This has happened twice now to varying degrees of lukewarmness.  Oh I wanted to give you another star, Ritual, I really did- to reward your newly found customer service skills!  But, well, my $4.50 latte was actually worse than the dregs at the bottom of the pot at the coffee shop around the corner.   I'm just gonna stick with Phil'z.  *sigh*
author: Alli J.

description:
Ritual on a weekday morning is something good for the soul.

The coffee is excellent, as is the urban ethnography. Embrace the hipness, don't fight it.

I love sitting on the leather couch, reading a book, while basking in the sun.
author: George S.

description: Had a fun afternoon catch up with an old friend in this cute SF cafe.  Great coffee and relaxed atmosphere.
author: Bryanna E.

description:
Dear Ritual, 

Your iced mochas are cup-lickingly delicious, but you decided to cover up every electrical outlet so that no one could plug in their laptop? Wow, that's so short-sighted that it hurts.

Recommended? = No.
author: Chris R.

description:
Today, on this glorious, overly humid, too bright and sticky New York day, when I am as hungover as the guy that's always sleeping on the subway platform*, I crave only one thing: Ritual Coffee.

I hate that I am 3,000 miles away from not only this coffee, but this cafe. 

Everything was delicious, so much so that some of us went multiple times a day. Regular coffee was good, iced coffee was good, the chai was good, the lattes were good. Sense a pattern? Except substitute "perfect" for "good."

But I also have a feeling that if I lived here, this would be where I spend all my time reading, writing, Interneting (free wi-fi!) or just simply hanging out (if you can secure a nook; this place is popular, and rightfully so). It's a laid-back, adorable cafe that I'm still searching for in New York. Ritual Coffee, where is your east coast equivalent?!**

Now, I must return to slumber to heal my head, and dream about delicious coffee.
__________

* I was almost that guy this morning. 3 hours of sleep is rough; not doctor recommended.
** Whoever can help me: I'll buy you coffee!
author: Brett W.

description: I don't have a whole lot to say. The mocha was a little sweet for my taste, but not bad. My friend's cappuccino was okay but not stellar. The staff was nice. Ritual was not disappointing, but not memorable either. I do however love their logo, and thought about buying a mug just for that.
author: Katie L.

description:
since it was ranked on the GQ magazine, my curious butt went to check out their latte.   honestly, i was not that impressed.  mmm maybe i was expecting too much?!?!?

on a side note, their small size is like micro small size.  less than 8oz for real.  so keep that in mind and you prolly wanna order large.
author: Jee C.

description:
Not my favorite coffee joint in San Francisco but their baristi can make wicked cups of coffee.   However, they are a little too full of themselves.  I like some attitude in my baristi, but they push it a little too much.

Slightly overpriced for what you get , but there are plenty of seats and allot of power outlets.  If you are in the mission and need a coffee fix, this is a solid place to go.
author: Domo S.

description:
Any coffee shop that can't make a cappuccino is failing on a very basic level. I attempted to order a 'dry' cappuccino, and was informed that they can't give me just foam because they can't just spoon it off the top. What I received was a small latte. Hot milk with the tiniest surface of foam poured into a shot of espresso. The espresso was not terrible, but not particularly inspirational either, especially considering being muted by the milk. I suspect that they have this policy because the barista want to draw fancy patterns into the top of your drink, which I hear is all the rage now, and with a traditional cappuccino, there is no chance to draw a fun little heart or rose or pair of skinny jeans into the top of your coffee.

However, outside of an inability to make foam, the ambiance is not bad. There is good natural lighting, muted and elegant decoration, and comfortable (and available) seating with no hassle free internet. The music is a bit too noisy and experimental for my tastes, but it is not overpowering. Also, there is a distinct lack of available power outlets, which I suppose discourages the type of table hogging and camping that can often occur in coffee shops nowadays. I think that a larger collection of small tables would be of service here, as only one of the many 4 person tables has more than a single person with a laptop occupying.

If I come back, I'd either order one of the specialty espresso shots or a latte proper. I've been spoiled by amazing coffee elsewhere in the mission, which leaves my expectations for a hip cafe like this rather high, especially when it comes to the very basics of espresso drinks.
author: Christophe T.

description:
Ritual represents a new form of Mission (well, perhaps not so new now) - hippie intellectuals drinking coffee with vaguely Communist insignia stamped on paper cups.

So for a non-coffee drinker, it's actually difficult to get ... anything other than coffee. I asked for a juice: they didn't have any. Nor did they have much in terms of edibles.

The pastry I had, some sort of sherry chocolate cake, seemed a bit too dry, with not enough sherry, or whatever alcohol it purportedly is supposed to have.

The atmosphere on a Sunday or Saturday afternoon is typically lively, chatty, fun. But will 20-somethings really write their next great novel here?
author: Hubert H.

description:
How the times have changed. First off, ritual doesn't serve french pressed coffee anymore. They've moved on to the V60, a one cup at a time system similar to Philz and bluebottle. I, for one, am happy for the change. The coffee is much less acidic and more consistent. They've got coffee making down to an exact science, the same temperature, bean content and pour every time. An unfortunate side effect of this switch is that the coffee price has gone up a bit. You can still pay 2.50 for the cheapest beans, but you can also splurge 5.00 for beans that are better in some way that I'm not privy to.

Everything else is the same, great vegan donuts, free wifi, no power plugs, and comfortable abundant seating. They finally got rid of the roaster that used up 1/3 of their space.
author: Ralph G.

description:
I've tried all of the elite "on site roasters" including Blue Bottle(4.9 stars for me).  I love this coffee and after living in France and Italy, I still think ritual is the best.

In the last couple of years, a couple of employees went and opened up 4 barrel at the other end of Valencia.  They get a 4 out of 5 because their coffee is very good.  I am happy they did this because:

1- Ritual was too crowded. and,
2- Four Barrel took the most arrogant, pretentious and unfriendly employees out of Ritual (thank you).  

FYI, 4 barrel's space was designed to be uncomfortable, too (so you don't sit too long) and they don't have any tea at all for non-coffee drinkers ("we want to focus on coffee").  Gee, you don't know how to pour hot water, but you're happy to sell $3 donuts?  No thanks.

Keep up the good work, Ritual!  I love ya!
author: John A.

description: Serious about their coffee, well-lit space, great art work, reliable wifi. All-in-all a solid coffee shop.
author: Michael A.

description: Very friendly service! We got an explanation of how the espresso was being made, and how they do their pour overs. The barista actually felt the drink was not made up to standard an re-did it. Pretty impressive given the customer didn't even know or complain in advance. It's was very similar to cafe grumpy in New York. Had the Kenya for $3, and a soy latte. Espresso was pretty good, but could have been a bit more foamy. The Kenyan was pretty good, and would have gone good with a walnut bread. Lots of graphic design and programmers, and water at the bar which was nice, although seems standard in San Fran. They also had a good flow, even though there was a line and each coffee took longer to make there was little to no bottle necking. It's a great place, but I would have liked a little something special as well. Seems too similar to cafe grumpy or blue bottle.
author: Stephen L.

description:
i grew up with dad who was bit of a coffee connoisseur and as a treat, he used to buy a freak'n expensive, but yummy real blue mountain coffee using siphon coffee maker.  once you know the taste of blue mountain, most other coffee is just another dark brown water with just a hint of flavor.  (and that's why i can't give 5 stars)   

i tried everything and after drinking blue bottle and was deeply disappointed, i discovered ritual!   this is THE BEST in the city.  their coffee is never burnt like Starbucks and other more commercialized coffee; good amount of acidy flavor and doesn't give you bad aftertaste.  

trust your taste buds....
author: Peaceful S.

description:
The coffee is outstanding. A single cup of drip, and I was feeling like I didn't want any more coffee for a few days.
The aesthetic is very hip and sparse, and there is lots of seating and free internet. 
Good luck finding an AC outlet, though!
The staff was generally friendly, and I will come back here whenever I am in the area.
author: Chris W.

description: If there is any way that I can rate it for 6 stars, I would. The coffee here is the best around my area. No wonder everytime I go here, the line is always long.
author: Cavin T.

description:
[Green Zebra Coupon: Free cup of coffee with 3/4 lb of beans or buy one, get on free coffee]

I've only seen longer lines at the Starbucks on Union Square. Seriously, the coffee was OK, but in San Francisco, OK coffee just won't cut it. 

So how does Ritual do it? Is it the free WiFi? Probably not. Is it the location? I'm sure that has something to do with it, but places a few doors down were half as crowded. 

Oh, is it the hipsters? OH! IT MUST BE THE HIPSHTAHS!

Now the mob of 30 year-old road bikes and just-sub-30 year-olds crowding in a cafe who's logo makes one think of Soviet-Communism makes perfect sense.

Come here if you have a lot of time to spend waiting for your coffee and like to ogle at creatively-dressed Valencia-frequenters.
author: Elena C.

description: Great place to grab a cup of coffee and get some work done. Or people watch.
author: Espie B.

description:
The coffee is good, but I didn't like the service. 
I felt rushed.
Staff wasn't friendly, courteous or helpful.
And the place was packed with people.
It just wasn't a good place to hang so I took my capps and left.
Will I be back? Probably not, but I'm sure they could care less.
They seem like they've got a nice following.
Again, coffee is good, but it's not the right place for me.
author: Mary M.

description:
My first visit, I really enjoyed the people watching - all walks of life - ignore haters when they go 'It's all hipsters here.' And so what if it is? 

I ordered a drip coffee of the day - auuuggghh - too floral, too Sumatra-y. I'm an Italian / French Roast man - gimme that burned note every time. I approached the grrrl on point, "This is ok, I'm just not fan of floral coffees... could I swap?" 

She says, "Listen, let me do you an Americano, it's cool."

Best. Americano. Ever. Thanks for *totally* taking care of me, blonde bob Ritual grrl.
author: Mark S. I.

description:
I love this coffee, and don't feel guilty about being a coffee snob. The baristas are all serious about making the coffee, and if I have to wait a little I don't mind because I know it will be awesome.

I must say it's definitely a hipster hangout, and thought it amusing when I walked in once to find almost every single person in the shop working on their silver Macbook- not even a white one. Any PC user will definitely be a minority here.

This brings me to the reason I give a 4 star- simply because everyone here sits and works all day so finding a place to sit is rather difficult.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
I am officially DONE with Ritual.  Either their staff is totally stoned 24/7 or just underwater.  I am not willing to wait in a line for 15 minutes for a freaking cup of coffee.  For that time I can walk the 15 feet to Blue Fig, have a nice chat with the guy behind the counter and then walk back to work sipping my coffee.  

I get they grind every cup etc but then they should hire some more staff to make it run a little smother for busy days.  

DO NOT GO HERE!
author: Amy P.

description: I heard that these guys compete with blue bottle? I'm definitely a bigger fan of these guys than blue bottle!
author: Eugene T.

description:
Four stars because I haven't yet decided if this place is too hipster or not.

I almost gulped down my latte because it was so delicious, and it came with a fancy foam design to rival any other I've seen (this one was a leaf).  There weren't any non-vegan cake options (!) but the one I chose is light and delectable, a chocolate sherry confection of some kind, covered with powdered sugar.  The drink service was not as fast as the big chains, which is kind of refreshing.  

The clientele are a cross-section of money and age, which is always a good sign.  Some "ladies who do lunch" were waiting in line, designer bags draped over their arms, and paid with credit card.  They were fortunately in the minority.  The guy behind me in line struck up a conversation; turns out he grew up in Saudi Arabia.

So there's enough substance--people and refreshment--to keep me coming back.  A substantial demographic of the painfully hip, young, white-people-trying-to-be-poor set, but they don't seem to dominate.  The music is unobtrusive.

The insignia above the door looks like a communist sign, but since many patrons are using fancy laptops and paying with credit cards, that would be a consistency FAIL if I'm right about the symbol.  The whole neighborhood is, though, so maybe that's good.
author: Diana G.

description:
Overly pretentious.  Long lines.  Hipsters to you puke.  Looks like an Apple Store with all the technology being used by peops in the joint.  BUT they do make excellent coffee.

Take it to go!
author: Celeste S.

description: A very nice place to study/work. They serve great coffee and free wifi. Definitely more local friendly and less commercial than Starbucks. They have small tables for 2 people , larger tables and some couches. However, some tables are a little bit loose on the screws.
author: Wayne Z.

description: If this is hipster coffee, I'd rather be a normie.  I'll stick to Philz when in the area.
author: Michael M.

description:
Ritual is my favorite coffee in SF, but it may not be yours. 

I don't really like espresso, so I only get the single-pour cups. It's strong, on the bitter side, and super flavorful. You may hate it, but I crave it.

The staff are generally chilly and probably won't flash a smile or banter with you. If chit-chat with baristas is important to you, you'll probably want to go elsewhere. 

I love the spare, minimal decor of the place, the airiness, and the light. I'm not a MacBook warrior, so I don't care about the lack of outlets. Seriously, they get so many customers each day, if they had outlets, the tables would all be taken in the morning and held for hours. Sucks for those who want to work from cafes, but great for people who want to hang out and talk or read a little and then move on. 

My complaints are few. I wish they had more and better food options. More savory things, especially. I wish they had a better sound system. The music the staff chooses is often excellent, but the speakers are awful. And really that's about it. 

I can see why some people hate the place, but fortunately there are about 10,000 alternatives in this great city. For me, it's close to ideal.
author: Kaley D.

description:
Up: Good coffee. Cool people. Free wifi

Down: Almost no electrical outlets for customers. Blisteringly loud music.
author: Michael T.

description:
Coffee is pretty good here and I like the vibe.  It's a great place to spend  an hour here sipping coffee and reading the paper.  The vibe is laid back, young and is both yuppie and bohemian at the same time.  Their beans are expensive at $16 to $20+ per bag.

For me, the coffee at Blue Bottle and Philz are stronger and better.  It's   is a good alternative to Peet's.

3.5 stars for their coffee
4-5 stars for atmosphere / space
author: Paul K.

description: Great place to hang out.  Comfy couches in the back and lots of seating.  Started with a latte and a slice of ginger bread.  Followed up with an iced coffee.  We were there on a Friday late morning and there was practically no line to speak of. :)
author: Tracy A.

description:
I can't speak for the coffee as I didn't get any.  

However, their croissants are almost exactly akin to an authentic croissant from Paris.  The size was a little larger than ones in France, but it had a good ratio of fluffy inside to buttery and crispy outside.  Lovely, and simply delicious, even without an espresso to match. 

I can't wait to try a pain au chocolat there.
author: June H.

description: Their coffee was rated one of top 7 in a 7x7 article and we tried all 7.  Ritual is my least favorite.  The coffee is too acidic for my taste.   I also tried their decaf mocha and it was not good at all, tasted watery with little coffee taste.  I know it's decaf but the decaf mochas from Sightglass and Four Barrel are way better.  I will not be back as there are better coffee out there for my taste.
author: Irene C.

description:
I finished my grad school thesis here...I now spend a few days a week looking for jobs here. It's like my little dream office where people make me coffee and they play good music and I can people watch. It's not for everyone, but I love it. 

Perfect lattes and everything else. I've spent countless content hours here. 

My new year's resolution is to use the punchy-card so I get a free latte 
every now and then. I've probably earned a few by now......
author: C Z.

description:
Antipodeans and espresso lovers, take heart! 

Ritual has real baristas making their coffees, there's no drip coffee here.

For those of you looking for a flat white, their lattes are pretty close. 

There's not much in the way of food, but then you're coming here for coffee and nothing else. 

Atmosphere-wise the cafe seems to be largely populated with tables of MacBook users. Perfect for those of you who like that sort of thing, but perhaps a little impersonal otherwise. They have free wifi.

Oh, and be aware that there could be a long queue on weekends. This place is popular for a reason.
author: J S.

description: Coffee made with a pinch of devotion and love. The baristas make lovely coffee-art and the quality of the coffee is excellent. For my taste the roast aroma of the coffee is a bit to heavy. But all in all, it's worth to take a break there and have a coffee and a vegan ginger bread.
author: Julia D.

description: Great coffee, but the level of pretension in this joint is suffocating. I'd prefer to just order the beans online and sip a cup at home.
author: Zeenat H.

description: As East Coasters, we aren't used to Mocha's being under $4 so that already gives Ritual some bonus points. Tasty drinks, good enough service (quicker than what we're used to as they're service line is a bit different than most), and reasonable prices. Sure Ritual's a bit snobby and hipstery, but they serve more-than-decent coffee and espresso drinks so it's all good. Oh and they take credit card... Down with that.
author: Fede O.

description:
It's true: there's no shortage of decent coffee in SF. I used to think that included Peet's (and not that it's "bad" per se), but when you've had Philz, Blue Bottle and Four Barrel, well it's hard to compare. And we won't even talk about Starbucks. Enter Ritual. It's probably not that different than the other 3, but I just like the beans. A lot. They don't shine and I used to think that was indicative of "industrial roast" (i.e. crap) but that isn't necessarily the case. I have a burr grinder and it's to my advantage to not use uber oily beans (lest I clean it religiously), plus Ritual would say that dark / black / oily beans are most likely over roasted. Remember the days when dark roast was the coffee connoisseur's roast? Not anymore. 

The venue itself is far too hip for me. I go typically on a Friday at 6am (when they open) with ratted / matted hair , having rolled right out of bed to grab some beans quickly before my first conference call. I'm in no mood to socialize. No, I don't want to wait for them to make me a cup - it takes too long, it costs too much, it's waaaaaay too small. I hate the line and I feel weird about cutting (but I'm *only* buying beans). It's actually kind of stressful going, but I'm hooked so I suck it up. It may be easier to sustain other addictions. Consider carefully.
author: erin s.

description:
I came to Ritual with great expectations! But I was totally disappointed.
Possibly the worst coffee I had in the city.. no flavor at all, very diluted  and watery. This coffee almost ruined my entire afternoon..that BAD!  
I am going back to Philz coffee.
author: Mekhala M.

description:
I will say, I like the logo...and everyone who works there is gold star worthy...but they sure let you know they are roasting all the damn time...

(and endless amounts of Built to Spill blaring over the roasta' does not help me keep my chi in check!!)
author: sophia s.

description: This place is really cool and not to be missed. I am so happy I came across it walking by. I ended up staying and hanging out for a bit. It is spacious, has a great staff, and the best coffee around.
author: Jeanie L.

description: Dropped in for an Americano nightcap. This trendy progressive way of single serving coffee is pretty freakin' bougie, but I guess I can dig it. I would definitely say Ritual has one upped Blue Bottle. My espresso had bite, but didn't leave me parched like most espressos do. Ritual will definitely be my go-to when in the Mission.
author: Heather P.

description: You walk in to see the sign say order with Barista, which personally I think is very cool! I wasnt sure what to order and asked for the darkest roast, having to previous not so good watered down coffee experience the day before. She pointed the costarican blend, I ordered that and a kids hot chocolate. My coffee was so disappointing. it was tangy and watered down, which was really too bad because i read so many great reviews and heard a lot about this place.. If you like a bold cup of coffee this is NOT the place for you. The ambiance was cool, the employees or "hipsters" were all really sweet and attentive. I had a cheese danish which was  nice and flaky. My daughters hot chocolate was average. Overall, not my cup of Joe.
author: Giselle G.

description:
I've kinda given up on Ritual despite trying terribly hard to like it for a number of months.  

Ritual has this problem of just sort of hating their customers.  Maybe not explicitly hating them but it's sort a de facto, implied hatred.  There's a certain kind of blase about the place.  The lines are long, it closes early, the music is loud, there are never enough tables, the staff is just-so friendly, but not so much ... I can't put my finger on it.  It's the elements put together.  Like when there's a staff ping-pong tournament (or something) at 7pm on some random Wednesday, and you just took the BART specifically to go there and hang out a bit, and well ... sorry ...

I applaud them very much for having a high standard of coffee.  Pastries?  Not so much.  The pastry is kind of sad.  If you want good pastry, well, go to Tartine, you prig ... whoops, that's the bad me coming out ... trying not to be snippy ... trying ...

I'm not saying not to go here; the coffee is quite good, I'm sure they're good people and all, but ... go guarded.  Bring your thick skin.  Paying money has its price, and you must endure a thousand cuts if you dare to make Ritual your regular spot.  Consider yourself warned.
author: J W.

description: Some of the best of the Bay.  My cappuccino was pretty much heaven in a cup.  Trendy location.  The only thing is that this place is always full and there's no where to sit.  The staff is kinda stuffy too.  Nobody's got time for that.
author: Michelle H.

description:
By far my favorite coffee in town.  Their lattes alone make a trip across town worth it.

The lack of one star comes down to the seating & general over crowdedness.  Do not expect to sit while here.  Get your heavenly caffeine laden bean nectar to go.
author: Eric S.

description:
Great beans, I buy here regularly for home grinding and espresso pulling. And unlike the juvenile barristas here I know how to serve a latte that is in fact hot not lukewarm.

Horrible place to stay, bad and loud music, line out the door, never a place to sit, very spotty service (from rude to just fine)

Not kid friendly. Not adult friendly. Very much grimy 20 something hipster in poorly fitting tights jeans with macbook pro friendly. Which is fine, everybody needs a spot to enjoy, but this isn't it for me
author: B. M.

description:
If only I lived closer, I would come here all the time.  Then I might be able to figure out the slower times so I could actually sit down to enjoy my coffee.  Usually I only come on Sunday afternoons, and even if the line isn't out the door (not that I mind waiting for a fantastic macchiato), every table and couch seems to be full with the Mission's hipsters and their macbooks.  Then again, I would be the shabbier version in the corner if I lived in the neighborhood.

Aside from the great espresso, extra points for the vegan pastry selection, offering French press coffee, and the LOGO.
author: katie e.

description: Popped in last night for a coffee and to borrow some wifi to pretend to study.  Had the basic cup of joe....FANTASTIC and the servers were awesome.
author: Amy S.

description: om nom nom nom nom nom nom.  i love their lattes.  they're perfect, and i love to hate on lattes.  mmm so good.
author: Amy M.

description: Very friendly and competent staff, great space, and good coffee (!), but haven't appreciated the significant price hikes over the past 12-18 months.
author: Peg W.

description:
This place is a little too cool for me.  I wouldn't have any issues spending time in a place because it is too hipster - I think that's countering pretentiousness with pretentiousness.  But the baristas here are a bit cold and have attitudes like bartenders.  I appreciate warmth out of people, especially when I'm about to spend $6 on my coffee break.  Other issues:  There aren't many outlets in the walls here - it looks like they blocked many of them so that people wouldn't spend too much time here.  Loud 80's punk music doesn't bother me but it is something to consider.

3 stars because their coffee is actually really good - their redeeming quality.
author: Nathan V.

description: Usually love the coffee (it can be very weak sometimes; wish we could have muddy French press) but no cafe should have rap (or any other kind) music so loud it vibrates the chair I'm sitting in and can be heard over the best noise-canceling headphones money can buy.
author: John A.

description:
I don't care how hip you are, Ritual.
Nowhere to sit?
No vanilla syrup?!?
Fuck off.

(But thank you for the vegan donuts.)
author: shane s.

description:
The Clover coffee is what they are known for--so be sure to try it. But it's fun watching the baristas pour out the milk, too, so also go for the lattes!

Definitely one of the hippest places in SF! But don't be intimidated--just go because you want some good coffee!
author: Joyce L.

description:
Great stuff--have never had a bad cup of coffee here. Only gripe is that the music is always cranked up too high. And a few more baked goods wouldn't hurt. 

Hate the monolithic trendoid atmosphere of the Mission? Try the coffee at one of their vendors, such as Horatius in Potrero. Or try the Ritual at the tranquil and inviting Flora Grubb Gardens in Bayview, or the one up in Napa at Oxbow Market (where you can also grab a Kara's Cupcake just a few counters away).
author: Tom M.

description:
Ritual has good coffee, but it's bit pricier than what I'm used to paying. My BF and I came here two weeks ago and each had a cup of the Kenyan roast with orange/guava flavors. I had high hopes, but was somewhat disappointed with the blend. The blend was just too sweet for what I had expected. Almost overly tangy than what was intended to be a hint at the end of the taste. My pallet was left with a sour aftertaste that needed to be washed down with a York peppermint patty. 

The bag of Colombian that I brought home with me redeemed what I had on Sunday. If I had could give Ritual two separate ratings - one for first impression, the other for what I brought home... the first would be 2 stars, the second would be 4.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Delicious soy latte, double rainbow was a little too sweet of a shot for my taste.  I know a lot of people complain about the crowd, but it was surprisingly not as overrun by hipsters as the rest of Valencia can be.  The baristas were friendly and patient when they explained to the person in front of me that they don't add syrups or sauces to their drinks.

A good local coffee shop, but would I seek it out if it weren't four blocks from where I live? Maybe.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Ritual had the best coffee in SF before they remodeled no contest, and after they remodeled they still have the best coffee in SF. the new space might be a touch too "new Mission," but they've at least added some art to it. i like to think the remodel is a sign they're adapting and doing well. before judging, keep in mind their clientele is no longer the artist/punker/hip/cool/writer type(those folks don't live in the mission anymore). it's the super corporate/yuppie/lame/uber/mainstream type and there's nothing they can do about it. Ritual couldn't predict that valencia street would become  bay street emeryville. 
yep the coffee is still great. go for the pour over coffee. always go for the pour over coffee(as in don't get the "quick" drip or whatever it's called), i'm pretty sure those are always the best on the menu. really though if you go here get the espresso. it's like no other espresso i've ever had in the best of ways and has been for several years. i don't live in the neighborhood anymore so unfortunately i don't make it by much, but when i stop in on the friday commute home down the peninsula for an espresso and then grab a movie next door, i feel like all is well in the world.
author: Kyle W.

description: On an out of town visit, I stumbled cross Ritual seeking a place with wifi. The crowd and vibe overall seemed chill and sorta hipstery but overall friendly. I bought two packages of coffee to take back to Seattle on my way out. Holy greatness! Sorry Stumptown Roasters, you're my second favorite roaster now. As much as I sorta hate to admit it, Ritual's Sweet Tooth Santa Lucia (Brasil) puts a few of my favorite northwest roasters to shame. I will be stockpiling my freezer with more packages soon.
author: Ellen T.

description:
This is high quality coffee people! They only serve the high grade A stuff here, and make one cup at a time. This stuff tastes really fresh, and goes down smooth.  Some of the best Colombian coffee I've ever had. Try it, seriously. 

I plan to go back and try the other drinks- I will update my review with recommendations!
author: Harvinder K.

description: YUCK................... The coffee here was weak and bitter tasting.. It was so thinly tasting that I thought they messed up and gave me decaf or even ice tea... While the barista was very polite .. The cashier was yapping it up with a woman.. This woman wasn't buying anything but sure didn't mind tying up the line to chat with the cashier and the cashier. sure didn't mind talking and talking.. All the while, the paying customers waited in line..... If you want a good cup of coffee and good service.. don't go here... save your money... how this place got on the map is beyond me.. It truly isn't a good cup of coffee....
author: Franco L.

description:
Yes-- real coffee!!! 
Laid back, good music and strong coffee. 
No flavored syrup but you wouldn't want it once you have a sip. 
Plus we brought a cake and the barista gave us some plates and forks-- in exchange for cake but it was worth it!
author: Juliet C.

description:
Ritual can convert anyone to the religion of coffee drinking.  If you fancy yourself a coffee connoisseur, this is where you should make your altar... at the barista booth. Ritual serves all sorts of coffee and their board describes the taste of each brew like Robert Parker would a Bordeaux.  They also pay homage to the region by letting you know where their beans come from and how they are roasted.  Pretentious a bit? Yes.  My boyfriend, who has had 10 cups of coffee in his whole life, had a cup here. That attests to something beyond snobbishness.    He had  his cup of coffee fresh and brewed through a V60 dripper which made him excited. The artwork on the wall is playful and lightens up the mood for comfortable talk. 

Plus: They also serve vegan desserts at the front.  But doesn't everyone in SF?
author: Juliet R.

description:
I (usually) really like the music here.  The coffee is absurdly overpriced, and they don't have any cups larger than 8-12 ounces.  Always order it to go, even if you're going to have it there, because their for-here mugs are even smaller than their paper cups.
