It's a decent place to study when you want to get out of the house and hang out.  If you only have one or two cups over a few hours of studying, using the wifi, lounging and enjoying the music, it feels less overpriced -- you're just paying for the ambiance and a place to hang out.
The tall barista with green eyes is pretty hot.  I always roll in not having shaved in like days wearing some dirty hoody or something, and generally looking like a child molester, and still the baristas are all reasonably friendly.  I don't know what everyone else is griping about as far as service/attitude goes.
author: Harry L.

description:
My neighbourhood coffee shop.

My FAVOURITE coffee shop.

All my Mission locals hang out here with me and we always get a seat on the corner couches near the window, so we can get sassy and make Mission Talk.

I am a REALLY big fan of their vegan pastry selections which are ever rotating and are always delicious...especially the carrot cake.

The place is lit really nicely, and for a local coffee shop, it's pretty damn big.

This place would get four stars, except that pastry case I love OH SO MUCH ALWAYS has a fly in it every time I go. Once they fix that problem, they get the last star.
author: Trav M.

description: Finally got to taste what people have been raving about.  It is yummy.  I got the one where there is a little sweet after taste.  I'm going back to get one!
author: Byron L.

description:
I almost had to give 4 stars because I love Blue Bottle just a skoch more.  But it's just too good.  For me to dole out 5 stars over coffee is quite the token.  Ritual, you should be proud.  
My roomie turned me on to this place and I love the simple things about them.  Simple menu, simple decor, and it's excellent coffee, plain and simple.
In fact, I think I'm ready for my fix right now....see you there!
author: Jessica S.

description: Just your typical Mission coffeeshop, with some quasi-Soviet iconography...
author: Danny C.

description: First of all I think the "coffee wars of san Francisco" is just great!!!  My personal favorite ended up being Blue Bottle Coffee for their killer Kenya blend and their relaxed down to earth attitudes.  Ritual does have some great coffee though.  I tried their Columbian blend and it was a good light roast (which I like).  The staff is more hipster if that's your style and the company's colors and logo are clearly a nod to communism... not my style.  They have a very good storefront and a unique atmosphere.  I would recommend trying both roasters and choosing for yourself!!  If you want to see some pic's of Rituals store go to my blog!
author: Golden F.

description:
When I go to ritual, I get shit done. Maybe it's the ultra powerful coffee or maybe it's the snappy internet, but I attribute my productivity to the fact that almost every time that I raise my head from my computer, I notice someone else with their head raised, we make brief, awkward eye contact and I immediately go back to nervously typing. The unblinking eye at ritual steers me from distraction and into a coffee induced trance of productivity.

But man, when I spend more than five hours there (which I often do) I really crave something more substantial than a three dollar vegan doughnut. 

I guess they also sell pork rinds, go figure.
author: Ian T.

description:
If I ever go back to San Francisco, which I likely will as I have friends there, I will stop by Ritual Coffee for a fabulous latte.  The coffee was one of the best I have ever had.

HOWEVER.  I did not care for the staff.  People are not at all friendly.  I don't mean Starbucks friendly, but a smile and a hello would have been nice.  Someone else here on Yelp called the staff surly, and I have to agree.

Also, the atmosphere was very pretentious and not kid-friendly.  Not that I have kids, but still.  The three stars are for the fabulous coffee and the lack of the other two stars are for mean and nasty baristas!

And Nabisco is probably going to come after them one of these days for offering an Oreo for sale.  Fabulous cookie with creme filling, but for Pete's sake, change the name to something more original!
author: Deb J.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I never liked Ritual as a cofee house in the first place. I never have sit there with my matching Macbook and my little hipster glasses surfing the internet while pretending to be desgining something.

I have, however, purchased their delicious coffee to-go as well as purchased their whole beans to make at home. Ritual is clearly going through hard times. The place is much more empty now and I can't help but think that their compulsory single-serve coffee is the reason. It takes like 10 minutes to order a small coffee. You are also charged through the nose. You could spend up to $4.50 for a medium cup of coffee.

More frustratingly for us long-time Ritual coffee drinkers, their bulk coffee is sadly stale. I check their "roast on dates" every time I go on there and I cannot, for the life of me, find any bulk coffee available that was roasted more recently than a week. That is an outrage when you are spending $15 for 8 ounces of coffee. You want the freshest roast so that you can make the best coffee. Ritual no longer offers that. They used to roast their coffee once a week. Now I have no idea when they do but they clearly don't sell freshly roasted coffee anymore. Its too bad.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Still the best cafe in SF.  Don't like hipsters stacked six deep?  Perhaps you should avoid the mission?

I'm torn between a Clover cup of a Cup of Excellence finalist, or a demitasse of espresso or a cappuccino.  Next time I'm there and it's before six PM I 'm gettin' one of each. 

I'm a major coffee freak and am always pleased with the dialogue I get with either the cashier or the Clover pilot.  I know better to try to chat up a barista driving their 

NEW SYNESSO ESPRESSO MACHINE!!!
(those folks are hecka busy).
author: Robi P.

description:
Exceptional espresso can be found here! 

They also have super lighting. I mean they hang light bulbs bald from the celling . 

I think I got..A British penny with my change? I never expect foreign coins, but one of these must be worth more than a U.S. penny, and it looks way cooler.

Good stuff.
author: Anna Z.

description:
San Francisco Magazine recently published a list of their top 3 places to get a cup of coffee based on the reader's input.

I think it's a bit of a crime this place didn't even make the cut, nevermind that Peet's was rated the best.

If you haven't come here for some coffee, you're missing out.  There isn't anything really alluring to get you in the place.  They aren't a chain and I actually hadn't heard of this place before randomly walking in (i'm just a sucker for kitschy Industrial Revolution era Soviet decor).  But the coffee is superb.  I'm even going so far to say it rivals Blue Bottle in quality, though i realize I'm walking on thin ice making that assertion.

I'm a brewed coffee kind of guy.  I was sucking on my cup like a baby on a bottle.  The coffee was good.  If you're not caught up in lattes and cappuccinos, give this place a shot.  Places like this are starting to (undesirably) turn me into a coffee snob.
author: Steven R.

description:
Coffee was good. It's kind of a typical hipster coffee joint with appropriately condescending, scraggly workers. OOoooh the apathy.

Has a reputation of being a "communist" coffee shop, which is pretty obnoxious... for an enterprising business to be communist... hm. I think it's because the logo is red and white.  

I'd say to give this coffee shop the apathy it emits... go there, don't go there... doesn't matter... who cares.
author: dug h.

description:
San Francisco has some good coffee.  My coffee friend says that it is no Seattle, though.  I trust my friend.  Regardless, I have had pots and pots of Ritual and Blue Bottle, and I am in the Blue Bottle camp.  Not as creamy as Ritual's, it is just more my speed.  Mr. Espresso beans at Coffee Bar is great, too.

There is always a line here, but it moves quickly.  I always get the soy latte or regular latte and they are good--creamy (in fact, a bit too creamy for my taste, but it's still good, just prefer Blue Bottle), good foam, texture, and richness.  The pastries do not look like anything worth buying.  They use real mugs and saucers and the baristas provide artwork.  Good luck trying to find a seat.  The owners have the outlets covered due to heavy ass phenomenon, i.e., those who sit here end up never leaving.  My friend says that "company" owners essentially come here and do their "work."  How do their laptops keep running without outlets, you might wonder?  He surmises that they tote along extra batteries.
author: Dee C.

description:
So it was not only my first time at In N Out today, but also my first time at Ritual. What a beautiful coffee shop. And all they do is coffee. I like that. Do something you're good at and do it properly.
We had both decaf americanos with tasty aromas. 
When I'm in the neighborhood, I'll definitely come back here, even though it seems that the wait can be long.
author: Alexandra D.

description: The coffee and espresso are both good, but the place itself can get a bit annoying. It's crowded, slightly pretentious and doesn't have enough electrical outlets (or even tables). That being said, it is next door to my house, so I make it here on weekends.
author: E-dough R.

description:
Whats the deal? Last time I was here they were selling french press coffee and clover brewed coffee. Now they've eliminated both brewing methods, eliminated any differentiation between sizes and raised the price of each cup, now you can count on a coffee brewed to a rather watery state and lacking any body whatsoever. The espresso is pretty good, but other than that this place has turned into turds-ville.

Feeling more and more with each visit that Four Barrel has filled the gap
that Ritual Cafe just keeps widening. Four Barrel has got a multitude of different brewing methods to experiment with, multiple cash registers to speed up the line, customers I personally relate to a bit more and an overall more inviting and comfortable decor going on.

 Folk's the warm, inviting, young creative glow has moved down the street to 15th and Valencia, see you there!
author: Julian S.

description:
The coffee is excellent. Great baristas, great dripper--they brew works of art. I love they offer a clear menu with a variety of single-origin dripper coffees and their proposed seasonal espresso. You always get something different, but always expertly done. My lower rating is for switching from one of my favorite places to hang out at with a cup of coffee into a depressing, clean, minimalist area that tries to be like Sight Glass and Blue Bottle. Those are great places that work as locations, but were there alread. Ritual not only loses its distinct feel, but does so while failing in the execution of what it apparently tries to be. It now looks most similar to Four Barrels'The Mill, but even that looks livelier. The ideas of most specific things in the decor look good, but they don't come together nicely. The yellow light on white walls and dull yellow wood-colored tables, bars and floor makes for a depressing ambiance. They also significantly reduced the amount of seating spaces and tables. Gone are the comfy couches, the bar at the counter ( my favorite spot) and the authentic feel of the place that didn't need "nice" and polished to sell (it had actually worked for appearing to decidedly not do precisely that). The decision to eliminate wifi is respectable, but I simply am one of those that doesn't like it.

As a place to visit or be at, I now prefer Four Barrel, Sight Glass, or Blue Bottle, and they all have great coffee. Ritual still has my favorite dripper menu.
author: Alex R.

description:
Coffee is good here, not the best I've ever had.  It reminds me a lot of Verve Cafe in Santa Cruz.  I think I like Philz a little better, on Folsom and 24th.  But lets be real, if you're going here, it's definitely for the ambiance.  There's a particular scene, and they play pretty loud music, so everyone "studying" here...well, I know you're actually people watching.  And I do it too, no shame.  Lots of cuties frequent this place.  

The bathrooms are relatively clean.  It's a nice place to meet up with a few friends and chit chat.  They don't have outlets anymore, so you can't plug your computer in and sit for hours there without buying a drink.  But despite the mediocre rating I gave, I do have very fond memories of this place.  Now it gets too crowded, so I like going down to four barrels on 16th and Valencia.  They serve ritual's coffee over there too, but it's quieter, no outlets, and brighter.

Oh, and I agree with Jessica L, the mini cupcakes ain't all that.  AT ALL.  Too much frosting, not enough cake.
author: Tracy N.

description:
I now live less than 5 blocks from Ritual. I cannot quite express how happy this makes me. 

Also, Ritual doesn't brew Stumptown anymore, but it's cool. They now offer their own selection of beans and brews, and everything is just heavenly.
author: Anna G.

description:
I have recently found myself walking 2 1/2 blocks, as opposed to my usual 1 block, to get coffee in the morning. Now, I don't know about you, but for me when it's cold in the morning and I actually put on pants for coffee, that's a pretty big deal. So, Ritual must be doing something right. 

It's a busy place, but it generally doesn't take too long to get a coffee. And the great part is it's only $2 for a large coffee! Although, with my addiction getting stronger and stronger, I would probably splurge for an extra large. Now, I'm not talking about the infamous "clover" cause to be honest with you, I can't really tell the difference and think it's a waste of time. The French press is a-ok in my book. They're pastries aren't the best, but that really shouldn't be the point of going there.

It's great that they have free wi-fi, and plenty of spots to sit, but when it's busy finding a free seat could be hard. Although sometimes I go there and hope it's busy so I can share a table with an attractive young gentleman...even though they rarely talk to me cause they're working on some 250 page philosophy paper or something. Well, that's what I tell myself at least.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
So. Let me first say that I am not in any way a coffee connoisseur. I am Southern, and essentially I want my coffee sweet and milky...more of a dash of coffee to go with my creme and sugar affair, really.

My boyfriend is a total coffee equivalent to a foodie, and he lives and dies for this place's coffee, so I am guessing that its pretty good.

HOWEVER. I have been here twice, and let me just say this: get off your pretentious vintage horses, hipsters, put some effing electrical sockets in the walls so people can plug things in while they use your somewhat impotent wi-fi and PLEASE, if you cop one more 'i am indier than thou' attiude with me when I want my chai made with the heaviest creme you have I will slap the ugly Steve Urkel glasses you are desperately trying to bring back into the 80s where you belong.

Service is atrocious, coffee is obscenely overpriced and they have covered up all the sockets in their walls so people have frantic laptop issues.

I write this as my battery dwindles.
author: Rylan S.

description:
On several occasions over the last year and a half, I have tried to write a review for Ritual.  But each time I erased what I had written, or aimed my browser elsewhere in search of a less frustrating endeavor.  

Once I tried to bring up how it was mentioned in the Economist, but then I sounded pompous.

Then I tried to paint an image of the clientele, or how long they linger, but decided that I would sound judgmental or insecure.

On another occasion, I wanted to emphasize how this place doesn't add hazelnut  or raspberry flavoring to any of its coffee drinks, or in fact even carry any of those blasphemous additives.  But then I sounded pompous again.  

So I'm going to get back to basics here:

Best latte served in SF: equal, or perhaps superior to Blue Bottle.
author: James M.

description:
My mom makes me weak. My dad makes me depressed.

There are many things I wish I wasn't. Restless. Impatient. Emotional. Delusional. Arugula. And so I blame my flaws on my folks, focusing on what I lack genetically rather than the good I possess. Negative thought occurs so frequently it exists as a persistent sermon, waking daily on the wrong side of bed until there isn't a pleasant side left. And I toil away everyday until work and a lackluster life settle into some routine agenda.

A limit for credit cards. Not having enough chairs.

But then, for some reason, something clicks inside and I'm reminded of the better things in life - music and inspiration from hopeful lovelust, espresso shots from freshly-roasted beans, sexy cafes, sexier people, and sharing tables with strangers in a place more cozy than cramped... So, I'm reminded of warmth and light, hopefully in such a way I repeat the mantra on a daily basis, until upward thought becomes a ritual of itself.

My mom makes me kindhearted. My dad makes me deep.
author: Keane L.

description:
Dear Ritual,

You are so affordable. I love you for that. You are what coffee is. You are simple, basic, no raz-mitaz good. And best yet, you are below $2 for a medium. You are my hero!
author: Alexandra M.

description:
...

*toss*

...

*turn*

...



3 am. 
Fuck.  
Why do I not have cable in my bedroom? 

Fucking caffeine-induced sleeplessness.  This is what cable channels are made for.  Give me a nice Too Close For Comfort rerun or, better yet, a Roseannathon.  INSOMNIACS NEED CABLE.  Network television is made for morning people only.  Everyone knows that after Conan it's a fucking broadcast wasteland out there.  I would rather watch a test pattern or pull a Heather O'Rourke with a snowy screen (THEY'RE HEEEEEEEEEEERE) than watch an infomercial for Extenze and hear that smartass chick talk about "that certain part of the male anatomy"  *WINK FUCKING WINK* for the seven-hundredth time.

I gave up caffeine three years ago this month.  For the most part, I have not missed it.  And there are perks.  I sleep better.  I am more focused.  I sweat less.  Sweat is a big one.  When I drank caffeine I was one tsweaty Tsada.  Not tsexy.

I have a few exceptions to my no caffeine policy.

1) Thai iced tea / iced coffee--I get these rarely because they are basically a big glass of fat and sugar, and I need that even less than I need caffeine, although I desire it more than I do being ravished by Bill Maher on a pile of marzipan penises.  Okay, maybe not more than that, but almost as much.

2) McDonalds sweet tea--STFU

3) really, really special coffee

One of my sassiest, purtiest Yelp homegirls took me out for coffee at Ritual's last week.  As we stood at the counter, I debated ordering my usual cup of decaf, but was swayed when dollface pointed to the legendary roasting machine, aswirl with bright, glossy beans.

I ordered a glass of the richest, most delicious, FRESH iced coffee I have ever tasted.  Full caf.  And unlike most iced coffee, this didn't taste like leftovers poured over ice.  It had clearly been brewed for the express purpose of being served over ice.

Of course I tossed and turned for most of that night.  Oh, well.  Ritual's coffee is worth it.  In fact, rich, smooth coffee like that is  just about the only thing for whichTsada will forgo her beauty sleep.  I mean, the only thing besides that "certain part of the male anatomy." 

*WINK FUCKING WINK*
author: Tsada K.

description:
not so good....

the cappuccino has waaaay toooo much milk in it, i want to wake up not fall back asleep - with a full babies belly of hot milk.

the coffee isnt really all that good

and the staff seems to be forever changing.....what could that mean...
author: joy f.

description:
Yes, it's good coffee.

But why does everyone who hangs out there have to look so fucking miserable? Oh, what's wrong little hipster? Is it hard being cool? It makes you unhappy? Are you cranky because you're starving yourself to fit into those skinny jeans? Are you mad because you spilled coffee on your favorite black hoodie? Did you just find out that your roommate's been stealing your black eyeliner? Did somebody hurt your feelings by telling you that the real hipsters are in Williamsburg? Your friends got tickets to Silversun Pickups and you didn't? Boo fucking hoo. 

And don't tell me I can't deduct stars because of the people who patronize the place. I can do whatever the fuck I want.
author: Suge K.

description:
My friend gave birth to a cute little sweet baby boy 3 months ago. She lives blocks away from Ritual. 

For a nice relaxing Sunday, we decided to go for coffee at Ritual to catch up.

While at Ritual, she discreetly nursed baby boy under a blanket. 

She needed to use the restroom, so she asked me to hold baby boy.

Delighted, I jumped up for the exchange.

The baby is facing me as my friend is stretching her arms out for me to reach baby boy. 

My face is now inches a way from baby boy.

Without a moment's notice, I have regurgitated breast milk all over my face. 

Oh no. Oh no! Duuck! 
Too late! Yeah, now I have breast milk all over my shoulder.

Baby boy is awesome at PROJECTILE VOMITING.

I shall call him Thrasher.

Tip from older sister: Burp baby before a face on exchange.

Overall: The large Cafe Latte ($4) is splendid and delicious.  Perfect place to grab a cup of delicious java and talk about the weather. Or grab a cup while taking in the sites of the Mission with Thrasher in tow.
author: Liz K.

description:
Hi there, can I come in for a sec? I love the coffee here.
I put on this cowboy shirt for you. See? Should I have gone with the graphic hoodie? Why did that dude over there just scowl at me? Is it my shoes? It's just that I thought cowboy boots would be a bit much, you know, with this shirt. Why do those people keep looking at me like that?

I'll just sit right over here, with my back to the room. Is that ok with everyone? I won't stay long.

Seriously though, I do love the coffee here. Geek obsessiveness applied to the *other* java turns out to be a really good thing. I love that the iced coffee is done toddy style. I'm a bit baffled by (but still love) the presence of that crazy "clover" device. I don't know why it makes coffee cost twice as much, but I love the willingness to experiment. I love that when I ask you to grind some for my french press at home, it comes out so perfectly that my guests think I've performed some kind of sorcery on them.

Ok I'm sorry. I know it's not cool to enjoy things. I'll try to be gloomier while I'm here.

I meant everything I said. I love the coffee here, but I wish I didn't have to go through this every time. Therapy is costing me a fortune.
author: Shawn S.

description: It was good expensive cup of black coffee but nothing really stood out to me. The staff was OK but not super friendly. Place was busy so I'm sure this is a really popular place to hangout and have some coffee. Nothing really stood out to me as out of the ordinary or extraordinary about this place so I rate this as "A-OK."  This place is for people who take their coffee seriously and want to know where the beans are from, etc. etc.
author: Anne Explores LA +.

description:
I have to say, I really love Ritual's coffee. A lot. Their latte's are the perfect balance between freshly-roasted beans and perfectly frothed milk with a little Italian-style heart or leaf 'etched' on top.  So pretty you almost hate to have to stir in your Sugar-in-the-Raw, 'cause you can see that this is true artisan-ship, made by a true artisan, and it's just so darned pretty! An invigorating work of art served hot in a recyclable paper cup. Truly a 5-star cup of Italian-influenced love.

But riddle me this: what gives with the lovely latte being poured 2-fingers from the top? Did someone accidentally write the secret code for "room for cream" on the side of the cup? Did you run out of milk leaving my latte a little short on the pour? Are you helping me watch my waistline by eliminating calories? (trust me, those 2-fingers of milk really aren't going to make a dent)

No. That's not the case, is it? In fact, you *always* give me a latte filled 2-fingers from the top, *don't* you, Ritual? You get some kind of sicko pleasure from making me ask for more milk! And you know it's not the cold milk I want, but more frothy hot milk your artisan hands must hold and transform into creamy goodness!! You know that I know that you hold the power -- the key to the makings of the perfect latte!

All I know is that for almost $4.00 for a large latte, y'all need to stop bein' so stingy with the milk, because no one needs room for cream in a latte, my waistline is my responsibility, and the power exchange business is, well, it's for the Power Exchange. Honestly, Ritual, it gets a little old asking for my cup to be filled every single time I come in.  I hate asking, for when I do, you look annoyed and I feel lame.

And paying customers never like to feel lame.  Especially if that customer was kind enough to stuff a dollar into your tip cup, expecting a full cup of latte love.

p.s. 3.5 stars, 'cause the dude at the cash register was genuinely nice to me this time. Friendly and nice. Something this customer *always* likes :)

p.p.s. uncover the outlet's already, will ya, or the stars get it!
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
1. I don't own a Mac

2. I don't like to wait 20 minutes for a latte

3. The coffee is too bitter for me
author: Shal J.

description:
Best cup of soy hot chocolate EVER. I wanted to rub my face in it. Actually, I took it in the bathroom with me to douche with.  I think that douche and the girls that use it are fucked up, but this cocoa made me realize that my junk seriously lacks even an ounce of the deliciousness that Ritual's soy cocoa embodies. 

This review has just caused a million former Ritual lovers to never, ever go back. Which is good for me cuz shit, that place is crowded like whoa.
author: Chloe S.

description:
There's an etiquette to thinking your customers are idiots. I know, I've worked a zillion food service shifts and hated a huge percentage of my patrons- but almost none of them would ever know it. Why? Because I wanted them to like me, which would make them want to come back to me, which would mean more and greater tips.

Earlier today I had a rather nice time at Ritual, getting some schoolwork done, futzing on email. When I got home, I futzed for a bit before finishing up a project I was working on. I opened up my bag to pull out my computer...

...But my laptop wasn't in my bag. Feeling like an idiot, I called Ritual and told them that I thought that I may have left my laptop there. The woman who answered the phone laughed at me, was away from the phone for less than ten seconds and then laughed some more as she told me it wasn't there. 

Like I said, there's an etiquette involved. The correct procedure would have been to take on a concerned tone, to cover the mouthpiece for another twenty seconds, and then to assure me that if my computer turned up then she'd make sure I got it. Maybe even to pretend to want my number just in case, and then, when she got off the phone, THEN she could have laughed at me for being an idiot. 

I rode my bike over and- hey! It was right where I'd left it, right where I told her it was! Thanks, Ritual! See you at Phil'z!

Also, an anecdote: 

A few days after the Aqua Teen movie came out, some friends of mine and I ate a bunch of brownies and went to go see it. Before the movie started, we looked around and realized that we were sitting behind a row of men who all looked exactly like the Comic Book Guy on "The Simpsons". And behind us were a bunch of 14-year-old boys who giggled whenever one of my friends cursed out loud. 

"Oh my God," my girlfriend said. "Everyone in here is a nerd but us."

If you're in a place and you're surrounded by hipsters and someone walks by outside, they won't look at you and think, "Hey! That guy is the only not-hipster in the joint!" Nope. They'll just say, "Hey! A bunch of hipsters!" and keep going.
author: jason l.

description:
The only mother effin' ritual at this place is that you have to stand in line to order.  Stand in line to pay.  And then stand in line to get your drink. 

I am shocked that they don't make you stand in line to drink the damn stuff.

That said, after you pay that small (read: VERY LARGE) inconvenience to the coffee gods, you are awarded with some really amazing coffee laced with what must be crack cocaine, since I have never waited 15 minutes for a latte before and I did just that yesterday.  Not once, not twice, but THREE times in the course of 6 hours.

The first was to get my eyes open.  

The second was to keep them open.

The third was to bring me up or down or under or over, as I am pretty sure I will need to start main lining espresso from Ritual just to appear somewhat integrated into society on a seemingly healthy level.

That obviously didn't work.  

I'm as spun as La Lohan on her way to rehab.
author: Rachel G.

description: I stopped by this place for some tea and snacks.  The music and atmosphere are great, but I'd avoid the brownie and cookies.  I prefer chewy brownies and these were dry and flaky and not very chocolate-y.  The chocolate chip cookie had very few chips and the texture was just off.  It was more like a scone than a cookie.
author: Christine L.

description: Top-notch coffee in San Francisco!  I had a marvelous soy latte here--c'mon don'tcha' just love the logo?  I do!
author: Jessika L.

description: I have been to ritual a couple of times to work (free wifi) in the cafe or to just get a coffee to go. I must say that I really like their coffee (it's pretty strong) and I also like the inside of the cafe with it's coffee smell and numerous coffee bean bags laying around. BUT I must also say that ritual is hipster central, but nonetheless the coffee is great. If i remember correctly they also have a little coffee "truck" that shows up in dolores park.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Try the Sweet Tooth macchiato!  It's the bomb!

I've been going to Ritual since it first opened and I can't believe I haven't praised them yet! This was one of the first coffee joints that I found into the Third Wave Coffee culture. Amazing single origin coffees, awesome latte art, and they host coffee cuppings!

Although there are tons of seating, it still has hard to grab a table. So a double espresso shot at the coffee bar is my usual ritual. The coffees are complex, the milk is steamed silky smooth and the latte art is always spot on! I also love that they give you options on espresso for your drinks. Today it was Sweet Tooth for me...yum.
author: Rodel B.

description:
My roommate, Jeremy W, an incredibly coffee-savvy fellow, told me when I was but a wee Mission novice that Ritual was the best cup o' Joe in the neighborhood.

Now, I can't attest to this fact. Because I don't drink coffee.

I do, however, drink the occasional soy chai. And I do, however, love cafe life. I often work from home, especially when I'm editing scripts or on the beginning or end of my frequent travels, and I love a friendly, laid-back coffeehouse with a good selection of vegan yummies in which to make out with my Macbook.

Ritual, more or less, is such a place. 

HOWEVER!

I refuse to make a ritual of Ritual. Because it's just over the line as far as hippness is concerned.

I mean, I know people need their caffeine in the AM, but WHAT COFFEEHOUSE HAS A LINE OUT THE DOOR AT 6:00 IN THE MORNING?

There's never NOT a line out the door here.

If you need it that bad, get it wherever you can. Like in your own kitchen. Jesus.

People just come here to be seen.
author: Lisa T.

description:
It's kind of difficult to write a review of a place while you are at said establishment. 
Shit, today I needed wifi in the Mission and remembered walking past here about a million times... you need a laptop to enter right? That and a slight grudge on the establishment.
Check and check.
But fudge.... when I walked in, it was hipster central. They rank up there with zombies and the black duende as my biggest fears.
I AM IN THE BELLY OF THE BEAST!

But the barista let me cut it when I was 10cents short for my latte. (See bitches, I don't dress poor, I am poor. Posers) And the music is pretty good, the wifi connection is good, the coffee is good ... and pretty,  and the guys with sleeves are goooooood to look at. 

Wait, what is that machine in the back? Someone's pouring coffee into a turbine. Oh shit... I remember you. THOMAS THE TANK ENGINE! I haven't see you since my childhood. I didn't know you retired to the Mission! Do you still talk to  Sir Topham Hatt??

I'm sorry, I just had 6 lattes. Excuse my slight bout with insanity
author: Mary F.

description:
(Three stars based only on the hot chocolate not coffee.)

My large hot chocolate consisted of a squeeze of chocolate syrup, some steamed milk, another squeeze of chocolate syrup and more steamed milk. Ended up tasting like...you guessed it, slightly chocolatey steamed milk! 

Maybe that's why Ritual doesn't list a hot chocolate on their menu board. I ordered it based on other reviewers' raves. Ah well. One less person in line. :)
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Ritual is a place where hipsters and techies come together to worship espresso and Macs. In some ways I feel like it encapsulates the "now"ness of the Mission with its modern simplicity and stand-out art.  

While I love their cappuccinos, let's be honest -- this cafe is all about seeing and being seen. I'm more likely to stop in for fashion inspiration than to satiate my coffee cravings.  

I suppose that's why Ritual could never truly be a daily ritual for me. It's a little too self-conscious. Still, it has a magnetic scene that's hard to resist. See you there...
author: Nicole G.

description:
We stopped in last Sunday and stood in a lengthy queue of caffeine-starved hipsters. One of them looked like Bret from Flight of the Conchords; he wore skinny jeans and carried a record player in one arm, as casually as one would carry a textbook.  No one batted an eye.

RCR makes a pleasing soy chai, spicy but sweet, though a tad too frothy.

I was also impressed with the perfectly heart-shaped froth the baristas created in my friend's latte.

My friend and I snagged a cramped table with not much room to move in and out of our chairs. Of course since the place was so crowded, we weren't alone for long. A couple girls asked if they could join our table, dragged over an extra chair, asked my friend to scoot over (even though she couldn't really, given how cramped the space was) and then they proceeded to talk loudly all over us so we couldn't really have a conversation.  We chugged our drinks and left.
author: angela n.

description:
It's all about the first sip for me.  If the first sip of my coffee doesn't make my  knees weak and my mind go blank for a minute, it's just not that great.

My first sip of a cappuccino from Ritual always makes my knees weak.

Another good sign?  I always find a parking spot right out front.  To me, that means that God wants me to get my coffee at Ritual.  Thanks, God!

Lovely baked goods, including an impressive number of vegan treats.  I was told by a reliable source (laura b.) about the sherry cake, and it is indeed delicious.

The place is always packed with people staring intently at their Macs (I brought my Mac for a visit once, but we did not end up staying), and the music is usually loud and intense, so if you like to work or study in that kind of atmosphere, this is your perfect grown-up anarchist study hall.

Just look for me, I am the one standing at the counter with my eyes closed, having a "moment" with my coffee.
author: Liz S.

description:
I drive all the way down here to buy my coffee beans.  That's right...I live in Pac Heights but will brave...THE MISSION for coffee.  Ew.  Just kidding, flame away.  And I even brave the parking situation.  Which leads to my story.

A few months ago, I was driving down Valencia.  I saw a person getting into his car directly outside Ritual.  Full Bob Hope parking.  I was so excited.  I pulled up behind him and put my blinker on.

He departed said parking space, and I pulled forward to reverse in.  I wait for traffic to pass and, as I started backing up, I saw a flash in my rear view mirror.  A cab driver had pulled a U-turn ACROSS Valencia, directly into the spot.  That I'd been waiting for.  With my blinker on.  Patiently.

I'm not a violent man.  But for some reason, at about 10:30am on a Saturday, I decided I wasn't going to stand for this.  I backed up and rolled down my window.  The cabbie was on his phone, of course.

GK: "That was my spot!"
Cabbie: "I was waiting for it."
GK: "What, across the street?  I was sitting here signaling!"
Cabbie: "Well, I was waiting and I took it."
GK: "You mean you made an illegal u-turn and took the spot *I* was waiting for?  What is wrong with you?"

(crowd starts to form)

Cabbie: "Nothing's wrong with me.  I took the spot."
GK: "Dude, you're a cabbie!  Shouldn't you be driving around looking for fares instead of stealing people's parking spots?"
Cabbie: "You know what man?  Fuck you.  It's my spot."
GK: "Fuck me?  FUCK YOU.  You stole my space!"
Cabbie: "Man, nobody gives me a break, ever."
GK: "Maybe nobody give you a break because you're a fucking asshole!  Did you ever think about that?"
Cabbie: "You motherfu...."

Anyway, I'd said what I needed to say.  I didn't take it any further, figuring either he had a gun or I'd kick his ass, and I didn't feel like ending up in jail or the hospital.  I drove up the street and actually found a street spot for free.  Then I paid $2.75 for a latte and dumped it on his hood.  Asshole.  It was a "City Cab," which is such a derelict company that I couldn't even find it to give it one star.

Great coffee, though.
author: Geoff K.

description: The baristas and cashiers seem to work at a snail's pace. I don't mind a wait, but I do mind an unnecessary one.  Their coffees tend to be more on the light side, fruity and sweet rather than dark and robust, the latter of which I prefer. About 90% of the customers are on computers. They have a chocolate chip & sea salt cookie... as if adding "sea" to salt means anything, and it's dry. Overall: smeh.
author: Kevin X.

description:
I was in the Mission (an old hood of mine) and decided to see what all the hoopla is about Ritual Coffee Roasters.

What is the big deal?  Sure they make a fantastic cup of coffee and cappucino.  They did mess up my easy order but I took the mess up b/c I'm easy going like dat. . . it was good too.  So yes, as a coffee lover, I do appreciate this place as far as the quality of the coffee.  Fabulous but,  what else am I missing?  

The layout is a little dark and  cavernous.  The "design excellence" plaque they have in front is hilarious.  Okay yes, the place is very cool in design so put your plaque out!  I thought that was a little cheeky.  Oh well.

I loved the current artwork as well as the table tops.  

So yes, good coffee but did they not give me the rock of crack like they gave everyone else because I thought the place is just okay.  If I lived in the neighborhood I'd probably get coffee here and then not because it's too cool for me but then go back because the coffee is good but then stop for a while because it's too cool for me. . .but then go back because I'm a coffee snob but then. . .

. . .you get it.
author: James M.

description:
The good
+ Espresso made the right way even if it takes awhile (grind beans and froth milk to order)
+ Excellent baked goods, including vegan stuff that actually tastes good
+ They seem to be roasting coffee now (aka no more false advertising)
+ No power outlets on the weekends means fewer laptop zombies

The bad
- The loud music makes it a difficult place to work
- I feel oh so out of place with my lack of tight jeans, tattoos, and piercings. At least I have a mac.
author: matt m.

description:
Great spot to meet up with a friend for coffee. Lots of seating and good atmosphere. The coffee is brewed fresh and good selection of pastries. 

Just wish they had yogurt or some non-carb heavy options.
author: Katie S.

description:
Ritual is popular for a reason.  They really planned their space out well and went with a good design and theme.  They are one of the few places in the mission to actually turn on the heat when it gets cold.   The owners worked really hard on the place and it shows.  Being open so late doesn't hurt them at all either.

Their coffee to me is the best of the rest in SF.  The top spot goes to Blue Bottle, but Ritual make a decent effort.

I give Ritual extra points for listening to their customers.  When it first opened we wandered in and the person behind the counter noticed Mr. Fatty was wearing a garment emblazoned with the word "VEGAN" and began to question us about the kinds of vegan treats we'd like to see them carry.  A few weeks later they were carrying what we suggested - the sherry cakes and the macaroons.

The laptop squatters are a problem.  I have never understood why cafes tolerate that scene when it so obviously drives paying customers away while the laptoper sits there sipping the cold dregs of their one cup of coffee.  I wish cafes would give these people a time limit and then turf them out, either that or get another room just for the laptop people and have them pay rent.  Dolores Park Cafe is bad for this too, though it's not generally laptops, it's people with 10 giant textbooks and a notebook.

It's funny to me when people complain that hipsters go to a certain place, therefore it's pretentious.  Come on.  Leave your own insecurity at home and perhaps you won't feel like you're being judged all the time.  God forbid someone have silly hair or wear black.  It doesn't mean they're an asshole.
author: Olivia G.

description:
I don't drink coffee, but I do love coffee shops and  Ritual has a special place in my heart...It's where I stop for a little R&R after a day of wandering around the Mission. It's the place I first met my Yelp crimey. It's where my hot dates with Sooj always end up, the perfect setting for our intellectual intercourse and general existential lamentations.

I love the variety of music they play from indie rock to hip hop to random cheesy music, though it can get a little too loud and clubby on the weekend nights (do you really need that much bass in a coffee shop?). The old-school grinder they have releases a wonderful aroma, though I can't comment on the coffee. But I can say that their chai is excellent! Stay away from the non-cupcake baked goods...blech! Can't comment on the cupcakes though b/c I always end up coming here right after I've already had one (or 3).

Hipsters be damned! I know I'm not cool enough to hang out at Ritual, but I love it!
author: Steph P.

description:
Sorry, folks, but Emperor Ritual is really not wearing any clothes.
I know you may all be lulled into thinking this place is the best thing since sliced bread, as the line out the door suggests, but it really, simply isn't.

Sure, the coffee beans are roasted in-house, which for San Francisco is a big deal (I spent two years in Seattle, so I'm admittedly no stranger to big fancy roasting equipment), and the beans are good. I've had very good coffee and espresso here. Hence, the second star.

What I've *never* had is efficient service, a properly hot latte, or anything approaching decent pastries (lose all the vegan stuff people: it is held together by that plastic wrap). 

For example, my housemate Peter G. (also a yelper, see his review on Ritual) was served a latte when he ordered a house coffee (he does not latte, as he is from the midwest). When he inquired why he was waiting so long for a house brew, he was incorrectly told he had ordered a latte, served a latte, and informed he'd have to wait at least 12 minutes if he wanted his house brew, because they'd have to brew a new pot of coffee.  That this might defeat the entire point of drinking coffee is an argument seemingly lost on Ritual's uber-hip, vainglorious staff.

Their edict that one not use a cell phone while in line would be reasonable, if the line did not take 30 minutes to wade through. And---and this is truly amazing---even when the line is nil, a cappuccino is STILL 11 solid minutes from my hands. And it ain't gonna warm those hands, either, because it's so damn lukewarm, even if I plead for it be "extra-hot".

I don't know what you all are seeing, but this emperor is butt naked, people. And while the coffee is good, if it takes eons to get it, it ain't that good.
author: Kathleen G.

description: Incredible lattes, always steamed at the right temperature and always delicious.
author: Zal B.

description:
The coffee is amazing, but I haven't felt so unwelcome since I tried to order a bloody mary at the Mecca International Airport bar.

Between the overworked and overly opinionated staff and the holier than thou Mission clientle, I should have assumed as much. Perhaps it was the fact that my shirt had a collar. Who knows?  

Whatever it was I ain't going back. If I want their coffee I'll go down to Flora Grubb and order it from the much friendlier staff at that outlet.

Hey Mission, get over yourself. You haven't been cool since '02.
author: Jason R.

description: Very good espresso, but they need to refresh the furniture which is looking a bit dated.   Unless they are trying to look like Muddy Waters.
author: Joyce J.

description:
As if sidewalk traffic in front of this yuppie-posing-as-hipster trustafarian place couldn't get any worse, they once decided to put outdoor tables on the sidewalk. This place is like a cancer that is slowly spreading down Valencia.

I would groove on this place if there was one Powerbook-free table in the joint where I could sit down and enjoy equal use of the place. Unfortunately, day-campers come here early, greedily claiming up each 4-seat table by splaying their crap on every square inch of table. (Why they don't simply urinate on the table to mark their territory, I don't know...). Everywhere you look it's people consciously and conspicuously demonstrating that they are not truly part of the working masses. And who wouldn't want to sit down and share that table?

Nota Bene to hipsters with one-speed bicycles: You may have to circle the block to find a meter to hitch up to. Dozens of your lame friends have already found this place.
author: Selim N.

description:
I'll be honest.  I've lived 4 blocks from Valencia St.  for over six years now and I've seen it changed.  Ritual personifies this change.  This coffee shop is the most overrated coffee shop in town.  I went there one time after all of the hype and I promised myself to never go back there again.  The coffee is ok, I'll give them that, but everything runs so expensive.  The service is horrible and the scene is even worse.  I feel like I get discriminated upon if I don't have my laptop handy.    Everyone in there seems like they are so important that they don't have time to either talk to you or make you feel welcome.  Too many places in Valencia Street have changed to become like this, and it saddens me so.

I'll leave it at that.  It seems like people on this thread really like the place, so maybe I'm missing something.  I'm just saying that there are just so many coffee places in the Mission that are so much better.  Try the Little Spot Cafe on 23rd and South Van Ness, for example.  The coffee is just as good and without the attitude.  

My 2 cents.
author: Eric S.

description:
I know I'm supposed to compare them to Blue Bottle or something, but that would require me to have actually been to Blue Bottle (hey, I'm working my way there, ok?)

What I can compare them to is Philz, because their one-cup-at-a-time "Clover" machine is a similar concept (of course, Philz will make your one cup by *hand*, so there!).  The price of this one cup all depends on the price of the beans, and believe me, I was tempted to get the $10 cup of Hacienda Esmeralda, but I chickened out and got Duncan Estate instead, another of the "hot new arrivals" from Panama (because Salvadoran beans are so pre-Labor Day).

The verdict?  Yes, I do like trying to spot the hints of meyer lemon, toffee and lily (perhaps coffee-tasting will be the new wine-tasting?), and I must give props to their iconic Islamo-Communist logo.  But for that bowl-you-over sensation of out-of-this-world coffee, I still say Philz takes home the gold...pending a final, epic showdown with Big Blue, of course.
author: Wes M.

description: While it can be a little dark, Ritual is very spacious and open, with plenty of tables for studying, catching-up, and taking time to enjoy the coffee. The mocha was delicious, with just the right amount of chocolate to add the bit of sweetness and the right amount of caffeine to wake-up, but not over-jitter, the nerves. It's got a very functional and nonsensical feel, but the tables are large, the chairs are comfortable, and it's a great place to sit and talk for a while.
author: Jing P.

description:
Hey!!! Look at me!!! I'm so cooooool! I'm hanging out in "the Mish". I'm drinking Ritual Coffee and hanging out in "the Mish"!!! Wow... I never thought I'd be able to do this. I feel so cool! 

Ok. Sorry. Had to get that out of my system. So anyways...

So I'm taking a class at the Mission Campus of CCSF. I'm mad early and in need of coffee. Jump on mobile.yelp.com and what do I find? RCR. Only a block away from my campus. Head on down. Wow.. I like this place. HUGE coffee bean sacks on the floor. Big giant contraption which I later learn is a coffee roaster. Lots of tables. Couches. and best of all... 

FREE WIFI!!!!!!!!!!!

So on a school day, you can probably find me here. Sitting in "the Mish", sipping my gooooood coffee, surfing on my mac book, taking advantage of the Free Wifi. I'm cool. Yeah I said it!
author: Jen D.

description: Calculating the price of the small cup that I purchased at price per drop, that was the most expensive liquid that I've ever purchased in my life.  And I can do without the hipster attitude because I'm not wearing 3 pieces of vintage clothing and riding a single speed.
author: Juan R.

description: Ritual coffee rocks me sweet and strong. Ritual is in the cadre of delicious Bay Area coffee roasters. They keep me coming back for the seasonal espresso roast (watch how the art work changes when the flavor of the roast does).  The location is bright and open with the back wall serving as a window to their giant terrarium.  That view only matched by the parklet in front shaped like the hull of a ship.
author: Sasha W.

description:
I tried to like it.  I thought the space was nice, but the coffee was lacking.  I've had coffee in places that take coffee seriously, and Ritual didn't measure up.  I thought it was nice that they do the whole French press thing, so your coffee is fresh, but it would be better if it was fresh and tasty.

Plus, the staff got very upset when we told them that the lattes they made for us had no coffee flavor.  We were told it was, get this, *our* fault for ordering a medium, which meant more milk.  I told them they were the first place to not balance the coffee to milk ratio properly, and boy, you would have thought I had started talking trash about her mom.

If I want to pay money and be abused, I'll go somewhere else.
author: Joe W.

description:
Ritual's beans are the finest roasted in San Francisco.  I don't know how they do it.  The premium price ($21 per pound and up) is worth it if you treat it right.  Brew it slowly by hand and it will be magic in your mouth.

As a cafe, it's not my first choice for ordering in.  It's poorly ventilated and there are a few people working there who would clearly be happier doing something else.  (Maybe because of the stifling heat and humidity?)  

My wish for the management: install a big exhaust fan and fire anyone who won't smile.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Amazing coffee and the pastries looks fantastic too (but my belly said no).  

One point off because I think I'd have a hard time hanging out here for extended periods of time--the loud music and crowd are fine for a quick stop in, but for extended reading or lazing about they don't really work for me.
author: Katie S.

description:
The friend told me this was BFF #1's favorite coffee spot.  I hadn't been yet so we stopped in one morning before brunch, knowing that we had a wait ahead of us.  Hmm, this was probably the 10th new to me place I'd been taken to in a 3 week span.  Kind of nice.

So, we got an iced americano and said my name was Omar B. to see if we could shake out some Yelpers when my order came up.  Unfortunately, they didn't say the last initial so FAIL.

It looks like a good place to read or get some work done and is more spacious than it appears from the outside.  The iced americano was ok, a little more bitter than I like, but I have faith the iced coffee is better.  I'll bump it up a star if I am proven correct.
author: Seong P.

description:
Just a small note for those who miss the french press coffee:

You can still get Ritual french press at Crave Cafe on Polk Street - so check it out.
author: Smartwater o.

description: The Soviet inspired colors and logo were a bit off-putting (they were a pretty mean regime, right?), but the beautifully prepared cappuccino and nice ambiance made it all okay. The attractive spot was crowded with well dressed people; for the Mission it's more Foreign Cinema and less Zeitgeist.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This place is great.  If I lived in the mission I would march my little trendy butt into this place and order coffee every day probably upsetting the way too cool hipster attitude that seems to waft out the front doors.  Honestly, the coffee is THAT good.  Free trade coffee, vegan goodies as well as non-vegan goodies to delight your taste buds on to compliment your coffee, and I believe there is Internet access.  

The tables and artwork at this place give it a flavor that is distinctly Valencia and regardless of how "clean" (for lack of a better word) I look, the people who work there are always nice to me.  Great place to study or just people watch.  Also, honestly... this place SCREAMS coffee date.  Not sure why but it does in a way that I can only describe as "safe space that leads for a non creepy experience" (speaking towards the coffee date thing).  hmmm...  

Anyway, if you like no I mean LOVE coffee then you have to check it out.  They are also really clever with how they pour the milk into the lattes.  designs and all.. Enjoy on an early morning, before work, coffee run or for just a lazy afternoon sitting with some friends or a good book, or just to get a caffeine fix to satisfy the craving in order to make it through the dedicated study time you made sure to pencil no make that ink into your planner!
author: Kylie L.

description: I'm not super impressed with the tea. It was $3.29 for a cup for here and the metal thing they steep the tea in is so larger that I ended up with 1/2 a cup of tea when all was said and done. A bit of a rip off.
author: Dara O.

description:
Yes, I am a little slow. You see this wanna-be hipster hasn't finished her soy latte yet.

First I noticed the absence of my beloved back-corner couch (at first I thought it may have been eaten by the guilty-looking burlap sacks, and then, regretably, briefly wondered if the coffee sacks were meant as seating. I warned you I am slow today).

Then my laptop battery ran low and while searching for an outlet, I knocked into not one, but two to-go patrons who, again regretably, lost a couple ounces of foam. I realize: the outlets are gone, some with wires hanging out like severed tendons.

The epiphany: I am not wanted here. I have been here for two hours on the price of one latte (albeit soy is an extra 40c). The seating is gone, as are the power sources - someone is trying to tell me something (eg you don't live here nor does your contribution help pay rent, get the hell out).

Ritual, you used to want me and I you and not to even discuss this and to be this blunt? 

Sadly, I write this outside on the corner from my phone. My thumb is tired.

Ritual, your choice is regretable.

But I get it, I really do.

See you around.
author: Karey G.

description:
Pros: nice decor, good coffee, good atmosphere, good for people watching, comfy couches, line moves reasonably fast

Biggest Peeve: the cashier has NEVER asked me for my name even when she's asked for others. Probably because I'm clearly "ethnic" so she won't even attempt to pronounce my name. A bit disappointing to be called "chai latte" when everyone's else name is called out. 

Cons: too many bloody hipsters and macbooks. not enough seating at most points of the day (prepared to stuggle) and they cover the power outlets so good luck when you run out of battery power.
author: Ahmed A.

description:
Edit 3: Years later, with stiff competition from Four Barrel, Blue Bottle, and others, Ritual has lost the attitude and focused on a pleasing customer experience. Have had 8-10 just-fine experiences in the last year or two. A fine place to sip coffee or have a casual meeting. My only suggestion for improvement would be to use thicker, non-bleached filters for the pour-over coffee; it will reduce bitterness and provide a bleach-free coffee experience.

Edit No 2: Gabe from Ritual followed up with me, and we came to an understanding. Part of running a good business is following up on customer feedback, which he did; Since my beef was with the service and not the coffee, and the service gripe has been rectified, I'm adjusting the review to reflect this. 

I'm new to the neighborhood, so I wanted to check this place out. I've heard great things about it.

The espresso was great. The attitude of the barrista was not. I was in a hurry and wanted my espresso to go. I don't like hot liquids, or being hurried in consumption of food or drink. However, I was informed by the man behind the counter that espresso is traditionally enjoyed "at the bar" and not "to go." No shit? I thought they had cardboard cups centuries ago in Italy! It wasn't a malicious or mean attitude. Just a sort of condescending fact-delivery by someone who assumed I needed to be educated on something I already know about. It is analogous to a waiter telling you that you should "really be placing the knife back on the plate before taking a bite." 

The point is, even if you are right, you shouldn't make a customer argue with you to get what they order. Hell, I could have a ceramic phobia, and it would be publicly embarrassing to have to go into it in front of other customers. Assumptions are definitely not cool, nor is it very enlightened to put people on the spot when providing a service to them.

Anyway, I finally gave up just to get my espresso. At this point, I'm just pissed and want to cut my losses and get out. I downed it at the counter instead of enjoying sipping it slowly like I wanted to, and left.

Still, gets two stars due to the amazing quality of the drink. 

I'll be going to Revolution on the corner here on out. At least there, they don't make me explain why I am ordering a Boont Amber when they offer Sierra Nevada.
author: Eric G.

description:
It was so funny when I walked in on a Thursday mid afternoon and it was  a rainy day.  To see EVERYONE sippin on their coffee and what not and tune in on their lap tops. I swear I stood in the middle of the room and busted out a loud laughed. It looked like it was study hall but with coffee and cookies.

I must say thou....their cappuccino's was really delicious!!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: I don't rate coffee base on the amount of hipsters present in the place. I love a excellent latte and Ritual Coffee has it. When I see a female barista I usually clinch my teeth. On my quest of finding a good latte, I have found that female baristas are not as good as male baristas. At Ritual, I was surprise to get my latte done perfectly by a chick!.
author: Angelica S.

description:
Am I a hipster? Have I ever said that word out loud? 

Are first impressions important? Is this the best looking coffee house in the Mission? 
Why is this place so crowded on a weekday afternoon? Don't these people have jobs? 
You can't put hazelnut in my latte? No flavored syrups? 
Will you grunt if I sit next to you? 
Do laptops come standard with each table? 
Why is there so much noise? Is that coffee roaster always humming? 
Am I going to get a parking ticket? 
Don't you think Ritual is a nice change from the usual? But it's not worth a trip across town, is it? 
Are you looking at my jeans? How YOU doing?
author: Teddy B.

description:
The coffee is good (aka, strong). 

But it's too crowded with a line out the door more often than not. There are no power outlets if you're working on a laptop. Really slim food / baked goods selection. The music is often annoying and too loud to tune out.

Nice stencils about gentrification on the sidewalk out front, bashing Google employees, haha!
author: Sally C.

description:
I remember when this place was a furniture store and when it closed, my roommates and I would joke about how it was going to turn into another coffee shop, which we all know, is the last thing this over caffeinated city needs, right? 

So we watched as they opened up and laughed and laughed. Hahahaha, more coffee! Suckers. 

Of course, who's laughing now? Ritual, of course. Their French Press coffee taught me that my daily cup didn't have to be giant cups of sludge that I'd been drinking at Muddy Waters and their creamy, wonderful espresso drinks cured me from years of Starbucks conditioning. That the clientele are all walking steretoypes doesn't bother me; I of course, wear my black hooded sweatshirts very proudly.
author: Maria D.

description:
Their espresso drinks are so delicious, I even get mochas here, and I never get mochas because they usually drown the coffee flavor. I'm the kind of person who gets mopey when my "for here" order gets dumped into a paper cup and whose heart does cartwheels when there are pictures in the foam and the cup and saucer come with a tiny spoon, so this place makes me happy. It's good to have lots of plants and tables inlaid with beautiful wood stripes. Sometimes it's a little too rambunctious in there for the mood I'm in, but then I just go to Que Tal or the Mission library for quiet. But no one makes coffee around here like they do. I heard someone there today (a manager? owner?) talking about a coffee convention she had just attended, which made me wonder if perhaps their coffee could get even better....

I think people are just psyching themselves out about the hipster vibe because if you actually watch the people behind the counter, they are extremely polite, usually friendly, and never snooty, at least not in my experience. And most of the customers are probably worried about everyone else being cooler than they are without realizing that they too have a certain sauciness that is making others insecure. p.s. I have a huge asexual crush on the Asian girl with fringy hair and glasses. She has a nice bicycle. If they made a doll based on her, I would hug it at night.
author: Katrina D.

description:
The beans here are awesome; I should know, they're a big part of my daily grind.
Ha, ha.
Anyway.
The environment, however, leaves something to be desired. I'm talking about YOU, T.A. taking up a four-person table with your papers and scowling at people for having conversations in public places while milking the same cup of coffee for four hours.
Most coffee houses ask these sort of patrons to leave, but not Ritual, and it's the reason I'm knocking off two stars.
I'll gladly drink the coffee--because it is definitely quality brew--but I won't stick around to fight for a table and relax because the staff can't make room for actual patrons. These guys really need to at get rid of internet access or _something_, 'cause it's way out of hand.
author: Erin P.

description: First of all, I swear the logo looks very similar to the Turkish flag. So naturally I thought it was a Turkish coffee house. Easy mistake! After dinner across the street, my group went to Ritual for some coffee. We ordered some coffee and had a great time getting to know everyone, old and new. My bf bought a bag of Colombian coffee and it smelled SO GOOD! It was so aromatic even without tearing open the bag. I wanted to take a bean with me and stick it into my pocket. It was THAT good.
author: Anna S.

description:
So here I am, sitting at ritual coffee roasters on a wednesday evening, enjoying my last few unemployed days. I am here with my friend Kerrie (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=1Idc35tGsgkB3G2ntig0LA), talking to each other via google talk even though she's sitting on the same table as I am, yelping the place, looking around and sizing up guys, giggling like school girls. Too bad every time K asked me if a certain guy was cute, I always looked at the wrong one :-\ We need to establish a better spying system.

Ritual provides a pleasant space for people watching, very cozy. A bit noisy, but it doesn't really bother me. Coffee is good. The mocha is actually bitter, not super sweet like starbucks'. If I lived around here I'd come here more often.
author: Ari C.

description:
Yay for cozy atmosphere, good music (and sometimes funny and nostalgic, like "The Thong Song"), cool people, lots of seats.

Boo for all the seats being taken, and for leaving the door open when it's 45 degrees out!

Yowza! for the spicy, spicy chai.
author: Gina K.

description:
The stars are ONLY, I repeat, ONLY for the taste of the coffee I had and NOT, I repeat NOT for the service or atmosphere here.

The coffee is good.  It is brewed well, strong enough (could be a bit more robust but it was my third cup of the day and I wasn't dying to overdose on caffeine). 

The atmosphere is the typical hipster mission crowd.  Not my scene, but I guess it works for some.  The service was robotic.  Maybe it was because I was not wearing the mission hipster uniform: mismatched clothes, some sort of ugly hat, some sort of ugly flat shoes, a big hobo bag and a bad haircut...I feel like they would have been nicer to me if I looked like I belonged there, but oh well.  
I had to wait about 8 minutes for a cup of coffee which makes me edgy...but the coffee was good.  
I wanted to give less stars but I really enjoyed my coffee, it felt more like a "second cup" rather than a "third cup" so I had to add that last star.
author: Nilu r.

description:
let me tell you, moving to sf, and valencia st. no less, is a shock for a new york coffee drinking pleb.  as an outsider, you don't realize that at any moment, if you happen to be somewhere north of 24th and west of mission people are walking around with little paper cups stamped with gang signs.  between four barrel (both the real one and tartine), the summit now serving blue bottle, ritual, and two philz within a few blocks, coffee gang wars could break out and at moment.  it didn't occur at all to me that i'd moved into the crosshairs of the most contentious, vicious ongoing battle for respect in the streets of sf.  

anyway, ritual-- i don't care if i get gunned down somewhere on guerrero leaving nothing but my broken custom framed art and spilling the last foamy remains of my latte on the street.  i choose you above all others.  there, i said it.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Mmmm... delicious sweet coffee... I love you!

Friendly staff and extremely talented baristas who pull some amazing shots. You know your latte will be fantastic when they finish it with the 'leaf' design in the steamed milk. Yum yum -- always absolutely excellent.

I always get my coffee to go, because the atmosphere is a little hectic for my tastes. There are rarely any open tables; most of them are overflowing with people furiously typing away on their laptops. It is rather reminiscent of the main stacks at Berkeley during finals time.

Another bonus: quite reasonably priced for an independent coffee house. Cheers!
author: Jill M.

description:
Great coffee and decent hangout/workspace. The various drinks I've had have been well-prepared. Sometimes there is a horrible line, and in moments like that I look around and wonder why I'm so desperate for a cup that I'll wait like a Communist during rations. I guess that explains the vaguely communist style logo emblazoned on the wall. 

The atmosphere of the place is simple and cold, but lively with talk and clatter. There are scads of people doing who knows what on their Apple laptops, but the place is a little small to spread all your gear out.
author: Nik D.

description: I say suck it to the nay sayers out there for disregarding this place. First off, the roaster is right behind the counter, and the bean bags are literally right by the back door. It smells like a coffee house the minute you step in! Yes. the place took out all of their electricity outlets for laptop users to stop hogging the tables for hours at an end, but let's face it - the coffee is simply amazing. These guys know what they're creating and yes, they're slightly egotistical about it, but can you blame them? Hell, if my coffee tasted this good at home, I'd stop buying from them. Anyways, try their cappuccino with an alfajor. THEN tell me you'll by from Starbucks from now on!
author: Carolina S.

description:
The best coffee anywhere!

The only thing negative (and it cancels itself out out because it adds to the ambiance) is the notebook parking; the place is always filled with people totally absorbed in their own little 15" world (dominated by Macs - a good thing!).  I only hope that they spend more than they appear to so the good people that work there get their just rewards (tips, etc.)!
author: Rich N.

description:
I enjoyed a very  tasty soy chai brewed to creamy/spicy/frothy 
perfection by a cutie-pie barista with very curly hair. 
*hello sir* 
Perfect fuel for window shopping on valencia.
Yup,  this place is such a scene, but I'll be back. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
Ritual Coffee will indeed be a new weekend ritual. 
It's so very hip, open, modern, but mellow-yellow too. My powerbook felt right at home with all the other uber hipster's...(and so did my hair, i might add :)

AND, surprise- the coffee is amazing too, and I love the simplicity & strength in Ritual's Russian Constructivist-esque identity...Talk about POWER! BAM! No corporate bullshit, it's the real deal. They even have an itty-bitty back patio where you arent allowed to talk - and i think they are serious due to neighbors' complaints. (Dolly & I tried it for approx 2 seconds and it was near impossible, so we snagged seats inside)

Go to Ritual to work, unwind, chat, or people watch...just don't tell everyone about it. I would just about move back to the Mission for this place.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Update 10/20/06:
Came back yesterday for a drive by after lunch cappucino. Man these guys are at the top of the game. Not sure if there was a change recently but this is some of the best in the city. I'm going to come back on a different day and time to check for consistency but these guys / and gals are true craftsman! 
end update:
Writing a screenplay on mission hipsters? Come here. This place is mecca all day long. 

Gotta love it for that, and as you'll see in one of the pics they know the ancient art of making trees and bushes in their coffee and milk concoctions, ie cappu, maciattios, and lattes. It's awesome to watch these drinks come off the press. I just stare in wonder and then the customer picks it up w/o looking and drinks it down.j

Good beans also, esp the Colombian roast. And all the coffee is fresh cooked in French Press. Good luck finding a seat but it's worth checking out if your in the 20's on Valencia.
author: Phil M.

description:
Caveat #1: I don't have it in for hipsters.  I don't get them, but I'm not a hater.
Caveat #2: I'm not a snobby connoisseur of coffee.  Just an avid fan, especially of the non-Starbucks, fair trade variety.  

That being said, let's review my first (and probably last) Ritual Coffee experience:

I walk in.  There is no line, just a customer chatting with the cashier/barista at the counter.  Neither of them chose to acknowledge my existence until they had finished their chat.  In the meantime, I perused the list of special roasts.  I winced a bit inside at the prices (I have yet to become fully accustomed to San Francisco costs).  In my head I decided, "What the hell?  Give it a try."

I ordered a small non-fat chai.  The cashier took my $3 and pulled out a paper cup that seemed not much bigger than your average Dixie cup.  I was stunned that I was being charged $3 for what seemed to be not much more than a shot of chai tea.  Again, I tried to remind myself that this is foodie-ville and one has to accept high prices for truly delectable fare.

Then I waited for my Dixie cup to be filled.  Gradually, the group of people waiting grew larger and larger.  The too-cool-for-school barista could not have been less affected by the number of people waiting for their coffees.  Instead, he opened some newly arrived boxes and chatted with other customers.  Once he was good and ready, he decided to start working on our orders.  

When he finally finished mine, he announced, "Small soy chai."  I said, "Oh, I'm sorry, I actually ordered a non-fat chai,  not a soy chai."  In response, he shot me a look of pure disdain.  And, in stereotypical hipster sarcastic form, he exasperatedly droned, "Sweeeeeeeet" and threw out the contents of the Dixie cup.  

I immediately felt bad about being responsible for wasted caffeinated goodness.  But, I reminded myself, I'd been waiting at least 15 minutes and I had paid more than usual.  It was fair of me to insist on being served what I had ordered!  Just as I was reassuring myself, I noticed that Mr. Barista was pouring soy milk into my chai *again*!  He pushed my Dixie cup towards me and immediately busied himself with the next drink before I could protest.

In the end, the chai was excellent.  I usually do not like the taste of soy in my coffee/chai, but I guess there are always exceptions.  If it weren't for the unreasonably long wait and shoddy customer service, I might even be convinced to return to Ritual Coffee and upgrade to a normal sized paper cup.  But I just can't convince myself to patronize a place where I was so blatantly disrespected and dismissed.  Maybe things would be different if I owned an ironic vintage t-shirt or two.  Maybe not.
author: Jessie R.

description:
NEW FAVORITE COFFEE PLACE, EVER.  No, for real.  List of why I Don't Care That La Onda Closed, Now That I've Found Ritual:

1. Ceramic cups
2. Red fiestaware plates
3. Mugs with the hammer-and-sickle coffee logo on it
4. Cute hipsters with mac laptops
5. Good music
6. Free WiFi (appears to be decently fast, too!)
7. Vegan pastries (pear bread was delish!)
8. BEST COFFEE I'VE HAD IN YEARS.  Like, since Vienna.  With soy milk, and a pretty design on the top, as if it were made with real milk -- none of this you-dumb-vegan,-you-get-an-ugly-coffee bullshit.  These guys are not fucking around.

I'm never going anywhere else.  Maybe I should move apartments, just to be closer to this one.
author: Nori H.

description:
I have no idea why this place is so packed everytime I try to stop in, and in fact I often just give up. Finally, my buddy Phil and I checked it out the other afternoon.

Is the coffee good? Yeah, it's good. I suppose the real draw though is the people watching. It's decidedly Mission Hipster, or at least those that subscribe to that lifestyle. It's actually a little comical at times.

I'd give this place 3.5 stars, but unless I still lived right nearby would not make a ritual out of frequenting this place.
author: Nish N.

description:
Sure I'm late to the Ritual Coffee Bandwagon, but now when ever I'm around Valencia this is my new coffee spot.  I really didn't hear too much hype about this place, just the long lines leaking outside when I would drive by.  I ordered my regular drink, an iced mocha.  It has to be the smoothest that I've had, ever!  Not too sweet nor strong tasting, but its like good alcohol beverages, it creeps up on you and your wired without even knowing it!

The place is huge like the size of 3 regular coffee shops put together and they offer free, non-complicated Wi-Fi.  For you coffee fanatics, they roast their beans in the middle of their place, so I guess you can see and smell the roasting process.  I came by in the AM during the week and most seats were taken already, I would hate to see what its like at night or on the weekends.
author: Jason A.

description:
I, Maia Bittner, am not cool enough to drink coffee at Ritual.

I keep trying, but it's just out of my league.  I'm going to give up trying to fit in - there certainly aren't any friendly faces welcoming me in to "their" coffeehouse.

Also, the couches are really uncomfortable.  I know they look old and worn-in and comfortable, but don't be fooled.  This is not a good place to sit with your laptop for hours - and because of the ever-present wait, not a good place to stop by a grab a quick cup either.
author: Maia B.

description:
An absolutely incredible cappuccino.  Worth the wait in line.  Perfection in a cup.

Not to mention they had "double rainbow coffee".  Nothing goes better with coffee than a sense of humor.
author: C J.

description:
Am I the first person to not have heard of Ritual Coffee Roasters before coming here?  Quite possibly...but hey, I'm an un-hip, Mission neophyte - I'm still learning.

Came here last Saturday before hip-hop class with the always knowledgeable Tim V.  Love the interior - roomy, vaulted ceilings...not your typical cramped coffee shop.  The trees in back add a lovely touch.  But really what it's all about is the coffee.  I took a sip of my latte, completely forgetting that I normally add Splenda and I marveled at the taste...Wow, a latte where I actually don't feel like I need to add sweetener!  There is a first time for everything, people.

I can't wait to come back...if only I lived in The Mission....*idea*.

Oh, and to watch these people work is quite amazing....they're like clockwork...it's down to a science here....which you really have to be considering how popular this place is....I can see why they named it Ritual as I'm sure for many, it is.
author: Melanie N.

description:
The espresso is amazing - I think probably the best I have ever had.  I love wasting an hour on the stoop with my roommate laughing over the scene - because it is such a scene. 

Sometimes it makes me a bit sick to my stomach seeing all these holier than thou hipster wanna be black clothes bad haircut no grips on their single speed road bike tiny locks in their tapered black vintage jeans sipping coffee and talking about their pathetic social scenes ins and outs.  maybe its just me......  but the coffee would be so much better without all that nonsense.
author: amy b.

description:
I love the coffee here, but what I can't stand is the lack of places to sit. Either one person with a laptop has commandeered a 4-person table and won't share, or people are using the barstools to hold their messenger bags. Seriously, courtesy, people!
