I have only once ONCE! gotten a seat at an actual table in this place.
Get your java to go, you'll be ok.
Or, walk one block down Valencia to Mission Grounds and sit at a huge table with your friends.
Your call.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Here's a Thursday afternoon observation: 
MacBook, MacBook Pro, MacBook, another MacBook, more MacBooks, MacBook, MacBook Pro, MacBook, another MacBook, more MacBooks everywhere!  

And there was my non-MacBook PC notebook.  I AM NOT A HIPSTER, HEAR ME ROAR!

Great people watching.  Good free wireless internet. And oh, this place has AWESOME STRONG coffee.  You'll bounce off the walls for hours - I know I did!
-------------------
CUPCAKE Update 2/20/07:

I had my first Ritual vanilla cupcake with chocolate frosting - TWO THUMBS up!  The cake could have been a little more moist, but the chocolate frosting? Absolutely delectable.... A bit pricey at $2.75, but gee, this cupcake goes GREAT with Ritual's awesome coffee....
author: Jane A.

description:
A friend and I happened upon this place while looking for somewhere to work and chill out. This is a great find! Coffee was delicious and the doughnuts surprisingly tasty.

Internet could be a bit faster since it seems to be a haven for tech wizards and designer types to come work. Would also think it awesome if there were more electrical outlets that worked and less fake ones:) But I'll definitely be back!!
author: Greg F.

description:
I agree with Mitch M.'s review & Ritual is truly the 2nd best place (after Blue Bottle Coffee Company) for a nonfat latte in San Francisco & possibly the whole wide world.  

About the skinny latte:  Smooth as silk & flavor so full & fresh as if you just picked the beans yourself & put it in your mouth!  

Additional cherry on top's: They have a frequent purchase card & they're open real late.  The only bad thing is that they blocked the electrical outlets, so you'll definitely make use of your laptop's battery here.
author: Sheryl S.

description: Yeah...it's a ritual.  They grind the beans and drip your individual cup right before your eyes, but the end result is no better than other, faster methods. It seems like it should taste better, but it doesn't.
author: Bleep S.

description:
I used to live in Seattle, and now I don't have to only dream about marvelous espresso way up in the northwest. Ritual has got us covered down here in SF - thank the lord of coffee. 
It's funny, I don't even drink much coffee at all. I'm really a tea person, but when I want a creamy, caramel-like espresso I'll drive/ ride my bike all the way across town. 
Some issues I've come across are super loud music, but who needs to talk these days anyway, let's just gchat.
author: Laura A.

description:
I went back last weekend with a couple friends for coffee. It was the first stop in our Mission progressive for brunch. lol!

Sundae espresso double shot - A blend of three beans, fairly acidic, with a tart/bitter finish.

Sweet tooth double shot (I forgot which bean it was) - Much better, smoother, more mellow. Good crema.

Had a cup of clover coffee as well. Very good, totally worth it.

The double shots are pulled extremely short. I've never had such a small double shot anywhere. Blended beans can be hard to pull off for espresso (zoka in seattle is one of the few i would buy blended beans from), so I recommend to stick to single origin if you're gonna have espresso here. Or just get a clover and that will last you much longer. I downed both double shots before my friends even got their coffees. ;P

There's always a line, so be prepared to wait.
author: Kenny J.

description:
Amazing coffee drinks, best in SF.

Crowds may "annoy" you with either their fashion sense or their large quantity. I don't care, because I come for the coffee, not to look at other people's clothes.


To Reviewer "Dan G."- 

You wrote  "minus another two for the staff's holier than thou attitude if you ever so politely ask if they have vanilla syrup for a latte..."


Um, this is because they a a Seattle-style gourmet coffee bar. The artisan style coffee drinks rarely have flavorings,   as they are usually added into coffee drinks TO COVER the taste of the espresso (see: sour)

And :

" Oh and one time I felt like a mocha so I ordered one... it came with a beautiful leaf pattern... very talented I thought to myself and then I asked, "could I have some whipped cream please?"  You would have thought I asked the Batista to blow me judging by his reaction...  fuck off..."

Real mochas don't have whipped cream on top, just creamy micro-foam (that's why people come to this cafe dummy)

Also:

"I bet if they served french fries, they'd yell at you for asking for ketchup...." 

Possibly. If it was a artisan Belgian style or French style french fry place they would probably use MAYO instead of ketchup, so I'm afraid your wrong about that one too.

Just give in. It's great coffee.
author: Lisa M.

description:
First time I went was right after they opened. Espresso drinks were amazing. And I didn't try it but I think they make their regular coffee in french presses.  

I have lived in the mission for a good long while, and am generally over the surly, pretentious, smelly dirty mission hipsters that seem to somehow seem to make a living doing customer service.  No exception here. 

But if you get lucky enough to get a seat, there is free wifi, and it has a nice buzz of people chatting and working on the mac books, and decent music. And I get a lot done. However, you just can't ever get a seat. 

And last two times I went, I was in a rush. And it literally took 25 minutes to get my drink. I finally had to leave the last time. The time before, the drink was nasty. down right nasty. 

Not sure what happened, between when they opened and now, but this place sucks. I won't be going back.
author: Dapper D.

description: It's alright.   Nothing to write home about.  The wait is long and staff less than friendly.  All you coffee drinkers that rate this place and blue bottle at the top of your list must not have tried Philz coffee.  I'm just sayin'.
author: Blu n.

description:
There are certain things you need to know about this place:
1) Far and away the best coffee in SF
2) Even though it gets crowded, nobody here is too full of themselves to share a table with you. Try asking if you can sit down, it's a great way to meet people.
3) People have laptops these days, stop complaining about it. When was the last time you actually wrote a letter to somebody? Exactly. 
4) The people behind the counter are friendly.
5) The Mission might be teeming with hipsters, but complaining about hipsters is another way of being a hipster. If you don't like it, put on a vertically striped shirt and go to the Marina. 
6) Did I mention that this place has the best coffee in SF?
author: Josh K.

description:
I really like the coffee, but this place is such a scene that i can't stand to go in.  Some people come here for the coffee (GREAT!), but a lot of people come here to be cool and to be seen and that fuc.ing bothers me.  i don't find it conducive to working or reading or really even hanging out.   The scene here is like the alter-ego to city tavern in the Marina.  I hate both but they exist for the same reason.

I love the coffee (5 stars), hate the scene (1 star)
author: Spencer G.

description:
laptops are overrated.
while you blog about the new scarf you bought your cat, i'm keepin it real with my old school comp book writing about fucking awesomeness that binary cannot comprehend.

this is accompanied by either a soy latte or au lait and some vegan donut or pastry thing.
but once i'm done i just up and go while you are hampered by shutting down and wrapping up your power cable.
i'm like a ghost. a really charming ghost free of the cold icy grip of technology.

i like ritual. ever since la onda closed down it's been my default spot because they are pretty solid.
sadly there aren't many other coffee houses that put up a fight.
i like options.
author: JAYCE B.

description: Espresso just wasn't in the same league as other top rated places in the area (Blue Bottle).  Ritual was much more bitter and if memory serves me well, it actually cost more here too (maybe I had the "sweet tooth" shot though).  Restroom was alright.  Sparse seating, or maybe it was incredibly busy, but I was surprised how few seats there were for so much square footage.  Cool emblem though, indirectly resembling the old Soviet Union flag somewhat.
author: Albert H.

description:
I don't care who frequents this place, what they look like, how many lap tops they own or at this point how long it takes (sometimes service is slow- but mostly because they are busy).  This is some GOOD coffee and I'm finding it harder and harder to order a latte in any other cafe in this city.  I've actually wanted to cry the few times I've headed in before my Tuesday night bartending shift in the hood to find that they were closed for remodeling or whatever.    Having to go elsewhere now actually physically hurts me.  I'll drink other neighborhood coffees, but it's not the same.  

I recently asked one of the hott barrista ladies as to why their coffee tastes so much better and her response was reasonable:  "better coffee beans and less espresso per milk ratio." 

The PERFECT balance.  The proof is in the pudding.

I love it.
author: annie s.

description:
San Francisco doesn't pride itself on its efficiencies (see: BART fare, schedule and map).  One thing, though, that we all (presumably) want quickly is a cup of coffee.  Circumstance dictates whether I sit and drink my coffee or take it on the run.  Nonetheless, it's coffee and coffee reins quickly.

I was excited to see a handful of coffee shops within a minute's walk from my front door when I moved to the neighborhood.  It took about two trips to Ritual to realize that Mission Creek Cafe was the local mom and pop (old pop, that is) joint to support.  Combined, I've probably waited 15 minutes for two cups of house coffee.  If they need to brew it, I'll give them ten or twelve minutes.  That wasn't exactly the case though... either time.  In both instances, the employees just stood behind the counter, hipply looking at the ground, presumably contemplating how uncool Animal Collective has gotten, while they should have been filling my cup.

I'm pretty practical - and patient.  The coffee is good but the sizes are small.  Before working a full day of construction I'd like a substantial, or at least status quo, sized cup.  

Good work on the coffee flavors and even better job making me feel unwanted.
author: Peter G.

description:
ha ha 
So, at the time of this review 156 out of 660 reviews mention the term "hipster" in a derogatory manner. 
How do all of you over paid under worked insecure people live with yourselves? How do you find the time to categorize and insult strangers living in one of the most expensive cities in the country?
How can you even walk out the door into your hipster infested neighborhood? aren't you worried that you are too ugly or lame to even live in san francisco? hahahahaha 
name calling and pigeon-holing strangers seems really lonely and limiting. if you must name call think about what it is that you dislike so much about these "hipsters" and be more specific. as it is this is a very vague expression of judgment. i mean, chances are, someone is calling YOU a hipster right now! hahahahahahahahahahahaha

GO HOME KOOKS! LOCALS ONLY!! CALIFORNIA RULES DUDES! HAHAHAH
author: Eric B.

description:
Superb coffee. Some of the best you will ever find. 

The atmosphere is lame mostly due to loud obnoxious music but the free wifi is nice.
author: peter c.

description:
Since my usual place closed when I was away attending college in New York, I HAD to find a new study spot when i returned home.

This place is nice.

The coffee was ok (not really waht I was there for, I was there for the study space) and the music was awesome if a bit loud.  The only things I would wish for would be more places to sit (it was packed) and more than two rest rooms.

The barristas were awesome, nice and not arrogant or "I'm hipper than you" 

I'll be back :)
author: Lisa B.

description:
So I finally did the ritual thing this morning, here's how I break it down:

+ 1 star for super friendly service
+ 1 star for the really gorgeous girl sitting next to me. she must have been a model (also included in this star is Ritual affording me access to view the latest fashions as displayed by the model and other customers).
+1 star for great music

- 1 potential star for being COLD in there even after two elderly gentleman asked for the back door to be closed.
- .5 potential stars for their chai latte tasting like frothy nonfat milk mixed with some honey, but then again, what was I doing ordering tea in a place that specializes in coffee? My bad there.

I like to round up and that girl was some serious pretty, so I rate my experience 4 stars.
author: Tea A.

description: Needed to re-fuel for some more Christmas shopping and stop by my old hood.  Well I have to say what I liked was made to order coffee.  I tried of course their Salvadorean blend not bad not great;usually Salvadorean blend is a little fruity with a lighter taste. The coffee did have a fruity taste but barely tasted the fruitiness and tasted more of a harsher heavy taste.  I will try another blend that is not so harsh on my palate.  Overall, give it a try at least once, I was impressed with some of their do it yourself items on their shelves.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
As a transplanted seattleite, I have been consistently disappointed with baristas in the bay area (or for that matter, anywhere else in the country).

4 stars for ritual roasters because their staff reminds me of home: they give 100% of a damn about their drinks and they don't give a damn about you.  (By comparison, a typical bay area starbucks barista gives about 50% of a damn to what they are going to do that night, 30% of a damn about not getting fired, and 20% of a damn about not adding more than the corporate-defined amount of vanilla syrup to your venti frappacino - gross).

Any good barista knows that when you order a "short nonfat", its a latte.  "Latte" is implied, much like a pronoun is implied in spanish (given that you've conjugated your verbs correctly).  It is my litmus test for a good roaster.  Ritual passes.  keep up the good work, you smarmy hipsters.
author: Anthony L.

description:
As best I can tell, the granddaddy of San Francisco's nascent rise to coffee supremacy. Opened in 2005, these guys are a Mission institution. There were so many startupy people using them as an office, they recently had to permanently remove all of the electrical outlets. Four Barrel coffee down the street was recently founded by an ex-Ritual employee.

Good coffee. They have a clover, know how to use it, and roast their own premium coffee onsite to brew in it. Starbuck's acquired clover, so the aforementioned combination will remain a rarity.
author: Joseph R.

description:
This is the best coffee shop in all of San Francisco !! 
I love coffee and so do the people of Ritual .
I always come here to drink great coffee and meet with friends...
And i can't forget the kick ass cupcakes !!! almost too good :)
author: lizabeth j.

description:
Thumbs Up: Best coffee in the city. It's hard to find stronger, more full-bodied coffees than the ones you'll find at Ritual, and it's comforting to know that the sources of their bean supplies harvest them in ways that are ethical in trade to the farmers.

Thumbs Down: The occasional rude hipster working the counter. Ritual has actually gotten a lot friendlier to their customers, so I am going to bump them up to four stars. 

There used to be this guy working there who looked kind of like Hitler? Anyway, one morning I ordered a bagel with cream cheese, then paid at the counter. He put the bagel in the toaster and gave me a bag with cream cheese. So I went and sat down at a table waiting for the bagel, thinking when it was done I could pop it in the bag that he gave me and leave.

He called me over and said, "Um yeah...I don't have anything to put it in."

I said, "Put...what in?"

He gave a condescending laugh and said, "Um, the bagel? I can't put it in the bag if you walk away with it."

I was thinking, "Ok Hitler...if you didn't want me to walk away with the bag, then why did you give me the bag in the first place? And like you don't have 80,000 other bags behind the counter? Like I took the last bag in the entire store? After you gave it to me?"

Anyway, it was 6:30 or 7:00 in the morning, I was too drowsy to fight, so I just sighed and gave him the bag, but in my head I was goosestepping with my finger under my nose, mocking the oppressive iron fist of the kaiser barista.

Anyway-- kickass coffee and a revamped staff. As long as you don't run into Hitler, you should be good to go!
author: Bionic F.

description:
Ritual, despite its pretentious hipster fashion show aspect, has the best soy latte I've ever tasted.  It's perfect as is--no need for sugar or anything else--and it's gorgeously presented with a perfect heart or leaf or whatever designed with the milk on top.

It's loud in there and extremely crowded, so not the most desirable spot for studying or reading, but any time I'm in the neighborhood and want a coffee I stop by and get a to-go latte, and they are ridiculously good.
author: Claire K.

description:
Good espresso drinks.  One of a hand full of places that can pull a proper shot.  Not over pulled, over caffeinated and burnt like so SO many places in SF.  It is a bit "too cool for school", but I like it. 

One thing to note, no outlets for your laptop.  I've heard this is purposeful, because people just don't leave.  funny to think about actually.  :)  

Price is as to be expected, about $3 for a cappuccino, $2 for an espresso, that type of thing, and the milk is done right, smooth and buttery soft with the bubbles a perfect cascade amidst the sweet espresso...god I need coffee again now....later,
author: Matthew D.

description:
Ritiual is as close to Italian espresso as I have found in the Bay Area.  Unlike the big chains, Ritual knows that a burned bean does NOT make gooi coffee. They roast lightly, which allows me to taste and smell the difference among the coffees on hand.

The good and bad is that the offerings change so that, when I find one close to Nirvana, it is gone in a month or so. :-/  Reluctantly I try something else and find another variety to please me.

The quality of espresso drinks is much appreciated. They look, smell, and taste fabulous. I have never had a coffee I did not savor. I'm transported back to Italy...

The bad: table hogs. With free Wifi, some singles take a table for four, cover it with their stuff, and won't share. Best to get there early for a place to sit. Then again, among those who do share, we have meet some people we enjoyed a lot and been ab le to exchange restaurant tips.

We have now moved from SF and still include Ritual into each visit and manage our bean purchases so we can buy them there. Everything else tastes over-roasted. We lived in Europe for a while and never saw an over-roasted bean. As a French friend remarked at a chain shop, "Why do they call this French roast? The French would never roast coffee like this. To get our strong taste, we use more coffee, not darker coffee,"
author: Sandra M.

description:
I applaud Ritual's obvious dedication to espresso, but I can't help but feel slightly exasperated by the overtly hipster stylings of the cafe, the display cases full of mediocre pastry, and the sea of laptop barricades separating the patrons from one and others' haircuts. 

If you can brave the snaking line of the faithful, the Stumptown grinds make a fine brew, though by the time you fight your way over to your cup, you may no longer care.
author: Stellah D.

description:
Ok, so this is a tentative four star review.  Tentative because I've only been here twice, and don't want to get too far ahead of myself.  Truthfully, based on those two experiences I'm actually fully inclined to give Ritual a five star review - however, I take coffee very seriously, so instead I show a little restraint.  The true test will be when I buy a pound of their coffee to prepare at home and try a shot of their espresso - which I haven't done yet.

All of that said, people who know me know that I take my coffee very seriously.  Until I tried Ritual I honestly haven't found any coffee roasters in the city that I felt comfortable describing as much more than slightly above average.  

There are so many bad coffee roasters in the city I started dropping my standards (if you are a coffee roaster and you only offer dark roasts - I'd automatically award you one star without trying your crappy dark roasts).  I've actually gone as far as to regularly have coffee from my favorite coffee roaster, Boston Stoker Coffee (ironically not based from or located in Boston), mailed to me from the Midwest.  

Here is where Ritual has so far gone very very right (and why I suspect I'll not need to have coffee mailed to me from the Midwest anymore):

On my first trip to Ritual I merely had a cup of drip coffee.  It was excellent - not too acidic, a slightly nutty taste, and a nice smooth taste.  I was impressed.  

On my second trip to Ritual I ordered a cafe au lait.  In my opinion, a cafe au lait is a very subtle drink, and easily (and often) fucked up by crappy barristas (which constitute 90%+ of the barristas in the city).  For example, if you have ever sat the pitcher of milk on the espresso machine and walked away while frothing milk - you are a crappy barrista.  Here the milk was frothed with care (not scorched),  the drink was poured properly, and a nice interesting design was left on the surface of the foam.  The drink itself?  Perfect.  Honestly, this was the best cafe au lait I've ever had including those I've made for myself.  

Anyways, I've not spent any time hanging around Ritual - so I can't and won't review the WiFi, the interior, the ambiance, etc.  Honest truth is that even if the floor was covered in feces and urine and enraged simians attacked unsuspecting customers with AIDS covered, rusty syringes at the door - I'd brave it for a cup of coffee/cafe au lait this good.  

I suspect I'll be upgrading Ritual Coffee Roasters a full star after my next visit.

[Edit: I went back last week and bought a lb of the Peruvian coffee that they roast - it is fantaastic.  Thus, Ritual has earned their full five stars.  In fact, previously, I was thrilled by the fact that the coffee was good, and my review had nothing to do with the place itself.  On my last trip they were blasting Beirut's Gulag Orkestar and later Neutral Milk Hotel - which would have earned Ritual a 6th Star if that was possible.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!]
author: Matthew H.

description:
Yay.  I like Ritual...good coffee, good scenery, good sherry cake, mochas are not too sweet (per Ari).  There are lots of tables, but it's hard to find space at peak times...we scored a table right in front of the counter because we got here late afternoon on a Wednesday.  However, when I tried to come here on a Saturday evening I had to go to another cafe down the street.  

It was hot today though, so seats near the front of the place were a must - as I moved toward the back it got hotter and hotter.  And I'm noticing that they keep playing the same 5 Patsy Cline songs over and over again.

-----------------------------------------------------
Update 9/5/2007

Recently returned and found that the tables are really close together...which I guess I had noticed before, but it didn't affect me until now.  This time I actually was talking, and the music was loud, so the dude next to us had the privilege of hearing our weird-ass conversation.  Poor dude, unless he enjoyed it...at least it was interesting.

Oh, and my coffee cup was cracked.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
As a youthful looking 45 year old without a laptop, I often feel completely out of place  at RCR, but that is not a real issue for me. The greater issue is that some of the counter staff seem to think that I am out of place, as I have on occasion received very curt service. Just yesterday I went in and there was this very bohemian dude working the counter. A friend of his was in front of me in line, and the guy working did everything short of jumping over the counter to give the fellow a big hug and kiss. Ah, what a convivial guy I thought to myself. But when my turn came he barely looked me in the eye and was very gruff with me even though I was smiling and being very nice.

In addition, however much I like their selection of baked goods, my experience has been that the freshness has been very inconsistent.

The big issue for me as a neighbor is the amount of crowding that occurs in front of the cafe, often making it impossible to pass; and the amount of noise coming from these folks out in front -- especially at night. Now of course some of this is unavoidable in this kind of urban setting and particularly with an establishment that is so popular. But there should be some basic consideration shown for pedestrians just wanting to get on with their business, not to mention neighbors who would like a certain level of peace when they get home from a long day's work or whatever they been up to.

Update: over the last couple of years the service has been on the whole more consistently friendly and hospitable. The owner was very responsive to the noise issue, which has made a big difference.
author: Eric P.

description: I was at Ritual last week and was very sad they removed the Clover Machine. I had a drip coffee and it just wasn't the same. The exciting thing is that a swarm of bees appeared right outside on Valencia and I was stuck inside for 15 minutes! A nice employee offered to go out and unlock my bike so I could run out and ride away but we both knew it would never work. I've seen waay too many horror movies to even attempt such a thing.
author: Mitsi M.

description: Really good clove coffee when I had it a few years back. It has a dark and modern vibe with really chill employees. The crowd is a bit pretentious (it's the mission after all) but come in here expecting to leave with quality.
author: Alex H.

description:
Superb coffee! I am one of those unfortunate flavored latte drinkers, BUT putting a little brown sugar in my coffee helps that need. Also, their brownies were amazing and the chairs up front were super comfy. 

Have to agree with the fact that it is very hipster...think it depends on my mood if i want to deal with attitude or not. This last time around was better than the first. The latter was not as great of an experience, very rude service and snotty baristas. Better tonight, but i still keep the attitude factor in when i want to SIT at a coffee shop......
author: Susanna B.

description: An excellent cup.  THe shop itself can be a little nutty, but the staff is helpful if you have questions about new beans, or just aren't too familiar with the roasts.  The espresso extraction times are well set delivering a complex and deep shot and the pourover bar is leaves nothing to the imagination, being right out were you can watch the goings on and ask questions if you choose.  THe beans can be a little bit pricey, even more so than other third wave cafe's, and perhaps the product is a little overhyped, as it is one of the hipper places to get a cup in the MIssion, but make no mistake, you will not walk out disappointed.
author: Adam B.

description:
Here's a quick way to get jumped in public:

Walk into Ritual with a Dell laptop and begin espousing the benefits of George Bush's foreign policy.
author: Jackson R.

description:
Hey!  Did you know that there are these people called Hipsters?  Apparently when one person is wearing oversized sunglasses and skinny jeans three sizes too small and really big neon sneakers and a semi-ironic 80's hair metal band T-shirt and one of those giant Palestinian hounds-tooth scarves, and they see another person who is also dressed in the same fashion, these persons will look at each other and scoff and mutter to their friends "Fucking Hipster."

Oh, and the coffee at Ritual is really, really good, as long as you can get your order in over the sound of all the people muttering "Fucking Hipster" under their breath.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Wow the number of reviews for this place is insane.  Although not really that surprising given its hipster mecca status.

I like Ritual's space a lot, the design is cozy and genuine, it's well lit over the tables and couches for reading, it's good for hipster people watching (the peeps here should win "best dressed coffee shop goers"), and they have awesome mini cupcakes from Sweet Things.

Major props for the renegade creativity in the logo and its take on the hammer and sickle Communist symbol!
author: Chris P.

description:
Best coffee in SF but be prepared to make some sacrifices.

It was raining when I made my way by bicycle over to ritual.  
1.  no dry bike parking left and I would have to park in the rain.  
2.  line out the door on this rainy saturday morning.  
3.  workers looked super hipster, but patrons looked super yuppie, and EVERYONE (I mean EVERYONE) had macbooks.  

Maybe I had ridden my fixie to the wrong coffee joint?  Oh no! And I had come all the way from Glen Park!  Once I got my drink I realized I hadn't come to the wrong place, I had just been looking at the wrong aspects.  

An amazing americano, with crema over 1/2 inch thick.  As I watched other drinks come out I realized mine wasn't a fluke.  Their latte's came out looking beautiful with pretty little designs in the foam.  Amazing.  No wonder I can't find a place to sit.

update:  
came here again today a week or so later, but this time on a weekday.   

Same yuppies here with their damn macbooks!  

Can I please sit somewhere?!?!  

I mean really, you and your polo shirt don't even have a drink!  Why are you still here?  Damn it Yuppies, just because you sit in Ritual on facebook and iChat all day editing your blog and telling people you're a writer doesn't make you any cooler.  At least at Cafe Bello the Glen Park yuppies that have less of a need to be trendy than mission yuppies who are aging and desperately trying to cling to that last batch of coolness they made way back in 1995.  

Sitting in rutual with your macbook and marina haircut is like a bald man wearing a combover.  It's not going to bring anything back!  

And I'm not the only one bitching about the macbooks, so it must not be just me who thinks it's a problem.  If you were really that cool you'd have an iPhone and I'd have a seat.  

4 stars down to three....
author: Matt N.

description:
Lattes and tigers and Tats   oh my!
gotta love this mission haunt / fashion extravaganza/ extraordinary coffee nursery and mac lab...
By the glow of 99% of the patrons glued to their laptop screens you stand in your Long caffeine starved line to receive your art piece latte...complete with tree, bird or heart painting in the froth of your beverage? how do they do that...looks soooo great! I like to read the designs in the froth and tell the future....  Their tea list is lovely and there are usually places to sit or slouch....but the best part by far is the people watching.....oh what my eyes have seen there...
author: Christina M.

description:
I came here with a friend who actually likes coffee. I don't like coffee, but had the iced tea and it was divine. We got our order to go, but it seemed like it would be a cool place to hang out and have coffee with friends. 

There is a definite social scene here. Very scenester. Very hipster. Very Mission. If that sort of thing turns you off, then you wont really dig this place. If you are looking for a quiet coffee shop to read or study at, this might not be the place for you either unless you are really good at tuning out noise. This place was bursting at the seams with people. 

I have a special place in my heart for businesses that forbid people to use cell phones at the register.  :)
author: Kathleen N.

description:
From a non-coffee drinker... it's ok.  

Like it or not, unless you have a Mac, you are going to feel out of place.  Maybe I'm one of the cheapest guys out there relative to the amount of technology that I oversee, but I still use my company issued Thinkpad.

Works for me...

anyway... yes... wifi.... no power.  but... I understand that as well.

Coffee only... no other drinks... some pastries, but I had eaten enough.

My co-worker loves this place.  It was a good place to hunker down and get online.
author: Eric K.

description:
Gosh.  Where to begin?  I love Ritual.  I love their coffee, americanos, soy on the bar, vegan treats, mugs, plant art on the wall, ample hipster-viewing opportunity and sometimes the people that work there, too.  I spent far too much time there over the summer, but it was all enjoyable.  

My only complaint is that I'm pretty sure you can't plug your laptop into their outlets, so your free wifi is limited to your laptop's battery life.  I think.  

Ritual, I miss you!
author: Bridget S.

description:
still love this place and now that i'm a visitor so i can lounge.  love, love, love this place.  i wish i could transplant it in brooklyn.

if you are going to work on your laptop, make sure you have a fully charge battery because they ain't got outlets.
author: Sharlene C.

description: yes the coffee is good but wow, rude service sours the flavor.  i go with the three strikes rule.  and they are OUT.  i have worked in a cafe or two or three and i know we all have our bad days, but sheesh, it seems like ones face might break when snarling so hard.  it's seems like bad attitude is part of their training program.  i've heard the same from many other people.  and just a few blocks away, four barrel serves the best with a warm smile.  i think the one star is helping me feel less abused.
author: tod o.

description:
I stood in line for the barista to work her magic. The gentleman in front of me, having just been served his mocha, reached into his camo green camera bag to produce a digiSLR bigger than his head. Propping the behemoth against his body in lanky arms, he leaned in... and for a good half-minute slo-w-l-y adjusted focus, until: Snap! He nodded to himself as he surveyed the close-up photo of the leaf floating in his coffee. Perfection. 

Ritual is one of several coffee houses I frequent. You can get a good cup of coffee, cop internet/catch up on email, and there's always the aforementioned uberchic clientele that epitomizes the aesthetic of the Mission to act as muse. You could cast your next indie feature here on any given day; the quirky and quirkily beautiful populate its assorted sofas and tables. There are the cute emo-punk cherubs toting big sunglasses, cross-dressers, patrons outfitted in Sauconys and rolled up tight jeans, rockers done up with exquisite greasy garage band mops and funky facial hair. About the only knock I have against Ritual is the music volume. While I too have Spoon, Arcade Fire, Clinic, MJ, JT, Thom Y. tracks in my collection, sometimes I'd like to spin my own tunes, ya heard?

If Farley's represents Po' Hill's community in a cup, Ritual is the Mission counterpart.
author: dave y.

description:
Yes, Ritual is great coffee, great friendly employees, and despite so many people with the laptops there still is a liveliness to the place that gives me energy (...or was it that third espresso...).  I love how the huge store front windows let in so much light that everything else seems dark.  The art on the walls often isn't that great, and it is true that the hipster quotient is pretty lofty, but the employees don't take themselves nearly as seriously as most of the clientele, so you can chat it up with them instead when it isn't busy.

I'm mostly reviewing, though, to point out that after a year I've just discovered that Ritual has amazing good iced coffee.  Turns out they use some 12 hour cold brew process for extra-delicousness.  It takes so long to brew that they can't keep up with the demand during these hot days so get in there before late afternoon and have some or you'll have to settle for a still yummy but not-what-I-was-looking-forward-to iced americano.
author: Dan G.

description:
I feel odd about not giving ritual five stars on account of the fact that I go there several times a week. I mean, I pretty much love it. here's why:

-Great location, great space, great "edgy commie theme"

-The lovely little swirly designs they make in the foam on the lattes...details like that can be so pleasing, you know?

-Some of the best vegan breads I have ever tasted. 

-The fact that they have that grill thingy behind the counter and they will grill any pastry that you ask them to.

-The "frequent flier" punch cards come in real handy. I have three full ones hanging out in my wallet right now...I'm saving them for the winter when I'll be drinking more lattes, because these days I'm all about iced coffee.

-The employees never seem pooped-out or bitchy even though they deal with such a high volume of customers coming through the place at what seems like all hours of the day.

-The bathrooms are killer, and there are TWO. We all know that this is key in a coffee shop :)

-Definitely go there if you are in the mood to see and be seen. I love people watching here. I literally take fashion cues from women I see in Ritual sometimes. 

a few mild criticisms:

-They are always out of bagels, unless you are in there before 9 am. 

-What's up with the mini cupcakes that cost $1.00?

-I usually feel as though I have to put myself together before I go in there...no throwbacks to the college days of sauntering in with some sweats and a fleece, unless you don't care about feeling out of place, but if you actually don't care, then hey, mad props to you!

-If you are looking to go to a coffee shop and have a chat with some folks, DON"T go to Ritual! I mean, unless you are in with the in-crowd or whatever. Ritual patrons seem to really like their independence, at best, and at times, the vibe is just bordering on snotty, at worst. 

Check it out, though. It's a mission staple these days.
author: Shannon R.

description:
In my acclimation period of moving to San Francisco, I spent a good part of a day at this fantastic coffee shop.  My advice to those wanting to park and gawk: Get there before noon.  

The great vegan-friendly pastries were definitely a good sign of home.  And the French-pressed coffee is to die for... or at least to die from!  Two cups had me jumping for the rest of the day.

..which leads me to what I'd like to add to my fellow Yelpers , I'd like to complement on the human capital of this place.  The clientele were friendly and kind; even poking out from their iBooks to say hi to my new-kid-on-the-block MacBook.  Also, let's talk about hotness.  Between the clientele and the baristas, there's plenty for every one to get a little jumpy over.  So, if you like some eye candy to sweeten your joe, definitely put Ritual in your "to do" list...  and maybe some of the clientele will follow ;-)  

Cheers
author: Nathan M.

description:
No sir, I don't like it.

Unlike others, every time I've gotten coffee here I've gotten my choice of seating.  A table, the couch near the window.  I bet you want to know my secret.  It's not B.O., it's 6:30 AM.

Anyway, even if i was 1/36th as cool as the rest of the people there, I would still think the coffee wanks.  They're good milk artists though.

Update; 9/25/07
Man, you people love their coffee (except for you, Dem. M., why didn't you like it?)!  Maybe i have really bad taste, I dunno.  I could be wrong, I could like crappy coffee.  This really changes my whole world.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I have tattoos and larger than normal piercings.
I have read all of the French postmodernists and modernists.

I even have a degree in literature from UCSC but I am still not cool enough for Ritual.

The first time I attended this drama in real life I must admit I was off put by the sight of two people at the same table with their laptops pushed together as though that was a substitute for actual interaction.

I had to ask myself if they were i.m.ing each other instead of talking.

Since I am taking a class at City College Mission Campus I thought I'd give it another try.

This time, after watching five girls in nearly identical outfits with nearly identical hair go through the line without a glitch (two of whom came in after I did) and seeing no evidence that anyone even remembered that I had ordered, I asked for my money back (I was late for class) and the girl at the counter gave me attitude.

True, the nice man behind the counter gave me a ticket for a free coffee in the future but it's cold comfort since I plan never to return.

True, I was bitchy about being passed over; it happened after one of the girls who came in after me pushed past me while pretending not to see me.

During class it occurred to me.
This place is no different from the Marina except that there it's blonde bob with or without bangs and here it's black chunky haircut long or short.

I hate the Marina because it's so cliquey and richer than thou.
It would be hypocritical to not hate this place since it's pretty much the same only hipper instead of richer.
author: Trixie R.

description:
I'm not a San Francisco native so I might be more easy to please than your average San Franciscan. Personally, I think there are more great cafes to choose from in SF than in LA or OC.  Still, I love this place!  I love their name, decor and the idea behind the cafe. Not to mention their coffee is good: strong, perfect temperature and smooth!  A cup of their coffee is just the thing you need to help you wake-up anytime of the day. 
The place definitely attracts the hipster crowd but it doesn't take away from the good coffee.
author: Christine L.

description:
I have often wondered how looking impoverished and miserable has become so trendy (not to mention costing a lot of money).  But I suppose many people thought that about me when I was in my 20s.  Oh, right.  I actually *was* poor.  Now that I'm a certified, card-carrying, 30-something yuppie, I get a kick out of walking into Ritual in my J. Crew work clothes (their post-fur incarnation, mind you) and feeling the daggers of disdain.  It's palpable.  One day I'll summon the courage to proclaim, "Keep staring people.  You're only feeding my yuppie angst."  Or perhaps I'll scare the shit out of them and say, "Take a good look at your future self."

The coffee is good, just like everyone else has said.
author: mcmalaprop ..

description:
Ritual is over-rated, over-priced, and crowded.  But it's a great atmosphere for getting things done, if you want to do some "mindless" stuff in a bustling atmosphere. 

In the four hours I was there, there was always a line, and rarely and open seat.  And, they "locked" the outlets on the weekend!  (Though they did have the decency to keep wi-fi open.)  

I had the iced mocha, and for almost $4, just got a tiny cup of that stuff.  But, it was oh-so-good, I'll give them that.

Ritual is a great place to people watch, to pretend to be "hip," and to pretend to do some work.  It has quite a bit of character, but I wouldn't go back regularly, especially not on weekends.

They're not explicit about it, but they don't welcome campers.
author: Athena ..

description:
I wanted to treat myself to a leisurely Saturday morning by getting a good cup of coffee so I went to Ritual. This is not my first time here and I always thought their coffee is okay. My experience this morning made me want to immediately write a review.  So going back to my story, I stood and waited in line. When it was my turn to order, the barista ignored me and just stood there sipping her latte while she chit chatted with the cashier. I must have waited for a few minutes or so before she looked at me. Seriously?!? Is that how you treat your customers? Are you paying us to buy coffee from you?  I'm shocked at how ridiculous the situation was. It's like ordering at a crowded bar and the bartender just stands there chitchatting and sipping her wine. 
On top of it all, my coffee had a sour after taste. Needless to say, will not go back here.
author: gor d.

description:
This is the closest I've found in San Francisco to some real, Seattle-quality coffee.  Their Baristas are trained, their coffee quality is excellent.  Their space is large, and mostly well-laid out, although I can't help but think it could be better realized with less hodge-podge seating/table choices.  

My standard 3-shot Latte was perfectly crafted.  I recognized some of the crew from various cafes in Seattle.  This is no Cafe Vivace, but it definitely reminds me of all the stuff I liked in Seattle.

The problem with being the best in the city is that it's way, way, way too crowded.  I'm in love with the coffee there, and the space, but I can never just ride my motorcycle down there, and enjoy a cup.  I generally end up heading down there, getting something to go, and sitting sadly outside with it due to the laptop squatters that permeate the space.  My suggestion?  Do what the Victrola did in Seattle.  Turn the wi-fi tap off once in a while, just to stimulate good, natural ol' coffeehouse conversation.  It should also stimulate more turnover.  The more new people that experience the coffee the better.  Word of mouth is a powerful thing.
author: Steve A.

description:
There is much to be said about Ritual Coffee Roasters.  Quite squarely on the pro side are probably the best espresso drinks I've had in San Francisco.  After becoming accustomed to the slosh and pour method of drink making at many cafes, I was delighted not only by the sheer beauty of the drink (A nice leafy shape for the Mocha) but also by the markedly more rich and profound flavor that far exceeds any other Mission cafe.  There is an art and care to their drinkmaking here.  The drip coffee, on the other hand , is just fine, but Peet's drinkers will likely prefer their drip to the slightly watery (but still flavorful) mix made at Ritual.

While the space is gorgeous, it is always packed with people, and the prospect of finding a non-ibook populated table is challenging.  Also, the open layout that was seemingly perfect before has been slightly tattered by a new platform intended for roasting beans, and the subsequent table adjustment doesn't quite work.  Some patrons may be a little put out by a passive waft of attitude from staff and regulars (where did they go before?), or by the music which is steadily getting louder, but it's worth it for the simply delicious drink, great room, and a cafe that has filled a great void in the San Francisco landscape.
author: Trent B.

description:
Where did the worm store that used to be here go? It's been a while.

I want my red wigglers!

I thought that they did a good job of latte art and the coffee is all right too.

The feeling that you are crashing a burning man planning committee meeting, or a Mac OSX beta group testing session, or a speed Yelp marathon writing contest amongst aspiring hipsters and the fashionably dressed unemployed just visiting for the summer from the mid-west crowd (difference?) is entertaining and even strangely comforting.

I want my red wigglers!
author: Jack K.

description:
It's been a while since I've been back here and it seems Ritual Roasters has finally managed to balance the laptop-to-conversation ratio nicely. I'm in a sea of flatscreens, but I still here chatter and good music at a nice volume. Even the roaster is going this afternoon. It's a lovely hive of activity and caffeine.

The people are good looking, hip without tragedy, and there's free wifi.
author: Taj M.

description:
First, the political undertones of the cleverly graphic designed logo is pretty smart and witty so that was the initial pull for me.  That and my arts mentor told me to meet her there for mentoring session.  

It's fairly roomy but gets crowded quickly around 6-7 pm no matter what day it is.  RCR is quite the popular hot spot for many different types of people.  They serve a mean latte and they are very environmentally conscious.  Basically, if you don't say anything, you're getting served a huge mug versus a paper cup.  Oh yeah, there's wireless so you can surf your favorite social networking site or actually do research.  The music is pretty stellar considering it is a place where so many different people go.  The times I've been there, I haven't found it distracting.  The staff is pretty sweet and the wall of foreign money is fantastic to look at.  The money wall has become a part of the overall aesthetic.  

I think it's a fantastic place to either meet up, study, or just get a great cup of coffee or tea.  The only issue you may have -- parking.  Then again, what's new in San Francisco.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
Okay, let's review the basics.

Ritual is located on Valencia... Valencia where all the hipsters hang out.  So, it makes no sense to go to Ritual and then complain that the place is full of hipsters... it's like going to a restaurant in the Marina and complaining that the place has yuppies.

Yes, there are hipsters, there's a line, and there's loud music.

But the staff is friendly and efficient, most people at tables are willing to share if you ask nicely, and the cappuccino makes my weekend.

Plus, they let you sit there for hours with your computer...I do it every weekend (I am one of those people that the complainers are complaining about).  

Oh...that salty fudge chocolate cupcake you might have hesitated about... get it.  A perfect combination of salty and sweet (kinda like me).
author: Sooj O.

description:
Good coffee, good music...blah, blah, blah

Only problem I have  is going in there day after day in a striped shirt and pleated pants (work clothes). Opposite of Hip. 

Mac should film a commercial in there.
author: Joe G.

description:
Young Urban Hipsters are EVERYWHERE!!!!!!!!!!

Welcome to Ritual Roasters and Review #295 for this place.  Not sure why I have not been here before, but alas the first time happened this AM.

Four Stars because it is pretty cool.  The best part about it is that is represents yet another level of SF indie cafe's.  But again, if you are are not hip, get your butt on down to Muddy Waters where 
I will undoubtedly be.
author: Bruce R.

description:
Great Espresso!!!!!! 

If you are in search of genuine, fair trade, & local Espresso this is the Spot.  It's a dwelling place for hipsters(no offense), telecommuters, the office space for internet start ups and artists.  If you can look past all that to get some awesome espresso good for you.  

*Biggest Complain: 
I came here a few times with a friends to sit and chat (respectfully) over espressos and the people "working" around us were looking at us with contempt as if we've crashed into their home and invaded their privacy.  Not cool! This is a public place of business, if you want your peace, quiet and concentration go work from home.
author: Christina D.

description: No real surprises here.  Awesome latte with milk to die for.  I haven't bought beans for myself, but when I give them as a gift they are extremely well received.
author: Scott C.

description:
I really enjoy going to ritual roasters because the atmosphere is enticing.  It always has the buzz and energy you expect when in the city.  I've ordered  the chai tea latte, and I have yet to find a better one.  Its spicy, creamy, and oh so yummy!  My mother ordered the jasmine tea, and I love the little pots they come in.  Soo cute!  The tea tastes so fresh, and soothing.  The free wifi is ALWAYS a good thing.

The only thing that kept me from giving them a five star rating is that you cannot plug your lap top in.  When my battery dies, Im out.
author: Valerie R.

description:
The hot cocoa looks like a piece of art and tastes like a piece of heaven.  The pastry/cake called "dirt bomb" rocks! 

Be sure to get their early w/ your laptop and enjoy the wonderful ambience and beautiful ppl!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I hate to think of myself one of those many self-employed cafe denizens, pecking away at a laptop, oblivious to the their surroundings and comrades. But I am, at least occasionally, and so despite by better intentions - and intuition, for that matter - I have found myself at Ritual a couple of times. The coffee is pretty good - certainly better than, let's say, Atlas, but that ain't saying all that much. I'd agree that Blue Bottle is clearly superior for that cappucino fix, and and AND I had SUCH a horrible bean-buying experience at Ritual the other day, everyone has to know about it. I was a bit delirious - but the cute little sign by the register suggested why not buy some beans with your coffee, and I needed some, so I asked for half a pound. I picked up my coffee and the bag of beans, drank up, and went home. 

I didn't inspect the product until a day later. OH MY GOD. What are they thinking?!?! First of all, this was a very scant half pound. But no matter, because I threw them away almost immediately anyhow. The beans were light brown and dry as dust, and smelled of old shoes and what might have been mouse turds. Who knows. They were so pathetic I simply cannot imagine how anyone with any sense at all would sell them. I like fresh, dark, black, oily beans that I grind coarse and put through the french press. These weren't even fit for gas-station coffee. 

I also agree that the place itself it far too much of a hipster sweatshop. When I want to work on my laptop in a cafe, I don't want a bunch of *other* people there doing the same thing. Sheesh. And finally, for those of you who do go there work, they recently covered up almost all of the power outlets. Well, aren't they smart.
author: Bowen D.

description:
When you walk in, you'll probably see a line to the counter about 10 people long and a dozen 2-person tables with a dozen apple laptops. 

Better than your average cappuccino, and you'll fit right in with your powerbook (or the l33t dell inspiron 6400).
author: Jae K.

description:
After doing a quick tour of SF, I decided that I wanted to continue my West Coast vacation at home in Massachusetts. Why not bring some local beans home. I rushed into Ritual grabbed some High Striker beans and left. I can comment on the coffee drinks they serve. 

I will say the there were a ton of emo/aggro hipsters when I came in.
author: Nick B.

description:
Hands-down my favorite coffee place in San Francisco.  I almost always order a double short cappuccino to go and it's usually gone before I even walk the three blocks back to the yoga studio.  Yes, I drink coffee before I teach yoga.  No, I don't drink it before I practice.  Yes, that's pretty normal from the empirical evidence I have culled from the SF yoga scene.

Today, I splurged and got myself the Grand Ol' Lodge to go cup with genuine faux-wood look.  It is super stylee and it makes me feel almost as cool as the people who serve me up my coffee.  My dear husband pointed out that the cup was made in China, of course.  I feel a bit bad about that, but I'm still supporting a local business, right?  And, I'm reusing my cup!

When I feeling like getting away, I like to take my laptop to Ritual and work with all the cool kids there.  If I'm feeling decadent I'll get a cupcake or a 7-layer cookie to pair with my massive cappuccino in one of those cups that reminds me of a big boob.  I look for a spot and try not to spill all over and usually fail a little bit.  Just a small fail for me in the spilling department, but a big win in the coffee department.

Your mileage may vary.
author: J Liberty S.

description: I love this place for its well-made coffee with sweet underlying tones and its friendly service.  However, there is almost never any place to settle down because people claim whole 4 people tables for themselves and their laptop.
author: Eeway H.

description:
Wonderful coffee with a dash of pretense.

First and foremost: Ritual does coffee correctly. They think about where they buy their beans from, roast them in house, and create some of the best f'n coffee around. Beautiful and tasty, it alone could make up for just about any shortcoming.

Ritual Coffee Roasters is a wonderful place to meet up with a friend for some coffee or to sit for a bit and work on something together. A lot of people come to work away from home or even as their every day spot.

Despite all it's got going for it, I can't help but feel a bit out of place here. I can't really place it; but somehow I just feel a little weird coming in as a non-track-bike-riding-bandana-scarf-wearing hipster. Not that I have anything against it, it's actually rather attractive to me, but it just feels pretty consistently pretentious.

Geek perks: huge. Blogebrity / Digerati sightings are very likely, fast Speakeasy wifi all over, and plenty of outlets. There's no power however on weekends. They put cute velcro covers on their outlets because you should be frolicking in the park on weekeds, dammit.
Open wireless is a little bit concerning with such a technical crowd. I'll almost always tunnel IPSEC out of there. I've even watched people playing with ethereal while they're in there. Granted, I've done the same, but it still makes me a little more cautious
author: Jonathan L.

description:
too hip...too trendy...too many pseudo beautiful people trying too hard to pick up other beautiful people while appearing to be aloof and disinterested- 

BUT! The best most amazing hot chocolate laced with dark chocolate I have as yet to discover on the planet , and I like that the straws actually biodegrade into your drinks-- another place I get cravings for. Someday I will have a personal chef who can bribe all my favorite places to divulge and teach their secrets so I can have my favorites any time I want. Until then, the diva will wait in line for hot chocolate.....and try to look aloof and disinterested....
author: Keri B.

description:
Why am I bothering?

You know what this place is. You hate the staff for being hipper than you, you hate the place for being cleaner than your room & you want to be the attention the people drinking coffee there won't give you. 

Only minus one star cause they had the best caramel ginger black tea & I'm not a fan of the weird teas. 

Bring it back bitches!
author: Rebekah K.

description:
Ritual is the place to be if you have one pant leg rolled up and a carabiner key chain.  Haha, I mock those who I love.

Seriously though, this is a great coffeeshop for hanging out, meeting new people (they have those little signs you can put on your table offering to share your space), dancing (they play some good music in here..  I once had to throwdown to Chromeo on my way out of the restroom), people watching, and getting some work done.

One star is deducted due to the lack of flavor (i.e., sweetness) contained in any of their beverages.  You might want to overlook this point since I'm not a coffee drinker and I like sugar in my tea.  But yea, the iced tea is not sweet, and they don't have any syrups for their coffee drinks.. if you're into that sort of thing.  That said, I will be back!
author: bridget h.

description: my most favorite place to throw money away on something that I will drink in a matter of minutes. The best cappuccino I've every had- better than the one from four barrels, better than Medici, better than anything I've had in Austin. Why? dont' know. The milk is the sweetest! My every visit to San Fran is beautifully accented by any and every morning delightfully presented with one of their masterpieces.
author: Lucy M.

description:
UPDATE! The Valencia Ritual is now much faster. Possible reason/conspiracy theory: because they opened a new branch at Flora Grubb's so all the drive in traffic can go there and loiter and let us working folk in the mission get our coffee in under an hour. I'm upgrading to five stars but would still like some damn whip cream.

From their website- We Take Coffee Seriously, Not Ourselves

Ha! Should share this with the world's slowest barristas, who were undoubtedly the coolist kids in their high school class of Trailer Park, Missouri. Seriously, with four people making drinks requiring combining two to three ingredients why does it take an hour and a half? Yeah, I love watching you all grow facial hair and spurn the advances of other marginally attractive underachievers before I recieve my favorite drug of choice. I should take up smoking. 

Yet it is too difficult to put names on drinks so fights don't erupt over absconded beverages when they finally make it across the counter. And for the love of god, get some whipped cream! It is delicious and can be organic/fair trade/free range. The precious leaf design could be done in 3D.

Three stars because the owners are nice, they provide jobs to small town escapees, and the tiny cupcakes are super yummy when they are in stock.
author: Krismet C.

description:
Slightly weak but well-made coffee, unfortunately spoiled by a lack of seating.

Update: upgrading by one star because the cookies here, even late at night, are freshly homemade tasty goodness.
author: Glen M.

description:
Updated Review:  Ritual hauled in a big bean roasting machine and now roasts their beans on-site.  Previously their beans were coming from Stumptown, a small chain in PDX that roasts their beans on-site in their cafes at two of their three locations.  Now they have fully embraced the Stumptown style and roast in front of your very eyes.  Fresh coffee doesn't get any better than that.  The barista informed me that they still order a few of their roasts from Stumptown and have them sent down. 

The prices for their beans are ~$12/lb and they're roasted right on-site.  If you don't want to deal with the crowded hipster scene just stock up like a chipmunk in the winter, it's a far better deal than Blue Bottle and you can watch them make the beans.

Minus one star because the last time I was there some lady bumped into me trying to slither through the crowds and dumped half my cup of hot coffee on my shirt.  Owwie.
author: SC ..

description:
I know the mission has its whole rep and scene about hip-ness and hip-sters and being too cool for school, and it can get made fun off for it, but i think ritual epitomizes that whole scene in the best possible way. i love cafe ritual! i want to be a secret hipster, although i'm really.. just.. not...

so...
the coffee here is fantastic. it really is. all tasty french pressed goodness. they have a nice tea selection as well- fragrant and varied- not just bigelow and twinnings. i can't comment on latte-type drinks because i'm a house coffee kind of girl, sorry.

i must say though- there are plenty of good coffee coffee shops in san francisco where i would never spend much time, i get won over by this place because of the set-up and scene.

the cafe is large and spacious- good lighting too. there are couches and tables both big and small which allow patrons many options in their level of social-ness. they can be antisocial and productive at one's own small table, meet friends to catch up over coffee in the lounge-y back area that looks like a living room, or make new friends while trading sections of the paper at the big community table. 

the scene is hip, young, smart, intellectual- lots of books, lots of macs- i would say that laptops dominate the landscape. lots of people who rode in on their fixed-gear bikes. i like people watching here because there are lots of attractive and smart looking people.. i just wish i could get seated next to a smart and attractive dude at the community table who doesn't have his head buried in a book or laptop... one day...
author: Lizzie C.

description:
Done with this place....
I have been coffee shop touring all over the city since my recent laptop acquisition.  I have been here many times for the fact that it is close to my house and they make good coffee drinks. This time was different though. I sat down and got ready to jack my plug into the socket but there were plastic plates screwed over all of the outlets.  I had noticed that they had done the same thing before with velcro and a marker saying something about no using the outlets on the weekend.  I always ignored the message, and apparently so did other people to the effect that that they permanently put a halt to anyone plugging in their device.  Guess they get enough business that they don't have to please people who want to occupy tables and use computers.  And that's fine, I always got a bad taste in my mouth being in that hot coffee box of indie-ism.
author: Eric T.

description:
In all honesty, I have not tried your coffee because...
the masses of bug eyed yups and students clinging to their laptops and I pods makes me want to vomit.
Long gone are the days when people actually TALKED to each other over a cup of coffee. Now they just surf the porn sites at Ritual..sigh.
author: City G.

description:
I am confused... people don't seem to see me here... it's like I'm invisible.  Maybe I am not wearing the right fur?  The coffee is good, and the cupcakes are GREAT!! I smear them all over myself and then wipe myself off under the couch. Still, no one notices... well, maybe they do, but I cannot tell behind their bangs, or sunglasses, or laptop screens. The cupcakes are a bit of an expensive habit though, since they cost $2.50 each, but maybe the extra cost is for atmosphere? 

I do enjoy the fact that the people who hang out here all seem to have very skinny legs... that makes my life easier.

-Lola the otter (and sometimes ferret).
author: Lola B.

description:
Good things about RR:

- Nice coffee served in nice cups (but you have to ask for the cup otherwise you get cardboard)
- Nice nibbly things (the cookies are good)
- Nice, big, spacious interior

Not-so-good things about RR:

- Busy (like, a big line outside busy)
- A wait for your coffee (get in another line inside)
- Hard to find a seat
- A bit 'scene-y' - I always feel that my hair isn't asymmetrical enough to hang out here

If you just want a coffee, a sit-down and free wi-fi, I would head up the street to Muddy's, which is hardly ever busy and the most comfy spot I've found for a spot of solo coffee-drinking and laptopping.
author: Kelly P.

description: Good coffee, serious baristas. Great space to sit and work or read a good book. Free wifi. A slight hint of the Bay area syndrome, when it comes to the coffee quality. I'll revisit that in some future reviews. All a really good spot for coffee.
author: Lars R.

description: I love recommending Ritual Seasonal Espresso Blend to my clients.  It consistently tastes great.  Samuel - Kanen Coffee Espresso Machine Repair
author: Samuel K.

description:
I hate to love Ritual. It is the epicenter of hipster chic and if there is anything I loathe, it is a hipster. 

My shrink would say that I am uncomfortable with characteristics within me that may be construed as "hipster". 

Well, I'm going too need to come to terms with my inner hipster because the coffee here is the bomb. Give me some ironic tattoos and a fixed gear bike. If you can't beat them join them..
author: Monica L.

description: Their Sweet Tooth espresso is one of the best I've ever tasted.  Quick and friendly service makes me a repeat customer.
author: Abby H.

description:
Initially I ignored them because I did not want to stand in line.  One day I stopped for a latte and a slice of vegan banana bread.  All yummy, even the vegan bread.  I went there a few more times.  Always crowded and always good.  I even tried their drip coffee and it was also good.  Then I tried the Sweet Tooth Espresso fresh ground and brewed at home.  I have never made a cup of coffee that good at home before.  So yummy!  I am sold and  now buy their coffee beans "ritually". 
I don't really have a problem with the too-cool-for-school "fixie" vibe of the place.  It is entertaining, and it is clean and well kept.  The neighborhood around it is wonderful for a walk as well, so I have never stayed to drink my coffee there.  Perhaps I'll try that next.
author: Liz R.

description: Why is this place so popular? I do not get it AT ALL!..Do people really like coffee that is brewed with hot vinegar or something? Super sour, very waterdown....but somehow, i feel like it has much more caffein than usual coffee... Ritual, you failed me so bad!!!
author: Berry P.

description:
Soon after my move here my new roommate and his friend took me down here telling me about its' rich history of start-up moguls, software design geeks and good coffee. I thought it was a hip place for a coffee house. Well, I started coming down here more frequently lately because I'm doing more work in the area and have grown to really like it.

The coffee is always really good, the music always makes me wanna move and like the other reviewers have mentioned, it's a good place to people-watch. Sometimes it's a little difficult to pay attention to my work actually because there are quite a few good looking women coming in and out of here. But, life goes on. I have a mission and must do my work.

The only complaint I would have would be that the music can be a little loud at times and the place does get rather crowded. 

I do like the diversity of the people here, it reminds me of home. Good place overall.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
Seriously the best coffee I've had in years.  I think it's really only better in Italy itself, it's that good. You don't even need the flavored syrups (which they don't have) cause the coffee is honestly better without it.

The first time I went here was mistakenly on a weekend in the middle of the morning...use caution at these times: you could easily end up waiting twenty damn minutes for your soy latte so plan accordingly. Being clever and anti-conventional, Ritual cannot just ask you your name to send you off with your fresh coffee, they ask you to answer a silly question. After I ordered the barista asked me my favorite Jennifer Tilly movie, to which I replied '"I have no idea who that is", so when my coffee was ready they hollered "Driving Miss Daisy?" at me.

Nice studying atmosphere here too, interesting art, and very hip.
author: Eva L.

description:
I love the decor. The coffee is great. They even make tasty vegan treats (I'm a carnivore so that says alot!) Free wi-fi and last time I was there they were blasting Jay-Z.

I will never go anywhere else in San Francisco to purchase my whole bean coffee.
author: Shayna N.

description:
My new escape from the Marina....nice place to come and settle, to ponder, to be busy, to be lazy, to get coffee!
Love the atmosphere: great selection of art on walls, spacious environment, not a tunnel, not stuffy, not a death trap.
The tunes: my first visit, they were playing The Black Angels...excellent!...since then, the music has been appropriate and tasteful.
The coffee: great bold coffee with lots of flavor, the espresso drinks that I've observed having been made are beautiful.  The foam is perfectly frothed, as it should be!  No flimsy fake looking mock foam.  Very skilled foamers =).  
Lots of peeps to watch, whom are all busy in their own electronic worlds or socializing.  As we all are.....
OK selection of bites....good vegan selections, kinda limited and slightly pricey...but hey, gas is 4.09 a gallon right now, so a 2 dollar cookie is a bargain I guess.
author: ERICA E.

description: Are hipster coffee shops usually overrated? God, yes. Is Ritual Coffee overrated? GOD, NO. It is my first time here (yes, I am actually yelping FROM ritual right now, that is how in love I am), and I sit here with my Gibraltar in complete bliss. I don't care what else is on their menu, I will never get anything else.
author: Jeni E.

description:
I feel ok about this place. Just spent the morning working there and the soy latte was ok, the service nice enough, actually I would likely still be there if they didn't cover up all the outlets with little blank covers. Yeah, you can see that there WAS a lot of outlets are one point, but guess they only want you for a few hours. 

I will be working from Mission Creek Cafe from now on. Not that I mind :)
author: Kate M.

description: The coffee is sooooooo good!! And it is fun to watch how they brew the single serving coffee.  Fun art and music.  Just a cool, laid back cafe to hang out at.
author: Kara R.

description: I had the san vicente coffee.  It was a bit weak...perhaps too watered down.  On the plus side, the line moves quick, they serve beverages promptly and there are quite a few tables and couches to lounge and enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Karen N.

description:
The interior is a little too run down for my taste, but certainly still urban-chic. The service isn't Starbucks smiley-face, but gawd, who the heck wants that.

Had a clover of some Costa Rican stuff, and Kenyan. That's their terminology for a cup of freshly dripped coffee made from specialty fincas they're in touch with. Clover is the name of the machine that does this. It'll cost you about 3-4 bucks a pop. 

I myself am more into the freshly dripped stuff made by human hand. That said, it tasted somewhere in between auto-drip machine made and human made, so not too metallic, retains a lot of the various vegetal/fruit characteristics of the roasted beans, but not quite as much as manual fresh drip. They have about a half dozen varietals for you to try at once.

Did NOT try the mixed espresso drinks, that's for next time. Gotta judge a coffee joint by its straight up fresh drips at first. 

Hard to get seats here; went on a Saturday afternoon around 4 and the place was packed with solitary laptop junkies taking up entire tables. If it's full, though, don't forget to overlook the few tables by the restrooms in the back, luckily they're not RIGHT next to the restrooms, but sheltered by a corner and a hallway, so it looked like a pleasant, last-ditch place to make a stand if you can't get past the RoboLaptopUsers.

Not my fave SF coffee place, but hey, not a bad place to kill an hour or two off Valencia.
author: Kevvy K.

description: Best cafe lattes I've ever had.  They are consistently good.  I also can't get enough of the blackberry scones; when they're in stock.  You've gotta go early to get your fingers on a blackberry scone at Ritual.  But, it's worth getting up early.
author: Michael P.

description:
Ritual is the best coffee joint I have ever been to. It appeals to me...the guy at the corner table sipping his delicious mocha and hogging the free (and reliable) wifi.

For food, I recommend indulging in the rather unhealthy pecan bar. They also carry a wonderful variety of loafs (try the banana nut).

The place can get crowded and seating can be a problem for 2 or more. I am usually there working by myself so I rarely have any difficulty finding a place to sit.

The staff is friendly. I appreciate the details, including the decorated foam. Every swirled foam leaf is unique!

Ritual does not allow you to use the power outlets during the weekends. I totally understand why, but call me selfish I hate restrictions, so I give them 4 stars. I spend enough on coffee and food to contribute to the power bill!
author: Bruce A.

description:
Yes, coffee is above average, but did not blow me away.  What i did like is that it is good without being super strong - i love peet's coffee, but a cup of that jet fuel leaves me more jittery than ritual.  Even tho they are average on food/service/value (3/5), they get 4/5 stars overall since the most important things at a cafe are the coffee and atmosphere.

Did i mention the atmosphere?  Usually its too crowded, and
i hate that and sometimes just go other places.  But i love 
people watching here.  There's like 40 people in here at any
given moment - and they're all different.  I mean, they're all the same.  Ok, kinda different (mission hipsters, moms with kids, foreigners who just stumbled upon it, college kids,  30 somethin's ) and kinda
the same (don't mind hot, crowded noisy coffee shops, and love laptops).

A hour or more here and you get a taste of real SF

4/5 coffee
5/5 atmosphere
3/5 service
3/5 food
3/5 value

And they have Fast Free Wireless - list .. http://www.yelp.com/list_details?userid=mkQ-J4uMULsJvc9V8gMENw&list_id=xJ_tC-4_YAdDCurRxaQBNw
author: chad n.

description:
What's the deal with the saggy, droopy, all-enveloping loungy chairs in the back? Hey, I like being ensconced in a vagina, but this is ridiculous.

Great chocolate chip cookies though.
author: Dan S.

description:
Come on over, all the cool kids are doing it!

Beyond that though, they have some killer coffee and the French Press is making my body shake uncontrollably right now. I hope my heart doesn't explode. I'm actually here right now because the internet in my apartment is down and I thought to myself, "well, I may not have a sleek, shiny black Apple with a bunch of stickers on it, but goddamnit I'm not ashmed of my Toshiba and I'd like to finish downloading The Hills Have Eyes 2!" So here I am, doing just that. Everything is expensive though, but I guess that's just the price of cool and fair.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Ritual Roasters is my favorite coffee shop. I love, love, love the coffee. Did I tell you I love the coffee? Leaving Starbucks, Pete's, and Tully's  in the dust, Ritual Roasters has an international selection of coffee. El Salvador, Nicaragua, Kenya, Moka San'ani, Yemen, Muramba, Rwanda, and Guatemala are among their selections to name a few.  

You can sit and enjoy vegan pastries, wonderful coffee, and unique teas in big comfy coffee cups.

The coffee shop looks modern and embraces the unique San Francisco - Valencia street culture.

You can also take home a bag of the good stuff. For the true coffee lovers, you and everyone else around you will smell the robust aroma and flavor of the coffee waiting to escape the minute they put it in the bag. Ritual also grinds it to your specifications, paper filter, espresso machine, french press, etc. You can tell Ritual takes pride in their product. 

The staff is always upbeat and friendly. One day I was sitting in there, and I saw the meter maid lurking around my car. I hadn't remembered if I put enough money in the meter, so I ran out to add change. To my surprise, a Ritual employee had already put a quarter in my meter for me. I know this isn't the norm, and maybe he was extra nice that day, but that tells a little about the karma of the place. He didn't know me.That's service!

The only downfall is the lack of power plugs. They used to have a few available. I am a freelance writer, and this was my spot to drink coffee, tea, and work. I can no longer work from there. I sometimes can go through several cups of tea or coffee, but the plugs are a critical deciding factor for me. If the plugs weren't taken out, I would give Ritual 5 stars.

Favorite Drinks:

Soy Mocha extra hot $4 approx
Winter melon Tea (White Ginger & berries) $4 approx
Cranberry Rosemary Bread $2.50 approx
author: Ana S.

description:
I am a pseudo-regular here, and I keep coming back for the coffee.  I think the coffee is fantastic.  I love comparing the different espresso blends/roasts from BB, 4B, and Ritual in the purity of an eight ounce Americano-*sigh*:)
But.  Given this place has wifi, it enables patrons to work or study while enjoying the hand-crafted goodness in their cups.
