I've spent many hours in this place studying, and sweet jesus, it takes almost all my concentration to tune out the utterly obnoxious volume to which the workers are permitted to turn their music.  
I was in there the other day and they put on Metallica's And Justice For All..., and let it play twice through.  This is a dark and dismal archetypal late-eighties heavy metal album.  The volume was turned to blistering levels.  I could almost see the collective teeth gritting across the hoards of computer-concentrated people at the community table and in the back area, which is truly the worst for volume.  They have as many speakers in this place as a bar would, and they turn the music up so loud it feels as such.
'Coffee shop'.  It has a certain expectation.  Not silence, but not friday night at fill-in-the-blank bar in SF.  Why must the music always be so loud?  Why must it almost never be peaceful to listen to?  Why don't you regulate this, owner/manager of Ritual, whomever you are?  I'm trying to read or study or think, and I'm not the only one.
author: Dave H.

description:
2 coffees, a slice of banana bread and a miniscule vegan donut: $12. But the coffee tastes really good!

The line moved quickly and I didn't sense any pretentiousness. Staff was friendly.
author: Poppy P.

description: Always a cool place to take a break for coffee and people watching.
author: April M.

description:
I love Coffee. I love grand Cru, Aribica, single origin coffee. I know coffee. An so does Ritual. 
When you walk in, the baristas and the rest of the staff have this "Insiders Club" vibe. I don't mind that. It's not snobby, but more like they all have inside jokes and hang out together, and while at work there are only two kinds of people, themselves and patrons. 
I like em'.
author: Devon C.

description:
Great. Just what Yelp needs, another Ritual review. Oh well, here goes. 

Ambiance is great if you're coming there to chat with a friend and people watch but sucks if you actually want to sit and read or work on your laptop. They took out the outlets so you need to go there all charged up. Seating is almost impossible on typical weekday and the music is too FUCKING loud! 

I've been coming here for almost 2 years to get my capp fix. The good part was their cappucinos which was sooooo smooth and carmel tasting, you almost didn't need any sugar. I'm a true coffee lovah and in my humble opinion, it had the best capp in the city. I'm writing in the past tense because the last 4-5 times I've been there, their capps SUCKED! Then I figured out it was because the girl who usually makes the caps no longer works there!!! BOO. The one with the bangs and the tattoos which pretty much describes all the baristas AND the customers but she was the dark-haired skinny one who banged the shit out of the bean grinder, packed the espresso tightly and pulled that thing to make that PERFECT shot of espresso .. and now she's gone! 

Ritual- PLEASE train your new baristas better because your espresso stinks ! You had the best capp in the city and now it's worser than Starbucks. 
Damn!

Addendum *3 stars added back*: My prayer to the universe was answered! After talking to my favorite banged, banging and tatted barista :),  she ensured me that only the best capps will grace the halls of Ritual. I went there last week and enjoyed a delicious double capp and an audible conversation with my friend. 

Here's a tip: Go for the real sized cupcakes, not those mini "2 bites and it's gone" ones. Indulge yourself.
author: None o.

description:
Woah!  So good.  I'm going to admit here that I am one of those people that only likes coffee with lots of sugar and cream (I know...don't judge me).  BUT, when I tried the coffee here, it was so smooth and good that I drank it all before I had the chance to add anything to it.  This is a first for me.  

The next time I went I got a cappuccino and the barista did an amazing job at pouring beautiful latte art.  

Everything here is brewed on location and the prices are all really cheap.  Definitely worth experiencing.
author: Kim L.

description:
Aw...Ritual.

I don't drink coffee, so I'm not much of a cafe denizen, but Ritual has a charm that is difficult to resist.  The staff is cute (far more important to me than it should be!) and quick - the decor is funky chic - and I dig the couches in the back.

Ritual is a great place to sip a Hot Chocolate and moon over the cute boy working the latte machines.  *swoon*
author: Christopher S.

description:
Ritual is where I learned to drink coffee.  Before, the extent of my interaction with the stuff was when people left their dregs in our all-purpose hot-drink maker at work, and I'd notice that my hot chocolate had a slight coffee flavor to it.  At first it annoyed me; then I kind of started to like it.  I had mentioned this to a friend of mine who happened to be a long-time Ritual devotee, who mentioned that if I liked the taste of coffee and chocolate together, I might like a mocha.  I started out with single-shot mochas and eventually worked my way up to the full-strength version, which I now LOVE.  I didn't realize just how amazing Ritual's mochas were, though, until I started trying to drink them at other places.  At this point, I've had them at any number of chain and independent coffee shops, and nothing really compares to what I get at Ritual.

Other pros - They roast their beans on-site (which I guess a lot of independent places are starting to do these days); you can buy freshly roasted & packaged beans of all varieties in the store; they have excellent  pastries (I like the bran muffins & rosemary cranberry bread the best); they have a cool art display, which changes from time to time; there's free wi fi; and all the staff seem to be really, really genuinely excited about making amazing coffee drinks.  Once the barrista even remade mine for me once because I vaguely suggested that it might not have been quite as good as usual.  I don't drink plain coffee, but every time a coffee-drinking friend or family member of mine has visited, I've always taken them here, and they've always been very impressed.

Cons - It's often very crowded, and there's usually a line.  I'd say it usually takes us around 20 minutes to order and get coffee on a weekend, and we don't even bother trying to drink it in the shop.
author: Angela B.

description: Not impressed. In terms of taste, that is.  Intelligentsia in LA kills this place. I like Progressive Grounds in SF much better.
author: David R.

description:
best coffee ever! if you are into gourmet fresh coffee and still havent been to ritual, you are sadly missing out.

the staffs aren't the most friendly people you'll meet. they sort of seem like they are sO tired of working and would just like to NOT talk to you as much as possible even. people tell me its the mission street hipster thing. that's what the "cool people" do. lol so don't let that get to you at all. just get your coffee and enjoy!! i always buy a bag from them whenever i can. :)
author: Amy S.

description:
This is a review on the coffee only.. so 5 whopping stars for their joe. This review does not cover their baked goods, because they do absolutely nothing for me and look sort of sad. This review does not cover/judge those white apple lit typing skinny dirty jean wearing hipsters mentioned in the other reviews either - its the mission duh!

Rituals Coffee Review:
Move over Blue Bottle, I need my cappuccino with a nice leaf on it NOW!  Yum - this place has addicting coffee.
author: Sylvie L.

description:
I miss Portland.

It's been a year since I left, but I still miss it. 

I miss the rain, I miss restaurants I went to. I miss my friends.

And I miss Stumptown, too.

The first week I was here, getting my bearings, I found my way to Ritual and all of a sudden, I was home. It felt like I had just stepped in from 3rd Ave or Belmont. Amazing coffee. People who cared about the shot they were pulling. The fact that tapes-n-tapes was playing and that they had midnight cupcakes with lavender frosting didn't hurt much either.

That was a year ago, and Ritual is still great for me. Better, even, then Stumptown. It's not just the quality of the coffee, but the people behind the bar. The ones who remember me when I come back, that have a new coffee to suggest, that brew a perfect cup, every time.

I've bought art here. I've had blind dates here. I buy coffee here every week. I've run into people from elementary school here.

 I've developed one hell of a retail crush that has me coming back every Saturday to stutter at that one guy behind the bar that makes me nervous. And if anything ever did happen and then didn't work out and it was even more awkward than it is now it doesn't matter. I'd still be back for the coffee.
author: margo s.

description:
The lines are long here for a reason.  This place is up there with Blue Bottle as one of the only places in San Francisco that knows how to make a decent coffee. When I say coffee I don't mean drip. Drip is gross. No one anywhere else in the world drinks drip except in gas stations, or McDonalds.

Oh and hipster bashers get a life. Who cares if they like to flaunt funny hairstyles, and clothes and sweat up hills on their fixed gears. They are people too. For a town that seems to pride itself on accepting differences there's an awful lot of discimination going on here.
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
The coffee is downright awesome.  Complex, interesting, yummy.  All of the above.

And the hipster environment is totally there.  I can't be any funnier than just about every other review.

Worth noting, is that as of 7/13/2008, the ***WIFI IS GONE*** and nearly all the ***POWER OUTLETS have been REMOVED***.

My guess is that this is due to costs and trying to keep the room turning over -- drink your coffee and go, mr. self-important.  You'll have to read Salon.com on your MacBook somewhere else.

(Note: Mission Creek Cafe one block away wants your business with has free WiFi, lots of power outlets, good coffee and more food)
author: Davis F.

description: Yes, Blue Bottle kicks this place's butt although this place is an acceptable alternative if you're stuck in the Mission. Their snacks and their ambiance are way better than Blue Bottle though.  Their sea salt cookie was perfect although a little expensive at $2. The line was long but I'm wondering if that's because they take so long to make their coffee! Lots of upbeat  students working away on their laptops.
author: Kathy S.

description: Awesome coffee. And they have wi-fi, thank god.
author: A. M.

description:
Shall we say " Great Coffee?".... for sure!

5 stars for just some of the Best Coffee in San Francisco. 
5 stars for the great service, although always busy they never fail to be patient and attentive. 

They don't sell food but the coffee is enough... this place is usually pretty packed and even then I always find a seat. The pastries are good too..
author: Geena T.

description: Ok, I didn't REALLY order something here, but my coffee-lover friend got the espresso of the day (Finca Los Naranjos - vacuum packaged green from Huila, Colombia and roasted especially to showcase juicy berry and milk chocolate flavors). I'm not a coffee connoisseur but when we got the little tiny cups with the syrupy shot of espresso on the bottom, everyone's reaction was, "Is this it?! REALLY?? This is the smallest cup of espresso ever!" After tasting a drop (which was like half the cup) and almost dying from bitterness and instant caffeine rush, we added steamed milk and sugar and all that good stuff to it. That stretched it out a little more and the others swore they could taste the berry and chocolate flavors. Like I said, I'm not a coffee connoisseur so I just pretended to taste them too...
author: Esther Y.

description:
This place is neat-o, but a bit hipster-iffic for me. The coffee was good, the place was packed (as usual), the people behind the counter were really nice, but were super hipsters.

Oh yeah, so they roast their own and they have the usual array of espresso drinks and french press. Good stuff.
author: Reese W.

description:
And you have succeeded to fulfill my addiction to this crack called coffee. 

Coffee: Starbucks take that! Quality coffee for serious coffee drinkers. None of that sugary crap frap junk, no fancy syrups, straight up gangstar coffee. That's right! Yummy...flavors good, kicks good. Nothing to complain about. 

Environment: Love it. Great little place, free wifi, cool artwork! Only problem..this place is always crowded. A line occasionally forms out the door, so be aware..esp on weekends. Stay in line though, it doesn't take that long! 

People: friendly, and quick. Nothing to complain about! :)  

Hope to return soon...maybe find a seat to hang out next time!
author: Catherine O.

description: Often crowded, but rightfully so.  Barage of laptops perch on the laps of quarter-life folk on vintage couches, sipping on beautifully brewed cups of cappuccinos, lattes, and the like. Airy in atmosphere, friendly staff, and plenty of people to gawk at; this is a great place to get a good buzz.
author: I Love Beef C.

description: I'm a coffee-holic and this is where I treat myself for a nice cup of coffee! I don't come here everyday but I come here enough. Since I'm coming from So.SF and driving to Valencia just to get a cup... well that says it all! :)
author: Lee E.

description:
In the neverending battle of The Mission vs. The World, Ritual fits in with the tribe rather well.  For all the yapping down thread of hipster vs. indie vs. Marina vs. bridge & tunnel (as a native NYer, this one I remember well)--is the lefty-politic supporting, mac using, thrift-store rocking asthetic any less of a tribal tag than the Louie-Bag marina folk or cats in throwbacks and "Stop Snitchin" tees?

So yeah, I felt the "you're not indie enough to sip here" once when ordering, but the other baristas were chill on subsequent visits.  The chai was extremely overspiced--like hot wings that are so hot, you don't taste the chicken.  The coffee was strong, and I love that they serve soda--oh, and please bring back the cranberry bread.

Place gets extremely crowded super fast by the wifi crowd, and the volume levels may cause you to raise your voice to have a conversation.  The wifi quality is good when you can get on--the onslaught of laptops may keep you locked out of the system, or sometimes cause the whole thing to shut down.

Prices on everything are relatively cheap(they also have buy 10 drinks get 1 free punch cards), and this doesn't strike me as the type of place that will frown on someone staying from open to close.  That said, beware the crowds, the indie police, and if you absolutely have to be online, don't count on their network.
author: Chris R.

description:
To be honest, I think this place is a little *too* cool. 

However, I'm giving it 5 stars because their lattes kick ass. As a former barista (and someone who's been trained to make little designs in your drink) I'm telling you it can't get better than this. I can't speak for the coffee, because, honestly, I don't usually drink coffee or espresso except for when the mood strikes me. But the staff is friendly and having fun. The decor is cute and it's a great place to hang even if you don't bring your computer.
author: Emily L.

description:
The sign of a great hipster coffee shop is that the number of mac users outnumber the "I'm a PC" users. Don't come here unless you're toting a white laptop and writing for your blog. Ritual Roasters may as well sell iPod accessories at the counter. 

With that said, my new macbook and I have food a new home--but only if it is fully charged (no power plugins on the weekend) and if I'm lucky enough to find a seat. 

Ritual Roasters coffee is a work of art itself. I wouldn't be surprised if they've got their own Coffee Art on flickr, http://www.flickr.com/search/?q=coffee%20art.

The drinks appeal to the sophisticated coffee drinker. If you're a fan of  espresso and cappuccinos, come here. Latte fans will have mixed feelings, and mocha fans will find their drinks lacking chocolate.
author: John M.

description:
GABRIEL:  This place is about as close as it comes in San Francisco to Central Perk from "Friends."
JERRY: What?  Is Phoebe here?  She is soo hot!
GABRIEL: Comfy chairs.  Art on the walls.  Airy, high ceilings.  Oh and coffee!
JERRY: Uh.. you forgot something.
GABRIEL: What?
JERRY:  Phoebe!  She's hot, so where is she?
GABRIEL: Anyway...there's Joey.
JERRY: Joey!  I love Joey!
author: T. F.

description:
This place was my last stop on my latest jaunt through San Francisco. 

I was hungry and wandering down Valencia looking for at least a coffee shop with something vegan to nibble on. 
When I first walked by Ritual, the line was way out the door, so I just kept walking. I found no vegan nibbly bits anywhere else, so I browsed through Dogeared book store for awhile.

Afterwards, I went back by Ritual, and the line was reasonable, so I stopped in.

The coffee was excellent, and they had a fabulous array of vegan breakfast baked yummies. The plum bread was heaven. The atmophere was nice, though crowded (It was Sunday, so this is to be expected).
I will certainly go back on my next trip up there!
author: Andrea S.

description: delicious cappuccino in a roomy cafe with free wifi. done!
author: Stefanie S.

description:
Best coffee, no question, no competition.  
But why, oh why, does one have to wait 15 minutes to enjoy this cup of coffee?
author: J E.

description:
Ritual is so awesome.  I swear that their coffee keeps getting better and better, and it was amazing to begin with. The barristas here kick ass. They are so fast, but the coffee always comes to you tasting of pure love. 
If i had to keep 10 spots in the world, Ritual would be one of them.
author: sarah C.

description:
UPDATE:  I've gone through at least 6 of those frequent flyer cards since first writing this in March....will not be quitting coffee anytime soon.

Last year, I'd asked for a cappucino to go on one of those way too frequent days where I'd be out the door with a paper cup on the way to work, probably ending up spilling half of it.  The barrista suggested I have it in--and that's the beginning of my affection for this place.  It snuck into Valencia St. where other well-worn places and characters have found themselves: Lost Weekend Video,  Aquarius Records, Omar ( William H. Macy the faded rockstar!) and the schizo storefront guarded by a lazy junkyard kat.  AND it's relatively clean! 

I'm going to try to savor this place as slowly as is possible with coffee.  Double espresso, and punch that frequent flyer card again, yup.
author: Engracia A.

description:
Enough said about the great coffee. And the great people serving it. The laptop issue will resolve itself in time. Wait 'til Google gives out free WIFI over the entire city and we'll have to develop new social behaviors.

Ritual has so far been generous with the free internet connection and power outlets next to almost every table. The only problem are people who abuse it. If you are going to plug-in, don't take up a whole table and offer any free seats, limit it to not-all-day, don't be too anti-social, drink lots of coffee, and tip really really well. I say put up a tip jar for people plugging-in.
author: Esso E.

description:
Maybe I didn't arrive at the right/wrong time day or time here but I didn't experience that exclusionist, hipper-than-thou vibe when I went there.  If anything, after reading the reviews, I was surprised that I didn't (and a little annoyed that I couldn't get any skinny, hipster boy eyecandy to tell the truth).  The crowd was pretty chill and diverse.  

My soy latte and vegan donut (I love that they have vegan donuts) were very good.  Do you know how hard it is to get foam from soy? The barista managed to give me a perfect latte with a nice foamy top.  Very nice, quick service, too.  I'll def. be back.  Vegan goodies.  Mmmmm.

****Update****
Okay, I went on a Sunday afternoon and now I see.  Didn't receive attitude or stares but there was a line out the door and NO vegan donuts.  For shame!
author: MakeUp M.

description:
Just in case you haven't heard it already, the coffee is simply amazing!  

However, their free WiFi doesn't work with my MacBook, so... 

Bye-bye Ritual Roasters!  Call me when you get a working wireless network installed!
author: Sean G.

description:
Ritual Coffee = Crack = Yum

okay so they serve yummy crack. they also have hot bar staff and super hipster clientele. usually i am here working or doing homework and in my own "zone" (ie leave me the frak alone) but on occasion i've had a nice conversation with a couple strangers turned acquaintances. 

yeah yeah, so maybe Ritual is too uber cool for school but wtf so am I. 

ps. i love the pretty leaf designs they put in the foam on my lattes.
author: Joy A.

description: Sometimes, I feel like I could sit in this place for hours....and hours...and hours.  Excellent coffee, open environment, excellent coffee, not too hard to find a table or chair.  Oh, and excellent coffee.  Clearly, the cappuccino is a huge hit (there are about 30 pics of the frothy designs made by the baristas).  I have to agree...it's my favorite drink here.
author: Joel F.

description:
I don't think I really knew what coffee could be before.  It was something I drank in the morning that served a function, it tasted okay, and was cheap.  Enter the Soy Latte.  Add brown sugar.  The pearly gates of caffeinated heaven opened and I was one of the chosen.

Amazing vegan desserts, try the peach bread or the fig bread if its there.  Holy moly.  I don't mind the vibe or the clientele, if you're feeling insecure, thats really your own baggage.  Tough to find a spot to sit, but I always find one if I feel like being patient.  I know this is a coffee shop, and everyone has the caffeine shakes... but relax already.

Minus one star:  VEGANS BEWARE!  The Rooibos Teas apparently all have yogurt in them, for reasons unbeknownst to the employee we talked to.  The delicious blueberry rooibos, the chocolate-chamomile tea... not vegan.  Why would anyone put yogurt in tea?  Make sure you read the tea menu, which was recently changed to indicate the ingredients.
author: Mike A.

description:
Art student/waitress: What's up?

Designer: Nothing, just downloading the new Arcade Fire album onto my iphone. What about you?

A S/W: I'm trying on my new super tight black slim leg jeans.

D: Asstastic! Are you thinking what I'm thinking?

(Both, in Unison): Meet you at Ritual!

A S/W: Don't forget your Mac Book Pro!
author: Scout S.

description:
I don't care if it makes me sound like a crusty hipster, their coffee is fucking great.  Never one to shy from pretention, I've been known to take a twenty minute detour just for the only proper double-short americano in town. 

Come on. It's not THAT pretentious. It's not Blue Bottle or anything.
author: Ron A.

description:
Yes, this place is usually super-crowded and you have to wait 5 mins in line and then wait another 10 mins if you order an espresso drink. 

Yes, this place is overrun with hipsters sporting their thrift-store finest, making me feel like I'm just not cool enough. 

Yes, there is always weird art on the walls. 

Yes, it is often hard to find a seat. 

But you know what? I don't fucking care because they serve some of the best coffee in the city. And if you want really quality coffee or espresso, Ritual and Blue Bottle are probably the only two places worth your time and money. 

Plus, people there are usually pretty nice and pet my dog while she's waiting for me outside.
author: Julie J.

description:
Ritual serves up a very nice cup of french press as well, they rinse the cups off with boiling water before they serve it.  The flavor was nice and smoky to perfection.

I don't know what the fuss is about with rude service, the ppl behind the counter seem alright.  There was no loud music, short line, and even a few open tables.  Maybe I just got lucky?

I wish they had more comfortable seats though...vs. just the old normal table and chairs set up but they serve great coffee so who cares?
author: Mel S.

description:
So, I'm actually sitting in Ritual as I write this review.  I really wish I could make it better, I REALLY do.

1. Coffee - Decent.  Now, I'm a total coffee snob...I've worked coffee for many years, and I can tell a good cup from a bad cup.  So when I say decent..that DOES mean something.  Can't really say it's a place I would tell someone who knows coffer that they HAVE to try though...

2. Pastry (ham and cheese croissant - Bleh.  No way to warm it up even?  No thanks.  This breakfast sucks.

3. Wi-Fi - Well, yeah..that's great.  Like I said, I'm on it now.  But, I won't be for long.  Why.  Cause they're NO DAMN POWER PLUGS IN THE PLACE.  Like...they're been deliberately taken out!  WTF?!  A whole room full of people choosing to do "work" on laptops in a place to cheap to kick you some AC?...

4. Atmosphere - If being in places like this makes you feel cool...more power to ya I guess.  I'm unimpressed.

Conculsion:

I don't get it.  No wait, I do.  It's cool.  It's cool to be here.  The coffee is so-so, the pastries kinda suck, and there's no power outlet.  I really can't think of another reason to be here other than the cool factor.

In fact, I literally amd going to leave a walk a block down the street to go somewhere worth being...
author: Uriah F.

description:
Edit:  I have to update Ritual to 5 stars.  I have been frequenting Ritual a lot since I have moved to the Mission and I have had nothing but great service and great coffee.  I have also on many occasions been able to taste some of their awesome vegan delights such as the chocolate vegan cake, the plain vegan sherry cake and the vegan carrot cake and have been completely overwhelmed by how fresh and crumbly they are.  The one experiece I will never forget though was at the time of our stressful move when hubby and I came here to fuel up on some coffee and eat some chocolate sherry cake and read the new comics on the wall.  While we were at Ritual enjoying our coffee and eating the heavenly chocolate sherry cake, I really felt like I was transported somewhere else-somewhere far, far away from the cries of reality. It was magical!

I love the coffee here, but I am not into the cappuccinos-they are too weak for my liking.  And thanks to Ritual I have now found myself some beans that I love and now making wonderful coffee from my French press.  However, I have to agree with Sara G. and maybe we got the same person as I was made to feel stupid when according to Coffee God I asked a stupid question and pointed to what I thought might have been my cappuccino and was shot down with a rolling of the eyes and a sharp-It's a macchiato, stupid tone.
 Sorry, Coffee God I came from the village and after putting me through that the cappuccino you made was awful.
author: Shilpa K.

description:
Finally visted RCR after hearing countless great reviews about it from friends & spotting an article mentioning it in San Franciso magazine.
What a dissappointment; I walked in and there was maybe 15 tables with one person sitting at each with a laptop opened in from of them. Even the couch inside the front window was occupied by three zombies with their laptops. WTF!! If you want to surf the web go to the damn library. Latte was pretty good as was the staff friendly, but I had to get it to go as there was no room to sit down. I think this is another SF spot that has succumbed to its own hype and is now crowded with hipsters and students more interested in being trendy than the coffee or having a worthwhile dicussion with a friend or stranger. I would recommend Blue Bottle, just as pretentious but less space for the fakers too hang out.
author: Brendan H.

description:
So delicious, so well prepared, roasted in house with a golden Probat and served by the hippest of Valencia's hipsters. 12 foot ceilings, tons of natural light, the chairs support my back well (I'm 6'6"), free wifi, clean bathrooms, local artists on the walls, real plants, a proper bar to consume your drink on the spot and save the trees and leave. Tables for 4 and 2, a couch and arm chair and a table for 8 make roomy seating for 56. When I got here shortly before noon today there was a line up out the door.

This is espresso you can savour. This is espresso your tongue should make love with before you swallow. This is espresso that'll make the saliva glands at the corner of your jaws nearly explode.

If you don't know much about espresso, I share my opinion and google research here: http://rubyurl.com/0hg5
author: Caleb B.

description: Mission + Coffee + Hipsters = Ritual. This spot is always busling, but the line on the weekends is sometimes out the door and down a ways. The cool thing is, if you're like me and not perpetually in skinny jeans nor constantly rocking something plaid, this place is still great: the staff is efficient, and yes, they are PC compatible :)   Not crazy about their chai tea lattes, but they do deliver a great cup of joe. Lots of tables for computer work, as well.
author: Amy M.

description: This place is a joke. Pompous barista who likes to move at the pace of a snail while literally "shuffling" around cups on top of the coffee machine only to end up serving a sour and bitter lousy single shot of espresso for $2.50. Also, the space isn't well looked after with an excessive quantity of dirty cups, saucers, plates and napkins strewn about at time of my visit.
author: Steven H.

description: The coffee no doubt gets five stars. Some of the best I've ever had. But I don't go there even though it's a block away. Why? I think the "help" has actually looked me in the eyes once, maybe? And then there's the "space" or lack of it -- a room full of zombies staring into their laptops. Sort of like some sort of Star Trek force field that sucks ALL pleasure out of the room. Yeah, I'm an old dude, in my 40's and I  don't get the whole go-out-and-socialize-but-stare-at-the-computer thing. Seriously, these folks look tortured. Is writing their novels really bumming them out that badly? Is the gchat not going well with the ex? Then go home and have a good cry but don't sit there looking like you've just been disemboweled. I'm trying to enjoy the nice coffee.
author: Brent H.

description: The hype around this place is lost on me.  Am I missing something or are there just a bunch of lemmings in the Mission?  First off, the tattooed 'hipsters' who work there have too much attitude - and frankly, it's a cliche.  More importantly, they served me a lukewarm latte.  Nothing worse than that.  Enough said.
author: Eric C.

description:
Move over Blue Bottle - make room for Ritual Coffee!

Be prepared for a line, and perhaps even a password (mine was "street") to get your drink when it's ready, but trust me it's all worth it.

The mocha was so good I couldn't help but smile as I took my first sip.  "So that's what all the hype is about!"
author: Corey C.

description:
I would give Ritual five stars because the coffee is so good, but because of the fact that it's very difficult to get a seat due to single customers taking over four person tables for hours, I have to knock one star off...

The coffee is the best in the city in my opinion...and I don't normally like coffee. But someone took me here, and I had the creamiest least bitter latte I've ever had. I didn't need to put sugar in it (and that's incredible for me) and there was no aftertaste. The baristas are very skilled at what they do.

What I don't like- It's impossible to find somewhere to sit, even during off hours. It would be nice if they had a policy that if you bought one cup of coffee an hour ago it's time to go so new customers could sit down. I've walked out on a few occasions because I saw no open tables, and many tables with one person taking a four person table, tapping away on their laptop, no coffee mug or plate to be seen...completely oblivious to the fact that it would be polite to share some space. I would definitely go more frequently if my only option were not just to go...I'd like to be able to sit and chat with the person/people I'm hanging with, and by the droves of people who sit there for hours not buying anymore coffee...it's pretty difficult to do.
author: Nick M.

description:
Yesterday I had a soy macchiato here, and it was so good it made me want to cry.  If only I was a little emo, I'd just wish to die after taking a few sips of some of their espresso, and that way it'd be the last thing I tasted before I bit it.

 Also of note are the fantastic beans they sell here, their frequent drinkers' card, and the fact they have a Clover machine, which, I suppose, very few places are going to be able to get their hands on, now that Starbucks has purchased the company that makes them.

Worth going out of your way for.
author: Juliette S.

description:
Well...darn great coffee spots with a rep!

II had no intentions of searching out any yelp food locals, after just gaining 10 beautiful pounds of curves  from empanadas and dulce de leche on a recent trip, but darn if my first day back at work didn't land me at a meeting that was only 2 blocks away from Ritual Roasters.  As I was walking to my car after the meeting, what did I pass, but RR.  No choice.  After reading so much about it, I HAD to stop.

The girl at the register was so sweet and helpful.for my newbie experience.  I ordered a low-fat lattte...AND a brownie. (OMG!).  Seriously, both were divine.  Coffee was definitely very high ranking (possibly, above BB!), the brownie..(which, was NOT vegan, BTW) was quite possibly just as impressive.

Thank goodness I don't live or work in the neighborhood.  But, I do happen to have another meeting there on Thursday this week.....
author: Elle S.

description:
Very good coffee beverages here. It just tastes freakin good. Like good. Not good, but Good.

A bustling atmosphere that I could live without, but creates an energetic weekend afternoon type of feel. Very SF artwork on display, couches, and free wifi. I'm not exactly sure why, but the largeness of the area just seems out of place for a local coffee shop.

The beverages are definitely delicious, and the feel has its time and place, but I'd still rather spend my cafe time at Simple Pleasures.
author: Darrell L.

description:
Last time I went to this place (on a weekend afternoon), there was a literally a line going out the door, and there were no more tables available inside. Usually you'd just walk on and get coffee at the next cafe down the block, but I chose to get in line, which is telling. Ritual is probably San Francisco's "most serious" coffee shop right now. The espresso is excellent (rich crema), they do delightful latte art, and the brewed coffee is solid.

Unfortunately they've become somewhat of a victim of their own success, as the place is always teeming with dot-com hipsters (but it's only other dot-com hipsters who complain about this) and often it's hard to find a place to sit. So far, though, the quality of their coffee has remained high, and for me, that's the most important thing.
author: John C.

description:
Ritual sets the standard for the ubercool coffee house.  I was crazy about this place before the coffee even hit my lips.  

They are clearly serious about their brew.  I've got to admit though, the cup they served when I ordered just a simple coffee wasn't as strong as I like it.  I'm sure they change it daily and I know they sell a ton of different types of coffee (check out the tasting notes on the menu, my personal favorite is the one with "indisputable aroma of cannabis") ... it's just that I was expecting an orgasmic eye roll upon my first sip and .... ladies you know what a let down that can be ;).

But aside from that, what an awesome joint.  Ritual is slick and fully branded with it's clever communist inspired logo.  LCD Soundsystem blaring from the speakers had me and others grooving while waiting in the always long line.  The wall of foreign currency put a smile on my face (I made a Cambodian contribution).  Local art covers the walls, and both the staff behind the counter and the clientele at the tables bled hipster.

It's really too loud in there to get any real work done, but what a cool freaking place to hang out.
author: Jenny S.

description:
The best espresso I had in the City so far. 

I must say that their assortment of vegan donuts look a bit weird: there was a purple one the other day...  mmmm.... not for me.

But the espresso is awesome.
author: Lili G.

description:
Okay, so here is my relationship with Ritual. I show up some weekday afternoon, all the hipsters are busy at art school or still asleep in bed milking that hangover, or wherever it they all hide during the day. There are generally no lines, maybe one or two people ahead of me. I chat up the cashier a little, choose a roast, buy the bag of beans and walk out. Now for the next few weeks I will grind and french press my own coffee. 

I had previously tried to squeeze my non hipster-bulimic ass in here on a weekend, but very quickly realized that even if I did find a table, I would not enjoy sitting there since I obviously wouldn't get any work done and it would be too loud to talk the the BF. 

So their coffee, which I have also noticed is available in some Whole Foods locations, is exquisite. If you have the time to make your own coffee at home I would highly recommend this place.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Great coffee (beautiful lattes), great service, great music, free wi-fi and plenty of outlets for  this industrious grad student.

The only reason I don't give it a full five is that they've instituted a no-outlets on weekends policy, which makes sense seeing how crowded it gets on the weekends, but it really is a bummer. Also, salty foods other than bagels would be nice and FRUIT. I like the chocolate chip cookies!
author: Jen M.

description:
UPDATE: I'm an espresso guy so for me drip coffee is out but I really have to say that they carry the most horrible drip coffe I've ever had. Lukewarm, without body, burnt and acid. OMG how is it possible that there's that much of a gap between an espresso and a small coffee here? This happened three times now, so it's pretty much established. They can keep my 5 star but be aware, no drip coffee.

If you have a new laptop, this is the place to show it up! Is it Compusa or a coffee-shop? The perfume of coffee is surrounding all your senses and I really think that this Valencia shelter is competing for the best single espresso in town. Golden-brown cream, hyper-short, dense, chocolate background and smooth taste. I've probably found my daily coffee mecca (Greco on Columbus is a little bit too far for my everyday treat). Cappuccino was also a big surprise to me...better than the one I took every morning in the last 5 years in Italy and it also comes with styled foam (you know, those kind of flowery designs that you can make swinging milk cream while you pour it). Thumbs up for the roasters.
author: Dario B.

description:
I (latte art) HEART Ritual Coffee Roasters.

Not only does Ritual know how to make a damn good mocha, it makes its mochas look good too.  How can you not smile when you are served with a big, bright red mug of warm coffee with foam on top shaped like a heart?   And to really turn your frown upside down,  try their mini-cupcakes.  Trust me, the funny looking one with the plastic looking sprinkles is actually the best of the bunch.

The only reason this place doesn't get the last star is because it has become a haven for too many too cool laptop users who snatch up too many seats for too freakin' long.  Listen homies, if you can afford an espresso everyday, you can afford to get your AIM chat on at HOME.
author: Deborah L.

description:
Nothing beats sipping a latte (I admit, it was a delicious latte) in a coffee shop that resembles a dentist's office. I felt like I had to get my cavities filled shortly after enjoying my drink. Has an extremely sterile aesthetic appeal to it.

Their coffee is good though. Strong. I was seriously up all night.
I also happen to be in a terrible mood while writing this review.
author: Shereen R.

description:
This was the most delicious cup of coffee I can remember having.  It was of Brasilian origin, but I don't know what it's called.   They told me, but I don't remember.  So much for carrying around a notebook AND a smart phone ...

I can't give this place five stars because if you're not getting plain old coffee, it is remarkably slow.  I think it was ten minutes before my friend got her espresso drink.  Also, they say "french press" but they actually press the coffee in advance and then pour it into urns.  When I get french press coffee, I kinda like to see the pressing happen and get a direct pour.  At least that's how I do it at home.

Looking back at this last Saturday, I'm thinking I definitely should have bought some of this coffee to take home and make in my own press.  At least now I know what to do next Saturday!
author: Gordon E.

description:
You'll be tripping over hipsters *and* the elegant coffee in this joint. 

Beautiful capps and lattes and a very cool space. They have a selection of sweets/savories and free wi-fi too.
author: Sharand N.

description:
The house coffee was poured from the same kind of pump dispenser you see at funerals and luncheons, which was odd, considering the reputation of this place. The barista that helped me was friendly but seemed like she was in a hurry to move on to the next customer. Also, the place is such a hipster mecca, I fell like I should resent it just out of principle.

However, I also purchased a pound of coffee that had been roasted that day, and the next day when I made it at home in a French Press it turned out fantastic. I enjoy the lighter roast since it brings out the flavors without overdoing it and producing burnt tastes. I definitely have to make a trip across town now every couple of weeks just to pick up fresh roast from Ritual.
author: Jon D.

description:
Went here for the first time this morning, after hearing a slew of hype for, well, forever. 

I had an espresso and it was excellent. It can seem an expensive shot, but considering Ritual positions itself as a designer coffeehouse alongside places like Sightglass, the price makes sense. 

As someone mentioned below, the decor is excellent and it lends itself to productivity. I will definitely be coming here again.
author: John B.

description:
I gave up drinking coffee about almost 16 years ago but recently I have been on a chai kick with a shot of espresso and these guys make an amazing "dirty chai" - 
great place to sit and connect with friend or do some work - check it
author: Peter G.

description:
Coffee is a straight up ripoff at $4-5 per cup.  F-That.  Service is fairly slow, which must account for why they draw images in the foam.

Biggest positive of this place is the free Wifi and close proximity to Lost Weekend.  Lots of room inside with oddly spaced tables for how much business they have;  sheer number of single people hogging entire tables with their Macbook Pro and headphones can make you feel unwelcome.
author: Zed J.

description:
Ok, my first Yelp review.  Ritual Roasters is THE SHIT.  If you like coffee, run to Ritual and get one.  It's my almost daily ritual.

- Jon
author: Jon B.

description:
WTF?
This place is lame.  The coffee is crap and the clientelle are hipster D-bags.  i'm over it.
author: Minotaur N.

description:
I like coffee places like this. The coffee itself was pretty good, but what I really like about this place is the atmosphere. It was a little messy though.

But we got there kinda late and only got to sit for about 30 minutes. One of the guys behind the counter was BLASTING music to the point where it was really annoying and I couldn't talk to my friend without yelling everything. Plus it was that hipster obscure music which made it a . I'm not sure if he was doing that to kick us out, but it did the trick.

I wish this place was open a little later because it would make alternative to a night out drinking (which I'm definitely not opposed to!)
author: Rocky K.

description: Fantastic coffee + awesome seating area with couches + free wifi + takes credit cards = 5 stars!  Well done ritual!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Typical hipster place.  The coffee was good and I appreciate the selection but seriously, these pretentious customers and people behind the counter ruin the experience. The long lines/crowding/arrogance are not worth it. Don't go unless you want to rub shoulders with a greasy annoying hipster.
author: Christina K.

description:
I was told that the coffee here was good, but really didn't understand why until I tasted the latte!  OMG!  the taste was smooth and very flavorful .  We ordered a brownie to go with the latte and the brownie too was smooth and very good.

I live in the Japan town area so going to Valencia isn't that convenient so I bought myself a little bag of grinded coffee to go.

The ambience is very spacious and very relaxed.

If driving there, it is not an easy spot to catch because it it has a little flag of their logo so keep your eyes open.
author: R M.

description:
Good coffee spot if you're in the Mission!

I've only ever had an iced coffee here, but it was yummy, and the setting, while not exactly original or unique in any way, was inviting and cozy. I'm not sure that it merits all the hype, but it certainly does the trick if you're just looking for a reliably decent cafe to get your daily fix.
author: G. J.

description:
Pros
- Decent coffee, but I think there are some better options in SF
- Good location
- Late hours

Cons
- Removed the roaster and added more seating
- Seems to have lost the charm that it used to have
- Baristas didn't seem to friendly

Verdict
- Not a bad choice, but there is better coffee to be had in SF
author: Roger R.

description:
I live in the Haight, but I have no problem trekking to Valencia, even in the rain, for this coffee.  This Is Coffee. OMG is this coffee.

Big and airy with lots of places to sit, but I've never stayed and sat down... Every table seems to be occupied by lap-toppers. Next time I'm there (Today), I'll ask one if I may join them.  I'm sure they wouldn't mind... They look friendly enough...

A Neighborhood-y feeling place with screaming coffee.  Go.  Drink.  Sit.  Meet.  See and be Scene.
author: Grrrl W.

description: The coffee is very good, and there is a lot of seating, however, most of the seating is taken up by the SF City College folk. They get an extra star just for the coffee. Also, they do coffee "flights" where you get to have smaller cups of two or three coffees.
author: Anton S.

description: Just got home from Ritual on Valencia...I didn't get a chance to try their coffee because they were closing and I couldn't read the menu so I just ordered a latte and it was DELICIOUS!! I like the venue and how the place is set up. There are tables as well as couches which is pretty cool. Definitely going back to try their drip coffee.
author: nabil s.

description: I can get delicious mouthwatering, jaw-dropping, heart-achingly delicious coffee at home but when I'm not at home I go here. Even if I am nowhere near here (i.e. I'm in the Presidio or the Embarcadero) I will traipse over there for some otherworldly java delights on my tongue. Their drip coffee is not what I order (there are way better places for that here) I always get their latte. You really cannot find a finer one here in San Francisco. There is always a line and it usually moves quickly. Aaaaaannnnddddd!!! They have gluten free sweet nomnoms.... so so so good.
author: Arielle M.

description: Meh...went in around 12:30 and there was no food to speak of left forget it if you're looking for outlets for your laptop, good coffee though. Uncomfortable chairs, loud with echo.
author: Ingrid D.

description:
Great coffee, but not-so-great wait.  I *guess* it's worth it.  

Looks like a cool place to hang out, but since I live around the corner I'd rather be home.
author: Aimee B.

description:
This place is coffee mecca, as far as I'm concerned. It destroys Blue Bottle. The espresso is perfect. The cappuccino is perfect. You have to go here if you're a coffee fan. Just amazing.

I once had a barista apologize to me for 'screwing up' the latte art, which was still better than what I do at home.
author: Karl N.

description:
These guys are the coffee natzis....

This is the kind of place that I so wanted to love... the cool anti-establishment logo, the folk-house grassroots feel, the indie music. I gotta say its dissapointing on so many levels - but mostly on service. The staff are pretentious, grumpy and make you feel like they are doing you a favor by making you an overpriced cup of coffee from their extremely limited selection. The place is packed beyond comprehension. 

I have been there twice shortly before closing and they practically beat you out the door before you have had a chance to taste your coffee (which by the way will be drunk from a paper cup and standing up) - as early as a half hour before closing they only serve coffee to go. 

The coffeee itself is very limited and I find highly acidic - each time I have gone there I have had major heartburn - which I have never had elsewhere. Maybe its the acidic coffee, maybe its the rude staff - or maybe its being told every minute during the last 15 min before closing that they are closing in X minutes as they stare you down... in any case, Ritual roasters is was a huge disspointment to me... and I have vowed to avoid it at all costs. 

Despite all this, Ritual is packed every day/ night... so that says to me that this area of the mission is ripe for a competitor to set up shop and if they also treat people with courtesey and respect and they will give Ritual a run for their money.
author: Karen O.

description: i like this place. so san francisco. eclectic place with hip eclectic people and eclectic artwork on the walls and eclectic and exotic coffee flavors. love the fact that they dont use automatic coffeemakers for drip coffees. love the rustic craftsy-looking custom made copper stands that hold the filters used by the baristas for the drip coffees. looks like someone went to home depot, bought some copper piping and made it themselves. pretty creative!
author: p f.

description:
Good:
-- Great-tasting coffee. They take time to make it right; make you a drawing.
-- Neat atmosphere with many hipster customers and hipster staff.

Could be better:
-- Recently removed the couches in the back area; hard to find seats. 
-- Recently removed power outlets to discourage laptop users.
-- Long lines.
-- A little dark for studying.
author: Alej L.

description:
It's not that all change is bad. It's that the changes at Ritual that are bad. While the coffee is still better than a few others on the same couple of blocks..

1) No more French Press does seem to make the coffee taste worse and feel less rich. I really liked the deep, dense, almost oily coffee I used to get here
2) It does take even longer to get a coffee (add to that the waitstaff are still super chatty with each other and often don't make eye contact with you while you stand there forever).
3) there's almost never a plain cup of coffee for 2 bucks or less. SO EXPENSIVE NOW.
4) because you are supposed to order by bean (even for a single cup), and each bean has a different price it's getting nearly impossible to just order a cup of coffee. I don't memorize which kind of bean I am getting when I just want the cheapest. So when they call out "cup of Java weasel deluxe" or whatever I'm not sure if that's the one I ordered or not.

it's getting less and less like a cafe and more like a gourmet coffee sampling/learning experience. which is probably a better way to make money (?) but a real waste of all that space. They could seat another 20 or so people instead of having it be the museum to coffee grinding it seems to be becoming.
author: La M.

description:
Well, I just LOVE the idea of being the 132nd person to review a place!! Oh goody I can write with pure abandonment! That being said I have to ad that having read 85% of the reviews for Ritual, I am sure to have nothing new to ad. I went there on a Friday afternoon and the place was packed. Most people had there laptops, and some wrote -(yes, with a PEN!) in notebooks, -(actual paper bound together!)
I ordered an astonishingly BEAUTIFUL Soy Capuccino and settled into a perfect corner for people watching and reading my magazine. ("Ode", by the way a very intelligent publication.) 
Any ways, all I can say is: I'd go back. 

P.S. One thing though. That music is LOUD, unnecessary noise. I kept imagining what it would be like with more civilized music playing. I guess I'm not hip. I was probably the oldest person in that whole place though, I must have missed the "under 30 only" sign on the way in.
author: Roanna Z.

description:
a little sketch inspired by Ritual...

PC (aka round nerdy guy):  Hello, I'm a PC
MAC (aka slim dude with totally rad hair):  And I'm a Mac
PC: So Mac, today I'd like to go to a coffee shop in the Mission. Any suggestions?
MAC: Let's see there's the Marsh, Revolution Cafe, Muddy..
PC: What about that Ritual place I've been hearing about?
MAC: Umm..... will you be getting your coffee to go?
PC: Well I'd like to stick around a while.
MAC: Yeah, that might be a problem.
PC: Is it my hair?
MAC: No, although it could use some mousse.
PC: Then what?
MAC: Ummm...assuming you even find a place to sit...it's kind of a Mac party?
PC: I enjoy free wi-fi and good coffee too you know!
MAC: You just don't get it man.
PC: Oh I get it.  I get it buddy.  Eff you. (Rips Mac's arms out of sockets)
MAC: Oh Dear God, why!!!???

And SCENE! (Cast takes a bow)

p.s. I own a Mac, but used to go here during my PC days and felt like a leper...which was probably all in my head.

Great coffee though. Nice art that changes frequently.  And I have no issues with the hipsters actually (still figuring out if I myself am one),.  I just find it damn funny how it looks like a MacWorld Expo every time I'm in here.
author: Neej M.

description:
I like this place and its Mission hipster douchebag atmosphere.  They serve Stumptown coffee, which I haven't seen anywhere else in the city.  Once you've had stump...you never go back!  

HA HA HA HA HA HA!

Seriously, this place, along with Philz and Blue Bottle forms one of the cornerstones of my cross town coffee excursion list.  You see, I live in the Sunset, and I consider the Mission to be exotic and exciting.  So I come down to places like Ritual on weekends in the morning and wander around the neighborhood after getting a cup.  Ritual has the added bonus of being a good place watch people.  You get a whole class of 20 and 30 year olds wearing stylish tatters and playing with fancy gizmos, all while talking in urgent tones about things that sound exciting from afar.  If you can find a seat and a something to read while you watch them, then so much the better.  The service isn't all that great, but that could have something to do with the fact that its almost always packed when I get there.  And yet...I'm always alone.

LOOOOOOOOOOSER!!!

I'm a big fan of Peet's, and while that place is the mainstay of my weekend coffee excursioning, places like this provide a nice and neccessary diversion when I need to add some primary colors to the dreary eggshell of semi-urban living.
author: Gopal R.

description:
The best espresso in the city, hands down.  Each shot takes the barista like 5 minutes to make, but it's totally worth it.  I swear, every time I drink a Ritual espresso I go into an orgasmic state.  Yeah, kinda gross, but what can I do?  The coffee is just that good.

The hipster crowd is all part of the experience at Ritual, so it kinda pisses me off that yuppie reviewers are dinging this place for its clientle (see dumb-ass reviews below).  I guess I shouldn't expect anything less from the Starbucks crowd, eh?
author: Mike M.

description:
dropping it down about a notch. here's why...

got a cup of the serra negra (excellent) and a vegan donut at 10am. at around 1:30 that same afternoon, my insides start to percolate (i'm not talking coffee this time). only thing i had eaten was that donut. next thing i know, full on "running" shoes on...for the rest of the wretched day and into the crampy evening. 

i'm pretty sure the donut was the culprit. note: donuts are left out uncovered on top of the counter. 

still a huge fan of ritual coffee and the folks there despite that experience. however, let the vegan donut buyer beware. maybe they can put one of those clear glass dome things over the donut display.
author: Rob D.

description:
******UPDATE************************************************************

So I'm going from 3 stars to 5 stars.

Why?? Because I finally got to try the coffee (excellent!)

And I got to hang out a bit, and EVERY single person who works there (that I've talked to or has helped me) is AWESOME and super friendly and excellent customer service.

Also, they carry Peoples Donuts... and how can you hate on a business that offers organic vegan donuts??

The answer my friend, is that you cannot.

***************************************************************************


I really wanted to like this place.

Having met some people who worked there, and hearing SO MUCH about how great it was, and how yummy the coffee was, I finally got my ass over on a day off.

The line was out the fucking door.

THE LINE TO GET COFFEE WAS OUT THE DOOR.

Now as someone who drinks COFFEE, and not a frappo-moco-bull-crapo half-caf nonsense, this was unacceptable to me.

But, having heard about how INCREDIBLE their coffee was, I waited.

So I looked around.... hipsters behind the counter (well, duh, i mean coffeeshop!), red wall with a faux communist theme going on.... a metric f-ton of people crowding the tables with their laptops for the free interweb....

Everyone in line probably made 3-5 times more than me annually, and I got this "too clean" vibe from the place that smacks of the borgeois-bohemian culture.

If you want to go hang out with a bunch of yuppies who still pretend they're young poor artist types-- this is your place.  (As though that hoodie will give you a soul)
author: Roachie D.

description:
Ritual makes any stroll down Valencia that much better. Definitely worth the wait in line, at the counter, and the seat. Say what you will about the evils of diet soda - I can't live without my Diet Coke, let alone wake up without it. Coffee just doesn't do it for me. A basic latte at Ritual though had be forgetting my corporate can of caffeine with the first sip.

Oh and vegan baked goods galore. Can't wait to get my paws on a piece of vegan sherry cake, but I can say the vegan carrot bread was muy delicious and way better than any standard coffee shop pastry.

The atmosphere shows that minimalist and modern can still be inviting when done without attitude and the lively patrons make the space exciting; great for people watching, relaxing, or reading the afternoon away.

My stack of books and magazines is begging for a Sunday encore!
author: Ennis O.

description: Their service has gotten much better since I last reviewed them.  I also like their free coffee tastings on Friday afternoons.
author: Cristina G.

description: Pretty solid place. I really can't give that detailed of a review, because I've only been there once and only had one item. It was a mocha. Delicious, but a bit small for what it costs. My coffee date got some sort of Chai-related drink and I assume it's a regular thing for her. Clean, but not sterile environment. Friendly staff and crowd. I'd go back! Oh yeah, and the latte art is excellent!
author: Andrew L.

description:
I am part owner of a bar/coffee house in Austin.  

I may have to figure out how to get Ritual's blends.

There are always too many people here.  The wait for the latte is long (but that's because they take care making your coffee).  

However, the coffee is fantastic and isn't that the most important thing?

I ordered a latte from Starbuck's the other day (and I have always found the sbux espresso drink to be good) and it SUCKED because I had a ritual latte the day before.

This is bad.  I have been dreaming about the latte here - the delicious creamy foam (and foam art), the balanced coffee taste, the lingering finish.

Okay, I'm heading over now.
author: Hanson L.

description:
I really don't get what all the huzzah is about this place.
Their coffee is weak, the lines are long, the place is full of wanky hipsters and people on myspace...
I do like the fact that they have Vegan Donuts, I just wish the Vegan Donuts tasted like Donuts...
author: Tom S.

description:
Ritual Roasters is often described as the best cup of coffee in the city by people who have never been to Philz.

Yes, the coffee is good. Yes the hipster vibe/crowdedness in here sucks. Not much to add. When I worked from home I would come here during the day and it was pretty chill (better working environment than Philz:). After 6 the feel of the place would change a lot. I guess it's only the 9-5 hipsters that suck.
author: eliah g.

description:
Good to chill in a couch on a good ol unsecured wireless network for your laptop.

However, it might have been a bad day, but the coffee was masta yuckie to a point barely palpable. It felt like the coffee had been made out of compost.

The design is tip top. It perfectly suits the spirit of the neighborhood. And the baristas are classy enough to make you feel insignificant.

Good times
author: xavier v.

description:
Ritual coffee is a spot that you go to if you like the taste of black coffee. And I do, so I go. 

The best part about this place is the french press coffee. They also make lattes and whatnot with skill. If you've ever been to Intelligentsia in LA's sunset junction. Their coffee is seasonal, roasted on site and fresh. 

They have art on the wall that changes often and is pretty nice to look at. The music is good, the smell is delightful and it's nice an bright. Sometimes seating is hard to find, but there are plenty of dudes with Mac's and square glasses.

I've experienced both great service and rude service at Ritual depending on the day. It's annoying when the person working is trying hard to be aloof. I get it, but I'm a patron at your business, so a smile won't hurt. Then again, I've noticed its quite the hipster hang out so maybe it's all part of the scene. 

Either way if you love coffee and are in the Mission, stop in. You won't be disappointed in the quality of their coffee.
author: Heather O.

description: Hella hipsters. Lots of room, but way crowded. Barista was kind of rude, even though I was trying to be playful and nice to him. I'm pretty sure the drink I ordered made me nauseous. Clean bathrooms.
author: k h.

description: I am a coffee snob and this place fulfills my snobbish needs by making what I think is "THE" best coffee place in the city now.  Great roast and truly a wonderful ritual every time I go or brew at home now.
author: D B.

description: This is a favorite place to contemplate love, loss and life.  Of the countless coffee places I've frequented, this is a top.  I've certainly never found a better pour-over than those done here.
author: B F.

description:
Dear Ritual,

Met a friend for a b-day brunch at Boogaloo across the street.  I said, "Hey is there any place close to get a good soy cap?"  She said, "fuck yes there is. Walk 1 block that way and get ready for some of the best coffee of your life."  I ordered a soy cap, not expecting much because nobody in this city seems to know how to steam soy milk.  The wait was decent, but the people watching in this place makes the time fly by.  
Alas my cup was ready.  I picked it up and the weight felt right, perfect balance of coffee to foam ratio.  The barista was a fucking magician.  I had no idea how he created that perfect foam flower, and he pored it right in front of my eyes! 
Damn you,best cappuccino of my life.  Why do you have to be so inconvenient, so far from my house.  You will haunt me in my sleep as I will have to wake up an hour earlier to get you in the a.m.

Love, 

Me
author: Michele M.

description:
I like this place, but I'm definitely not hip enough for this place.

I used to come in here just to use the bathroom during my long treks in the Mission. Its so packed the hell out I never felt ashamed for not buying anything, I'd use the john then vanish like I was never there.

I don't even like coffee. I don't even drink coffee. I order tea here. Everyone says I'm in denial and one day I'll start hitting the stuff like crack. When that happens I'll know I've come full circle. 

Once I put my used napkin into a empty coffee cup on the counter, you know--to be courteous and shit, but apparently this angered the hipster girl working there, cause she mumbled something that I couldn't quite hear. Whatever though, she had a real ugly haircut anyways, and I know deep in my heart that I had good intentions of getting rid of my napkin. Next time I'll make her happier and leave my shit on the floor. Did I mention she had a real ugly haircut? Well she did.

I like this place, its definitely a "scene," but I like it.
author: kate r.

description:
Whoa whoa whoa! Where does Ritual get off making such fantastic coffee? Now I'm gonna have to go all the way to the Mission to get my fix, or else settle for the putrid sludge other places try to pass off as "gourmet" coffee.

Best. Latte. Ever. EVER!!! There was a line out the door, a cute boy took my order, and we even found seats! 2 of 'em! They have a tray of sugar, honey, etc. but you don't need it, trust me. I usually dump at least a few Sweet 'n Lows in my coffee, but that's because it's crappy. Ritual roasts their beans right in-house, so you know it's fresh. And I don't know why people are bitching about the staff, they were all SO friendly! True, the tables and couches are basically impossible to get in on, which sucks, but if you got one you probably wouldn't leave either. Admit it!
author: Valerie N.

description:
SF's finest place to get beaned and do bidness. 

ideal midafternoon coffeehouse. end of story.
author: Andy S.

description:
A friend is an espresso-rating fanatic (coffeeratings.com) and his top espresso in the city comes from Ritual. So we espresso/cappuccino fiends head over to see what the fuss is about. The cappuccino has been consistently disappointing - here's the 101 Cappuccino making formula from Italy 1/3 espresso, 1/3 milk, 1/3 foam. This was a latte and we gave it a few chances and it was still a milky mixture.

Now, different story if you buy the beans and make your espresso at home like we do on our kickass Jura Capresso machine. Ritual's beans make for a chocolately espresso that doesn't even need milk, much less any sugar it is so good.

So brave the 'tude and get the beans.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Yes, the coffee is good. That much is true. 

I only go about once every two weeks, though. Why? 

The wait ends up being about twenty minutes total for a frickin' Americano. Everyone there is ridiculously there to see-and-be-seen. The vibe is pretentiousness and stuffy. The decor is sterile and uninspired. 

But, the coffee is good. Verrrry good. It's like a caffeine-induced orgasm for the mouth. 

And they have vegan treats, which always makes me happy. 

Only go if you have a half-hour of your life to waste and never gain back, then take your coffee to-go, buy a vegan tasty, and venture down Valencia to gawk at all of the hipster-infused window displays.

But, seriously: the coffee is good.
author: Danyell K.

description: I get a latte here every time I'm in the neighborhood! I wish they had more seating because they're always packed and finding a table is near impossible, but the drinks are great and the staff are friendly so it's worth standing around for.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Hmmm... 

Okay, first off, the coffee here is fantastic. Whether you just want a regular coffee (made with a French press) or a triple latte in a 12-oz cup (like me), you won't find a better coffee drink in town. This is quality shit. 

There's something uncommonly delicious and rich about the lattes I order here, and that's with lowfat milk. I can't exactly explain it, but somehow I continue to subject myself to the requisite 20-minute waits.

Their espresso is flavorful but really smooth. It's not metallic or burned like many domestic dark roasts.

Yeah, waiting 20 minutes blows. I do it anyway. This has become my joint. It's just that much better than the other nearby spots.

On to the atmosphere... 

I've lived in the Mission for a little while.  Ya know, I love its many splendors, but I've definitely grown tired of a few things. I certainly don't like being called a douchebag to my face or being heckled on the street just because I like to present myself a certain way, or because I wear leather jackets and decent clothes. I don't like the fact that I have to work extra-hard with certain people to convince them that I am a decent human being, just because I am not some scruffy dude with a barbell through his septum. I am an "inclusionist". I loathe elitism in all its forms.

You may think that I've encountered all this BS at Ritual, but I actually never have. Oh sure, there are plenty of people here that LOOK like they might give you attitude. I've never been given any shit here. The servers have generally been pretty friendly. Maybe it's because I smile a lot and I'm generous. I dunno. Sure I've had a couple of service issues in my dozens of visits, but that was only because the place was packed.

...That last paragraph refers to the servers, BTW. I can't really comment on the douchiness of the patrons. I've been given the evil eye here once because I was talking too loud, but generally people kinda keep to themselves. I guess it's not the most social atmosphere, even for a wi-fi coffee house.

It's definitely worth the experience. More than once.

Vegan donuts? Huh. I may actually try one some day.
author: Angelo B.

description:
Dear Ritual,

You finally got your mention in the NYT. Please don't change, though.

Love,
Carla C. 

PS - I love that you don't make your coffee too hot.
author: Carla C.

description: Okay, I will say I do actually like the coffee here, but, I'm no coffee snob by far. The two factors that bring my review down are the service and wait. The first time I had ever gone in, one of the counter staff yelled at me when I asked for a caramel latte that "We DON'T have flavors!" Well, I'm sorry, I didn't know, you don't have to be a douche about it. The last time I went in, I ordered a simple latte and it took close to 20 minutes for them to make it! I'm not super impatient, but, in that time, I didn't see any other espresso drinks being made or served, so it didn't seem like a line up for the espresso machine or anything. Did it take 15 minutes for you a draw a leaf on my foam?! How about we skip the leaf and just give me the fucking coffee.
author: Jessica R.

description: The atmosphere is really nice, but coffee is weak - literally! Plenty of tables and super clean. They don't have any strong coffee, nope nada, zero...they only brew medium roast. The coffee is not worth the $2.50+ for a drip coffee and THEY FREAKIN' TOOK FOREVER TO MAKE IT. Great place if you want to hang and study (music is at right level), but if you like strong coffee it's not the place for you.
author: H D.

description: Nothing great. Music is too loud and annoying. Brownies and cookies weren't the best. Coffee was just OK. Definitely not "second best in the city" like others are saying. Staff isn't that friendly. Wouldn't come again.
author: Tanner W.

description: Yep - here's another glowing review of Ritual. Everything here is really, as good as it gets. The coffee is award winning. It can get a little grungy in there since the traffic is so thick, but whatever - it's not a wifi-friendly spot either. All plugs are covered.
author: Catherine C.

description: The coffee is amazing.  Among the best I've ever tasted.  Unfortunately, it's no longer a nice place to spend time.  The music is way too loud.  They installed new speakers in the back and it's actually unbearable.  Sitting the front can be ok depending on who is working that day.  The internet is also declined recently -- cutting in and out as well as just slow. Sorry Ritual -- LOVE your coffee, but I'll be sipping it from a to-go cup from now on.
author: L V.

description: by far the best coffee in Northern California.  Coffee and Latte are smooth and creamy like butter with a high octane kick.  Perfect!
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
great coffee, these people know a lot about it, and how to make it!
but people at register need to learn how to be more friendly and smile, last time i spent 60 dollars there....the girl at the register did not even say thank you! just plain rude. always crowded, there is another ritual in Napa in Oxebow market place, less busier and you get a better experience.
author: Davey J.

description:
Dear Comrades,
I come to you with a report on the state of coffee in the great utopian land of the working party in SF.  The employees are strong like bull, the coffee output is decent and the electricity production is low.  That is all...

I really wanted to dig this place.  Their coffee was highly touted. The theme of the place is unique and the people who frequent the joint are as um..unique as they come.  When the coffee arrived, I thought the design in the foam was pretty neat and the barista was friendly. But the taste of the coffee itself was just so-so.  When I sat down to work on a project with my friend, he looked for an outlet to plug in his laptop as he forgot to charge his before he left.  No dice.  Apparently cutbacks in the budget forced ritual roasters to cover all of their outlets. Fortunately my 'puter still had 4 hours of charge left, so we ended up sharing a computer until our coffee was gone. But seriously, unless you are a communist, who the hell covers up all the electrical ports at a coffee shop? At that point, we escaped out the front door by climbing the wall and ran past the guard tower to freedom, known as my car.

All in all, I dug the retro humorous communist theme.  But I didn't like that they took out the electrical outlets.  Ritual Roasters isn't a bad place to go, its just that there are better places in the city to get coffee.
author: Jeff G.

description:
3.25.2007
3:30PM

Best coffee shop in the mission.

GREAT LATTE.  Perfect balance of foam and heat.

Definitely a must try.   

Come here when you have time...25 minutes for 2 lattes.  

You HAVE to order from the guy that's taking orders.  If you try to order from the cashier, you will surely be mocked and sent to internment.  

Certified Order-taking Man (COM):  What can I get you?
Girlfriend (GF):  Medium non-fat Latte.
COM: OK.

Cashier:  what did you have?
ME: two medium nonfat lattes...but we only ordered one so far
Cashier:  huh?
ME:  He only asked her what she wanted, so I hadn't placed my order yet.
COM: ....you can place all your orders through me...I'm the order taking guy.....duh...
ME:  .....ok....medium nonfat latte...
COM:  ......
cashier:  that'll be $8
ME:  whatever....

*as I'm walking away*

Cashier:  wait....here's some money back.  i overcharged you...
ME:.....ok.....

Rigidly structured and disorganized....perfectly reminiscent of the USSR.
author: William R.

description:
Came here to make my pretrial brief writing more enjoyable on a Sat afternoon, and this place certainly did it!  Don't come here to do serious work though (my brief is just a fake brief for a fake trial), esp if you can't take the loud bumpin' music (ranging from monk chants to club trance to Slim Shady -- not joking), if you don't like crowds, if your laptop battery doesn't last long, or if don't like to bug people for the FOUR outlets they have here (the only reason why this place gets FOUR stars).  They covered up all the outlets in the front to prevent table squatting, but the tables w/ outlets in the back are rather dark and near the bathroom it kinda smells, so take heed. Also, the line is frequently crazy and often out the door, even when I went on a rainy day, but it's not impossible to get a seat to do work for a few hours.

My drink of choice is latte and I think this place's latte ranks really high on my list for being strong and fragrant , and not just b/c it had a lovely heart drawn into the foam (they have all sorts of other shapes too!).  They also roast their coffee beans in this hugeass tub and this guy manually swirls them around.  You come out smelling as if you bathed in those beans, but if you like that smell like I do, mmmm...

I wish they had real food other than desserts and pastries.
author: Erica Y.

description:
Really good cappuccino.  Nothing fancy except a special refined kinda taste.  Lots of seating even though it's mighty busy, and the free WiFi is a plus.  Liked watching one of the workers roast coffee beans in the big red and silver spinning machine.  Guess it was hypnotizing because was too stunned to react when after waiting for my coffee near the counter with a dozen others, some  guy swooped down into the crowd and somehow stole my coffee right as I was reaching my arm out to grab it, and then disappeared.  The barrista was nice and quick with a replacement, but damn, he got away with not so much as even getting called-out, errrgh.  Good pastries, too.  But bagel was kinda bland, and hate cream cheese served in those single serving sealed packets.  Overall, it's a cool place to sit and read or take a laptop.  Damn good cappuccino.  Keep an eye on your coffee.

(update... 5th star added because aside from the crappy cream cheese packets, they have a few other great pastries to make up for the lousy bagels, and all around is a fun place to sit with great coffee, but most of all somehow inspiring or interesting every time.)
author: Today Y.

description:
Stumptown in Portland ruined me.  Stumptown is like the one that got away.  The benchmark lover.  No one else compares to their sultry and sensuous cups.  Mmmmmmm.

Sorry Ritual, I like you but I don't love you.  I spend a lot of my time with you--writing papers, reading, people watching, chatting with the friendly barristas--but you just aren't Stumptown.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Ritual? WHY AREN'T THERE MORE OF YOU??? I just recently learned of the "Ritual" coffee. Reminded me of an authentic coffee shop in Seattle. Though...I've never actually been to Seattle, let alone a coffee shop "in" Seattle - but it reminded me of what I'd think an authentic coffee shop in Seattle would be like. Not pretentious at all. A definite sense of "cool" - but not pretentious (except for maybe the vegan donuts). Love the current art exhibit. Twisted little fairies and mermaids. 

As much as I absolutely love Philz and Blue Bottle Coffee - I didn't walk out of Ritual with the cocaine-esque twitches (caused by extreme amounts of caffeine). That was nice. Their latte's are great - and the barista even showed us how to make the cute little leaf on top in the espresso! I also really like the "French Press" technique for their traditional coffee.
