The 10 tons of coffee beans, and roaster in the back led me to believe that they are either smuggling drugs into the country or "roast their own" (likely the latter). I always appreciate it when coffee shops roast their own. Ritual? Union Street needs you. I need you! Branch out of the Mission! ...please?  :-)
author: Eli S.

description: I paid $5 for a shitty mocha at Ritual.  Don't come here.
author: Dan S.

description:
Ritual, on Valencia st. in the Mission, definitely makes the best cappuccinos I have ever had. The amazing barristas (who take a great deal of pride in what they do and seem to work very well together) make the best foam I have ever had the please to see and taste. They manage to get the consistency just right ( bubbles not too big or small, milk just at the right temp) and they make these beautiful rosettas to complete each cup. 
It can get pretty packed in there and nearly everyone seems to have a mac laptop, so you sometimes feel like you're at the library. But the sofas in the back are comfy, and even with the crowd I've always somehow managed to find a spot to sit. Sometimes there is a pretty long line but you'd be surprised how quickly you reach the front and, soon enough, have a nice, hot capp or latte in your hands.
author: Regina P.

description:
The coffee is exceptional
The music is very loud but I like it.
The art is the summum of hipster crap but fine for a coffee shop
The old ones in the staff would probably shit on me if they could or they are intimidated (they seam uneasy)
The new ones in the staff don't have the attitude (yet) and are nice to me
I am a little worried that they are opening a branch on Bayview, though. 5 to 1 on a Molotov cocktail by the end of July.

03/06/08 update: the toaster is broken and they are not going to replace it ("we got annoyed with it"...) and there is one power outlet left (and 2 stars only in my review).
author: Bobby T.

description:
Love it. I am a coffee snob. They make excellent coffee.

They have snacks you actually want to eat. The boys/girls are cute. They are sometimes even nice. GREAT coffee.
author: Valencia B.

description:
I love coffee. Though, admittedly, as long as it swims on the seriously strong side and isn't Folgers, I am pretty happy. 

I have imbibed coffee and/or espresso at the following Bay Area locations: Blue Bottle, Starbucks, Peet's, Philz, Caffe Trieste and Cafe Roma. All of the above (including Starbucks) have a tastebud ranking of somewhere between decently satisfying and nearing perfection. 

Seriously - what is so special about Ritual? I had the drip coffee which was not brewed by the cup and was overtly bitter.

Am going to have to go against the crowd on this one - too many other places I can go to and be guaranteed to enjoy the 2-3 dollar investment.
author: Natalie L.

description:
In house bean roaster
never suffered bad service
or ill-steamed latte
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Dear Ritual,

Thank you for existing.  Thank you.

Sincerely,

Me
author: Buckminster F.

description:
I apreciate their concept, however when I got my mocha, and chocolate donut, I had one of the worst culinary experiences of my life, (sorry).
I guess I do need my butter, eggs, milk, and animal products more than i thought .
author: J Angel G.

description:
Did I get a bad pot? It wasn't the hipsters or the laptops that bothered me, it was the coffee. I haven't had such watered down coffee since I left the east coast. Seriously. It was east coast diner coffee. I promise. It's hard because everyone seems to love their coffee, but I just don't know what they are talking about. Granted I think they are known more for their espresso drinks, but you'd think they could brew a decent cup as well. 

I'll give them another try. Hopefully it was a fluke because that would make a lot of sense. I'm having a hard time believing that so many people could be so wrong.
author: Claudia M.

description: RCR is awesome, and in my opinion doesnt need yet another 5 star review. Yet - im still compelled to write one.  Its my belief that one shouldnt waste the finite number one will have coffee in a life time on crappy coffee. I dont like crazy concoctions that involve caramel, and "flavors". Coffee's one of the most complex beverages, like tea, and to adulterate it with some overpowering yummy syrup is the equivalent of drowning a top grade kobe steak in ketchup. Shouldnt be done if the coffee's good. And the awesome thing about RCR is that not only the coffee's generally good, the staff is pretty knowledgeable and can point you in the right direction, or at least sound very authoritatively while pretending to point  you in the right direction, either way its awesome.  If you want my unsolicited advice id say go with espresso, or maybe a macchiato, if you're a serious caffeine fiend - consider the cup of coffee.
author: Oleg H.

description: The one in the mission always has a line (longer than any starbucks), but the coffee is definitely amazing!
author: Laura D.

description: Not..a fan. Not a fan at all. My coffee was flat and weak. A complete waste of time. I actually threw it out after a few sips. Oh..and the 'barista' if you could call her that was rude to boot. No thank you.
author: Natalie G.

description: This has to be my absoloute fav coffie house in San Fran. My sister had been goin here for awhile and invited me to join her one afternoon. To my delight i fell in love and have been coming back ever since. The floor plan is airy and i like how you can watch the cute staff grind the breans in front of you. Bottom line, great coffee in a great shop.
author: Meg O.

description: Coffee is delicious, vegan treats are good, and they have been very nice to our dog who frequents the place with us.  Usually crowded and hard to find seating but get your coffee to go and enjoy a walk around the old hood.
author: K W.

description: Never tried Ritual's although they have one in Napa.  Never took a chance till now.   I figured, I'm in La Mission, so why not?   I walked in it was freakin' hipsters paradise.  Hipsters with laptops galore.  Whoever made this place is marketing/design genius.  I can see how it's a cool place to hang.  But on to more importantly, the coffee.   Not bad.  Not as good as Blue Bottle.  Definitely not as good as Peets.   But they're not bad.  Above average I'd say.  They have a great selection of single origins.   I tried the Sweet Tooth Ethiopian and it was great.   Nice floral and berry like finish.
author: Norm P.

description: The coffee quality is inconsistent and because of bad design, the place is always packed and you can hardly move around.  All the people working there cultivate the "I haven't showered in a week" look, and it works because they all look dirty.
author: Denis Y.

description: We were told that this place had amazing coffee, but it was the worst coffee we have ever had! It tasted burnt and sour and no amount of biodegradable cups or lids can make up for it.
author: Anita C.

description: Ritual has greatly improved the speed at which they serve their customers. I originally wrote a 1 star review for the cafe as I was unhappy with the service. However, since my original review things have improved significantly. I hope to update to 5 stars soon :)
author: Alejandro M.

description:
I think I have to break the mold here.  I judge coffee by tasting a plain cup of coffee, no caramel, no vanilla, blah, blah, blah.  Ritual's coffee is OK, just OK.  I drink it twice a week on my way to class, but my coffee at home is way better (French press & I grind my own beans).  AND, they only offer soy milk or half & half to add to the coffee.  I have to ask for milk each time.  Why is that?

Ritual coffee is just OK folks.
author: Jean C.

description: 3.5 stars. Hip and crowded. Not a good choice when I'm alone, too loud. I'm not a coffee drinker, but they have a good selection of tea. I now order where they get their tea, pen & jens online.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I started my day of coffee shop hopping to do some writing here at Ritual, mostly because I had been here once before and vaguely remembered liking the coffee. I am by no means a connoisseur when it comes to this specialized muddy water, I can pretty much drink anything and assume that however it tastes, is supposed to be approved. Kind of like my understanding of wine. I ordered my go-to drink, a soy latte, and was quite surprised by how nice and rather smooth it tasted. I actually started to understand how to discern quality coffee. 

When I finally found and settled into my seat, I realized that my outlet was a fake-out. The shop was already super packed with mid morning Mac minions working away, and I couldn't do much about it but stay where I was. While I probably could have sat around for more than the hour that I did, a few things eventually drove me out to find another location. The lack of an outlet cramping my work flow was one, while being sat near the restroom, which allowed me to catch a few lovely scents coming in and out of the revolving door, was another. The random mix of music was kind of headache inducing, but then I popped in my earphones and drowned it out. Beyond that, eventually a group of coffee taste testers set up camp right in front of me, making it fairly difficult to concentrate on anything else but their commentary on what makes for good coffee. And so, I left. But I will say that the coffee is ace. Four star coffee, three star atmosphere. Could be worse.
author: Karen T.

description:
In the words of B. Simpson, "Don't have a cow man"--let me explain my rating. The reason Ritual gets 3 stars instead of more is the change in its business plan. When RCR first opened, it was a Coffee place: you drank really really good coffee, there were places to sit in the back in couches, you could read email, write that great web site, chat with friends, people watching, or generally just hanging out. It was great for PhD students who just wanted work in a place for hours and finish that darn dissertation.

But alas, no more. The new business plan seems to be this: "We're a coffee roasting place and our main line of business is selling you bags of coffee, but we'll tolerate selling you a cup of coffee and give you a place to drink your coffee. Just don't stay too long." Evidence: they removed the couches in the back and put huge burlap bags of coffee beans, and equally important, removed all the AC outlets to prevent you from plugging in your laptop. There's still free wifi, but there isn't a feeling that you shouldn't expect to get too comfortable anymore.

What a shame. I hope they can find more space to store their beans and let their coffee sippers hang out and create a better sense of community. 
 that also happens to see
author: Arturo G.

description:
The coffee is okay, nothing special...but it's the hipster employees that really make this place worth two whole stars.  They are unbelievably better than any patron ever will be, and will make you will feel that when you walk up to the cash register to place your order.

Actually, now that I think of it, the last drip coffee I had there was undrinkable.  Maybe they do better when they have to put a little effort into it (i.e. espresso drinks).  Philz Coffee is way better, as is Blue Bottle Coffee.
author: Janie A.

description:
Depending on your taste, the hipster vibe can be a plus or a minus.  Personally, I've never had the baristas be anything but polite and professional.

Rating based entirely on espressos and capuccinos--I haven't had the drip coffee here.  Shots consistently pulled right.  I haven't had an over-extracted espresso here (a problem, either occasional or consistent, at a lot of places).  Double Rainbow seasonal espresso in fall 2010 was one of the best I've had.

4.5 stars if I could.
author: P K.

description:
I know this place is hipster central and whatever blah blah blah.  really, don't be so self conscious, who cares?  The service is so friendly and great, and I've had some decent pastries here before work.  It gets super crowded in the morning and that can suck if you want a place to sit.  The (i think it was paul madonna) art that was up last time I went was pretty cute, and their ice tea was 

GREAT.  Maybe that's an overstatement because ice tea just IS, but it was strong and delicious.  People have told me that their regular coffee is just normal but their actual coffee drinks are what to go there for.  Since I don't really drink milk, I've only ever had an americano which was good and their regular coffee which was nothing to talk about.  I had a good chai here, too.  I just think the service is really pleasant and on a beautiful day, it's fun to sit by the window to watch the mission walk/ bike by.
author: Miranda T.

description: Cute place but coffee was just okay. PLUS, the baristas were so unfriendly. How could you give bad service at this day and age? Definitely won't go back.
author: Trish P.

description:
I like Ritual. The atmosphere is airy, light-filled and productive. Lots of laptops. I used to do my homework here when I was in high school. The line seems intimidatingly long but it moves very quickly. I find their coffee a teensy bit on the acidic side but the tea selection is incredible. Give the vegan donuts a try as well. I got one once with maple glazing and these red crumbly things on top, which I thought were Pop Rocks. Turned out to be Fakin' Bacon. Still good! There's also a super cute guy who works here who looks just like Vince from Entourage.

People need to stop bitching about the lack of outlets. They took them out because (um, duh) they're a BUSINESS trying to make MONEY, and if they have no customer turnover because people spend hours there on their laptops after buying one drink, they don't make a profit. How is that a difficult concept to grasp?
author: Jane P.

description:
6 of us were on an espresso crawl in San Francisco...

Staff were friendly and nice and two people managed to serve the 6 of us quickly and efficiently. Nice.

We got espressos of both types offered (sweet tooth and 33 Amigos), a machiato, a cappuccino, and a latte. The sweet tooth was definitely what it advertised - sweet, bright, acidic. It had a real pop to it and a short but excellent finish. I am at a total loss to describe the 33 Amigos. I keep wanting to describe it as muddy, but I mean it in a good way. It was solid, good body, low acidity. I really liked it. The other drinks were good, the milk was perfectly steamed, but they didn't blow us away.

It ranked well in comparison to our usual East Bay haunt, Zocalo Coffeehouse, but the milk based drinks weren't quite as good.
author: Mitch H.

description: Delish!  Just big enough, with a cool laid back vibe, but they definitely take their coffee making seriously.  I like that it was not crammed with people on laptops like at Summit (I find that a bit creepy and unsettling).
author: Danielle P.

description: There are really plenty of reviews for Ritual and no need for me to fill in any more than what's already been said for four pages.  Just posting this review to add my stars and to note that I added a picture of the interior of Ritual - it only shows the front and misses the great community space in the back.  A large table which seats six or eight on extra cozy days, the two circles of couches and chairs and an open door in back to ensure good ventillation.  One key to note about Ritual is that they have plenty of plugs for laptop users but they do not allow access to the electrical on weekends.  Great WiFi, great coffee, great community!
author: Jack S.

description: Overall this place is a solid coffee shop and work space - quality brews and ample supply of tables. Ritual does not try to be anything more (e.g. limited food options and power outlets) and can certainly be noisy but I respect it. Plus its logo looks like a hammer and sickle and it makes me giggle.
author: Cyndie H.

description:
I arrived with the expectation that I was going to have my cup of coffee personally prepared just for me; the beans would be harvested, roasted, ground, and pressed into a hot, caffinated beverage expressly for me. Alas, this is not utopia, and indeed it was not Philz - my mistake.

Regardless, my coffee was drawn from an airpot full of French Pressed coffee and it was mighty good. My friend's cappuccino arrived about 10 minutes later, due to the Sunday evening business and bustle that inevitably clogged up the flow of what would seem to be an easy going coffee shop. As a result of the many lap-top using, law journal reading patrons, my friend and I were forced to walk a block down to another coffee shop and sit at their outdoor seats.

Not bad, but too busy to really gauge.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Great, great coffee! 
It was Sunday afternoon, 70 degrees and sunny in the Mission.
I was meeting a friend, feeling a bit dehydrated, but totally could be a bit hungover.
We waited in line - at least 10 people back for coffee.
All I kept thinking was, please let this be good because I may die before I get my beverage. 
I ordered a latte and wasn't being picky- so, it was a regular latte with whole milk- such a treat.
I added some raw sugar because I so needed the extra pick me up!
It was so good. No burned taste, the beans were totally full of flavor. 
lt really made me want to order like 5 more!
It was love, true coffee love, or would that be true latte love?
Either way, go.
Stand in line.
Enjoy the coffee:)
author: Valarie A.

description:
This place is stinkin' good.

Total hole in the wall, around the corner from my friend Audrey B.'s new house. I will be back.
author: Flora B.

description:
Great coffee and love the leaf design layered into my latte!  Free WiFi, but charge your laptop before you go because you will most likely not find a free outlet.  

Yes! Real porcelain cups! I could really get some great studying and work done here if my laptop power lasted as long as my latte.  It is crowded but pretty good food.  Forget the hipsters - I get 3 things I want: good coffee, free WiFi and tasty baked goodness.
author: Christina C.

description: My favorite coffee -- better than Blue Bottle, Phillz, Four Barrel, and all those other shops. No matter what city or where I go, nothing can compare to my Ritual coffee. And, I am a coffee lover -- I drink/taste coffee like some people have a passion for wine so if you find something better, let me know, but until then Ritual Coffee FTW!
author: Mel R.

description:
Great coffee. You might wait 5 minutes or more for a coffee drink.

Also, the place is full of robots on laptops with earbuds in. Sort of creepy.
author: kenny k.

description:
If nothing else, Ritual is great for aromatherapy.  Get a bag of fresh beans, and wherever it goes will smell fantastic.  We're talking transport-you-to-coffee-heaven fantastic.  And that's just the aroma!

There is, of course, so much else.  They make the best cup of brew coffee I have had in the city.  Some of their roasts are good, some are great, some are exceptional.  All make for a happy day.  Some of their baked goods are surprising winners.  Every once in a while I treat myself to a mini cupcake.

Where'd the fifth star go?  Well, I find the espresso drinks just good.  Not on par with the brew.  Some of the baked goods are surprising clunkers.  The music is junk.  The hipster attitude can get grating.  They have no plugs for my laptop (though this matters less with the extended battery).

That's not a tiny roster of complaints.  What I'm saying is that this is six-star coffee.   Mmmm....coffee....
author: Mad S.

description:
I ride a bike... I own more than 1 in fact , I even wear a lot of black.  Yet I too do not feel cool enough for this coffee shop.   

I do like how the hot chocolate have a neat leaf pattern on it.  Maybe they should spend less time decorating and more time getting the line moving though.   
I like Philz way more, better environment and it tastes better...( as far as coffee shops in SF).
author: amanda v.

description:
Phenomenal lattes and cappuccinos, with expertly pulled espresso and perfectly steamed milk.  Blue Bottle isn't on my way to anything so I haven't tried it, but compared to other coffee houses around it blows them all out of the water.  There simply is no comparison, I'd need piles of sugar to drink the swill from most other shops and I happily add nothing to the perfection served up by Ritual.

The cupcakes and breads are also amazing.  The $1 cupcake is one bite, but why have more when you've already had the perfect cupcake experience?

As for atmosphere, there's cool art and solid internet.  Good people about and good music.  It's a good place to hang out and or to get work done on your computer, though not my favorite for the purpose.  Expect a line at most times of day and perhaps no where to sit now that they've replaced their comfy seating area with bags of coffee.  I'm really sad to see that go.  Still worth 5 stars though.
author: Rich R.

description: Uh...I call shenanigans on this place.  Granted, this review is based on one experience, but I overpaid for a tepid, weak latte and waited kind of a while for it.  And is there a reason we need to furnish an entire place in all light colored wood and hipness to get across the sense of good coffee being brewed?  If I had to choose between Ritual and Starbucks, I'd go to Starbucks.
author: Briana L.

description:
small or no sign in their building except for their LOGO. 
parking can be hard to find. 

coffee is really good! they sell mugs, beans, have different ways to brew. i think there is also free wifi. big space but not enough tables or chairs. 

Prices are up there but you get what you pay for premium coffee. 
service was weird. looks like to me its more of a social hangout than a business. dont expect them to be friendly unless your a regular or their friend.
author: Cee B.

description: The coffee is great but expect a mildly pretentious crowd that is "hanging out" by sitting on their computers for hours at a time. Was there once and I could see it being the type of place where its an issue to get a table since enough customers just camp out for hours at a time. Definitely worth stopping buy for a good cup of coffee.
author: David S.

description: Great Baristas. Hipster. Double Rainbow Coffee.
author: katherine s.

description:
Update: Ritual roasts their own beans now (hence the name of the establishment).  Also, check out the following Economist article about the coffee machine at Ritual:

http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=10150312 

===

Great and consequently often crowded coffee shop in the Mission.  Back when I was looking for housing in the city, I would sit at Ritual with my laptop, peruse housing ads on Craigslist while sipping an expertly made cappuccino, run to an open house a block or two away, return to Ritual, and repeat...  I believe that Ritual uses Stumptown beans, an excellent choice which I was first introduced to in Portland last summer.
author: Grace W.

description:
So - this is review #302... at this point I'm pretty sure that its all been said and done for Ritual Coffee Roasters. Still:

The chai was a little on the watery side, frankly, but the flavor was good. It makes me wonder if I really know what a good chai is, given that much of my experience has been at *$'s. I didn't want much caffeine, so my options were limited. I'll try proper coffee next time I go, which hopefully will be soon.

What was lost in my less-than-awesome chai was made up for by the wide variety of comfy seating and action packed atmosphere. The store was busy the whole time I was there on a Monday night (about 3 hours), but there was reasonable turnover so people were able to find seats without too long a wait. As you might expect for a SF coffee shop, I met a friend and discussed business plans / product design for a few hours. Its likely that at least one other group was doing the same, given the number of laptops on the premises. Not at all hoity-toity, though - far from it. 

Tip: There's a $5 minimum for credit card purchases. I got a very good slice of vegan banana bread to make up the difference.
author: Phil K.

description:
Does this joint REALLY need another review? Nearly 500 people have chimed in on Ritual Roasters at this point. Is this overkill? Absolutely. Do they have really good coffee here? Absolutely. Is it the best in the city? No way in hell does it top Philz or Blue Bottle in quality of product. However, it does beat both of those places out in ambiance. 

Ritual Roasters operates in a modern space with a post-industrialized feel. It's like somebody walked into Stumptown Roasters in Portland & snuck out with the blueprints. But it works.

I'm actually kind of amazed that I've been living here for nearly four years & I'd never been to Ritual until last night. I'll definitely be back at some point.
author: Pete J.

description: I hate hipsters and the how you can feel their satisfaction when you ask for lowfat milk and they deny you.  I mean, c'mon, no lowfat milk?  What is this, the Soviet empire?  That explains the logo.  But, they will survive because their coffee is better than Peet's and even Blue Bottle in my opinion.  The space is also beautiful.  They also carry their coffee at Whole Foods.  F*ckin' sellouts.  Thanks.  I'd definitely go here vs. Peet's if it was near me. Plus 1 point for not having soy milk in the middle of the Mission.
author: Sarah B.

description:
The coffee is definitely good (I got a taste of the espresso and it's strong and has good flavor).

Ritual mainly deserves 2 stars because of the scene and ambiance, and the wait for your coffee.

What's with the 7-10 staff in the place, most of which kind of just walk around busying themselves doing nothing, with ONE barista on the machine??? Especially with the loads of customers they get. ONE BARISTA is not enough.

When I walked in, the entire counter in the back was filled with used cups. Why isn't anybody keeping the counter clear? It wasn't even as crowded as I've seen; waiting 10-15 minutes for an espresso is kind of lame. Not to mention, my boyfriend's espresso cup wasn't even that hot...which means the coffee itself cools rather quickly.

I like their water fountain. It's cool.

The scene is way too cool and smug for me. I like Four Barrel better.
author: Angela H.

description: Soy latte and a vegan donut please! I am not a hip SF vegan...Just a boring vegan who enjoys the simple pleasures of good coffee and a donut to dunk into it, which is hard to come by outside of SF.
author: Kat L.

description: If you show up without a Mac, you may very well feel like you are about to get lynched.  Good coffee though. Not quite as good as blue bottle but pretty pretty good.
author: Summit S.

description: Overly pretentious and expensive for the actual quality of coffee, filed with the über hip, dripping with tattoos, evoking soviet/turkish symbolism. go to philz, it's just down the block.
author: ben r.

description:
I don't get it.  I really liked the atmosphere, and the fact that they're four-legged friendly, but that's about all the good stuff I can say.
I ordered a decaf cappacino, and it was luke-warm at best.  The mug -- or cup I should say -- was on the small size.  There was more foam than coffee, and it was very bitter with an unpleasant aftertaste.
I also got a chocolate croissant.  There was no offer from the cashier to heat it up, which it should have been because the chocolate was too hard.  I've had way better, and will not go back to Ritual.
author: silvertongue- p.

description:
First coffee stop I made on this trip to SF.  I bought a bag of beans (some type of Kenya...) and got a pour over to go (same Kenya...).  

The pour over was good, though I they used a different method on their v60 pour overs.  I didn't examine everything carefully, but it seemed like they used a finer grind and then stirred the grind with a spoon while dumping the water in.  Kind of a quick and dirty method, but it got the flavors I was expecting.  Not a negative, just different.  

The service was a bit...rushed.  The employees weren't exactly unfriendly, but it seemed like they just wanted to get me out of there, even there there was no line behind me.  I kind of made me feel unwelcome, which isn't what I'm used to in the Bay Area/SF.  This is the reason for only four stars.  

I really enjoyed my pour over and the beans I got.  

I didn't stay, but they had plenty of comfy seating and even some power outlets for those who need to juice their macs while they enjoy their coffee.  

I would come back, especially if I heard rave reviews of a particular roast at the time, but I will have lower expectations on their friendliness.
author: John G.

description:
While I may not be a huge fan of the afternoon laptop "i'm alone-but not alone with all my lap-topers and internet friends" scene, I must say this: Ritual has the best coffee in town, hands down.  No one even comes close.  Get in and get out before you get sucked in to the powerbook vortex of flirtacious glances and failed attempts at socialization, but make sure you've got a coffee or an espresso drink with you as you flee the chaos and creeping destruction.

Update:  Blue Bottle comes close, and might even be a tie, but those fools ain't never open when I need them.  Also, there is this really cool tea you should try.  And I mean... REALLY COOL!  I don't know how to spell it, but it's something like Orange Blossom Osmanthus.  Check it out when you don't feel like writing 18 yelp reviews in a row because of the  amazing power of Ritual's Espresso...
author: Ben V.

description:
Erm... It's OKAY.

I love how many of the high ratings compliment the coffee with, "OMG it doesn't taste burnt!"  Would you give McDonald's 5 stars for not burning their burgers?

The fact is, there is -- OMG! -- much better coffee in the world.  Just offhand, I think a ripe handful of you need to at least try Philz (in the morning -- it can be iffy in the afternoon/evening) before any more OMGs are issued on Ritual's behalf.

I'm a sucker for good design, and this place has a nicely integrated kinda-commie aesthetic.  So, 2 points for design, and 1 point for the yummy spicy homebrew chai mix, whatever that is.

Come for the atmosphere and the unbeatable people-watching.  But the coffee... *shrug*.
author: Naomi M.

description:
Hands down THE best coffee in SF. Having being spoilt by great coffee shops and baristas in Sydney, Australia (my hometown), it was looking like a sad situation trying to find decent coffee here.

Having stumbled across Ritual and being drawn in by the vibe inside, it was time to put their coffee to the test. The wait for it is really worth it as it's great tasting coffee, really well made.

Definitely a great atmosphere to catch up with friends or even just to chill out listing to music and usuin the wifi.
author: Patrick W.

description:
A very cool coffee shop. Pretty simple. The coffee drinks are amazing and done with care and time and use Clover organic milk. As they should. People seem to come here more for the atmosphere than the drinks, which is a little unfortunate because the coffee far exceeds the vibe of the place. It's the center of the Mission hipster universe. Which has some ups and some down that go with it.

The place (which I'm sitting in right now on their free wi-fi) has a modern look and feel, simplistic design. Exposed dim yellow bulbs hanging from the cieling. It's new San Francisco brought to reality. The crowd is more-or-less young "new mission" people looking for somewhere to sit and relax with their coffee.

I am impressed by the literate crew sitting next to the "I work for Google...let me whip out my ENORMOUS laptop and work here" crew. A plus for the art that is in here right now...its hilarious and I'd love to buy a piece if I could.

UPDATE: Ritual was featured in a front-page article of the SF Chronicle which talks about the techno-nomads I mentioned above:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/03/11/MNGKKOCBA645.DTL
author: Tolga E.

description:
Do not try to use WiFi there... I don't know whether it's web 2.0 mission hipsters that overloaded it, or they just have a crappy access point, but the connection drops every 3 min. 
Also, they covered all power outlets in the front.
author: alec m.

description:
I felt naked without a laptop at  this place.
I went for the first time the other day I wanted to see what all the
fuss was about.    The first thing i spotted was the donut muffun
they call it the dirt bomb ( how cool). The crowd here looks like a cross
between MTV  and american idol.   It seems like there is NEVER  
I mean NEVER  anywhere to sit down. I went back a 2nd time  with
my sister same thing no seats. You have all these laptop people
sitting taking up all the tables. How does this place make any 
money  when they can't turn tables.  Well two strikes your out with
me baby . IF I want to stand with a cup of coffee and a roll I'll take a
ride on the 30 stockton . You'll find the real deal cool coffee cafes 
in North Beach  my hood.......
author: Bill H.

description:
I LOVE this place!  I've had my best cups of coffee here.  No other place compares.  I'm also impressed with the vegan pastries.  Quite tasty.  I think pricing is very reasonable.  They should sell 'actual food' too...  I clamored for a sandwich or something while I was there..

Only downside is the long wait to get your drink.  It's not a Starbucks mentality either...  It shouldn't take so long.  

Yeah, seating can be an issue..  I went last night and I was lucky to have found a seat...  But, most people will put books or SOMETHING on the chair next to them so no one will sit down next to them.  Ask them if you can sit there...  They won't have the balls to say no.

I'm not a big fan of people using WiFi for hours on end if they only bought a $3 drink.  Buy a $3 - $5 dollars worth of stuff every hour, and i would have no problem with that.

But, I go there to have a great drink with a great read.  I get to meet some interesting people once in a while...  So I'm happy  :-D
author: R G.

description:
Cool space, good coffee. Full of Mission district techno-hipsters. This is my favorite coffee shop in the Mission. Most tables are two-tops, with a big communal table and also some couches and stuffed chairs. 

They have free wi-fi, but power outlets are hard to find and often not operable on weekends anyway. (They used to have more outlets, but closed many of them off.)
author: Art K.

description:
Went here today to telecommute and treat myself to a cappuccino.

Was surprised to find essentially no electrical outlets, which limited the amount of work I could do to laptop battery life.  While at first this was a little irksome, I actually kind of liked this, as it forced me to ramble on and change scenery after about 2 hours.  I'm sure if they let people camp out, I'd never get a table there at all.

Also, sat at a big, sunny table shared with a few strangers.  A very feel-good neighborhood experience.

Five stars for a tasty soy cappuccino, warm ambiance, and gently mandated customer turnover.
author: Paul B.

description:
It's no secret---I really, and I mean REALLY, dislike hipsters *shudder* 

When I was at my previous job, we had to vacate our office for a few days so I tried to work from Ritual because their iced mochas are perfection. One of my co-workers quipped, "Be nice to the hipsters." 

Pfff.... well they weren't nice to me! All the tables were taken but some had an available seat. However, more than one hipster refused to move his/her shit from the otherwise empty seat so that I could actually work and not just pretend to work. 

OH, and what's with the barista not believing that my name is Iris?!

I almost gave Ritual 2 stars just to be a bitch, but their iced mocha and the fact that they have Honduran coffee were their saving graces.
author: Iris V.

description:
I don't know about the other Yelpers but I like the look of feeling like you are next to a giant coffee machine. 

Their tea was awesome, the service was quick and friendly, AND an entire huge cup of jasmine tea was only $2, what could be betteR?!
author: Ali L.

description:
There seems to be two camps in San Francisco -- those who love Blue Bottle, and those who love Ritual. I personally love both. 

A great place to get a little work done on your laptop, but you won't find a plug-in in the place. 

They have one of the barista-in-a-machine Clover's where you can have a custom cup of joe for $3-10.

Is Ritual going to be a ritual? Buy yourself a gift card... because as it says, "you're a bitch without your coffee"!
author: Angela G.

description: This is the kind of place that is crowded because the word of mouth says its great and hip, so people go there. However, the coffee is so good and the barristas so great  that people come back,  too.
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description:
I will preface this by saying I have never stepped foot in Ritual Coffee Roasters--and never will. 

I am only writing this review because I have some good friends that said their one-and-only experience was so traumatizing and awful, that they would never recommend this shop nor step foot in there again. 

Unfortunately I understand this cafe, although with semi-mediocre products according to the mixed reviews on Yelp!, is staffed with some super, unfriendly employees that make visiting this cafe an ugly experience. During my friends' visit, they were treated poorly at the counter and also while they were (trying to) enjoy their mediocre coffee. My friends are not big complainers and, frankly, have a cafe of their own so they understand the importance of being hospitable. 

I would give this cafe no stars but unfortunately Yelp! won't let me. There are way too many other cafes in San Francisco to experience so don't waste your time here.
author: Chubby D.

description:
Ritual is by far the best coffee roaster.  The espresso is delish, and the coffee is always fresh.   

They know what they're doing down there, and they do it well!
author: Lindsey A.

description:
I'm a newly converted fan.  I'm not going to lie, I don't know much about coffee.  In fact, the only coffee I drink are from Starbucks or Philz.  However, ever since I started working at 7:30 AM, I NEED my coffee fix.  

The coffee here is amazing!  To add to that, I enjoy their warm atmosphere and eye-catching marketing, especially the gift cards.  Hilarious!  I also want to thank the staff for being patient with me.

I'm SORRY!!!!!  ...and a big sorry to those standing behind me.

I'm one of those customers that kinda holds up the line and would ask the barista what coffee they would recommend.  

---Please Don't Hate Me---

+4 because parking is and will always be a bitch.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
This place is definitely for the hipster crowd, but whatever. The coffee is good and they make great foam designs on your latte or cappuccino which I happen to love. 

Good coffee, decent service and no crappy Starbucks music.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Admittedly I'm not a coffee snob - I just like what I like.  And I like Ritual.  I hate Starbucks - it makes me physically ill.  And I found Blue Bottle to be too sour for me.  But Ritual is nice and smooth.  I also like that it's never too crowded to get a seat here.
author: B. Y.

description:
MId week night, no lines, lots of tables and no hassle if you linger. 

Barista Coffee Art is quality.

Coffee is tangy not bitter or over roasted. 

People don't strike up a lot of random conversations, but they have a hip look and are reading books you want to inquire about. 

Pastry selection is limited and not so tasty. Tea is good quality but very obviously just a "got to have it for the random order".

Staff is friendly and not too hipster to make you feel like your qool quotient is lower than PeeWees. Hey, you didn't get caught in a bathroom.

Plus their logo is so cool, sickles rock.
author: Miel H.

description: Best lattes in town. The darkly sweet scent of Ritual's coffee beans manages to inspire me every time, for I've spent countless hours here writing a novel. The only downside: no outlets to charge your laptop. The music's usually good too!
author: Mercurio C.

description:
Get over it, laptop-wielding whiners! As a designer who has her laptop surgically attached to her hip, I'd like to thank Ritual, Cafe du Soleil, and other establishments that are helping me re-enter the human life sphere by denying access to plugs.

Ritual makes my favorite espresso right now, Lifesaver, which I buy whole and grind and pull at home. It's fruity and brown-sugary, and takes some trained taste buds to enjoy, but there's no going back. When the seasons/ trading conditions change, so will their roast, but I will be there with bells on to try it out.
author: Teresa A.

description: Okay, so now they accept credit cards on even small purchases. Yay, I'm a fan! The mocha I had was decent and the staff was nice.
author: Graham H.

description: When good coffee, yummy baked goods, nice baristas, free wifi, and a chill atmosphere come together...you gotta give it 5 stars! I was in the neighborhood and decided to yelp "latte" and remembered oh yeah, I've been wanting to try Ritual Coffee! I parked, fed the meter :p and was on my way when I first came upon a cute boutique called Dema (locally made clothing, soaps, bath salts and lotions, where I bought a lotion called Ocean Beach...I smell like a coconutty breezy beach soo good...my inner Pisces likey! ) anyways, I digress... I asked the very nice girl in the store what her favorite thing to get next door at Ritual is...and she gives me a pro tip...score! She starts off by saying, "well this not on the menu"...(awesome)..."but I get what is called the Gibraltar...it's espresso served in a small whiskey glass with a little milk on top, like a strong latte"...I was sold!! I ordered it: it was beautifully made, soo smooth and rich, very strong but didn't need any sugar at all! It's not served very hot, it's mildly warm but it's actually good that way because you can really taste the flavor of the coffee. I also got the vegan chocolate cherry cake...OMG best chocolate cake ever!!! And the thing was vegan!! Damn! Gotta come back here next time I'm in the city to try their regular coffee, and lattes, and mocha, and scones, and.....mmmm
author: jasdeep g.

description:
Plusses: Vegan donuts (from the People's Donut) and vegan sherry cake. Also, not-bad-at-all coffee and nice decor and a neat-coloured bathroom. 

Minuses: Often crowded, baristas can be kind of, well, douchey (but for every vaguely douchey barista here, there seems to be another really nice one, so I suppose it's a wash). 

Given how much the Ritual website hypes the coffee and the god-like skill of the baristas they have hand chosen from the graduating classes at Harvard School of Barista Studies, I would expect the coffee to be better. It's certainly not bad, but I feel like my dad makes better on his home espresso maker (though, to be fair, my dad is obsessive about coffee and has an associates degree in Baristology from Brown). My point is that the coffee is good but not amazing.

Other factors to consider: Ritual is most often crowded, and most of the crowds tend to be hipster types, which you may or may not like. There's also a big communal table near the front. I imagine this is designed to get people to be social. I think it's a nice touch.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Pro's; fresh roasted beans. Mix of blends. Fruity espresso (light roast).

Con's; fruity espresso (light roast).

It's great to have another good option for fresh, locally roasted beans in SF. If you like light fruity coffee I think you'll love Ritual. If you like Italian style coffee with deep complex flavours and aromas; nut, chocolate, sugars, etc - you'll be better off with Bluebottle.
author: Nick W.

description: Everything is good: drips, espresso, pastries, ambience, and relatively large space in SF. Unlimited / non-password required free Wi-Fi is very convenient.
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
The coffee is really really good, and the fancy designs in the lattes make me feel special.  I like it for a strong cup, and it helps that it is conveniently located on my favorite shopping street.

Good, but not mind-blowing.  I like the set-up, I like the coffee and the snacks are tasty.  I think I was too hyped up for Ritual by my friend who is a Stumptown Coffee Roasters junkie.

Check it out if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I read the review for this coffee shop before I went and prepared for the worst. No table space... check,  mob of hispters... check, and good coffee... check (they only had half and half the times I was there, but were very nice about offering other types of milk).

Quick pro and con list:
- Pro: Free Wifi
- Pro: One of the better cups of coffee I've had in my life
- Pro: Mini cupcakes - takes the guilt out of eating one the size of your fist
- Pro: Interesting spot for people watching
- Pro/Con:Other laptop users 
- Con: Really loud music
- Con: Constantly crowded

The Pros really outweigh the Cons. I'm also not worried about people stealing my laptop. Mine is three years old and the guy sitting across from me has a new Apple ;)
author: Emily A.

description:
Jon B. took me here and the place has some of the best coffee I've ever had. There's something about it that's different. I can't describe it - you have to try it. Since then I've gotten some whole bean coffee from there and was not disappointed.

As for the actual coffee shop; I've only been there once but this is what brings it down from 5 stars for me. The service seemed to be San Francisco standard for coffee shops - too cool to care. The atmosphere is coffee shop standard as well.
author: Stuart M.

description:
This is the home of the fixed gear, track bike. The front of this shop looks like a velodrome. I have a track bike, but I would never ride it on the street that is way to dangerous and uncomfortable.

Great coffee, good service, nice people and if you get there before 8:00AM like I usually do, then it is almost hipster free.
author: Seamus M.

description:
Here's my two cents on the good-hipster, bad-hipster debate: 

Speaking for me, my boyfriend and my dog, these people are really charming! Having lived in Wicker Park and Williamsburg, I think I'm qualified to evaluate the hipster baditude of a cafe. 

Yes, the staff and clientele are dressed hipply but this does not make them incompetent or rude as is the case with so many hipster haunts. Ritual is very friendly, has good coffee (and a mean savory breakfast muffin) and has a kind and professional staff all of the times I've been. The last time I went, it was a typically packed Saturday. When my bf spilled his espresso drink all over the counter, the barista offered him a towel and new drink, totally unprompted. Plus, I can take my very well-behaved dog, and that makes us happy.

However, I give only 4 stars instead of 5 because it is often unbelievably packed. Their take-out service is nevertheless great.
author: G Z.

description:
Damn that cappuccino... now I'm up and can't sleep...
Amazing foam... slightly bitter and strong, then mellows.
Beautiful art - on the drinks and the walls.
Good luck finding a table... super packed.
Great location.
Try the zucchini bread.
It shocked me.  Wow.
I'm gonna go fold laundry or something.
Or count sheep.
The sheep are running fast.
And the world is sHaKiNg . . .
author: Aaron W.

description:
Great coffee and cupcakes. I don't blame them at all for plugging up the outlets. I can see where it would be hard to run a business where people spend $1.50 then sit there for two hours. They're a coffee shop, not a hotel.

Definitely a see-and-be-seen kind of place, if you're into that. My friend Amber calls it the Mac Store.
author: Josh K.

description:
Ritual or Blue Bottle? Both, whichever I'm closer too. Although Ritual usually is rocking the cool tunes on Valencia. 

And Ritual has the funny sarcastic gift cards you want to buy just so you can show your friends how they made you laugh while you waited in line.
author: Helen J.

description:
When I first walked by Ritual, I thought what a cool, lesbian bike messenger coffeehouse, but after a few more trips by I realized they had a more diverse clientele--which kinda bummed me out--just kidding. 

I LOVE COFFEE! It is my legal drug of choice. I am not a connoisseur, but I know what I like, and Ritual is it. Great flavor and has a subtle kick to it. I also loved the fact that they grind their beans for me--unlike the place in the alley--the guy there was horrified that I asked them to grind the beans and was a bit snotty about it. Hey I do not own a grinder by choice; at 5:30 in the morning who the fuck wants to hear all that noise? Not me--I want coffee--quick.
author: Deborah S.

description:
Stopped by to get a quick pick me up and a sweet.  They have a variety of baked goods (not baked in house) with some vegan options, however, it doesn't look too fresh nor appealing.  I ordered the alfajores and biscotti and both were stale and borderline rancid tasting...I didn't even take another bite after the first.

As for the star of the show, the coffee - I like it strong, so when I got a taste of Ritual's coffee, it tasted a little weak for my taste, however, the soy was creamy and had a nice foam + design on top.

Atmosphere - it's a big cafe with a really good ambiance.  I loved the back section with the huge communal table and area with a couch, coffee table and lamps; it felt like a really cozy living room.

Overall, I'd go back again since Ritual has great hours - opened to 11 every night with the exception of Sunday opened till 10. It's a great alternative for friends to lounge and hang out instead of getting drinks at a crowded sweaty bar.
author: Miss H.

description:
I must say that the reviews here are pretty classic. I must commend everyone who states the overwhelming obviousness of the place, many of whom I doubt have dared to step into the place. So much unwarranted backlash because the patrons perhaps are a little cooler than thou? I can assure that neither the staff nor the "droves of hipsters" notice you nor do they pass judgment (or maybe you're sad because they don't want to be your friend and it rehashes some issues from high school?). It's a coffeeshop with wifi, no surprise that people are going to bring them some laptops. And apparently there is a big problem with the mission folk/ritual goers who don't adorn themselves in a "accurate" representation of their socioeconomic status? wah wah, it's been said ad nauseum but it's the Mission! and Ritual represents a composite of the neighborhood. 

It's good coffee, the staff are friendly despite being extremely busy, the  place is bustling and pretty fun, and the people watching is unrivaled.
author: Bryan E.

description:
I don't drink coffee so I'm not big on cafes (and my rating probably won't mean a whole lot), but I like coming here for several reasons:

1) Everyone here is really good-looking. I've got no shame in saying it. The clientele is attractive, the employees are attractive, and it improves the scenery.

2) Speaking of scenery, the art on the walls here is actually good. Usually.

3) They sell Peoples Donuts.

4) They've got two unisex bathrooms.

5) Their hot chocolate is good.

6) They play good music.

7) The seating area is usually clean.

It's usually pretty hard to find seating though, because most people who go there (myself included) tend to bring their laptops.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Holy shit, that's good coffee.

It's refreshing to find a scenester haven that actually puts out.  This place rocks.

There's not enough seats because people aren't social enough to share large tables.  Just find a cute guy/girl, slide an innocent 'is this seat taken?' in and plop yourself down next to them.  Maybe you'll make friends.

If I could get a caf coretto... I would be in heaven.  Get a liquor license, guys, or just hide some Sambuca under the counter.  I won't tell anybody.
author: davide g.

description:
Meh.

Decent coffee and environment, but I'm in the crowd that think it's over-hyped. 

I feel like this place is popular because everyone goes there, and everyone goes there because it's popular.
author: Levi B.

description:
I generally hit the Ritual lottery.  No attitude and a good pour.  The roasts are not quite up my personal alley but I'll give the props they are objectively due.

The missing star is for the scene-over-bean attitude I get.  I'll take my coffee in a back alley any day, if it means I get to talk wet processing.  What a nerd.
author: K M.

description:
Hey, there's only 540 reviews of this place!  I must have found a hidden gem.

Fantastic coffee (drip or espresso-based)!

Bring your bike, messenger bag, and MacBook.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I am so over this place! It was great at first, and then the word got out on how good their coffee is.
What is the point in waiting over 15-20 minutes for a cup of joe and then having to go drink it on the sidewalk??? It has become such a haven for laptop dwellers and book readers (seriously, the music is so loud- we all know you can't possibly concentrate). They never leave their coveted tables. Most of the time, it appears they just hope to be noticed. Is it me or has ritual become a meeting place for potential love? The attitude of the daily patrons becomes rather boring. 
Contrary to the desire of wanting perfect coffee...it is more enticing to have an average mug elsewhere. Ritual has turned into a pathetic haven of posers. I simply have no more use for this place.

What a shame to a coffee lover.
author: SF U.

description:
OMG. Smooth yet bold coffee. The creamiest, most beautiful latte.
We took home some beans, also great. 
We will be ordering beans from Ritual and have them shipped to Chicago. Really, really good.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Love love love the coffee. The coffee is amazing.

Service is alright. The baristas can get _really_ moody, but then again, they very well have a right to. The quality of the coffee outweighs any kind of attitude.

I give them two stars because they removed their outlets. Simply unacceptable.
author: Felix S.

description:
Tried the coffee. Not all that impressed; perhaps I just didn't like the type of coffee they offered that day.

But I do like their cafe latte! Thanks goodness bf ordered it (and was willing to share =P). Just the right combination of espresso, milk, and foam. Will definitely get it again next time I come.

Pastries are.. ehhh. Ambiance is okay. Not sure if it's the perfect setting to sit down and chill with a good book. Pretty okay spot for meeting up with a friend and chat; assuming u can find an empty spot. I especially like the back area where there are coffee bean bags laying around waiting to be mixed and roasted.
author: Poof S.

description:
Always friendly staff, always amazing coffee, always takes forever.
If you order anything other than drip joe then you have got some time to kill, but it's well worth it. Grab a vegan donut while you wait....
author: JawkDNA X.

description:
Coffee, lattes and americanos  are OK but inconsistent. Why is the line so long? sheez really??

I always feel like I'm inconveniencing the folks in there and that is not something I normally feel. I am not even that picky about my coffee but when it's average and the wait is long, I just don't get it...
author: Kara S.

description:
I am not a hipster, I'm just a guy that loves the true flavor of coffee and Ritual has found it(Four Barrels was started by the same crew, so they are on par as well).  

They understand that an espresso is not a cup of coffee.  It's to be pulled short, a double is to look like a 1/4 of a single, I kid you not, this is how it should be.  The espresso is bursting with flavors, citrus, nuts, chocolate and so on, just depends on the variety they are pulling.  

They currently are doing a special called Sweet Tooth Espresso, Jan and Feb were amazing.  I stocked up on Jan, it' still my favorite...... It's more expensive, but worth it.

One last note, avoid the crowd, go early, I'm there at 6:30 and the staff is always fun to talk coffee with!
author: Skip L.

description: I did my taxes this year quicker than Ritual was able to make a latte for me, literally. 40.00 on exactly 24oz. of beans and two coffees. You would think they have oh I don't know a bag for me to carry it out, something to hold the coffee so it doesn't spill. NO no they dont have time for that. Much too busy to take care of the customer. No coffee no matter how great it is is worth customer service like that. it's just  not. Taking my business elsewhere. You kids can have your tattoo review and make more coffee for fools, I am out!
author: Stu G.

description: Overpriced drink, weird ambiance.  Assuming you don't come to a coffee shop to have your voice and thoughts drowned out by loud angry thrash music, you may prefer to get your coffee buzz on elsewhere.  (I see several other customers here with their own noise canceling headphones!).
author: Laura K.

description: spacious work space, free wifi, good coffee, what more can you ask for?
author: Sydney L.

description: A nice cool hip atmosphere with hipster employees. Big place, however I didn't notice the list of drinks that they offered. Maybe I was blind? Maybe they only carried plain coffee and tea? Who knows, I didn't see it, and only referred to a sheet that listed out the teas. My friend and I had our coffee caffeine fix of the day, and probably didn't need anymore, so we both settled for tea. He ordered a jasmine type tea, and I had oolong. I saw that they had some really cute mini cupcakes, and being a red velvet cake connoisseur, I had yet to try one. For only a dollar, it seemed kind of expensive but the look of it was money. The staff there was really friendly, which is a plus. I did notice a large amount of mac users (actually I think all of the people who were using their notebooks there were mac users). [I think mac should really have rituals as a sponsor or something lolz] Anyways... The tea was perfection, and they even had these little pile-able tea cup and tea holders. My only complaint and huge turnoff was the small amount of lint or dust on the frosting of the cupcake. I know its nothing to cry about, but I didn't find that very attractive. I understand it might have came from the little display box and lighting, but I don't think I'll be getting pastries from them, strictly drinks.
author: Monina C.

description: Great coffee.  The baristas were helpful and wanted to make sure you enjoyed your beverage.  The cafe is large with lots of seating and free WIFI.  There is not much in the way of food but you are really coming here for the coffee.
author: T J.

description: For me, going to a cafe is all about the full experience - and I have high standards. Ritual has definitely got some great coffee - and if rated on coffee alone, would get closer to 4.5 stars. The atmosphere here killed it for me (not totally - just more like three stars killed it). I expect a cafe to be intimate-ish, with the ability to still get some work done, have a conversation, make some new friends - connect. The style here is very open - almost a little too modern/cold for me. The set up really doesn't facilitate conversation, but other than that - a fantastic place to go if you want to seclude yourself while still being surrounded by people.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Still the champ. They set the gold standard when it comes to cappuccinos. The key is in the temperature. Their cappuccinos and other espresso drinks are served warm, not blisteringly hot. This makes a huge difference. Props for consistently nailing the artful presentation required of modern espresso based drinks. 

For those that prefer coffee coffee I recommend getting a Matalapa made using the Clover machine. Delicious. The French press coffee is solid as well. 

The staff is friendly and savvy. Ritual isn't simply a 'hipster' haven. I see Mission professionals, Noe Valley families, students and people from all other walks of life in the mix.
author: Adam L.

description: a little disappointing.  latte had nice art but was a little "diluted."  want more bold coffee, less milk.  anyways, compared to philz, sightglass, blue bottle, four barrel, not quite as good.
author: Rob C.

description:
great fucking espresso makers. even the hipster "smug meter" reads down a bit and the place is infested with them. hipsters. 

but hipsters here can make espresso and are pleasant.
author: Nathan B.

description:
A friend brought me a pound of their coffee and ever since I've been wanting to stop in. Finally, I was on Valencia and could smell the delicious smell of fresh roasted coffee from a block away.
The first thing that struck me as I entered was the glow of Apple computers all over the cafe. This tells you the type of clientele and I suppose this can be a good thing or a bad thing depending on your affiliations. I assert that there is a  link between price of laptops being used and their coffee, but that's just a theory. Just be prepared to pay for what you get.  
Second, the cappuccino was heavenly. Strong espresso and thick cream artfully delivered. Even my non-coffee loving daughters "oo'ed" as it was served with heart in heart cream design. 
Finally, the seasonal espresso roast was so full of complex flavors that I spent a happy week analyzing every subtlety.  I am typically a dark roast fan but this medium roast was tremendous and made me feel I've been missing out. 
Mostly, this place made me feel like there is hope for coffee lovers in a Starbucks world. I'll be back.
author: Ken K.

description: My friend love the coffee here. I think it's okay, but I have to admit nice place in the city and the coffee is strong. Nice place to get coffee in San Francisco.
author: Leon C.

description:
hipsters, laptops(apple of course), pretentious locals...its not a formula i like too much
BUT
the lattes are the best thing i have ever tasted. their menu is diverse and i will subject myself to the cringe of it all just to savor the goodness of it.
author: Bee B.

description: It really is good coffee. I am a Starbucks fan usually...but this is a step up, more of a cultivated flavor. Caramel, salt with a little vanilla bean they boast- well yes indeed! It is always a good time on Valencia.
author: shelly m.

description:
Terrible service. I asked the mission hipster behind the counter if they have any whole milk so I can put a splash in my coffee. He replies, "we're in conservation mode, we only have one container left." What kind of service is that?

Never going back. The helpful staff at Four Barrels is getting my business.
author: H N.

description: Apple centric customers fill this hip coffee house.
author: Chad P.

description:
passable latte art.

baristettes are hardly cute. there was a hot one for a while but I don't know where she went. 

wifi sucks.

the location is blown out.

wtf is up with roasting on site? distracting.

calling it : good coffee has jumped the shark. I am going back to peets.

also: TERRIBLE PASTRIES.
author: Sean F.

description:
This place was so beautifully renovated to make a nice welcoming space. The espresso is okay, but what really makes me return to Ritual Roast is the cold process (I think that's what the barista called it) coffee. 
If you love the flavor of coffee, you must try it. It's amazing. The only drawbacks to RR are the long wait for coffee and the fact that there's no food other than sweets.
author: T O.

description:
Not the best latte you'll find in The City (ahem, Blue Bottle), but definately the prettiest. 
I do appreciate the detail they show for coffee. For example, all of their house coffee is from a French press and not drip. If coffee is a passion, you should be checking this place out. 
Thier pastry case has the same sweets every other coffe house has. It's a great spot for a meeting place. Ritual is clean and nicely furnished and a comfotable place to spend some time. Because of this, at night or on weekends it's often hard to even find a place to sit. People on laptops using the internet or playing computer games park in chairs for hours.
author: Jason D.

description:
They have the fanciest and most expensive coffee machine, but the coffee at Fayes Video is better! (Fayes is at 18th between Guerrero and Dolores). 

There are only sweet things to eat, so don't come for lunch.
author: Jacob L.

description:
This has become the cafe I head to on mornings like this one, when I feel the need to get out of the house.  The lattes are excellent, and beautiful--I almost don't want to stir sugar into the latte sitting in front of me, and ruin the mandala the baristas create with the crema.  Also, I like the open feel of the space, with lots of light pouring in from Valencia through the big windows.

The only downer is that this place is no secret.  It's a crapshoot as to whether there will be an open table most mornings.  It's also an amusing scene in some ways--right now I count about 15 people staring at laptops (with about an even breakdown between Mac and Windows machines, btw).

Update (3/28/2007): Just over a year later, I'm back on break, and so spending the occasional morning at a Mission coffeeshop.  This morning I'm back at Ritual.  The coffee is still great, but this place gets just a little too hectic.  I got here early this morning, so it wasn't an issue getting a table.  In fact, there's still plenty of open tables (8:30am now).  But I'm sure soon enough there will be people hovering, waiting to pounce on opening table.  The line is out the door onto the sidewalk right now, and most likely will be for the rest of the day.  

So I've retreated to mellower spots, like Progressive Grounds and Java Supreme...
author: Suman G.

description:
Great Coffee.  Great coffee.  (So good, I had to say it twice.)

And, although I just got my standard regular coffee with a crapload of sweet-n-low and skim milk (too cheap for a latte), I did see that the barrista was making little leaf shapes with skim milk on the tops of other peoples'.  That is truly a nice touch.

The downside?  The patrons, as with the actual barristas (the cashiers are pretty okay), are pretty snotty.  The place would be great if you're with a friend, but if you're by yourself, I would hope that you'd bring a book or get the coffee to go.  But, I suppose that's pretty on par for most coffee places here.
author: Hannah N.

description:
The high marks are primarily for the quality and taste of the lattes.  The atmosphere is a little peculiar.

The lattes:  The milk is the proper texture: Tiny Bubbles (Don Ho), and Hot (Gisele's Brazilian buddy, whats her name).  The barista's have a bit of flair, and zip.  I especially enjoy the various designs they can create.

Cappuccino: Never heard of a cappuccino "northwest style" (to me this appears to be a latte) BUT this is the standard method of delivery here.  So if you like em dry, you have to ask.  Northwest style??? I'm open minded and willing to learn.

The atmosphere:  I don't own an ibook/power book, I'm a PC guy, specifically IBM (no touch pad), so I feel woefully inadequate for this crowd.  I wish I could come to a place like this and work, but I try and get it all done Mon-Fri, and leave Sat for frolicking with the wife.   So don't plan on hanging out , this aint the place. . . most everyone here is glued to a computer screen . . . and everytime I have been in, seating seems to be at a premium ( I go only on Saturday, so that could likely be it).

Anyway,  well done.  Solid latte.
author: C M.

description:
I Want to preface this review by saying I don't drink coffee, which may make some of you ignore this review, but don't!
I love the atmosphere, I love the juices and teas and I love the free wireless internet even more. It's in a great part of the mission and is just an all around chill place that plays good music-- I recommend it.
author: Ashe M.

description:
I'm a firm believer that almost no cafe can make coffee as good as I make at home.  But today I was out of beans so I ventured into the mission to see if ritual lives up to its rep.

I ordered a single macchiato and my girlfriend got a small cup of coffee.  

The macchiato was delicious -- rich, strong, and smoky, not acidic at all.  The dollop of thick foam sat on top of about 3 cm of crema.

The house coffee, made in the exact same french press we use at home, was of equal caliber.  Even as an espresso drinker I could appreciate this cup -- not as 'watery' to me as most regular coffee is.

A lot of people comment on the hipster scene; I didn't sense it that much, but maybe it's because we were there at 9 AM, before they're all up.  :)
author: Phill W.

description:
Not much to add here...  Damn good coffee at the peak of the artform, great staff, but the seating is riddled with lots of hipster doofuses.

Get it to go and bask in its glory!

(BTW, if it weren't for the doofuses it would easily be a five star, and I don't think there is anything management can do about them since they shell out their $3 like the rest of us)
author: Brett M.

description:
Too hip, too cool, too trendy. I had read all about this place before going and these were the things I feared. After a half dozen reviews I had to go. I grabed a latte, sat on a couch and LOVED IT. 

The space is great, the coffee is excellent, and none of my fears have materialized. The coffe iws NOT bitter and brewed in samll batches. The lattes are a work of art for your eyes, nose and taste buds. 

The only bad part is that there's a line more often than not and tables can be hard to find. I hope this means they are making enough money to expand and add a Noe Valley location.  

(PS - If you like 'Geek Spotting' i have seen a couple of the techno-elite there.)
author: Kemp M.

description:
As I write this, I'm actually sitting down at Ritual.  And I've slowly but surely come to a singular conclusion: Ritual is the best coffee shop I've ever been to.  It is everything I've always wanted in a coffee shop. Places like this make me realize why I love San Francisco so much.  Although I could write a an essay on the virtues of this establishment, I'll keep this review brief, and list only a few of my favorite qualities:

1. The coffee.  I may only drink decaf, but I know a good cappuccino when I taste it, and Ritual makes the best I've ever had.  And check out the foam art!

2. The space.  Ritual is huge, full of tables, perfectly lit, and not overzealously decorated. While at first I disliked the scarcity of outlets, now I appreciate it for encouraging turnover of tables.

3. The people.  There are beautiful people everywhere here.  And most of them actually seem to be enjoying life, instead of worrying about being the saddest hipster at the coffee shop.

Don't let the hipsters fool you - Ritual blows away the competition.
author: jeremy f.

description:
A young entrepreneur invited me for a cup of coffee here. I had one of the best tasting chai here. Everyone here is young and cool, sporting their ibook. I was fortunate to find a table for the two of us. 

The place sure beats Starbucks or Peets for sure. There's definitely a young, cool vibe here.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
i love this place, the tiny cupcakes, and the super cute staff. Might try to make it my regular Saturday morning hangout. 

heart it.
author: rhiannon B.

description:
Coffee - fresh-roasted in house. Very light-bodied.  

Counter Help - up for debate. Between juggling the iPod playlist, talking to their friends, and trying to look cool, these "baristas" have little time for actually serving coffee.  Somehow they manage to move the line pretty fast.  Last time some commercial/movie/trendy docu-drama  was being shot in there. These are some industrious bitches. 

Scene - spartan but interesting decor. If you're a loner and like being glued to your Mac laptop, however,  this is your wet dream. BORING. Forget the hipster complaints. Is this a coffee shop or a satellite office of Apple?

**UPDATE** I was told by the baristas that they no longer import their roasted beans from Stumptown in Portland. THAT's why my coffee's been sucking lately. Their in-house roasts now taste very  light-bodied and too citrusy. Can't decide between coffee and orange juice this morning? Have a cup of Ritual's joe and you won't have to!  :(

Oh well, I'm still clutching my communist coffee mug at work.
author: BroSauce J.

description:
Ritual has the best logo for a coffee shop I've ever seen. Visually, it's one of the hottest coffee shops around SF. 

What kind of a review to you expect from a graphic designer?
author: Tim B.

description:
Automatic 3 stars for free wifi.
1 star for AMAZING coffee.

But this place is OVERFLOWING with digerati.  Who ISN'T blogging, or vlogging, or twittering, or yelping or playing Scrabulous on Facebook.

It's too crowded.
author: Kali D.

description:
I love Ritual! This is the only coffee place I've found in San Francisco that reminds me of my coffee places in Seattle, so it's very comforting for me. They have great coffee and pastry options (vegan things too!) and service is pretty fast considering there's always a pretty long line. 

Lots and lots of places to sit, I've never had trouble finding a table. And there's free wi-fi too. But beware if you've come here for a long day of work because there's no outlets to plug your computer into. I appreciate it because it keeps the tables turning over and I'm never here for more than a couple hours anyway.
author: Emily F.

description:
Ritual appears to be the most popular coffee spot in the area.  The line outside the door tells it all.  But, as much as I frequent here (I'm a block away), and this place should be most known for it's INCONSISTENCY.

I want a reliable espresso.  I don't get that here.
Mind you, once in a while, I get an AMAZING macchiato. 

Just be prepared for this experience:
Excited by the long line.
Irritated by the long wait after paying.
Disappointed by a bitter beverage. (Or if you're lucky, and the right barista is there, a really amazing one.)
author: Oren F.

description: I have just recently moved to the city and had a week off to explore all the coffee SF has to offer. Just like the name states, coffee here is a Ritual indeed. They offer traditional espresso drinks as well as crafting a selection of drip brewed coffee with amazing attention to water temperature, grind, and of course, the ritual of creating the most delicious cup of coffee I've had yet. I had a cup of the Esperanza w/ a little sugar and cream which in my opinion was tastier than most espresso drinks.
author: Eli S.

description: Ritual Coffee Roasters is composed of hipsters, Mac-toting geeks, Mac-toting hipster geeks, and really freakin' good coffee.   Many people hate the hipster/geek factor, and that's fine, but it's totally unreasonable to withhold stars for that reason.  It's like down-rating a donut place because donuts consist of empty calories and fat, or a high-end boutique because the clothing is expensive. If you're complaining about a variable that's integral to the business's identity, you're in the wrong place to begin with.
author: Janna M.

description: For serious coffee drinkers. For seriously, they bring in good coffee. You can tell by the smell of the beans that they are all for serving flavorful coffee. It's roasted light to medium (I personally like dark). It's a bit on the pricey side if you're used to the $2 Peets but each cup is worth what you pay. Their October Kenya is my favorite.
author: Vien T.

description: If you're into a $5 cup of coffee, then go on and do your thing. I spent $3 on a cup here today and it tasted really, really bad. If i'm gonna splurge like that, then I'm gonna go to Philz! The menu is printed all tiny and you only have a minute to look at it when it's your turn to order. I really wasn't bowled over, given all the hype around Ritual. There are zillions of other cafes on this street, so I'm not sure that I'll be back.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: I don't mind hipsters, I'm getting coffee in the mission, what were all you people expecting?? Sure it's a bummer when people hire them and they are bored with your order, but who cares... there's no way I'm docking this place it's rightful stars after that coffee and that latte...
author: Rhubarb M.

description: This place had a nice atmosphere and good coffee. My cappuccino was well made. I hear this place can have a line out the door but not on Thursday night. The coffee is a bit pricey to buy by the bag.
author: Eric G.

description:
I swear hands down this is the best coffee in the city. I love love love the cappuccinos here, they are flavorful but never bitter. It is truly an artform to brew an unbitter cup of coffee. And yes I believe this is way better than Blue Bottle. 

Good location close to bookstores, shopping, restaurants. perfect for people watching and taking a break on an afternoon. 

Be sure to take public transportation no parking in the area to speak of, but who really needs a car in the city anyways. The line can be long, but I think it's worth it.
author: ian m.

description: Great capps and coffee. LIttle too pricey for me, but I'll treat myself often. Not my ideal place to go and read/internet/etc though. One of the baristas, Kevin I think, is such a nice guy and always helpful.
author: Wes K.

description:
So add me to the list of people to say, "This is the best coffee I've ever had in my life and if I could sell my wife for another cup, I wouldn't, but I might consider  for a split-second."

Okay, here's the run-down. I usually drink double white mochas (not too sweet please), but they don't serve white mochas soo...  "It's cool. I'll have a medium latte." I'm not sure if the order was mine... "Triple shot small!" Probably someone else's I mistook for mine...

"Hey, babe. Taste it first and let me know what you think."

Her reply (with a sour face), "Wow, so bitter."

At this point I'm nervous, but willing to suffer my misfortune.  Sip.  Sip.  YUMMMMMMMMMMMM!!!!!  Oh my god. If it had ears I would be sexually harrassing the damn cup as if carressing it vigorously wasn't enough. "Babe, you can put the cup down now.  It's empty."

Shorty after I'm talking about politics in a drunken rage!!!  Paul Volcker?  Of the last bailout?

Alcides.
author: Alcides G.

description:
Dragged here by friends, I stepped inside, even though it was against my better judgement.

Then I realized the fable that best describes Ritual...

THE  EMPEROR  WEARS NO CLOTHES

It's simple really... everyone has varying degrees of immunity to crypto-fascist mind control techniques. And that's really the one useful aspect of RItual's horrid existence - you can use it as an immunity test...let us begin.

If you are somewhat immune to crypto-fascist mind control techniques, then you can experience clearly that the coffee is AWFUL. it's bitter and disgusting and rips through your stomach like battery acid. You also can experience clearly that it's not worth waiting 17 minutes (yes, SEVENTEEN MINUTES) for aforementioned AWFUL coffee. You can experience clearly that the pastry cases are not kept clean and are often full of flies.
