[Speaking of clear experiences, as I was waiting the seventeen minutes for the usual ugly bitter-as-fuck espresso; I witnessed the barista chatting with her friend while making him a cappucino... fair enough... but he didn't like the cappucino! ... so she remade it for him - aw isnt that nice? but ...oh no! he didnt like it AGAIN...so she remade it AGAIN... and not just a third time, but a fourth, a fifth.. and mind-bogglingly a SIXTH TIME  before he approved ... all of this while a crowd of people are waiting for their fucking coffee.. until FINALLY someone came over and started making the fucking drinks.... it's called ESPRESSO for a reason you morons!.. anyways, back to our test...]

If you are NOT immune to crypto-fascist mind control techniques, then you think Ritual has great coffee, great service, and that it's the place to be...
author: Currently A.

description:
I am one of the 6am crew. So there is no line.

The best cappoccino I have had anywhere.

Pastries also excellent.

Delish.
author: Colman S.

description: Great spot to enjoy your favorite, single origin bean roast, while working away on the free wifi network.  They have plenty of seating, and a nice communal table in the rear if you're feeling adventurous, or just creeping.  I enjoyed the finger puppet paintings, and was pleasantly surprised by the vegan snack offerings! Stop by Ritual if you're feelin' revolutionary, or you just want to wait in a really long line for a cup of coffee.
author: David M.

description:
Havn't been in awhile.... So, now their new pastries are 1/2 the size and same price !?!  And after repeating order 3 times, i got home and opened pastry bag with wrong item in it :/

It will be another long while before i'll be back!
author: Eli J.

description:
Very good coffee, very good espresso drinks - and not the longest wait for coffee in SF.  So, if this is all there were to a coffee place, then we'd be at 4.5 stars. 

The espresso drinks are well done and arrive as quickly as can be expected (a line is a line, and if its crowded, there will be a looong wait.). The mocha is exceptionally good if you like a less-sweet chocolate balance.The filtered coffees take forever...yes you can watch the slow, methodical approach they take, stirring each filtered batch as they pour...and hope none of the espresso drinkers slip around you and take the last seat...   So to recap: espresso drinks very good, filtered coffee very good, the wait can be a drag.  

UPDATE:  I wrote a review about a year or so ago, that complained about how dark the place was in the back and how this, combined with the bright street light, made it pretty unpleasant to sit and work.   BUT the interior space is much changed now (2013)...its brighter, with better lighting, and overall much less bright/dark contrast..(i obsess a little over this because I think space and design have a lot to do with how enjoyable a place can be..).  So, well, I'll keep the old rant here, just so i can come back and admire my own writing from time to time, but i do feel that the Ritual people have taken steps to really improve the space, and i for one, appreciate the changes..  

Original, now-out-of-date rant:  "If you choose to stay, and are particular about the atmosphere and space wherein you drink your over-priced cup of Joe, then this place drops a full 2 stars. What works about it is that overall, its a fairly relaxed atmosphere...and overall that is a very good thing when drinking a cup, in my opinion.  Is the atmosphere pretentious? Not really..but the space, furniture and lighting are not expertly thought out and kind of a drag now that I think on it...because for a place that celebrates the ritual of coffee making, and coffee flavor, they should pay attention to the experience of sitting in the space and drinking the stuff.  Am I mad about this? - a little, yes I am.  Design and space is important.  So I'm just saying that the space, lighting and furniture, taken together, fall flat.  There is one big wooden table which is cool...that's it...and the individual tables, as actual single-stem wooden-topped tables are fine...what doesn't work: the really dark and light walls, against the bright glare of the street-side window is actually disconcerting if you are in the darker, back half of the place.   Combine these high-contrast light-levels with a computer screen and its kind of stressful.  The eye can't adjust to stark differences in light like this.  This is basic design lighting 101 - cut down the glare, even-out the the contrasts or the eye will be stressed and lose details.  Try sitting in the back and looking towards someone in the front - you feel like a Chilean miner emerging from the pit.  Also, everyone in the place is on a laptop, so one would think the place had enough outlets...it doesn't.  They should just go on Angie's list, get an electrical contractor and add a circuit with 3 outlets...why is that not important to the owners?  Everyone during the day seems to be diligently working...one wall has zero outlets, but 3 tables, and the middle tables are out of luck.   Its not trivial if you want to utilize the flow of electrons to run your machine called a computer...as you move towards the back, where about 15 patrons usually sit, the whole space is just...blah...there's a couch, with a half-sized table sort of in front of it, and the open back door makes the space feel like a forgotten back porch that dad will get around to fixing up once the kids are grown.  So, the space falls pretty flat, and takes away from the experience, rather than creating, enhancing, supporting the experience of drinking coffee."
author: Andrew D.

description: Absolutely DO NOT get their iced mochas... bleah. Worst mocha I've ever had More water than mocha. That being said, if you're a coffee lover (aka you like it black), come here. That's why I'm not giving this place one star, because the coffee (which you're supposed to get here and not a mocha) is really good. I didn't get it because I'm not a coffee lover but my boyfriend is. Not a great place for studying unless you know their music (i.e. Radiohead if you're lucky) and then it can fade into background noise. Usually pretty busy. If you like your coffee black, go there.
author: Robin J.

description:
The coffee is excellent, the service comes with too much "I am cooler than you" attitude.  Twice I have overheard their staff talk trash about customers who just sat down and were out of range.  Just seems rude.  I am sure they have a lot of friendly staff, but it seems that it is in their nature to not smile that much.

Cool venue though.
author: Jon S.

description:
I generally don't go coffee house-hopping as a rule of thumb but the neat pseudo-communism graphics they display all over piqued my interest. I've now become a weekend regular and love-love-love the soy-chai latte's and green tea's. I also have a big crush on one the baristos, but he doesn't know that. The owner, Jeremy is super nice and so is his lady friend and gaggle of coffee wizards.  This is definitely the best coffeehouse in the city if not my favorite.

EDIT: I don't like coming here anymore.  This coffee shop was very cozy, comfortable and cool in the beginning.  Now it is crowded beyond the fire marshall's belief and I have begun to feel as if they would rather I get my coffee and go.  I don't go to Ritual at all except to say hi to my barista friend who works there. It's sad that it had to get so popular but such is the way of all things awesome.
author: Kate S.

description:
I stopped by this happening coffee joint to kill some time, and found in it a new hang-out spot in the Mission. The number of coffees and teas offers the usual suspects the usual drinks, but the teas list also includes little gems like blueberry rooibos tea (which I happily sipped). The chocolate chip cookie was fresh and soft, and quite the hot ticket on my thursday evening jaunt. 
With atmosphere and pleasant drinks this spot should be hit up often...
author: Mitchell W.

description:
Ritual is probably the best cappucino I've found in San Francisco, and after moving here from Seattle, I've been looking pretty hard.  They clearly take their espresso drinks very seriously, with a rich, flavorful espresso and perfectly textured milk.  
Although they're excellent at what they do, they're missing a few tihngs:
- No syrup flavorings.  I don't really mind, as their cappucino is sweet enough on its own, but sometimes you just need a little flava.
- No cocoa.  Same issue as above - their coffee doesn't need it, but it would be nice to have the choice.
- No good pastries.  I've only tried their cinnamon roll and their chocolate croissant.  The cinnamon roll was almost inedible; the chocolate croissant was Ok, but it tasted supiciously like the croissants at Starbucks.

It's hard to complain too much, though - I go to a coffee place to get coffee, and they do that incredibly well.  Yes, it's gotten crowded, but they handle the crowds very well, and I've never had to wait more than a few minutes for coffee (unlike the 15+ minute wait at Blue Bottle).
author: John H.

description:
I love Ritual for many reasons. First of all its an important part of my exercise routine. Since I live in Soma, the walk is LONG (okay maybe not that long...but lets pretend that I have to trudge miles and miles through the fog..) and dare I mention all the window shopping I do along the way? 

But at the end of the walk lies my reward of the yummiest breve latte around....served up by a stylin' barista who can manage to make the foam resemble a leaf pattern. How good does that get?? The taste is consistent the same every time, and itsn't that what you want from your coffee?

Secondly, there are loads of pretty people to look at and as an avid people watcher, there is no end of drama, shenanigans and the like at Ritual...People work here, chat here, socialize...the music is great and you can just sit back, do homework...read...slouch or whatever. It like your living room away from home.

Just make sure that you always get a "to go" cup because guaranteed you won't find a seat. I've come here in the middle of the week before during work hours and its still packed like sardines in a tin. 

Clearly, this is the beating heart of the neighborhood. And that's why I come here.
author: Nickee M.

description:
As far as coffee goes it's brilliant. So yeah, on the weekend there's a line and that can be kind of irritating at times. But honestly I'd rather wait in line for 5 min. than wait an hour to sit down to brunch.  I guess you now know that coffee is more important to me than food. 

Living in the mission I know that on the weekends I get my coffee to go and on weeknights I can always find somewhere to sit. The staff is great and the people are generally nice and let you share a table with them if you ask.
author: Melissa R.

description:
I've been looking for a coffee house that similar with this one coffee house back in Chicago and glad to say that I found it! It's such a relief their coffee is awesome too! They really know how to make a good cappuccino and not all coffee house know how to make one, unfortunately. 

The desserts and pastries are yum! It's always good to get something to snack with your coffee =) 

Feel free to bring your laptop and internet is free. The crowd is young and hip. Make sure you put on your indie rocker gear before you come here.
author: Perry S.

description:
Giving Stars for coffee...( not for ambiance )....coffee....I don't go there often....no reason....maybe cause it feels like school cafeteria....
the atmosphere and the staff seemed somewhat pretetious but if you and your  friends want some good coffee, it's a good place to go...
it's always crowded....so don't go there with a group unless you're planning to drink outside.....I suppose it's very lap top friendly....
author: Alex W.

description:
I can't get enough of the small cappucinos.  The art of pouring the frothed milk and espresso which yielded an image of a leave made you think that $$$$bucks is mediocre (waste of your bucks).

Good graphic as the logo - smart move tilting the cup and  a star as if this were made from some communist country, bravo!
author: gado.gado D.

description:
This place is pretty rad.
I would think it would be hard to hate on this place, but some people are pretty determined to be unhappy.

The fact is, the french press coffee is killer and I can't find a stronger espresso anywhere... 
except in this place called Banana in Isla Verde, Puerto Rico (A shot at 6pm kept me up long enough to go jogging on the beach at sunrise!).

Love the scene or hate it, the coffee is still amazing.
You have to give it credit there.
author: Daniel J.

description:
Atmosphere is great if you get there early. You won't have to wait in line or wait for a chair to open up. If you do get here late, prepare for a long line. It does move fast, but I prefer to avoid them.

All the coffee here is absolutely fantastic. Of all the places in San Francisco, this is number one for me with Blue Bottle running a close second and Caffe Trieste in third. I used to like Philz coffee, but the spices they roast and brew into their coffee are too much of a gut wrencher to have every weekend.

onwards...

The espressos here have a deep, deep flavor. Each little shot has a rich, thick layer of "crme" on top. A plain cup o' joe is quite good. I never get stomach aches or the jitters from their coffee. The soy cappuccinos are also very smooth and tasty. The puffed soy gives the top a nice silky finish.

Lastly, I really like the servings here. Very European. IMHO I don't think anyone needs a "supersized" coffee drink.
author: Mike S.

description:
Aside from the lines being long, the coffee is prepared the best way possible; French pressed. You read right. All drip coffee served at Ritual is French pressed to get all of the flavor out of the beans. You'll get a little coffee sludge on the bottom, but it's easy to ignore.

The atmosphere is a buzz with hipsters and the like chatting over coffee, checking email on a laptop, or just hanging out. Parking is a little hard being that it's kind of near the Mission.
author: D M.

description:
Ritual coffee roasters is one of the FEW places in San Francisco that gets coffee right.

*They source the best beans, all of which are remain single origin up to the point of sale.
*All of their beans are roasted by Ritual and sold fresh.  They can tell you the roast date on any of their selection
*Their espresso drinks are made proper.  The baristas pull the shots into heated porcelain cups and steam the milk per drink

My favorite roast of theirs right now is the Brazilian Sao Joao.  I made some of this for my parents, who are "International Delights" kind of coffee drinkers.  They were hesitant, but surprised that they were able to drink it black and still enjoy it.  When you have good coffee, you don't need to add to it.

Ritual Roasters is simply great.
author: Shea G.

description:
no complaints here. not a one. 

+ amazing consistent coffee 

+ pricey but worth it coffee beans in let's face it, the cutest/coolest dang coffee bags around

+ friendly staff

+ ample seating

+ good tunes

+ super yummy pastry stuff if you're hungry, I highly suggest the mini horchata cupcakes (I die).

still contemplating purchasing one of their new $10 tote bags which are ridiculously cute and feature the state of california. we have way too many totes as is, but man are they cute!
author: Callie K.

description: Some kick ass people making super tasty coffee. I appreciate their ever evolving single origin espresso and the dedication to staying true to the bean.
author: Lauren D.

description: This place is great!  I don't get to the Mission often but when I do, this is always a worthy stop.  They've renovated the interior and now there's more seating. A great place got better!
author: Anthony L.

description: I am always amazed at how awesome the staff is at Ritual.  The coffee is amazing - DUH - and their patience is what makes the out-the-door line at 9-10 AM on a Sunday bearable.  Thank you Ritual - you give me a vegan donut, a subtle smile, calm demeanor, and an incredible latte every time.
author: Lita F.

description: Other than Farleys in Portrero Hill district, and possibly Blue Bottle, coffee just doesn't get better than with Ritual. Smooth, smooth, smooth. We love it. They have also vastly improved their eats here too. All tasty and fresh throughout the day.
author: Artina M.

description: 4.5 points for the coffee.  Subtract 1.5 points because the clientele make me feel uncomfortable for not having a powerbook.
author: Floyd F.

description: Just moved back to SF and although ALL the power cables are gone, this place still rocks...need to get a backup battery now :)
author: Tony A.

description:
My brother lives right around the corner from Ritual Coffee Roasters, and it was the first of my 3 coffee stops this weekend.  My intent was to sample coffees from well-regarded coffee establishments that roast their own beans and prepare individual drip coffees. 

PROS:  Of the three, I liked Ritual's aesthetic the most and its coffee.  While, I didn't spend much time in the establishment, it felt large and spacious, and its decor was simple.  The red and black colors were a nice visual splash that played well off the wood.  The coffee I tried (I forget the name) was excellent, and I would return to sample more.  I love the individually dripped cups o' coffee; even just being able to watch your cup being made makes it that much more special.  Also, at Ritual, the barista was quick with my cup; I wasn't waiting an eternity like at Blue Bottle.  Also, unlike Blue Bottle, they offered sugar and all sugar substitutes, as well as different milks/half and half/etc.  Finally, the area where all of those materials were situated was wonderfully clean, which shows a level of professionalism.  I hate coffee chops were splashes of milk drops litter the counter, sugar's been scattered about like cokeheads OD'd in their powder, and scraps of Splenda packets or used stirrers lay littered about.  Ritual had none of this.  Well done!

CONS:  Overpriced like every other place.  $2.50 was the cheapest and they went up to ridiculous prices like $4 and $5 dollars.  Does my coffee come with a happy ending or something?  It had better for those prices.

Still, I'm glad I came.  Other than the price, this is a wonderful coffee shop.
author: Brendan Jude L.

description:
NO WORKING POWER OUTLETS.

Decent espresso, but no working power outlets for laptops.

This is bullshit
author: john s.

description: Still so good but now that they've switched to the individual drip coffees I can't afford to go as often. $3-4.25 for a cup! that hurts!
author: Mission S.

description: This place sucks. Their coffee sucks. Was at the street food festival that La Cocina put on and got to listen to their drunk obnoxious hipster staff with egos be lame.  Whatever, go to blue bottle or four barrel. Next time I go by this place I'm taking a dump out front.
author: Mike R.

description: Great coffee, cool vibe. The latte is especially good.
author: Tuhin S.

description:
This Mission hang-out services a high volume of both drop-in coffee lovers and mac-obsessed loiters.  The vanilla icing on the $1 mini cupcakes rival that of NY's Magnolia bakery and can be scarfed down at the check-out counter they're so good!  

The rotating artwork paired with artistically hung (track-lighting esque) lightblubs illuminate the coffee shop just perfectly.  If you're in the mood for some creative computing or just hanging out reading a book.. this is a perfect Mission hot spot.
author: Jenny C.

description:
It's not about the coffee. Yes, the coffee is alright, but coffee is coffee is coffee. It's about the environ, the vibe, the music, the people around you, and the feeling it stirs up inside you. It plays the best music bar none in all the coffee shops I have visited of late. Reminds me of the happy college days I spent in Minneapolis' coffee shops. 

The only downside is its deliberate lack of power sockets. Well, maybe that's why we managed to find a table Saturday afternoon.
author: Manch H.

description:
The most beautiful latte art! They use Clover organic milk, which makes their lattes send you up in a cloud-nine experience! Creamy and rich decadent lattes! I've also had a Cup of Excellence award-winning coffee made from a Clover (different company from the dairy) machine, which was brilliant. Those Clover machines really do make very flavorful coffee!

Ritual Roasters' atmosphere is great. Huge place with high ceilings. Spacious tables with a coffee table area in the back.
author: Daisuke K.

description:
I give it 4 starts because the coffee here is actually quite good.

The scene is young and Mission through and through. The typical uniform: Vans slip ons, one gear bikes, lock in back pocket, skinny jeans, anything retro 80s, some type of hat, and a generally scruffy, I am a starving artist type of chic.

The staff are quite a cast of characters. They do take themselves way too seriously and have a bit of a holier than thou attitude towards customers.
author: Spoon G.

description:
I go every morning.  Their cappucinos are amazing and their macchiatos are impeccable.  They roast their own "Red Flag Espresso" which is really good, and they use organic milk - you can taste the difference.  As someone who barista'd in both commercial and home settings, I can tell you that the milk makes a difference.  

To everyone that bitches that there are too many hipsters here, I remind you that you are calling the clientele hip, and therefore excluding yourself from that category.  Which is fine.  And like any other place, it takes time to get amazing service when the staff sees a thousand faces a day.  I've been going for about a year now, and most of the baristas know my name and when its slow they bring me my cappucino.  Nick and Drew are quite possibly the most positive people I have ever met.  The owner is more than happy to chat it up and she is a testament to the success of young people everywhere (don't worry, you'll get that NYTimes spread someday).  I love the art installations and there is always some great eye candy.  Put it to you this way: I consider the distance to Ritual in my current appartment hunting.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description:
i give it 3 stars because of the ok service, odd tasting espresso, and the treats.
the service is kinda like you get what you get. 
the espresso is really odd, nothing i've tasted before. its not good , but not bad also.
the treats are the best at ritual. vegan breads and vegan donuts are awesome. comfort food without the guilt. awesome!
author: Jeorge J.

description:
While I love coffee, I'm definitely no connoisseur. Even so, my novice palette can taste a difference between the coffee here and my normal brew. I've had french pressed coffee and a latte here and both have been great. I also had a piece of the ginger bread, and it was incredible. Try that out!

I don't get the impression that many below do that it's super hipster, but maybe that's because when I've been here it's been pretty early. It's true that even early the line is out the door!

Also of note are their nice, clean bathrooms.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Okay, so I don't drink coffee. 
*dodges flying, caffeinated invectives*
That aside, I really liked this place. I visited on a trip to SF with a friend who swears by this place, as well as a certain counterboy...
I had a chai latte that was neither too chai bitter nor too latte milky. It also wasn't too sweet, a boon in my tea-drinking world. I also got two amazing cupcakes, one vanilla with chocolate frosting and one perfect vanilla with pink strawberry frosting. I savored them slowly and now I am very sad that they are gone and that I am no longer is SF...oh Ritual cupcake, coffee-free though you were, you helped to make my world a better place.
author: Rachel G.

description: By far the best capuchinno I've ever had.  By far.  Love the smell.  The sense of community.  I'll be back, the next time I'm in SF
author: Eric K.

description: What a wonderful place for coffee. This is a place where taste meets style meets passion. Great open atmosphere. Deliciously prepared coffee. Free wireless. Every time I come here, I ask myself why don't I come here more often. Well - when there is room to sit down. Be prepared for a line of 5-10 people. But it goes fast.
author: Rick V.

description: good coffee, friendly staff, and it's always a good place to come and study. :)
author: Sabrina W.

description: Ritual simply struck me on one note. It was pretty weak and extremely bitter. I used more sugar than I ever had, and in the end, it just tasted a slight bit less bitter, and a slight bit more watery. The caffeine quantity was awesome, and the longer I sipped the cup, the more I enjoyed the flavor, but all in all, I'll go somewhere else for my cup of joe.
author: Shannon F.

description: Whenever I'm in this part of the city I make it a point to stop by this cafe. The coffee is really well done. It's not bitter or overpowering. I got a simple late and it was really delicious. The Barista whipped up a little bit of foam art on the top of my drink depicting a heart that actually remained intact till i finished the drink. With my drink I also had another well balanced mocha/cherry bundt cake and peanut butter cookie. They weren't too sweet and both had  been baked to the level that their consistency went perfectly with a coffee. I received great service from the barista, very friendly, a little timid but overall very helpful. On one downside their was a one female employee that made my guest with me feel bad for asking where the bathroom was. Aside from that it was a great visit. I will continue to come here for the fantastic coffee.
author: Andrew J.

description: Good drip and espresso, and better space, seating and ambiance than a lot of cafes I've seen in city's. However, most roasts seem a bit unusually sharp and citriousy for my taste and there's a tiny bit of a lofty aire when it comes to service. Would happily come back if in the area.
author: Royce R.

description: Commie Coffee... GREAT coffee, nice people.  a little too hipster to hang at, but a great mission coffee-to-go for sure.  nice that they train other shops selling their coffee how to brew it right.  but enough of that soviet iconography already.  let it die.
author: Chad W.

description: I came here last night because I wanted to take my espresso loving dad to get some really good quality coffee. I have taken him to Blue Bottle and he's obsessed with it.  I tried to take him to four barrel, but it was closed so we came here.  Unfortunately, neither of us were very impressed.  The espresso was bitter and not very enjoyable.  Also, this place seems to be a lot more expensive than those two previously mentioned places and not as good.  Maybe we just caught them on an off night.
author: Aaron L.

description:
My friends seem to be divided between those that want coffee from Ritual and those that want it from Blue Bottle. Really I can't tell the difference between the two. Maybe my tongue is dumb. (It's not the first time I've come to that conclusion-- right STJ?) Both seem exceptional to me. 

Since Ritual is closer to my house I go there more often. It's one of the few places where I don't mind tipping someone for pouring me a cup of coffee; of course it helps that the staff members are both genuinely nice and attractive. Except for that one... You know who you are.

Even if you don't have a PowerBook and aren't a fan of the scenester environment Ritual seems to foster, you can still get a cup to go of some of the finest coffee SF has to offer.
author: Eric B.

description:
This is the best coffee in SF.  It also features nice decor and surprisingly friendly staff.  With hipster credentials like this, I'd expect some snotty attitudes, but everyone they are always friendly.

The coffee is stong and has a lot of flavor.   Good espresso drinks too.  Even the decaf is good!
author: sam p.

description:
Hipe vibe, gets a little trendy in my opinion but every happening place does. With that said, the best Double Americano I have had.

I revise this post as the place is too trendy, and too loud to think. Where are the chill coffee shops...
author: Eric T.

description:
This place drives me crazy. Why is it so hard for coffee shops to be all around great? 
Good pastries, good coffee, nice baristas, and a comfortable environment where you may want to sit and drink coffee?
This place misses the last two. The baristas are generally kinda snobby,  and I feel like they are more into hanging out with each other than actually taking my order to make coffee.
Otherwise, damn good coffee and even vegan pastries. Typically I feel like I have to go in with a friend who feels my pain, so we can make quick getaways.
Oh and I typically don't like the art on the walls. Phew. That's it. 
It's got good coffee, but mostly too much hype.
author: Sarah M.

description:
They have excellent coffee, free wireless, and honestly, it's the Mission runway.  Love it or leave it, people.

PLEASE stop with all of the complaints about the baristas, the hipsters, the laptop users, and the endless comparisons to Blue Bottle.

Of course there will be hipster customers / baristas*.  It's the Mission.
Of course there will be scores of laptop folk.  They have free wireless.
Of course there is some better coffee in existence.  Preference is subjective, remember?
Of course the baristas will not always behave as if it is their life's mission to caffeinate you.  Get over yourself.

*Identifying employees by name and description in reviews is UGLY, UGLY business.  What is wrong with you Yelpers, seriously (eg. Nizaria D. and O L.)?  You should be ashamed of yourselves.

And no, I don't work there.  I'm just holding the mirror up.  Scary, isn't it?
author: InflatedSenseOfSelf U.

description:
They have a La Marzocco GB-5 witch is my second favorite machine next to the Mistral, just cuz it looks like a UFO! 
No but they have a good espresso here, they use a really strong African blend with great undertones for their espresso, it's great with a 12oz latte or just by it's self. However I must say that personally I am on the side of more south American blends, dark lower-toned stuff then what they pull here.  None the less the barista knew her shit and pulled a great shots with perfect crema! She had some latte art skill two throwing down some great hearts and Rosetta's props!
author: David P.

description:
My main goal is to find a good place to work from, hence I rate my establishments based on wifi connectivity, comfort and laptop friendliness.

The place itself is pretty lively, there seems to be a fair amount of traffic going in and out always. That's probably a good sign in regards to the quality of their coffee but its not so good if you are trying to get work done and want a little bit of a more quiet environment.

The biggest issue is that they don't have any power outlets so you can only be there for as long as you have battery power which in my case is about ten minutes these days. 

There is a lot of seating though and I would recommend this place if you really just want to hang out and people watch.
author: Krishnan S.

description: Sterile atmosphere during the day, everyone plugged into laptops. Espresso was good, but their idea of a single shot is the small, European size serving, so consider yourself warned.
author: Sam Z.

description:
4 stars for the nice coffee.
knocking off one star because the wifi is slow, gets really cold or hot, not so friendly staff, loong lines
author: Sri S.

description: Good tasting coffee.  Really crummy attitude with the service.  I tried Ritual Coffee many times, hoping that the service would improve.  Now I will not go there. Who needs a dose of arrogance and a crappy attitude with a cup of coffee?
author: T H.

description: This seems like a cool fun place to hang out and I would've liked to hang around for a bit and join the crazy amount of other mac users in this place, but I was w/ a group of friends and we were on our way somewhere else.  We took our coffees to go but in my opinion, it took longer than it should have to get that to go coffee.  There were 2 or 3 people behind he counter, no one else in line behind our group, and we only ordered 3 cups of coffee.  It still took over 10mins (or felt like it did) to get our drinks.  I'll give Ritual the benefit of the doubt since it seems like a hip place to be and it was fairly crowded.  At least the cashier was very helpful and friendly in helping us choose the right blend!
author: Tracy N.

description: Good place to hangout, hi-speed wifi with delicious hot chocolate.
author: Gercek K.

description: Unbelievably the best coffee I've EVER tasted and I've been drinking for years!  It was a first sip sensation that so delightful.  Smooth and very well rounded.  I actually had it at a restaurant.  Guess I'll call them to find out which one they serve.  I'm new to Ritual Coffee fan!.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Great AMERICANO. It's smooth and the bitterness is just right.

But honestly, I'm not a huge coffee drinker and I've only had "bad" coffee a few times.

I give it four stars for the super creative logo and the cool decor inside. To me, coffee has to come with the experience at the shop as well. 

I hope no one breaks into the shop at night to steal all the money on the wall though.
author: Kelly G.

description:
If you're in the Mission or if you aren't but - you just spent 20 minutes and $15 worth of hair product to look like you didn't comb your hair - then Ritual Roasters is for you.  The proverbial hipster cafe, RR serves a great cup of coffee and has good pastries, muffins, etc.  

An independent coffee house that roasts its own beans, RR takes coffee seriously - black coffee is served from a press pot and is not kept on a burner.  The upside:  you get a good tasting cup of coffee (i.e., not that burnt stuff from high-throughput coffee shops).  The downside (and it's a good down side):  you may have to wait two or three minutes while they refresh the pot.  Espresso drinks are made with love and are delicious.  If, however, you are looking for that tall nonfat extra hot no foam mocha pumpkin latte, you may want to go elsewhere.

The environment is friendly; the walls are covered with indie art; the music is fresh; and there are many t-shirts with ironic sayings to review.

On weekends, the outlets are covered to avoid long time computer squatters, which creates a lively community-oriented environment.  On weekdays, you'll find a multitude of iBooks with oh so down and out Mission-ites managing their iTunes Library.  

Come for the coffee or the decor, stay to swap that rare Japanese import that had limited pressings and is no longer available on line.  Ritual Roasters is a great neighborhood coffee shop.
author: Paul D.

description:
Lights, Cameras, Ritual!  This is *the* place where all the Mission hipsters have their cup of brew.  A color variety of people all looking for their inner groove while sipping the wonderful selection of teas and coffees.

On the weekdays, you might find yourself sitting next to an up-and-coming dot.com millionaire pounding away on the next big thing on his/her laptop.  Come the weekend, you'll be soaking up the hip social scene along with your java.  

Note: Free WiFi is available, but power plugs are closed/covered on the weekends.  Bring extra batteries!

Either way, prepare for a wait.  Watch out for long lines on the weekend and nights. Coffee perfection takes time and the friendly staff doesn't push your caffeine elixir like your local Starbucks.  Relax and enjoy the rotating art collection on display.
author: Karl W.

description:
I could drink mocha after mocha here while chatting with an old friend and indulging in one of their cupcakes!  YUM!!  

Wish there was a little more seating though.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Every time I visit ritual i feel severely out of place without a laptop. They litter all of the table tops as if it were the entry ticket to this bustling mission cafe. 

As a solo kaffehaus goer I can usually find a spot and hog a table after a short wait. Sometimes, If the stars have alligned themselves in my favor, I can snag one of the comfy chairs. (oh, how comfy they really are!) There are a few of these, along with couches.. Odds are, if you are determined, you can swoop in hawk like after one has been vacated. You must though be able to sprint with a full french bowl of joe in your grip..

SO..My time spent there is usually blissful, sans laptop, avec moleskin, the pounding beats of the bercool barista dj's shrieking loudly in the backround. Nice when it's rainy, you know?
author: L S.

description:
Five starts for what counts -- really good coffee. They go the extra mile to make it special. If Yelp did halves I'd give them 4.5 for coming in second to Blue Bottle, but that's not worth a whole star.

Ritual deserves another 5 stars for inspiring this hilarious reviews page where Mission's hipsters express their utter loathing for each other. If you don't like pretentious attitude, what are you doing in the Mission? Not that I even really see it. Perhaps you have to come during work hours.

It's possible there is the odd twerp on staff, but I've always gotten good friendly help. Which is saying something in a packed and popular place. Excellent coffee made with care, and lots of seating space. Good on Ritual!
author: Rainbucket B.

description:
I used to go to Ritual all the time, but stopped a couple years ago because the regular coffee which used to taste amazing started to become watery crap. Maybe it's gotten better since then, but I'm not that curious to try it out any more since:

 - the atmosphere of a few dozen people glowing in front of their laptops sucks
 - the staff take hipster elitism to a new level. A couple of staffers were sweet and cool while most would be obviously annoyed at my request for basic coffee and even gave me dirty looks for cashing in a fully punched card

The espresso drinks did rock my world, I can't deny that, but I'm just hooked on the basic stuff and now I get my fix elsewhere.
author: Ed L.

description:
The space is cool but really, it should be about the coffee.

My choice of joe has always been Americanos which is basically watered down espressos and should always be served hot (unless otherwise requested as an ICED Americano).   So I've seen the line stretch out the door which is proof of their popularity but also of  their slooooow service.  So more than once I've had my Americano be served luke warm.  I'm guessing they allow the hot water to sit until they get to making and unloading the shots for my coffee.  Bad thing.  I've also seen others complain about the temperature of their caffeinated beverage choice and asking the coffee maker to remake a HOT one  for her customers.
author: Yippidie Y.

description:
For their little cappuccinos and always being "on the way" to somewhere I'm heading to run errands. 

Yeah, the wait can be a pain - but even when I'm in a rush, what's the rush?  You want fast? Go to McDonalds. You want good? Come here
author: Jen A.

description: Yeah, that's some hipster vibe going on in there, but that clover coffee was really great. I love coffee that's so thick it leaves major stains on the sides and is basically grit at the bottom (which I drank). Little slow but worth the wait.
author: Jen D.

description: I make it my RITUAL, to drink their coffee-fay. When I'm not ritualistically sacrificing my peruvian goats, I'm chugging back the brown stuff at Habitual Coughee Toasters. You'll be french PRESSED to find a better cup of coffee at this address. The cost is equivalent to a long night with a short Mongolian mud-princess, (very seasonable) and the taste is thick and viscous with the tears of LDC laborers... wait, those are my tears.
author: Josh K.

description: I came here for the first time last night with my friend Lauren who loves their coffee.  I'm not exactly a coffee aficionado, more of a tea person but I like to get coffee when I'm with someone.  Maybe it was because I was w/ a Ritual Coffee regular or maybe they're just nice but the guy at the counter did not make me feel uncomfortable about my lack of coffee drinking/knowledge and made me a lovely cup of coffee.  I really like the layout of the space and unique and interesting artwork, I will definitely be back!
author: Suzanne V.

description: Somewhere in the Mission, there's a mustachioed barista practicing his pretension in the shiny reflection of a clover machine.
author: Amy Z.

description: Great coffee. They play the worst fucking music though. At levels which are enraging. Surly staff, snobby patronage. It's San Francisco after all.
author: Malcolm W.

description: Lines out the door. Hip and edgy vibe. And they make cool designs with their perfectly frothed milk (from Clover) and perfectly roasted beans. So delicious!
author: Natalie S.

description: Big fan of their lattes and the actual spot. Nice, clean place -for the most part.
author: Tania C.

description: I went to Ritual to get some coffee and do some emergency work on my laptop. Once I got to my seat I noticed that all the power outlets were covered up. WTF? If this place doesn't have power and couldn't use my laptop,  I might as well go to Four Barrel where it's at least nicer inside. And off I went.
author: Dave B.

description: Expensive, noisy and a bit too try to be trendy. If you want to feel like you're in an 'in' scene, this is the place. Their camomille tea is different and good.
author: Emmanuella A.

description: This place is great! Not quite the quality that one might find at Intelligentsia, but almost. It's a nice, friendly place and the coffee is complex and different. This ain't Starbucks! Thank goodness!
author: Ana A.

description: I appreciate that these people take their coffee seriously.  Their beans are roasted in-house from excellent sources in South and Central America, and Africa.  Both the drip coffee and espresso drinks are carefully and meticulously crafted to evoke the best characteristics of the beans.  The latter are done with an artistic twist in the foam, which I personally appreciate.  The employees are always friendly and willing to recommend a particular brew or pastry.  Try the vegan donuts.
author: Victor R.

description: If you want Mission malcontent attitude and people who get annoyed when you ask for more half/half then this place is for you.....I dont care if its good coffee,a friendly welcome would go along way......
author: james m.

description: Plain coffee is a little expensive. Limited seating. VEGAN DONUTS! They roast their own beans, so that is cool!
author: Tim M.

description: Having worked at a coffee shop before there are a few things I must comment on.  First off, the coffee is exceptional.  The heart designs they make in the foam are a beautiful touch.  However, when my friend and I go in before class, why is it an issue EVERY TIME that we ask for our espresso in a larger cup?  Some people just like to add more cream.  Pretty curly haired guy, you practically seethe behind the counter, yes, you're good looking, but that'll only get you so far.  It's become a game as of late to see how many people openly glare at me when I go in there.  Having said that; great coffee, but the attitude is simply not worth it.  If you know of or work in a good coffee place, let me know, two nice people looking for a new one!
author: Kasia P.

description:
well they're fucking at it again.  

my neighbors, karen and her charming boyfriend, woke me up at 5 fucking am screaming.  apparently her man is on his way to re-hab (quelle surprise!) and karen is lagging on putting her face on and getting into the car. 

so i hear, "karen, you fucking bitch, you know i have to get to my program!  come on!  if i'm late, they'll kick me out of the fucking thing!" and then you hear karen, "i'm coming!  fuck!" and then you hear the boyfriend, "fucking a, karen!  what are you doing?  putting on make-up?  like that's going to help!  HA!  if i'm late, i swear to fucking GOD!  i don't know what i'll do but it will not be good!" and then you hear karen, "i'm coming!  calm down!"

well telling an angry man to calm down is something you do not do.  it's like telling a fat person to eat more slowly and enjoy the taste of their food or calling a crazy person, crazy.  it will only serve to make them very, very fucking angry.

so i hear boyfriend, "I AM FUCKING CALM, YOU STUPID BITCH!  I have to get to my program or they cut me out!!!  surely your pea brain can comprehend that???  or wait, you would love for me to fail, wouldn't you???  oh, that would make you so happy, karen.  you fucking bitch.  COME THE FUCK ON!!!  WE HAVE TO GO!!!!"

and then i hear karen, "i'm coming!  shit!"

and on and on and on and on and on and i'll kill myself.

so i get out of the house and walk down to ritual where i enjoy the most finely crafted soy latte in the city and a slice of amazingly delicious vegan sherry cake.  they open early (i think 6 am?) for such occasions as this or say like, if you have a normal job and have to be to work at 8.  or is it 9?  what time is it that you people go into work?  anyway, i quite enjoy the staff and i've never had anything but stellar service here and i love the space.  plus, there is always at least one pup posted up outside at all times for cuddling.  if that doesn't say 5 stars I don't know what does.  you fucking bitch.
author: Laura B.

description: Yummy drinks - AND they make fun shapes and designs in your froth! A warm vibe, worth checking out!
author: Tara F.

description: I dig the coffee at Ritual but had the worst experience there today. For the first time I attempted to hang out there and do some work - big mistake. The music was so loud that I literally couldn't hear the music in my headphones over it! They were playing obnoxious wall-of-sound beach type music at levels unheard of in a coffee shop. I started to suspect that they were just trying to clear out the long-term table occupiers. Or perhaps they blew out their eardrums steaming coffee. Horrible, horrible, horrible.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
The Ritual begins with a magic phrase at the counter: "Guatemala Palo Alto Azul." Soon the incantation soaks your tongue in bittersweet cherry acid clover and summons Magnolia Electric Company from the speakers. You will still feel puzzled by the world-dusty barista with the pinned crisp foreign bills behind her, but you'll get distracted at how intuitively vegan dining fits with the First Church of Steve Jobs assembled here. Follow your hunger, try a spinach and parmesan hot bun; sit down and split open your black Apple. Take another sip, feel a thrill of anxious inspiration and immediately want to yelp - but wait you'll lapse too easily into your mythomaniac mode - so restrain yourself - desperately - and thick inconceivable cords slip and tighten around your thoughts with the pressure mounting you can't but take a deeper drink now a DENDRITIC RACE OF RELEVANCE breaks out across your brain from the global economy to schadenfreude and physical need and all things eager to insinuate their interconnections but gulp the rest of it down yelp intensely rise and say the magic words again and again till the wide pressurized associative world collapses into a single point.

My personal caffeine trip aside, if you like the best coffee made best, buy it here - it's like Kopi Luwak without the droppings element (for all I know). Try all the clovers. Try the teas too, especially the one with a big flower bud at the bottom that blossoms as it stews. If you're looking for a chic and spacious lounge for conspiratorial camaraderie or only the concentration that sets in amidst a crowd of industrious Mission academics and professionals, come join us. 

It's way better than a cult!
author: Alex Z.

description:
If you knew me at all you know I don't drink coffee. And if I did, I would be ordering it from Central Coffee Tea and Spice. For this I am glad. I only went into Ritual because I was walking by and I had to pee. I understand that it is rude to enter an establishment simply to use their bathroom so my baby ordered a macchiato while I relieved myself.  I ended waiting, I kid you not, ten full minutes for the bathroom. I was the only one in line! Well, I was the first one in line. In the minutes to follow I was joined by three more people, all with hands in pockets, trying their damnedest not to look like they were trying to not  look cool. Finally the kid in the bathroom emerged and had the nerve to give me a dirty look as he oh so carelessly brushed his perfectly messy, hipster bangs away from his sleepy "I'm-a-free- thinker-who- doesn't- give- a- crap- about- you-", eyes. If I hadn't had to go so bad, I might have taken the time to kick him in the shins. 
 When I finally made it back to MC he was JUST ordering his drink. MC asked Mr. Mustache behind the register if he could be sure and make the drink to-go. Now, MC does the coffee thing for a living as well. He knows what a good cup of coffee should taste like. However, Mr Mustache begins to "strongly urge" MC to enjoy the coffee 'for here' because if he did it to-go it would change the temperature and therefor alter the delicate flavor of the drink. I'm sorry - did we ask you for a glass of Opus One in a paper cup? Did we ask for 20yr old scotch in Styrofoam? No - it's a CUP OF COFFEE! After the bathroom situation, I was ready to throw down, but MC politely asked, again, if he could just have the coffee to-go. Mr Mustache looks all annoyed, grabs a to-go cup and hands it over to Mini Mr. Mustache, letting him know, "This guy would like his macchiato TO-GO" Mini Mr. Mustache smirks and the two share a quiet giggle. The macchiato is made and handed over. Oddly, everyone else's paper cup had their drinks written on them in sharpie. Single decaf latte. Soy chai. Double Capp w/ xtra foam. MC's macchiato? A broken heart! If that's some sort of inside hipster joke that the Mustache Twins came up with over discussing the molecular structure of their ultra fine Arabian mocha sunani, they can just BITE ME!
 Ritual blows. 
 And really dude, handle bar mustache and overalls really only looks good on the 68 yr old farmer from Arkansas. You look like a tool.
author: Nuvia C.

description: I had a very good cappuccino here, with a nice little latte art touch.  Fancy red La Marzocco espresso machine, which I would consider corporate, but the place definitely has the home-made touch.  Still, it tries a little too hard to be hip.  And the logo is quasi-Communist but otherwise the place seems to bear no relationship to communism.  Pastries were just ok, menu looks like it was written by a child for no reason.  But they have wireless and lots of seating and very good coffee, so you should go.
author: John D.

description: This is my new favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. I had a great cappuccino here for the first time in months. Everywhere I've lived I try to find a favorite place for coffee, but I went almost a year without finding a place I loved here. The baristas were friendly, the coffee was excellent, and there's a lot of seating even though the place is popular. I spent a long afternoon here planning out music for the Yelp party. You'll see me here, lost in my headphones. Wi-fi too.
author: William W.

description: Awesome coffee, way ahead of Blue Bottle.
author: Lee S.

description:
The first thing you'll notice is a sea of laptop computers.  Everywhere you look, people dressed in black outfits stare slack-jawed into the soft, luminous glow of their LCD displays while they do everything from compiling source code to cruising Craigslist.org for a new significant other.  Alas, the culture of any coffee shop lies somewhere on a scale that has unbridled interaction at one end and introverted solitude on the other.  You don't need much more than a quick look around to fathom where this place sits within the spectrum of human engagement.

The next thing you notice? Ordering something here can be downright complex.  Think the "Short, Tall, Grande, and Venti" system at Starbucks is a little whacked?  Try ordering a cup of decaf here.  To be fair, I'm a creature of habit...used to going to Martha's on 24th street, handing them my Nissan stainless mug, saying "decaf", and being outside on the bench browsing the headlines within two minutes. Heck, even Starbucks can process this simple request. Try the same thing here, and you'll find that ordering coffee at Ritual is infinitely trickier.

The six people in front of you seem to have some odd request or peculiar need that circumvents the ordering of normal coffee.  See the short line that any self-respecting crew of Starbucks baristas can chew through in nothing flat? Here, it does anything but move quickly.  When it's my turn, I hold out my stainless mug and say "decaf".  The person behind the counter looks at me like I'm a caveman that just walked into Gary Danko, sat down, and grunted "food" to the head waiter.  She tells me that "We don't brew decaf...we can only do a decaf Americana" and asks if I would "Like a double".  First off, I haven't the foggiest clue what an "Americana" is. Secondly, I've heard of ordering a double at a bar...but not at a coffee shop.  I decline on the "double", and after a 5-6 minute wait I finally get my mug back....half full with "Decaf Americana". It was more expensive than filled-to-the-brim at Martha's, so I can only speculate that filling the thing would have cost more than a rolling-pin sized Burrito on the other side of Mission street.

At any rate, I finally get my cup of coffee and start scouting out a place to sit, gently weaving through the sea of downward-gazing faces, all captivated by web pages and oblivious to my presence.  I normally wield a black-belt-in-chitchat when I go out for coffee, but after looking around at the zombie-like faces at Ritual, I quickly conceded and tapped out, retreating in abject defeat to a well-lit window spot shunned by the shade-seeking laptop users.  Outside of the trendy background music and the intermittent hiss of the espresso machine, the silence is eerie....and punctuated only by an occasional cell phone ring followed by a muted "Hello".  Sitting down I perused the headlines and compared myself to the crowd and thought to myself, "A newspaper...how quaint".

If this is your scene, by all means check it out.  Unlike allot of morning-centric coffee shops, this one has a crowd in it from dawn till dusk, and it's decor, layout, and atmosphere are *truly* unique in Northern California. And while it's not my scene, I'm thankful for it's presence, for it gives reclusive laptop users dressed in black outfits and pointy-toed shoes a place to congregate, isolating the burden of their presence from the rest of the coffee drinking world.  But if you find yourself irked by terms like Macciato, Frappachino, and Americano, consider this place best avoided....and meet me sans-laptop on the bench at Martha's on 24th street to soak up the sun and chat up the locals...
author: Mike W.

description: Simply put, Ritual makes me wish I drank coffee and/or had a laptop.  Beyond the fact that the employees make super-cool pattern thingies in their lattes and shit, I wish I drank coffee just so I didn't feel like an imposter in this place.  When I go in there now it feels like everyone knows I'm only going so I can meet pretty girls.  And the laptop thing, Jesus! I mean when you walk in everyone looks up from their ibooks in unison, gives you the once over and then returns back to whatever they were working on.  It's like a god-damn commercial for Apple computers.  The funny thing though is that probably 80% of the people in Ritual are there to pick-up/be picked up on and if they tell you any differently, then they're fucking liars.
author: Broke-Ass Stuart S.

description:
being a former barista for a major coffee roaster in the US. i will definitely give ritual a thumbs up. not only is the espresso great with a good acidity and fullness, but (depending on the barista) its milk is smooth and with appropriate froth. 

the only negative aspects are the facts that their cappuccinos are not made correctly (latte art is just that...on a latte, not cappuccino. half milk/espresso, half foam), and the wait on the weekend is outrageous (ultimately not their fault, but readers beware...arrive early).
author: Kaleb L.

description: Really hip. Good art. Decently bad music.  I used to do all my homework here until they took out all the plugs in the walls - nut still great people watching and atmosphere
author: Nisha M.

description:
The drip coffee is decent, but the espresso drinks are really good.  No debating that!  The atmosphere has a 'recent' feel to it, so I might give it five stars in about 10 years when its a little worn-in and has gained some more of its own character.  It's crowded on weekends.

Update: Too many laptops.  This place is good for popping by to get a quick espresso drink.  Something changed for the worse.
author: Arlo J.

description: How can you give Ritual anything less than five stars?  They serve possibly the best cup of coffee I've ever had, definitely in the top five, and the fact that you can get a French press coffee for less than a Starbucks mass-produced cup of coffee is itself meritorious of at least a three star rating.  That the beans are roasted on premises and are awesome justifies five stars.  The ample seating and cool look are the icing on the cake.  Maybe SFers would be more grateful for the ubiquitous good coffee  in the Bay Area if they came to D.C. and got a swig of the ubiquitous burnt Starbucks!
author: Elaine M.

description:
they are tracing paper cutouts... and now they've cloned the clones..

i'd rather mainline Folgers..

next...
author: miqual c.

description: this is a homegrown SF business success story, where some obsessed friends created a store that bust out.  Now they're becoming a local "brand," as marketing androids say, with multiple locations.  It is now the deux magot to the mission; maybe no new philosophical movements will come out from there, but they will help shut down American Apparel opening a new store down the street.  Who would've thunk it??  As long as the soy lattes are good and the burlap bean sacks remain in their rightful place on the floor, I don't care.
author: ed y.

description: Nice room.  Very good coffee.  It's THE hipster stronghold in the Mission, though, and therefore, incredibly pretentious.  There is an ocean of laptops in there, and it is nearly impossible to get a seat.  I prefer cafes that are a bit more unassuming, where I don't have to have a "cool card" in order to feel comfortable.  Not my scene...
author: Eric H.

description: My hot chocolate was nothing to write home about, but the cafe's interior is cleanly designed, modern, and spacious to the max.  Laptop squatting, which I unabashedly admit that I participate in,  is permitted and even encouraged (free Wi to da Fi).  I suggest coming before 7:30pm on any given night, because after that time, the place turns into Scene Central and seating becomes scarce.
author: Momo R.

description: I want to love this place because of the great location (in the heart of the Mission), fair-trade coffee, yummy pastries, and really nice staff. But I don't. Why? Because the music is so goddamn loud, I can hardly hear myself think, much less have a decent conversation without having to scream. Add that to the fact that they have practically no outlets open, and 50% of the few outlets that are open don't work, and I'm heading to Sugarlump. But judging from the line snaking out the door, I don't think I'll be missed.
author: Jen R.

description:
I am glad that this place has so many 5 star reviews to negate all the complainers who give it 1 star. How could you give this place 1 star? The coffee is amazing, enough said.
To address all the naysayers, there is plenty of seating. Man up and ask someone sitting at a 4-top to use one of the extra seats.
The baristas are rude? Have you ever tried to talk to a line cook while in the kitchen? They are creating something, don't expect them to massage your delicate ego. If you want to have your ass lapped like a bowl of milk, its not gonna happen. They are efficient and get you great coffee, but if what you are looking for is a relationship and not coffee, maybe you should try craigslist.
To the complaints about the "scene"..., its Valencia street. Is there a shop on this street that isn't run by hipsters? Its The Mission's uniform. If you are just cordial and read the signs telling you everything you are probably going to still ask the cashier, you will realize behind the tattoos and costumes, they are regular people. 
And lastly, to the idiot who gave this a 1 star review based on a friends experience, you absolutely defeat the purpose of yelp and should be waterboarded.
author: Casey W.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco.  Blue Bottle comes close, but Ritual wins.  You will never have Starbucks again once you discover this place.  I give it 5 stars but I think it deserves 6 stars.  Its a little too hipster for me in there (I swear on a Saturday morning, people are all dolled up ready to go clubbing).  Maybe they are all dolled up because they haven't gone to bed yet.  But despite the occasional overly trendy crowd in there, the coffee is so good I will wait in line in the rain for that coveted cup of lovely.  Wi Fi in there too, and delicious donuts.  Anyone familiar with Stumptown will find it strikes a similarly yummy chord.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Espresso that sits for even a few seconds after getting pulled starts to develop some bitterness if the steamed milk (made fresh) isn't immediately poured in. Even the best artisan roasters I've gone to don't always gets this right. But I'm crossing my fingers cause Ritual always has the past few times I've gone. Best cappuccinos and lattes I've ever had. Minus one star for the annoying hipsters who infest the place. 

And for those of you who complain about the lack of outlets for your laptops, that's a good thing for those of us who come here and try to find a seat only to be met with the sight of a sea of tables filled with people who plan to stay for hours with their laptop and a single drink.
author: Crystal L.

description:
update  12/15/06:
their coffee is so good that despite the lack of available tables, i'm compelled to upgrade ritual from 4 stars to 5 stars.
.

* * * *
original review  02/09/06:
their stuff deserves 5 stars. very good coffee and even a better lattee. here's my problem with ritual though. i can never find a damn table because of all these hipsters and laptop drones are occupying them all day and night. once, i came in the morning to get coffee. then i came back in the evening to get another shot of caffeine. the same morning people were still there in the evening. hey, you hipsters and laptop drones, go outside every now and then. it's a beautiful world out there.
author: frisco j.

description: All I can say about this joint is that they do make a pretty good cup of coffee, if you can stand the annoying hipster scene or snottiness behind the barista counter. The art hanging on the walls is usually pretty cool too, but my tolerance for this place is usually limited to a cup to go and only if I can't get to Philz Coffee.
author: Ingrid K.

description: Okay, so the coffee and hot chocolate are not bad.  But alas, the chaotic ambiance trumps the good beverage quality.  The exceedingly loud music is an assault on the ears, as are the oddly frequent dropping of plates and other tableware on the floor by the folks who work here.  Only recommended for "to go" orders; otherwise, bring your own noise-canceling headphones.
author: Squeaks L.

description: This place is a menace to The Mission. You can't walk by without forcing your way through the line of hipsters waiting for their coffee, or dogs, bikes, or smokers. There's never a table because the same 10 people are hogging them with their laptop every day of the week. Oh, and they don't have decaf coffee, you have to order a specialty drink (for $3 more) if you want decaf. God I hate this place. The coffee is good, but the atmosphere completely spoils anything they got going for them.
author: John G.

description: Great coffee but a few of the employees were insanely smug.
author: RYU r.

description: Apparently, people go to ritual to be seen. I just went there for coffee... and waited for 27 minutes for it.
author: Kathryn T.

description: Have never had a bad pull here. These guys and gals know what they are doing. I like this better than Blue Bottle. (BB in the Ferry bldg has twice served me a luke warm latte and they also refused to grind beans for me because of the "integrity of the beans"... give me a break.) So, yay Ritual. You guys rock!
author: Jason Y.

description:
If somebody ever asked me what a "hipster" was, I'd drag them down to this coffee shop and say "look around... this place is lousy with them."  
Ok, let's get to the coffee...  this is the place for a coffee purist.  They pull great shots, make awesome designs  with the foam and take pride in their coffee.  
So why the 2 stars you ask?
minus one for the hipsters hogging the tables with their Macbooks.
minus another two for the staff's holier than thou attitude if you ever so politely ask if they have vanilla syrup for a latte.  God forbid I like vanilla lattes... I appreciate a good cappuccino as much as the next guy but sometimes I have a hankerin' for something sweet...sue me.  I don't deserve the smug attitude.  Oh and one time I felt like a mocha so I ordered one... it came with a beautiful leaf pattern... very talented I thought to myself and then I asked, "could I have some whipped cream please?"  You would have thought I asked the barista to blow me judging by his reaction...  fuck off... now you're being ridiculous... it's not unreasonable to ask for whipped cream for a goddamn mocha.  I bet if they served french fries, they'd yell at you for asking for ketchup.
author: Dan G.

description: Paid over $7 for a cup of coffee and a doughnut, not worth it at all. Not the style or the amount of coffee I want for 4 bucks. At first I thought they over charged me, but no it's just really that expensive. I am not sure what all the fuss is about.
author: G F.

description: Everyone speaks of the 'attitude' here but I think it's a great place to enjoy some of the best coffee in the city. Nice friendly people, laid back, comfortable and non-corporate in tone and spirit. San Francisco and other cities could benefit from more 'real' coffee places where you can sit back, relax, think, create and drink quality coffee. I love it.
author: John B.

description: Place is riddled with hipsters and MacBook Airs. The coffee beans are overpriced, and the service is blah. Try The French Hotel in Berkeley if you want awesome espresso beans at half the cost, and no hipster fronts. Now I need to get back on my fixed gear and ride off to the barber to trim my beard while finishing this review on yelp.
author: Jean-Paul B.

description: Great coffee most of the time! The service is 50/50. Eileen train your people about good customer service, you know smile , be pleasant.
author: Lisa S.

description: So I finally drank coffee at Ritual for the first time ever yesterday. Even Shawn of Amnesia said "You don't know where Ritual is?" Thank God Jeff Gunderson told me where to find it. I went in there with my friend Annie and we had coffee while people checked out my new chopper sting ray bike parked on the sidewalk.  I loved it! My latte had some cool ass fern leaf design on it. I didn't want to mess it up but how would I drink it? So I did. I drank it. Yummmmm.
author: Glenn C.

description:
Shhh!  Don't tell my editor I was here...
As I've mentioned before, I spend what little free time I have interning at Performer.  A few weeks ago I made the fatal mistake of noting that I liked it when she "sent me on field trips".  At that time, she had only ever sent me to the post office down the street to send out trial copies to potential subscribers.
Since then, she will periodically make me her personal pack mule and ship me out to brave MUNI and our famous transients (one tried to make me sing with him today) in the good name of posting flyers promoting upcoming shows we are sponsoring.  She usually sends me to two of the rockingest hipster hotbeds in the city - Haight and The Mission.
So, I do love to be out of the office, but what I don't particularly love is bothering people at their place of work.  But whatever, I'm the one that opened my big trap about "field trips" and whatnot so now I have to live with it.  I spent this afternoon marching up and down Valencia Street, badgering managers to let me distract their customers' eyes from their business just because I'm asking nicely.  So far no one has been mean, even though I keep expecting it.  People are starting to recognize me.
Anyway, I very sweetly asked these guys a few weeks ago if I could post a sign in their window.  And they very sweetly told me the rule was I had to be an employee to gain Poster Real Estate privileges.  Whatev.  Today I was not expecting to be sent out as Performer Ambassador again and needed liquid courage.  This is where the review begins.
Um, can we say best latte I've ever had?
Hipster, schmipster.  Yeah, everyone behind the counter has scruffy hair and a firm belief in sustainable living.  But with the super-friendly service I received, they could have been neo-Nazis and it wouldn't have made a difference.  Defintely getting the bigger size next time and carving out a small time window for a stop here on my next flier mission.
author: Jody A.

description: I'm pretty sure I saw Chuck Norris getting his coffee here once.
author: Brandon B.

description: Point zero in the Mission for seriously good coffee. Long lines, slow service, sometimes friendly occasionally bitchy and forgetful. But the espresso will be worth all your sacrifice.
author: Ato B.

description: I always feel like a Gyllenhaal when I sit in this place, like I am about to fly far away to play a pervert secretary or a marine.  I can't tell whether being a Gyllenhaal  is a timeless feeling or just the product of strong coffee but this cafe remains suspect.
author: Rusty M.

description:
Ritual has good coffee but the back half or so of the place kind of smells like a toilet.  If you want to come in you must be a dude with a beard, you must not shower, you must ride your bike there, and you must be some kind of an artist.  The chicks all kind of look like Alanis Morrisette from that video where there are four of her in the car.  That would have been one long fucking car ride and sometimes this place is like that.

Oh - every cake that is Vegan tastes like shit.  I think it's an acronym for Very Esoteric Gross Ass Nourishment.
author: Dirk C.

description: Ok, yeah -- it's a little too cool for it's own pants, but the truth is everybody who works there is also very helpful and nice.  They've come down to us from Seattle and it shows.  The coffee and pastries are  really good, the atmosphere is relaxed and comfortable, the wireless works great, the art is usually interesting, and the roaster in the middle of the room, although sometimes a bit loud, is an attraction.  I don't go on weekends, though -- line out the door.
author: Amy E.

description:
So this is the place where all the cool kids hang out.  Now I know to avoid it.  I have kind of a love hate relationship with Ritual because the coffee there is awesome but the people and the cafe atmosphere is an absolute nightmare.  
First, the positive - there's no denying it, the coffee here is just about my favorite ever.  Both the coffee and espresso drinks are just phenomenal.  I'm a barista myself and I know a thing or two, but the staff literally puts me to shame.  They roast their own beans, every drink is made quality by the barista and the staff knows alot about coffee.  I mean, alot alot.  Like nerdy alot.
   But honestly, I've never been in a cafe where I felt like the other customers were judging me by my looks, clothes and how many tattoos i had on my arm.  Ritual happens to attract that kind of clientele unfortunately.  If you need to concentrate on your work you should go to another cafe.  The music is loud, it's almost always packed, no tables available, there are no outlets (probably because the staff wanted customers to not stay for 4 hours on their laptops, and i can't blame them).  Yuppy and hipster alert.  
   
     So I've made a compromise with Ritual; I go there for coffee (if there's no line out the door, which there usually is), but then I leave with my drink.
author: gavbo O.

description: A local designer and I planned to meet at Ritual over the weekend to do an interview.  Upon walking in, I adored the layout and simplicy of the place.  The folks at the counter seemed very nice and cool, let alone quite efficient.  I didn't order any coffee, but the designer (Stephanie) says that she comes there often & it is great.  I did have one of their "dirty bomb" (cinnamon) muffins, which was just ok - seemed like it was maybe a day old or so.  My only real grip about the place was just how busy it was - from what I know, this place is pretty popular in the Mission, so nearly all the seating was taken already.
author: Victoria K.

description: Whoa, dude. Amazing coffee. Free Wi-Fi. Nice baristas.
author: Casey C.

description:
wow, some pretty harsh reviews of this place! why all the negativity, people? 

yes, this place is often crowded, with a line out the door. they make excellent espresso drinks with pretty leafy designs on top of the foam which lasts till the last sip. they have a plethora of comfortable seating and free wifi to create the perfect out-of-home office. they have two bathrooms, good tunes, yummy treats (some that are vegan) and good looking people. and best thing is? they're NOT starbucks!!

HUGE bonus...they open in the wee hours of the morning (like when it's still dark). i happily found this out on my way to BART once when i had an early flight outta SFO. perhaps that's a good time to get there to establish your office space?
author: Isabel C.

description:
can someone PLEASE tell me where else to go i can get quality like this without the bad 'tude and business management?

i went there today. there was a very short line, involving only one person behind me and one person in front of me. the person in front of me was friends with the person working the register, so that person basically took her break right there on the spot to chat with her friend. not cool. especially because waiting for your coffee takes long enough on its own. no reason to make that wait even more painful.

that's another thing. if i have someone to be that requires being on time i cannot go to ritual, even if i allow myself an extra half-hour. the lack of predictability of the line length plus employee decision to blow off handling the line is too much.

i'm also tired of ordering the same thing each time i go and always being charged a different price. yes, i always bring my own container. yes, it's always two shots. WTF is the real price? and why do you fill my 17 oz container half-full for a 12 oz drink?

i keep coming back only because the coffee is so incredibly stellar and every place else pales in comparison. any suggestions as to where else i can go? especially in the mission?

i can't recommend this place in the way of efficiency or ambiance. only if you want a hella good cuppa joe.
author: Stephanie P.

description: This place should be boycotted. They have taken out all the electrical outlets so that laptop users can only be there for as long as they have battery. This is such a nasty capitalist move. These guys are on the mission district, the artist/bohemian/progerssive hub of the city. It is offensive and outrageous of them to treat the community like this.
author: Chuck N.

description: Had a "french press" cup of coffee.  What I found interesting was that the coffee was in a big containter and I am not sure how long it was sitting around after being "pressed."  The coffee was nice and smooth.  Not as good as Blue Bottle but a good quality product.  The space is a nice place to chill for a bit.  I would not wait in a line out the door for this place.  Saturday evening was not too packed though.
author: Moe J.

description: Like all the other billion reviews, I agree that they have extremely good coffee.  I met someone here for a meeting and it was difficult to communicate, the music and roaster was so-o-o loud.  I recommend this place if you are wanting a good cuppa and don't care so much about the company you are with.  Staff was not overly friendly, but not as pretentious as some have pointed out.
author: Kari L.

description: Excellent coffee.  Minus one star because service at the register is iffy.  Plus, is it me, or is San Francisco getting too cool for me?
author: Tangerine L.

description:
ten bizzillion points for the fact i was just handed a half pound bag of ritual sumatra, roasted today, as driving down valencia at 10pm on a saturday. is this something they regularly do? the coffee smells ridiculously good...
still haven't been inside since i believe all of mike w.'s reviews, especially if they involve mongolian beef, but walking by it always smells amazing, and now so does my car... and now my fridge.
author: Casey W.

description: Fellow yelp buddy John W. suggested that we get coffee here. I'm so glad we did! Not only were we privy to great iced lattes, I was lucky enough to hear about how the space was once a supermarket owned by his grandparents. This city has so much rich history and it's stories like these that make me feel lucky to be here. Anyway, the coffee was great (the iced mocha was fantastic... not overly chocolatey like you would find at chain coffee shops), the employees were friendly and sweet. Nice modern decor. Free wifi to boot.
author: Tatiana J.

description:
**NEWSFLASH**

ritual's owners are smart, yo. 

new seating arrangements: no more perfect-height tables that just beg to be laptopped upon. oh no. now, antique looking loveseats, facing the aisle, thus still perfect for people-watching, but blocking outlets and presumably awkward as hell for laptoppers. 

thus, the era of  "work from home" by staying at ritual for eight-hour shifts, buying at most a coffee and a pastry, must end. and a normal coffee shop customer flow (still fueled by hot hipster baristas and amazing coffee and espresso and good decor and ambiance) will surely ensue.

***NEWSFLASH: UPDATE***
ummm, i unknowingly wrote that shit on april fool's day. went in today to do my sunday crossword, and everything's back to normal.... never mind... 

(...embarassed...)
author: lauren a.

description:
Maybe its because I prefer drip or French press coffee rather than the fancy espresso drinks (I'm cheap, what can I say, and I don't need all that milk), but this place has left me really unimpressed despite all the rave reviews. Their "French press" coffee tastes like cardboard. Blue Bottle's individual drip is the standard, and they completely fail to live up to it.
