Just like the people of Egypt, bringing down a regime by standing in a square, we yelpers can change the workd by offering our views! The Ritual staff reads these reviews too - thank you for doing your best to make Ritual a bit more warm and accessible.
author: Eric S.

description:
Very good coffee served from coffee nazis that basically won't allow you to order a drink they way *you* want to...

Prices are not listed clearly.

Lacks decent complimentary menu.

Bean prices are WAY too high ($17 a pound?? wtf?).
author: Max L.

description: Truly exceptional.  There is a ton of tables and chairs, enough space to walk in between tables, and great service. My boyfriend's coffee had a perfect swirl leaf in it.  My tea had a special bag of spices.  We had a crumbly coffeecake that was out of this world.  Go here!  This place rocks!  I have to say, one of the best coffee shops in the city, by far.
author: Joanna S.

description: This really is the best coffee I've ever had. Have yourself a thick and rich hot chocolate, or a pen-n-jens cup of tea. It makes my 2 PM coffee break the highlight of my work week. And, the staff are very sweet and sociable.
author: Erin A.

description:
The most DELICIOUS espresso I've had this side of North Beach. And I LOVE my coffee. Order an art-topped cappuccino or an Americano and enjoy the crema. Gooey double chocolate cookies are great.
The only question I have after visiting this space is: doesn't anyone go to cafes to hang out and talk with one another anymore? It seemed that every single patron, even if sitting with a friend, was sucking up the free wireless here. Come on people--have a conversation!
author: Jackie C.

description: Amazing little place on the Mission, the baristas are talented and the space is comfortable.  A little noisy at times, but the atmosphere is great.  Nice.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Apollo L.

description: If you want to drink excellent coffee in a comfortable setting in the best neighborhood on earth, go to ritual.
author: Shira L.

description: Coffee can't get any better than this.  Their regular coffee is all French press, their espresso drinks are among the best I've had, and the cup cakes look oh so good. The great coffee is only augmented by the fact that the barristas really know what they're doing and have actually won barrista(ing) awards. (Yes, they have those apparently).  DRAWBACKS, it is always always always crowded! People literally run their .coms out of there, and there are more Macbooks in there than the Apple Store.  Also, apparently there is no heater, because when it is cold outside, it is freezing in there. And lastly, the hipster mania gets annoying.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The city's best non-Philz coffee, and best hipster watching.  Good music that's usually pretty loud.  Impossible to find a place to sit down, unless you get there very early in the morning.  I always come here to get work done, but that never happens.  The wireless crashes and there are few power outlets and even those are capped on weekends.
author: Adam Z.

description:
great coffee!! fun to watch the roasters at work!!

zucchini bread was just like grandmas... except organic.. haha
author: c e.

description: Absolutely love this place!  I love how their lattes come with a leaf shape on top.  Yeah, I am easily amused.  Plus it is great place to check out all the beautiful people in the Mission.
author: Jen S.

description: Ok, I know it's pretty ridiculous.  But if you do live nearby, you might as well acknowledge it and embrace it.  On Sunday mornings there is no more over-the-top hipster scene.  The casually messy flock here to wait in long lines for slow made (but delicious) coffee.  They could be more efficient.  They could be more sanitary.  But what do you expect?  And the lattes kill hangovers like nothing else.
author: Dolores Y.

description:
coffee here is amazing!  i've never tasted coffee so good...

i have to admit, this place has kinda made me a snob.  when i want good coffee, i crave this place.  the only downside is that when it's busy, it is busy.  they aren't exactly the fastest coffee makers - but i understand.  it's not supposed to be a starbucks where they get you in and out in no time flat...  i think it's kinda a culture difference between this place and starbucks for example.  starbucks is about fast service, and a good (or maybe what they may consider good) custom-made coffee.  the people at ritual i think actually care about the coffee they make and are actually interested in it.  don't get me wrong, i'll still go to starbucks, but man... if i could go to ritual everyday - i'd be spoiled!!

the free wi-fi is great too.  bring your laptop and sit on down (if you can find an open table / seat) with your coffee and enjoy.
author: Kimberly F.

description: Absolutely the best coffee in SF... don't expect the Starbucks experience here:  baristas actually take time to make you a cup of espresso the right way.  Any of their  vegan pastries are delicious.  Ritual is a neighborhood spot with style and soul.  Minus one star for the hectic street and parking.
author: Anne L.

description:
products are good, enjoy the community feel, but why are there so many coffee bags sitting where there could be couches and, more importantly, why does Ritual not have whipped cream???

Also, if you guys are going to play your music so loud so need to improve your shitty sound system!
author: Matt T.

description: I know it's wrong of me to go to a place like Ritual and ask for decaf, but I did, because my poor nervous system can't handle full-octane coffee, and I know decaf can taste amazing (Peet's, anyone?). Ritual's was watery and wimpy and like dirty water. I'm giving them one more star because they have a decent selection of herbal teas and their baked goods (even the vegan ones) are darn good, for those who aren't gluten-averse.
author: Beth W.

description: I have to give a disclaimer, I lived in Seattle for seven years.  I have been drinking and drinking coffee trying to find similar here in the Bay Area.  The first time I came there I had a latte, it was of Seattle quality...the second time I went for an espresso--it was not good.  The third time I went for another espresso it was not good.
author: Amy G.

description: I had a decaf machiatto the other day at Ritual. Boy was that strong! I got decaf  because I wanted the taste without the caffeine but that little cup got me moving anyways. I'm used to weak sauce Starbucks stuff...gotta stop going there! Also, I saw many flies buzzing around the pastries. Check that before you order those nice looking pastries. I opted to get a biscotti out of the jar instead.
author: Esther C.

description: Damn good coffee.  Kind of expensive, but I mean, this stuff is gourmet.  Yes, everybody inside has a macbook air/pro.  Yes, everybody is pretentious as shit, but dude, it is not like you have to hang out in there.  Buy some beans and go home and grind them.
author: Rikki D.

description: Think of Ritual as a social experiment with the goal to find out how long a person is willing to wait for delicious coffee.
author: Barna M.

description:
I want to give you 4 stars for hearing such good stuff about you prior to my visit and because you are a coffee snobs coffee shop, and I know you really care about the finer side of coffee.  I was going to give you a 3 STAR because as I first walked in one of the first things I saw was the pastries behind the glass and the little flies in there.   I still give the 4 stars for the overall presentation of a new school artsy coffee spot. I do appreciate the idea that this space was changed into the spot it now is with its artsy mission flare. 
 I read  that they might be snobby about not having certain things like whipped cream, and at first I got a short quick answer when I asked if they make their own whip cream. "We don't have whip cream"  was all she said.  How about  educating me?    It threw me off a bit, but I didn't let it get me down and I hung in there and called the barista out on making us customers appreciate coffee without even knowing it's happening to us. She was cool!  I have to say that the help behind the counter was very nice and appeared to know what they were doing. They definately looked like they were in the fast paced work mode. Sometimes you just need to engage people a little.  
So ...I am on a coffee shop MOCHA HUNT and have hit up a few spots that have been mentioned on YELP!  I am looking for a certain taste.  I like the espresso to be fairly strong -so I can taste it- and so far have found that the chocolate used is also very important.  I give this mocha a 3.5 stars.  They didn't  make coffee art in my cup so I felt let down, however they were training a barista and that might have been what happened to my drink.  I sometimes trip out on the idea that the cheapest cup of coffee is $3.25.  it was worth the fun of going somewhere and trying something new. 
 I have to say so far that Blue Bottle sits at the top of my Mocha Hunt, and I will continue my search.  I would go back, but not before I try Four Barrel, who happened to have run out of chocolate when I went in there??  Who knows Some people might think I am not even somebody that should be writing about coffee shops due to the fact that I am not drinking straight espresso or espresso in milk.
  Is it not just burned beans?
author: Andrew K.

description: Delicious servers, delicious coffee.  Cute little indie boys can service me anytime.  Yes there is attitude.  But I like attitude.  It is like reality television folks.  Sit back and enjoy.
author: Francesca B.

description: ritual has pretty good coffee, but probably not as good as four barrel or blue bottle. still, it's very good stuff. their beans are roughly about the same price as those other two, altho they seem to be selling their beans to a lot of small coffee shops everywhere now. this location is a pretty great hangout joint. it's big and spacious and has a lot of tables and a few couches. you can definitely do work here while sipping relatively expensive drinks. there're fun illustrations on the wall as well. it's a nice place. like all good coffee shops nowadays, the baristas are all hipster cool kids. if you're relatively "normal" (or *uncool*), don't be deterred. good coffee is good coffee, as are good coffee shops
author: Dave Y.

description: seasonal Hibernator espresso blend is beautiful. very comfortable atmosphere. free wifi. perfect iced mocha (aka not ridiculously chocolatey). two or three hoppers of espresso to choose from.
author: Jamie R.

description: The Sweet Tooth Macchiato was awesome! Hey, I have an idea. Put a Ritual in NYC. Then maybe ithis town will actually be on it's way to having decent coffee some day... maybe some day.
author: Carlie D.

description: I've just tried the cappuccino and coffee at Ritual, and they're both pretty far above average. The cappuccino especially was beautiful with a leaf traced on top and the little spoon for adding sugar.  I like the big space, the tables that don't wobble, the couches in the back, and the general gradient of light from bright near the front windows to cozy in the back. I've only gone on friday afternoons, and can generally find a little table or share one of the bigger ones. Otherwise I plop down at the big community table in the back.  Not a lot of conversations going on, as most people are engrossed in their papers/laptops, but music's always playing and there are enough people talking so it isn't eerie or uncomfortable. Someone said that the music keeps ratcheting up, and I think it's true. Last time I was there in the afternoon some songs were turned up too loud.
author: Arex J.

description:
like i always say whenever i walk by, this place is the antithesis and the epitomy of all that hipster missionites stand for.  think about it, you'll know what i mean.

with that being said, they make a damn good au lait (or ole as it is written on my cup) and i'm a sucker for any place that puts shapes in your foam. also, i keep coming back for those damn $2 vegan donuts. damn you, ritual :)
author: eve l.

description: If you find my web developers there please don't bother them - they are working, or at least that's what their "WFR" (working from Ritual) claims.
author: hunter w.

description: I miss you, you  bastard. I don't care what all of these people have to say about you. To me, you're home!
author: Jenny M.

description: Lately it seems like a lot of places that I used to really like are going downhill. The last 5 times I have been here the coffee was nowhere near as good as it used to be. It is still better than 90% of the coffee in this city, but just not as fabulous as it once was. So, very, very sad......
author: Claire B.

description:
I'm giving Ritual 4 stars because they make what are, probably, the best espresso drinks in The City. I think they work a little more flavor and color into their shots than Blue Bottle. Their coffee is roasted in-house and exceedingly fresh and their baristas are as good as any I've ever encountered. That also goes for the cashiers. When I order a double cap and they default to a six ounce cup - I am overjoyed . . . I forget that a certain chain milkshake shop is what most people know as an espresso destination.
I'm not giving it 5 stars because it is also the most expensive espresso bar in town (I know - they use free-trade beans, organic dairy, give staff insurance . . .), terrible pastries, it is so scene-y that you often have to wait in line 15 minutes . . . also, and I know they make coffee with care - but it can take 15 minutes for your drink to come up. Which is just sort of a long time. Also, I wish they had Indonesian coffees - they are all African and South/Central America (though they had a sign the other day saying Sumatra is coming). I wish they offered a darker full-city/Peets-style roast, and I wish their beans were not $15 a pound. So . . . no place is perfect but Ritual is close.
author: David C.

description:
The do have good coffee. I admit, I've always hated it here but the gf loves to get their coffee by the pound.

Make that 3/4 pound- that's right 1/4 less with NO LABELING.
What was already was outrageous is now making it impossible for us to support a local business.
author: Mr. Marie T.

description: This is the place for coffee.  I know there's a line sometimes, and there's tons of ppl with their mac notebook and it's difficult to find a place to sit to enjoy your coffee, but whenever I walk by, I'll go in there and grab a cup to go.  They have all kinds of coffee from different regions, and they taste great!
author: Candy C.

description:
My coffee addicted Peninsula friend claims this is the best coffee in the city.  That's quite a statement, coming from her, so when she decided to get coffee while we were hanging in Dolores Park over Labor Day weekend, I naturally asked her to get me a cup as well to see what the hype is all about.

Glad to say I was not one bit disappointed.  The coffee was great!  Now, I don't even remotely consider myself a coffee connoisseur, and by the time she got back to the park my coffee was lukewarm, but the taste, the flavor, the roasting, it was perfect!  I couldn't put it down for more than a minute before reaching for another sip.  Their coffee is only very slightly bitter, not at all like the burnt taste you get at Starbuck's and even Peet's.  Thumbs up!  My other friend claims Blue Bottle is the best in the city, so I guess I'll be trying that one very soon! :D
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm addicted. I might have to stop by here every time I go to the city...


too bad starbucks bought the clover...
author: Stephanie N.

description: I'm not usually a coffee drinker, but I enjoy a cup every once in a while. I had the french press cup. I wasn't impressed with it. The ham and cheese biscuit I had was tasty, but I didn't expect it to be hollow. Ambiance is great and they serve tiny little bite sized cupcakes.
author: C D.

description: go to philz or four barrel or blue bottle..... the coffee here has gone down the proverbial tubes
author: FAMOS A.

description:
People love to hate this place... It's too crowded, too cool, too many yuppies, too many laptops, too many hipsters, blah blah blah...

The bottom line is their coffee is some of the best in the city...despite their clientele, lines, etc.  Now people are saying Four Barrel is better (it's certainly less crowded.. but that's changing), but I think Ritual is great...
author: Walter P.

description: Overall a-ok because the hay-day of locals, tolerance and diversity in this great space are gone. It's become homogenized and pushed out the creative class for a 20-something impersonal hipster gone tweekin in the daylight with cold-stare-impersonal-vibe and vapid sexual exclusion-a-tude, or something or other. It's not the 'insider treasure' Mission I've come to know and love. I still grab a small coffee and vegan donut though.
author: James-Jimm P.

description:
ok, let me pace myself here.

for starters, i walked in here in THE BEST MOOD EVER and two fancy cocktails in.  my friend and i needed a pick me up before trekking across town for even more drinks and we were in the hood (she lives in the mission, we'd gone to her favorite restaurant for dinner and drinks - that place RULED... review forthcoming), so we stopped in here.  i browsed the different roasts and one called Sundae sounded delicious.  i walked up to the counter and expected the same kind of service you'd get at phil'z or blue bottle or one of these other "nice" coffee joints.  SILLY ME.  i must have forgotten i'd entered HIPSTER DEATH ZONE where NO ONE is enthusiastic about ANYTHING.  standing clueless and smiling, ready for a suggestion in front of these lot will get you absolutely nowhere.  she looked at me as if i had an arm growing out of my forehead when i told her that "sundae" sounded good and i wanted a cup.  jeez, sorry for not knowing you guys do ONE french press roast and the rest i can get only as espresso.  i just wanted a @!#$ing cup of coffee, really.  i should have just said GIVE ME A CUP OF DRIP, but you know, i was CURIOUS about the stuff this place crafts.  SUE... ME.

after this nearly intolerable exchange at the register, my friend and i both finally order a double shot of espresso.  now, look.  i've worked in a cafe.  i know what espresso tastes like.  and i like coffee, too... i appreciate the flavored stuff and i've tried my fair share.  hell, i'm cuban, so i MAKE cuban coffee (which is just espresso with a pinch of salt - it eats a lot of the bitterness - and a whole lot of sugar) pretty much daily at home.

what this person served me tasted like what i imagine a death draught tastes like.  i write pretty good and consistent reviews, and sense of humor aside i am telling you now, this stuff tasted like someone handed us each a cup of vinegar.  i put some of that syrupy water stuff in it, and TWO HEAPING SPOONFULS of sugar into my TINY ESPRESSO CUP... to absolutely NO avail.  this stuff was so disgustingly bitter, i walked back up to the counter after my first actual teensy sip, and left it there.  my friend attempted one more sip before doing the same.  i mean... they should be ASHAMED that they'd ever serve anything that revolting to a paying customer.

DISGUSTING.  i will never even so much as LOOK in the direction of this place EVER AGAIN.  GROSS, GROSS, GROSS.
author: Beccie F.

description: it is number 3 on my favorite places very affordable only issue is they aren't  very space conscience for wheelchairs or people with kids in strollers. You can't tell them not to serve hipster assholes that is not their fault bu I can do without them too
author: Kitty L.

description: I LOVE this place on weekend mornings....just before the masses awaken from their beds...and after I've landed my ass on one of their cozy chairs in the back!
author: R M.

description: A great addition to the neighborhood, although it's most definitely been discovered.  I agree with someone below - they are the #2 cup of coffee in SF, behind Blue Bottle in Hayes Valley (Jamie on Saturdays - you are the best!)  The latte art is a nice touch.  Coffee is the thing here though... if you want pastries, go to Tartine's a few blocks away.  I find the scene amusing too - I've never seen so many Powerbooks in one place outside of the Mac store.
author: Esther K.

description: Friendly, no-attitude baristas who actually care about the coffee.  Ritual is the best coffee house in SF.
author: Lesley G.

description:
Go for the Macchiatos...the best in the city: syrupy rich brew with just enough foam to leave you delighted.
But don't mind all the super wealthy trust-fund-babies clad in expensive thriftshop vintage rags hanging out at all hours, having a blast pretending to be writers and intellectuals, and hogging all the big tables, typing away at your thousand some dollar laptop. We know you're not broke and unemployment is just early retirement for you! So move over and let the people with real jobs sit down and get their much needed jolt of excellent caffeine there before going back to their real jobs!!!!
author: Sara K.

description: My wife hunted this one down in the Mission district based on a recommendation.  As a confirmed coffee geek, I can say it was worth the slight detour.  A casual and busy place cranking out excellent coffe in press pots for the morning session with expedient, upbeat service.  The crowd is a little of everything - it is the Mission after all.  Bought some beans as well.  The beans we perfectly roasted for each variety rather than the all too common char everything approach most places have.  A destination for true coffee aficionados.
author: Steve D.

description:
Soy latte rocks here - definitely one of the best I've had in the City.

The music is WAY too loud.  Thought it was an evening thing, but the music was blasting already when I went at 9am on a Sunday morning.  Not a great spot to study.

Note: they cover all power outlet for laptops on the weekends.
author: Minny W.

description: Very good scene, very good coffee, plenty of outlets, no decaf filtered coffee, just decaf steam-brewed. A big old roaster that really roasts right there all day. A great logo.
author: Geronimo G.

description:
Im writing this review as a former (future hopefully) barista. Here are some simple reasons why i love this place. The main problem at all coffee shops is the sacrifice of quality for quantity. As a buisness you want to turn a profit, yet the part of you that started a coffee shop in the first place wants to play loud music that you like, take your time and put out the best coffee in town, and if you make some friends and take care of your employees alon the way, then that is great. 
..............................................................................................
Instead of those annoying "friends dont let friends drink starbucks" stickers, coffee shop owners should stick "friends dont let friends open coffee shops that try to emulate starbucks" on their foreheads. While being starbucks is "lame" being a mom and pop coffee shop who has sold their souls to blended drinks is by 10 times worse.

This is why ritual is great, its the coffee shop that you and your friends always wanted to open. Consistantly putting out coffee drinks that are the best i have had since i was in Italy. 
.............................................................................................................
Remember, simple menu, consistancy, baristas commited to quality not customer service (i know you disagree), good music. makes a good coffee shop.
(i know that this is america and the customer is always right, but i dont agree, sometimes the customer is a douchbag. did you come to drink great coffee or to make new best friends with the people that are behind the counter, and be seen by people.)
author: jeff e.

description:
Wow. I'm so uncool. I can tell because I don't look anything like the people that come to this joint. Why aren't they working anyways? How do they all afford those Apples? Hmph.

Well, the coffee is yummy and the cupcakes are to die for. But....are you cool enough? ;)
author: Tracy Y.

description:
really great place, run by nice people.

but too goddamn crowded.

oh, the drip coffee is a little inconsistent.  usually amazingly smooth and delicious, but sometimes bitter.
author: Mike G.

description: This is trendy smooth coffee, good if you are into a smooth bean. I don't think it's worth going out of your way for.
author: Shayna K.

description: My new Favorite!  I really enjoyed the vibe here.  Some of the best coffee in the city.  Fun, funky art and neighborhood feel.  Filled with students, slackers, posers and relaxers
author: Jack S.

description:
fixed gear bicycles.
apple laptops.
ok coffee.

does this sound like your scene? i bet it probably does, you retard.

philz decaf coffee and folgers instant decaf coffee crystals for life, until theres soemthing better of course.
author: christopher a.

description:
You might be turned off by the high hipster factor but chill, ok? It's all going to be ok. Enjoy the eye candy, ignore the people you don't like, meet the people you do like, check your wireless, use the bathroom, and

drink some really really good coffee.

Man I was expecting the coffee to be overrated but it's incredible. Among the best coffee I've had in San Francisco.  It's a dream. The line isn't that bad either.
author: nadines d.

description: I used to love their coffee but after a few not-so-mind-blowing lattes and when you can't find a place to sit, I wander Valencia St for something else more down-to-earth.  I still remember my first few incredible coffees...but it hasn't quite been the same.  *sigh*
author: M S.

description: latte ok, comes with latte art, but cappuccino is worth the long line that extends out the freaking door. they all kno how to make latte art, i wonder if they can make smiley faces next time.
author: Bernard W.

description: Look, I enjoy their coffee and I enjoy their tea. Like Atlas in Potrero Hill they are good at this. But dammit there IS a problem with being too hip if you can't find any place to sit at most times of the day (especially after work on weekdays) What good is wireless internet if you have to sit outside to use it?
author: Yussef C.

description: It's a toss-up between Ritual Roasters and Blue Bottle Coffee, but both definitely represent SF's finest. All that RR is missing is a 4-star French/Italian/Catalan restaurant next door so that I might enjoy an RR espresso as a proper after-dinner drink.
author: Janice A.

description: I'm not even a coffee person but if I was rich I might have a RITUAL soy latte everyday.  Truly talented baristas and the drinks always taste perfect.  I also am always impressed by the featured artwork.  The hipster atmosphere is what you make of it.  When I was new to SF, hipster joints seemed very FAKE and out of place.  Now I settle myself and people-watch.  The coffee (and tea -ya gotta love tea!) is superb.
author: Sarah P.

description:
After hearing about Ritual from friends and reading Yelp reviews, I tip toed up in my yoga attire this morning, fearing the hip mecca that lay before me. I wore my sunglasses inside in an effort to look a bit cooler. I even considered giving attitude right back to any of the workers who were about to be rude to me. BUT, the first people I laid eyes on inside the cafe were a couple and their infant.  I though... not what I expected...maybe I won't be thrown out of here. Then, I got up to give my order and the guy behind the counter couldn't have been friendlier. He told me that his sister had the same name. He asked if I had a frequent shopper card and welcomed me when I said i was a first timer

My experience at Ritual was the antithese of most reviews I read. I thought the service was great (well, my latte did take a while ) and the staff didn't at all appear judgemental, too cool for school and were not bastards. On the other hand, my latte was good but hardly something I'd wait on a line down the block for again.
author: Michelle D.

description: Good coffee, decent snacks. A great place to socialize but not such a great place to accomplish any work. Music can be extremely loud and lots of fun and interesting characters to distract you. I've had my best luck at the long table near the back but the place fills up fast, leaving you to climb over people and computer cords when you want to run to the bathroom or get another drink.
author: martie j.

description:
I've only had the "french press" house coffee.  I found it weak and tangy.  The banana bread was good, but I came for the coffee.  My friends say the espresso drinks are to die for.

UPDATE - The espresso drinks aren't that great either.  And if you can't make decent drip coffee, well, maybe you shouldn't have a coffee shop.
author: Geoff L.

description:
i needed a spot to park my ass while buddies readied themselves for cocktails.  i was warned repeatedly that ritual was a hipster haven - not that it's a bad thing to be labeled "hipster", but I am known to hate clique-y/pretentious atmospheres...and i'm sure my friends were trying to avoid the Aunty showing up with a mouthful of opinions of why people who were so desperately trying to define a completely individual identity had to smirk and sneer at those who chose a moderate living...I digress.

staff genuinely friendly.  tables clean from considerate customers.  old school hip hop loud enough in da house.  and cute little first "coffee dates" happening all around me (I was there 7-9pm weeknight and am still washing off the discomfort of having to endure the first-date-conversations...ugh, good luck to you guys).

Ritual was not what I was preparing myself for. Perhaps the too-school-for-school reputation leaked to the masses and now the place has become a welcome spot to all.  After i tuned out from the datedotcom conversations i got deep into my book and felt totally at ease...oh yea, and the coffee rocked my adrenals.
author: niselynne X.

description:
What matters about this place: the coffee.

The Coffee: It's really effing good. These folks roast their own, and they don't over-roast. The body comes from the bean, not the roast. I'm not sure if they trade direct with the farmers or if they do the "fair trade" marketing BS, but the beans are always top quality. Buy your beans here for your home-brewed coffee and give it a couple of pounds. If your palette is used to the blown-out scortched earth mouthfeel of Starbucks, you'll be confused at first. Those are "flavors" you're tasting. ;-)

The place: cool space, neat old roaster past the pay/espresso bar, always busy. The line is usually long, moves fast, and the short wait is worth it. Laptops are up and out, proudly displaying their OiNK homepages (oh wait ... curse you Interpol!!!). It's definitely been christened by the Mission and SF kids young and old as a trend-maker, so seating is always scarce. I generally drop in, have a double macchiatto and grab a pound of beans and split.

The people: very cool, unpretentious, most importantly: knowledgeable and excited about their product. 

Where I'm coming from with this review: I'm not a coffee snob, but I really do like good coffee. Hell, I'll drink it from McDonald's if I really need the caffine. But I also have a pretty good palette and an appreciation for it. I've been schooled by my bro-in-law, Kyle Glanville, who's running Intelligensia's newly-opened Silver Lake storefront/roastery. He also ran the front of the house for Victrola in Seattle for years. (He won't drink it from McDonald's.)

I think we're at a point where the Starbucks "third place" business model that has brought coffee up to middle-class luxury item has peaked (a couple of years ago, actually). We're now at a point where coffee can move into a new phase, and companies like Intelligensia, Ritual, Stumptown and a few others who are sourcing and roasting small, select batches of beans are leading the way.

Bottom line: check these guys out. Best coffee in San Francisco.
author: Dave C.

description: I once had a friend comment that Ritual Coffee Roasters is single-handedly keeping the slow food movement alive in the Mission District.  You've been warned.  The usual weekend experience at this coffee shop involves waiting in a long line, sometimes 15 or more minutes for your caffeine fix.  Inside the cafe, you'll find yourself in a sea of lap tops and tapping your foot impatiently.  Try not to be a crabby McCrab face.  Good things come to those who wait.  The folks here are hardworking.  I enjoy the cappuccinos and the jasmine tea.  Ritual is kid-friendly.  I brought some little kids to the shop and on one occasion, a circus-loving barista balanced a stool on his chin to entertain the kiddos.  They really loved it.  For the kids who can't handle shots of espresso, Ritual often sells mini cupcakes and donuts.
author: Colleen B.

description: After buying a nice espresso machine of my own, I thought i knew what good espresso tasted like...wrong. My god, the coffee here is just amazing. Its just so damn good. They have a big roasting machine so you can be sure the coffee is REAL fresh. The cafe has a nice feel to it and there are many tables along with couches. However there are so many people there that its very difficult to find a seat to use their free Wi-Fi. Anyway, I definitely recommend the place.
author: Tim M.

description: I AM A TEA PERSON!  Alas, Ritual makes me dream of coffee!  I love their lighter, creamer roasts, their cappuccino with the beautiful crema and art foam, and their deep appreciation for the beverage that most of America takes everyday yet takes for granted.  If I'm in the area and in the mood for treating myself to a non-Camellia sinensis-based brew, I find myself wandering over to Ritual!
author: Scott N.

description: Good coffee, but long long line out front, far too few tables, and next-to-no electric sockets.  I just wish I had some free wi-fi plus electricity so that I could actually get some work done!
author: Jaime K.

description: I dunno so much about the crowded hipster atmosphere, but I that doesn't stop this place from having reasonably priced, damn good coffee.
author: R E.

description: Ok, so i clearly have some problems with this place, but the coffee is good and I still go on occasion. If Ritual is listening, i just want to say that there are easy ways to shorten that line. The number of people passing by that look in and see the line and then walk away is astounding, and its not even necessary. First, what about not having the busy barista be the one taking all the orders and making the espresso drinks? Half the time I'm waiting there in line to order a drip cup, the drip cup maker is completely empty, and the barista can't take my order and pass it on to her because he is making someone else's cup of coffee. Come on guys.
author: A F.

description: I was so happy when this place opened; I lived around the corner and this was the first coffeeshop that was open until late at night! Whenever I go to Revolution, I always had beer instead of coffee. I know it's crowded and the crowd is heavy on Mission single-speeders but I have a friend that has gotten 3 dates out of this place (and counting) and I have to give it props for that! I love sitting there. It's a fun place to write in your journal and wonder where the hell the guy who got the "Hulkinator" T-shirt got it from. High school closet, or did he actually pay $40 for it at Kid Robot or something? I never want to ask....
author: Liboo K.

description:
Before I came here (and Blue Bottle), I was not a coffee drinker.  
Their cappuccinos kick major ass, yum.  I am a convert.  Halleluja (spelling?).  Plus there are cute guys in there often, and hey, I'm always down for a little eye candy with my afternoon drink.  It's usually noisy, but I like that for getting work done.
author: Lauren E.

description:
Missionhipster haven it is, but DAAAANK are the brownies.  Quite similar to fudge, but in a more cake-like brownie form.  

Crowded, even at 9 in the evening.  And because caffeine has a half-life of 6 hours, so good effin' luck trying to get some shuteye after a cup o' this strong brew.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: The coffee is amazing. I mean it is really, exceptionally good coffee. BUT why oh why is the standard wait for a measly, teeny espresso or any espresso drink bordering on 15 minutes. (And I'm not talking about the line time, I'm talking about after ordering it!!) What the hell is going on? Is the theory that the longer I wait for a great tasting espresso, the more I'll appreciate the effort it took to make it? I'd love to stop in more often, but the saying between my biz partner and myself as we're driving by Ritual goes something like... "Quick coffee? Hey, we've got an extra half hour to kill before the meeting, let's go to Ritual." Overall the service is pretty good, but what's up with the sole espresso puller using one hand for the personal phone call and the other one for all of the espresso drinks. That day took the record for wait time, but the average is 15 min. Seriously.
author: Sandra H.

description: It's simply the best coffee and the best place to work on a computer in San Francisco. Brave the line, it does move. Ask to join a table with someone else. They rock coffee the way it should be done.
author: Margot M.

description: Great coffee, espresso drinks, and fresh roasted beans.  If you can get past the macfixedbloggers you'll have a good experience.  I just get mine to go, so I don't disturb their serious work.
author: Kevin W.

description: My favorite coffee in SF. The Baristas are always friendly.  The customers are super hip and fun to look at.  But, I get my Americano to go.
author: crystal r.

description:
coffee is overrated here. and man are they coffee nazi's. so rude!!!
the place itself is a fun place to hang out.
author: lapur p.

description:
oh double soy latte, since i had my first taste i was hooked on you.  sugar? no thanks, the espresso is so good it doesnt need it.  i put sugar in every latte from everywhere else.  the staff is amazing, and the little cupcakes....umm well they are little cupcakes.....

i give 5 stars...because they cant help it that lazy loiterers sit in  chairs with an empty coffee cup playing online gambling for hours at a time.  get a life, get a hobby, get the internet at home.
author: suzanne e.

description:
Ok. Before I start of this review, I should note that I'm one of those people who's perfectly ok with coffee that is made in a streetside cart, as long as there's enough sugar and milk. I don't care if the beans were grown in a backyard in Brooklyn or the steppes of Central Asia; if there's enough sugar, milk, and caffeine in there we're good. In other words, I'm not a coffee snob, I recoil in horror at the complexities of an expresso machine, etc.

I'm also not a hipster. My jeans tend to fit, my bike has nearly 20 gears, and while I own a MacBook I'm not a freelancer of any kind.

BUT. I loved this place. I walked in and there was a crazy sign about how the barista was a guest barista from somewhere else and he had just won the barista championships of the galaxy or something, so I was intimidated and quaking in my flip flops. Every single person in the place had a Mac. I get up to the counter. "Uh, can I get a cup of coffee, small, please?"

At this point I cringe, waiting for the sure-to-follow condescension to rain down upon me. "Coffee? From which continent? Would you like whole, skim, vegan, soy, foam? And small? Do you mean tall/skinny/short?" 

BUT no. The guy goes "sure, no problem. Anything else?" I'm amazed. I decide I want a latte, something I'd never order. (The coffee was for someone else.) 

A few minutes later I get an incredible cup of coffee and a wonderful looking latte with a leaf pattern in the foam. Most amazing of all was that I really liked the latte, even though I didn't put sugar in it. I could taste the coffee...and it was GOOD. Amazing. 

So...long story short: five stars for being not-douchebags, and for having really good coffee. I might just become a coffee snob with this place.
author: Vivek T.

description: Just had a double macchiato from here that was awesome. Super friendly staff. Its what you make of it.  If you can't find a place to sit take it to go.
author: Pat F.

description:
Can we say HELLA GOOD carrot cream cupcakes?

CUPCAKES!!! OMG. LOL. 

Love to you all at Ritual!
Happy Holidays!
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
* update * Tough to pick between Four Barrel (down the street) and Ritual. Feel like I get more consistent barista shots at 4 barrel, but Ritual remains a steady performer as well. They have later hours and take credit cards, which make it an easier choice late in the eve. **
I liked their cafe before... but since they started roasting, I am a superfan!
Their decaf espresso beans  are great. Double macchiattos are delish, and small enough to consume at the bar (convenient, since there is scarce seating). All of the baristas are competent, and a couple are stellar - producing perfect rosetta art, even in the smallest espresso-mug.
author: Robin K.

description: Between Ritual and Philz, San Francisco has offered the best coffee I've ever had. I prefer Ritual's atmosphere. They always have awesome art on the walls, the baristas have always been friendly, and there's no shortage of table space to hang out and work or play. The Honduras beans they have right now are awesome.
author: Damon K.

description:
Heard lots of hype.  Unfortunately the espresso was so acidic it tasted like metal.  This was confirmed by two other folks.  Maybe they were having an off day. 

The pastries looked terrible -- didn't even go near them.
author: Dave H.

description: Just because you make coffee from French Press doesn't mean that it needs to be gritty  with lots of silt in the bottom of the cup.  I know, I've used one at home for 5 years or so. Maybe not an expert, but I've definitely been called out as a coffee snob and I just don't understand the coffee from this place.......
author: aram s.

description: oh my goodness! excellent coffee all topped off with a beautiful milk foam design. i get the small latte and if it's busy (which on weekends is the usually the case) it's worth the wait every time!
author: Jenna S.

description: mmm mmm mission good... I used to drag myself to this place from the lower haight just to people watch.  The mission scene is at it's peak here, which is enjoyable in its own happy attitudinal kind of way.  Helps that the capps are top notch and never served without some sort of foamed design to boot.... details
author: Willy c.

description: Good coffee and chai.  Great scene.  A great place to hang out at.
author: Charles L.

description: double soy cappucino: yes. laptops hooked up like dialysis machines to their sallow sitters: please no. oh well, get it to go, gaze at the art while you wait. REALLY m.f. 'in GOOD smooth coffee.
author: Squinka C.

description: very tasty latte, and pretty friendly service to boot!  and they spelled my name (Jen, not Jenn) right.  w00t!
author: Jennifer L.

description: I'm not a coffee place kind of girl, cuz i dont like coffee...  BUT i needed a place to host a meeting and this was suggested, so i went.  got there at 6pm on a wednesday and it was pretty packed.  it's like coming to a bar at happy hr... you have to wait.  there was not a very long line at the register, i got my chai in just a couple minutes.  and it was YUMMY!  i would definitely get that chai again.  it comes in cute real cups (not paper) and i think was $3.20something for a medium.  There were little pastries there too, but i hadnt had dinner yet so didnt try it.  Of course there's coffee, but i cant say how it was.  Lots of spaces there for people on their laptops.  I guess its more social than being on the computer at home...  If i had a laptop i might go.  We got to sit on comfy couches and chairs that were like we were at someone's house, with a cute coffee table in the middle.  And no one bugged us to come around and buy more.  Very good experience.  If you didnt have to bart there (i like the muni) i'd go often!
author: Merredith L.

description: Ritual Coffee Roasters may very well be the Mission's answer to the esteemed Blue Bottle Coffee. Or maybe I'm getting it wrong and RCR came first. In any event, as I was in the area, I decided to give it a try. The ambiance is hands down, fantastic. How can you beat comfy leather couches, coffee tables stacked with the Chronicle and the Guardian, big bags of coffee beans in the back, and a gigantic coffee grinder! And more than enough wooden picnic style tables filled with a smattering of the local hipsters, their fixies lined up outside to prove it. At 10:15 on a Saturday, there was definitely a line, and I almost left thinking that I am beyond lines and won't put up with over hyped places. However, this line moved rather quickly, and within 5 minutes I was already placing my order, which was of course, the standard soy latte. The interesting thing about RCR is that their small is really incredibly small. Maybe a 5 oz cup, and I am used to a small latte being around 8 oz. So I asked if I could get a single shot in an 8 oz cup- I think they charged me more, but in any event that is how they get you money wise (don't be fooled thinking you are getting a regular sized small for 2.65, it ain't gonna happen). I waited by the counter and watched intently as they prepared my drink. These people are trying hard to be like Blue Bottle with their milk swirling artistry. However, I don't think they have it down just yet. The coffee was good, probably not as good as Blue Bottle, but I would definitely come back, just for the comfortable and relaxed coffee drinking atmosphere.
author: Kate A.

description:
so, I have to separate this review into two parts -- the cafe (its staff, its drinks, etc) itself and the people that go there.

The cafe itself is great.  The staff is friendly, the drinks and snacks are good (and well priced), they're open late, and there are a number of well-placed power outlets.  This is probably why it's so packed.

The people that go there are another story.  Let me tell you about tonight's experience.  It's totally packed.  So, my friend and I squish in at a large table in the back.  There aren't seats next to each other, we plan to sit across from each other.  I leave to buy us drinks.  As my friend inquires about the status of a seat with a purse in it, the woman who owns the bag snaps "what, the internet won't work on that side of the table?"  Beotch (and my friend didn't even have a computer!!).  My friend replies, "my friend is sitting here, and that's the only other available chair in this cafe."  The woman rolls her eyes and moves her purse.  Then later she makes some comment about how there are too many people on her side of the table ("why are there 6 people on this side of the table and only 2 on the other side?" -- the split was more like 4 and 3) and insists that my friend move to the other side.  Honestly, if she weren't so scraggly i would've taken her out.  But i kinda felt bad for her.

So, when another table opens, we move.  At this new table, we're squished, but we're happy.  More or less.  

I understand that when you're at a cafe, you can expect people to read your stuff.  But i don't expect people to comment on it.  I mean, maybe they're trying to make new friends or something, but really.  At least act like you're not reading my email or my dissertation please.

With so many cafes in the city, I must admit that I won't be returning to this one.  

If anyone has recs for that amazing cafe with good, well-priced food and drinks, free wireless, power outlets galore, nice people (both staff and customers), and isn't overcrowded, let me know!
author: S J.

description: Yes it is hipster, and the word has definitely gotten around... but good coffee is good coffee, and great coffee is even better! They have great coffee, and the cappuccinos are niiice. I like the couch and large communal table, but the customers are usually on labtops in their own bubble... so I guess the big table has no purpose. Maybe one day I will get lucky and engage in a random conversation with a stranger.
author: Alexandra a.

description:
by far my favorite coffee place
i love it here, it's expensive but fucking worth it.

i come all the way from alameda just to get some espresso.
author: King L.

description: Everyone feels compelled to point out to me that I "don't look a day over 16" or, on a good day "17." After that they feel compelled to tell me that I should take this is as a complement. Maybe it's just me, but being told that I don't look like I'm legally capable of making most decisions for myself doesn't feel like a complement. I can't wait to be older, or at least seem older, I often dress like a Sunday school teacher trying to look older. So you can imagine my surprise when I walked into Ritual for the first time and felt, you won't believe this, OLD. But not in the " I was drinking coffee before you were born" sense of old, in the "I really want to wash the smudged eyeliner off your face and buy you some properly fitting pants" sense of old. But even if the crowd makes me think I might actually be a Sunday school teacher, the service is perfectly friendly and that coffee is amazing. Coffee by itself is too much for me, so I usually drink au laits. Even latte's I stayed away from because of the dreaded espresso. But I'll have a latte here, and I gotta admit, it is gooood. As close to a drug as this Sunday school teacher will get.
author: Hallie R.

description: For the number of people behind the counter, you'd think the line would go faster.  Nonetheless, 2 stars for a surprisingly weak cup of coffee and the lame move of covering up all the power plugs on the weekends.  I expect a cup that puts hair on my chest and curls my toes, but this stuff is timid.  It reminds me of that Tom Waits song about the cup of coffee that couldn't defend itself.  I've had far better luck at Pete's or Muddy Waters on 24th & Valencia.  On the other hand, if you want to be seen, this is the place to be.  Just be sure to bring some iron-on tattoos and whatever dog/baby is handy.
author: Chris D.

description: starbucks in a thrift store dress.....ohh wait do the employees have health care...
author: chobs m.

description: 3 stars, mainly for the lack of wall outlets for us, PC USERS! oh yea, don't go to rituals if you're not a mac! please im begging you! LOL... i had their chai, and it hits you good...but next time, not gonna bring my laptop, unless they decided to have some respects with PC USERS!
author: Marc K.

description:
best espresso ever. not really a coffee drinker, but i know it's good because some of my best friends are coffee dorks and say it's equally on-par as stumptown. ritual gave me an appreciation for the art and depth of what coffee/espresso can be. so much that i won't drink lame lattes [read: most any other coffee from any other un-conscious coffee shop. it's like having real cheese after eating eazy cheez your whole life.]. 

i hate to deduct a star on a great business because of one person, but here lies the reason for the two star deduction: the tall dirty blonde girl with the tiny nose that works there. why do you have to be so snobby? ONE time i went in while you were at the register and i didn't tip. guess what? tips aren't mandatory. they're a kind gesture for good service and quality goods. and also, i live in sf - i am broke. and that was only ONE time of no tip. was it necessary to obviously talk shit about me to your bleached blonde barista friend? and to apparently hold a grudge about it, months later, so that every time i order from you and stick a dollar tip in your little jar i get no smile or greeting? ok, maybe you never even saw that i didn't tip; maybe you act like a snob because you don't like the way i dress, or because my hair is more bountiful than yours, or you secretly want to be 5'4. but you exude arrogance and you make me not want to step foot in my favorite coffee shop.

that said, the owners and rest of the staff that i've come in contact are super nice and genuinely appreciative, real people who treat return customers with respect.
author: Elle C.

description: I've been going to Ritual every so often since they opened.  They were pretty cool at the beginning but then they got too crowded after 8:00 AM. I like their coffee and applauded them for bringing in the Clover machines.  It's been a while since I visited so I decided to check them out. Boy what I disappointed!!  They've gone to the single cup method but when I asked for their darkest roast I was told, "we don't have anything that fits that flavor spectrum" and I was served an overpriced medium roast which I found "OK".  They also removed the roaster which leaves this location as SOS.  Next time I'm in the mood for Ritual Coffee I'll either go to Flora Grubb's or one of the many restaurants that serve their coffee...but with a more appealing atmosphere.
author: Dennis S.

description: Hands down the best latte I've EVER had. These people really know what they're doing and take the time to make sure each drink is made perfectly (as can be seen from the way they expertly pour the foam to make those cute little heart shapes in the cup). Their espresso is delicious and the foam in their lattes is always nice and creamy, even when ordering non-fat milk. They also have a small selection of teas which is a nice option for non-coffee drinkers (unlike the snobby and inferior Four Barrel).The service is excellent and no where near as pretentious as other local coffee shops (four barrel, blue bottle, philz). Just don't be in a hurry and wait your turn in line, it's DEFINITELY worth it!
author: lars s.

description: maybe i 'don't get it'. the coffee is always kind of sludgy. maybe i don't know anything about coffee. maybe it's supposed to be that way. the interior is 'pretty industrial', and i think they have some plants.
author: Sara M.

description:
so my boyfriend and I went to ritual coffee because everyone proclaims that it is comparable to our ever loved blue bottle. we did a taste test side by side.

one bitter, one ever so delicate
one with rich froth, one with not

Not saying that rituals coffee is horrid, but I stay true to what I love. My man & my coffee....

Either way, kudos to you ritual believers....but sorry ritual, you ain't got poop on blue bottle!
author: t f.

description: I have to say, I really like this place. The espresso is delicious, smooth and wonderfully flavorful (a little expensive, obviously, you're paying for pretention and also, presumably, for good quality coffee). Capps look good but I've never had one. I've also had a good time studying here--it's loud enough that I can't hear any particular conversation, which is conducive to focusing. It's a little dark, but there's a nice breeze on a beautiful summers day from the back door. And I've never had a problem finding a seat in the late-morning on the weekend.
author: Sam L.

description: Urgh, I've gotten a better one at McDonald's... I tried individually brewed Ethiopian and the weak stuff was nothing to write home about.  I'll stick to Philz and Blue Bottle from now on.  Two stars for ambiance.
author: tk s.

description: so i came by the other morning, there were two people in line including myself. this barista was a "locked" conversation with some woman and continued to s l o w l y complete the order in front of me as with my own. the man in front of me spoke up and then we finally got our drinks. * no apologies. here's the thing. i really like the drinks in every aspect, but i've decided that if i'm droppin' four dollars (w/tip) for an 8oz drink? i'm gonna spend it on beer from now on. i'll get my lattes elsewhere. i've been treated bad on too many occasions here. sorry ritual. money and time is too tight (like the pants on your employees) i've wasted too much of both giving my local the benefit of the doubt and i have to say that i've been let down.
author: Jubei K.

description: Don't believe the hype. First --and most important-- their coffee is just not that good. Even their fancy $4 clover coffee. That's reason enough not to patronize this place. Second, there is always a line out the door for their mediocre coffee. Third, there is probably one electric outlet in the entire place, presumably so you can only stay for exactly 45 minutes or however long your laptop battery lasts, before vacating your seat. Gotta keep that line moving, people! Fourth, this place is way too loud to get any work done anyway; I'd say it's less of a working place and more of a meeting place, Craigslist missed connection place, or a brood-alone-in-your-seat-regretting-the-$4-mediocre-coffee-you-bought-in-order-to-use-the-internet-for-45-minutes place. For better coffee, go to Philz. For a pleasant work atmosphere, try Sugarlump or Coffee Bar.
author: Tammy C.

description: had to edit my 5-star review to give them 1 star for removing all electric outlets.
author: Andrew N.

description: coffee is good--a little too robust, but, really, why is the music so fucking loud? biggie and puff daddy are giving me a terrible headache.
author: Y L.

description: Staff was rude. The coffee was terrible, it tasted like watered-down Sanka. The music was obnoxiously loud and the fusillade of banging doors, clanging plates and slamming plates absolutely drove us out the door.
author: J K.

description: I love this place. I go there nearly every weekend. They make great coffee: my favorite is the Sweet tooth Latte. Rituals has a good atmosphere and the staffers are generally pretty nice.
author: Jed C.

description: i love this place, they make coffee as a artform, best i have had in the city so far, but still more to check out!
author: dub g.

description: I really wasn't going to review it, but alas, I spend so much time here I have come to depend on it.  I wasn't even a regular coffee drinker until I became addicted to the toddy.  Really, even on windy, wet san francisco days I crave the subtle drive of my small cup of toddy to go, low on the ice please.  I want to give them 5 stars, but I am a hard ass and nothing is ever perfect.  Like the faulty wireless, or the lack of any brain food.  Despite the recent rap for a "hipster hang-out", which it is in all honesty, I think Ritual does a great job of maintaining a (socially) diverse crowd, thanks to that naturally occurring caffeine in every delicious and beautifully presented cup.
author: Lauren S.

description:
i prefer taking my drink & pastry to go, but if you don't mind the too cool for school, uber-hip, arty vibe permeating the coffee house, then it's a good place to hang out, people watch, and count the slew of mac laptops, if you're lucky enough to get a table. 

my one small complaint is their hot chocolate. nice presentation, but way too much froth and not enough chocolate. i've ordered it from them two times. thinking the first time might have been a one-off mistake, i ordered it again, only to be handed a second cup of hot frothed milk with a mere tinge of chocolate. totally disappointing for the hot chocolate enthusiasts. why can't the tattooed hipster over the counter get it right?
author: cat T.

description: when I want some coffee and I am around the mission, I always end up in this place.  the coffee is good, the service very friendly and clientele friendly as well. noisy?  sometimes, but still RCR is a very nice place to have your cup of coffee.
author: sixth s.

description: Latte was good. Based on reviews, I was expecting great. Frankly no better than McDonalds.  Caveat:  I haven't tried the drip coffee. And this did seem like a fun place to hangout
author: J M.

description: Disappointment. I am a big coffee lover, and had heard about Ritual coffee for quite a while. I was very surprised to realize my wife and I were walking past the coffee house after dinner. Despite the late hour and overly hipster crowd hanging out inside, I had to go in and try a cup the famous coffee. As I said, it was quite disappointing. The coffee was weak and a little watery. I think I'll stick to my preferences of Blue Bottle and Peet's.
author: Joe C.

description: there is a reason why there's always a line out the door.  they don't have many drink choices here, which is good, b/c you know a smaller menu means better quality in what they actually have.  their lattes are deliciously smooth, and the milk is frothy, just the way i like it.
author: Helen T.

description: I'd give this 3 and 1/2 if I could.  Nice environment, very good coffee.  They could improve the iced coffee.  Beans are good compared to a chain, but Blue Bottle clearly better.  I'd put this somewhere in between Peets and Blue Bottle.  Clearly dedicated to the craft (except for iced coffees) but I'm personally just not that huge a fan of their beans.
author: r h.

description:
i just had the best espresso of my life here... which says a lot... beautiful deep crema, super complex and chocolaty flavor... huh stumptown beans??... i thought i'ld never see them again after leaving p-town. 
great service, great space, good music. to the people feeling out of place... uhh drink your bitchin coffee and relax.... the hipsters are too self absorbed to notice or care what you are wearing.
update: minus one star because wtf kind of price is $1.63 for a mug of coffee?$1.63?? ok, maybe im just annoyed at digging through my bag for pennies. or maybe it's the fact that the $1.40 "to go" coffee is bigger than the aforementioned $1.63 "for here" mug. wierd taxes i guess. i'll just take it in a paper cup, sit on the street next time and save my pennies. also, the mass-produced press-pot coffee that they have on tap wasnt as sludgetastic as the pots i make at home, but still woke me up for sure.
author: Abi K.

description:
So, I don't pretend to be a "hipster" or anything else for that matter, but I like good coffee and when I'm at Flora Grub (the nursery in Bayview) or in the Mission, I've enjoyed the good coffee these folks have served for years.  The latte's are awesome.  No, I'm not some kind of coffee geek, in fact, I'm probably everything these "hipsters' hate but will one day themselves become.  I'm in a number of investment partnerships and end up traveling to a number of great places around the world  both work and pleasure and can say most often, I'm spoiled to find good coffee, albiet unique to that countries taste and culture.  But, I've always been able to order my Latte as I like it, with a pack of Equal or some local artificial sweetner on hand.   Ok, I know it' an "unnatural"," not substainable" chemical but this is how I like it.   And, I can say I'm amoung the millions of people, (some quite intelligent, educated, successful and well traveled) who take their coffee to their own taste.

So, here is the deal, it's a lovely Saturday over the 4th of July weekend and we're looking for some landscaping plants to add to our home in Napa.  I order my usual, "non-fat, coffee latte with one Equal.  The barista, named Keith, said he wouldn't make it that way for me.   I ask why, and he tells me he wouldn't because the equal would ruin "his" coffee.  Now, I can understand the gentleman takes pride in his work but I'm really quite interested in why it matters to him since I will be the one drinking the coffee, notwithstanding I'm paying for it.  He tells me "it's complicated".  He tells me he's "a barista" and he just won't make coffee in any way he thinks sucks.   To be honest, I was quite taken back, not that I couldn't put my discusting  chemical in my coffee (which I did after the fact,) but that I found it so counter intuitive that this person could make and serve such a good cup of coffee but the service and insulting attitude would ruin the whole experience.  Remeber, there is no essense of "second hand Equal" permeating the air and in the spirit of the Fourth of July, "my latte is my business" and I think there must some connection with our Independence Day and our ability to drink our Latte's as we like.   No matter where you shop, dine or exist, most people, even hipsters, like friendly, accomodationg people, without which most people will eventually stop forking over their money because "the coffee goes sour with a sour puss".
author: Mike G.

description: Ritual's coffee is better than Four Barrel, but not as good as Blue Bottle.  This cafe is extremely popular and the interior is starting to fall apart from the amount of traffic - leather sofas in front window were sticky and crumb-filled, tables not wiped down in between customers, and it is just generally feels dilapidated and not in the cool way.  I think head-to-head I would go to Four Barrel - much better space and Dynamo Donuts tip the scale.
author: Lori G.

description: Ritual has, by a longshot, the best coffee in my neighborhood.  They know what they're doing.  Good business ethics, better coffee.  When they opened I tried some of the pastries which weren't great.  My girlfriend loves this place.  I refuse to go there.  I ordered a double shot to go.  They wouldn't do it.  They tried to insist I drink it right there as the quality would degrade upon touching the vile paper of the cup.  I insisted that I had paid for it and would prefer it to go.  Grudgingly, and with a grimace, the barrista sloshed it into my to go cup.  By this time most of the employees were looking at me.  I hadn't made a scene, no yelling or harsh words, but I really wanted it to go.  Then I asked for a dash of cold soy milk.  They all froze, mouths straining to stay shut.  The barrista sighed, pushing the soy milk towards me.  That whole scenario was a little creepy.  I sling coffee for a living, and I try to provide good beverages, but jesus!  I'm sorry, I just like it this way.  I didn't order a frappachino or whatever!  I appreciate your handcrafted caffienated beverage but don't be so floofy.  I vowed then I would rather drink folgiers boiled on a stove and drained thru a paper towel than give them my money.  Or I guess Muddy Waters.  Occasionally I walk past, and give in to the smell of really good coffee and send my girl in to get me some.  I still wont go in.  So you see, I would give them five stars but I'm just not that hip.
author: Jett S.

description: There are a lot of jackasses that hang out here and their pastries suck, but damn, they make the best latte in the city
author: Cody R.

description: the coffee here is better than i have had anywhere else with any consistency in my life.  plus, it looks pretty.  the coffee, that is.   each foamy beverage comes with an artisan touch, not that the rich, deep brown brew isn't gorgeous with its glistening coffee bean oils swirling around.  there is usually great art on the walls, there is tons of bike parking, and if you want to sit, there is free wifi.  every drink they make is magic.
author: Kate M.

description: i feel nauseated every time i walk in this place. there's a long wait, so i have plenty of time to quietly hate myself for having no self-control. it's like when you have a crush on some jerk-- the head of the college Young Republicans for instance. you despise everything about this person, his politics, his style, his self-satisfied smirkiness. but you'd knock boots with the dude in a second 'cos he's so fine. anyway, that's how it is with the soy capp. so fine. in fact, i even have a Ritual coffee card: a punch hole for every time i've given into my weakness. i'm already just shy of a free cup.
author: Bill B.

description: Best macchiato I have ever had.  I really can't believe how much better it was than the same drink ordered at so many other places.  And the decaf beans I bought, with a clearly marked roasting date from the previous day, produced the best home espresso and lattes I have made.  Only two complaints:  service is a bit slow, and the macchiato was definitely not decaf, even though the barista who announced my drink for pickup repeated that it was decaf.  If you are as sensitive to caffeine as I am, make sure they really give you decaf.  Perhaps they thought it would taste better and I wouldn't know.  But as the clock ticked past 2am, 3am, 4am, then 5am while I lay awake, there wasn't a whole lot else on my mind.
author: Jack N.

description: The ultimate be-seen spot in San Francisco. Row upon row of miniature laptops, large cups bearing the Ritual logo (a tilted cup and star strongly reminiscent of the ominous soviet sickle and star), Eliot Smith hurting too loud in surround sound, and, finally, not a symmetrical haircut in its admittedly cavernous interior. There's lots of comfortable seating, however, and my triple shot latte was one of the better ones I've had in my travels, albeit expensive at an even four bucks. For all the combined productivity of so many laptops humming away it seemed as though nobody could keep his eyes on the screen for too long without glancing up to see the newest spread of hipsters waiting to place their orders. Hipsters everywhere I tell you! Something's off, as if they're all models in a photo shoot (say, "Cafe Chic"?) instead of real people working on homework. Fashion puts them at one remove from their mundane activities. Can you really study chemistry underneath that haircut? In those shoes?
author: Davi M.

description: best coffee in the city. free wireless. wear your black turtleneck.
author: Ellen B.

description: Fuck. The coffee here is amazing. And that's not an overstatement like claiming Pink Floyd's The Wall is one of the most revolutionary rock albums ever. It's the truth. Remember how John Locke's definition of property rights involved the infusion of one's labor of love into an object held natually in common? Nevermind, but be glad that the people who grind, pound, and pour your espresso are sharing it with you. And feel entitled, you smug San-Franciscan-who loves-the-smell-of-your-own-farts, to realize that Ritual exists for you and you only while your Central Valley brethen are relegated to the mere convenience of having a Starbucks on every block. Yes, Ritual serves as a pre-Critical Mass pitstop every last Friday of the month, and yes, many if not all of the people seen here typing away furiously on a Mac are self-employed freelancers but what the fuck, the least you can do is grab your goddamn coffee and go about your merry way.
author: Jenn W.

description: i'm a big fan of good coffee.  i will go out of my way for good coffee.  but... good coffee is only as good as your enjoyment of it.  it is sort of like if a tree falls in the forest and there is no one to hear it, does it make a sound?  if you have a good latte, but can't enjoy it, is it really good?  as good as the coffee is (and it really is quite good), the ambiance is just uncomfortable.  this place is so very, very cool.  so very, very cool that it makes me tense up and want to run away.  i don't have the right pants for this place and i certainly don't have the right shoes.  also, my hair is all wrong.  and my hair and my shoes should have nothing to do with my enjoyment of my latte.
author: Samantha W.

description: 'i'm addicted to the coffee and the vibe' .... was my review about a year ago. now i am often disappointed by the service and the coffee. the coffee is not very consistent, sometimes i get a great tasting one and just as often i find that i'm given a drink that was made by someone who doesn't know how to make one.
author: Barbara W.

description: so this place is seriously a pillar within the new movement of coffee houses in the bay area, their emphasis on small roasting batches, lighter roasting ( so you can taste the bean), freshness and single origin beans. takes coffee to a new level. effitianatos  may quibble about whether they are better than blue bottle or 4 barrels, but ive been to them all, and each has its own personality. they all rock and each has its own benefit, Ritual shines in that it is open late night, the music is always pumping and their always roasting fresh right there on premise. cant help but feel the art and the respect for the bean. much love to ritual
author: roman p.

description:
am not sure what the fuss is about, to be honest. i live in the mission and always go to philz on 24th. but i recall this place as i waited here 3 years back, after just landing in SF. so, finally got around to going back there. it is loud, extremely loud. and the coffee is very average (i had a mocha). there's no reason to ever go back here.
i havent been to blue bottle but the best coffee place is Barefoot in the south bay. Their Mocha Borgia is unbeatable.
author: Arvind A.

description: i liken this place to in-n-out burger (which is a good thing).  they know what they do here, and they do it well.  the menu is efficient and non-glorified.  if you're looking for a no whip sugar free vanilla caf double shot latte [sic] , this is no place for you.  the place is spacious and i dig the decor.  if you go on the weekend, you may have to vie for a spot.  they have an array of couches, a bar and regular tables/chairs to suffice any seating enthusiast.    good coffee.  good space.  good stuff.
author: Amy W.

description: Ridiculous!  Another candidate for the Emperor's New Clothes Award.  $3.75 for a mug of coffee 10 minutes after the order is taken?  I don't think so.  Coffee is quite good, but certainly not that good.  (The place is also full of hipper-than-thou Mission poseurs).
author: Ritch G.

description: Great atmosphere to grab a cup of coffee sit on your laptop and get some work done. It almost reminds me back to the days of college where you looked for a nice local coffee to shop to become caffeinated and focused on the textbook ahead or perhaps people watch. It's a bit slower than the normal place, but as long as you are not taking it to go or on a rush, this is a great place to get a cup of coffee.
author: Jeannette L.

description: Best coffee I had in SF. Everything else I tried was really...poorly made. I'm not particularly concerned about latte art, but theirs was beautiful which does show attention to detail, and, of course, a sign of good milk foaming. The coffee itself was delicious, rich, and completely comparable to Stumptown (the standard I judge all coffee by).
author: Kristen W.

description: The cappuccino is even smoother and creamier than Peet's. Slick design. Full of laptop-bearing hipsters.
author: Bob S.

description: Nights that I hang out in Mission aren't that many but sometimes Ritual is the reason to go to Mission.  Their smooth espresso or house blend and so San Francisco like atmosphere make me drink more coffee!!!  Is it good?  It became so popular it is hard to find a seat late at night but their espresso rocks!!!
author: Su Kyeong K.

description:
i will always wait in line at a place that knows how to steam soy milk RIGHT for my coffee drinks!

if you're waiting on the weekend brunch line for boogaloos, a trip to ritual makes the wait go by a lot faster.
author: J K.

description: not as good as  blue bottle.  my macchiato had way too much milk, BUT it is a close 2nd to blue bottle.  great logo and t-shirt design and a quintessential mission district hang-out.
author: Betsy K.

description: the 2 times that i have been here, i've had to sit in the back corner by the bathrooms because this place is so packed. the coffee/tea is descent but not fabulous enough for me to wait in the long line to get my beverage and wait again for some seats to free up. people who use the wifi i notice don't have any food/beverage on their tables so it leads me to believe that this is not a trendy, hipster, or "be seen" hangout. it is simply a place for kids who can't pay for their own wifi/internet service. the only time you see me in here is because my friends love it. maybe i'm the only gal in sf that doesn't own a pair of skinny jeans? nah well.
author: Linda T.

description: tasty coffee, awesome free wifi connection and overall great spot in the mish.  love it!
author: Ken L.

description: when i first moved to SF, Ritual was one of the places a friend recommended for me to check out. see, my friends know I'm somewhat of a coffee and beer elitist, having lived in Portland (aka the land of microbrews and independent coffee roasters) forever. and yes, for a while I went to Ritual fairly regularly. that's 'cause they used to use Stumptown (from Portland of course!) beans for their espresso and well, my palate is quite used to the coffee of my 2nd hometown... but then about a year or so ago, Ritual started using their own espresso roast - which, while still pretty decent, is just a tad on the bitter side for me. I still like to plunk down and chill with the hipsters and their computer gadgetry once in a while, but not as much as I used to.
author: ray e.

description: Awesome beans!  I ordered a bag of Finca el Guayabo and Hacienda la Esmeralda online.  MMmmm, so good.  2 day shipping, shipped the next day after roasting.  Now it's time to move to San Francisco.
author: Johnny B.

description:
Was really looking forward to this place, what with all the comparisons to Blue Bottle. The Valencia store is close to where I work, and I dropped in to check it out, with the intent to buy beans to take home as well.
Crowd is arrogant, staff is super friendly. I literally was blocked from reading the coffee descriptions on the wall by 5 guys holding (not drinking, mind you) coffee drinks. They seemed put out that I was standing in their midst. The remainder of the crowd could have been in any shop in Seattle (where I'm from) so didn't even really register as anything but normally hipper-than-thou, to be expected. When I finally sussed out how buying stuff worked, I elbowed my way back to the front, and bought a pound of good coffee. But that's it. It was good. Not spectacular. I've bought past-pull date Blue Bottle coffee (half price at a certain store I know) and loved it way more. I use a drip ceramic filter, so maybe that's the problem, Ritual is for espresso only? But a medium roast with all that hyperbole should benefit from the ceramic, not just roll over. Blah. Again, fine quality, but not life-changing like I had hoped. Probably won't bother with it again.
author: michelle o.

description: The drip coffee's solid-- sometimes a bit sour for my tastes-- but the espresso's amazing.  I had a Gibraltar here that was so good I had to go back for another (which of course left me gibbering like a madman until I crashed hard hours later).
author: Matt F.

description: its hard to find a table here. or a place to sit. but when i do, i feel like im a part of something alive. its weird, a hipster ant farm, a run into your ex kind of place, a place where if you go, you are annoyed at the crowd, but if you dont, you are missing out on something. coffee good. lemonade good.
author: coffeecake j.

description: The place is generally filled with hipsters and I usually feel out of place...but they make all of their drinks to perfection.
author: Sierra d.

description: best cappuccino in the city.  too bad it is so crowded.  maybe if someone else would figure out how to make a cappuccino...
author: Jason H.

description: excellent vegan pastries and good coffee. downside is that its very crowded and hard to find a table.
