You can wait forever for one to clear which is frustrating  when you're just looking to sit down and enjoy a cup of joe.  Most of them are occupied with people with laptops and you know they are there to stay.
author: Beena A.

description: damn good cuppa joe.
author: Adrienne G.

description: coffee is decent, but i was frowned upon when i ordered my 'cafe americano decafe.' a bit much attitude, just get over it, it is just coffee.  this is SF not paris.... for a nicer experience, get a coffee to go, and walk over to the nice, family owned Mission Creek cafe down the street, and have a cookie while you browse the internet.  Really...we can do with attitude...
author: reena a.

description:
i would give them five stars if the staff was nice and friendly.
the espresso is definitly great, but some people working there think they know it all ! come on people! not every customer you have is ignorant about coffe, be humble please.
author: james b.

description: 1st time I waited 20 minutes for the barista to make 3 espresso drinks. I assumed by the time I got mine it would be worth the wait. it was not. it was very weak and kind of expensive.  2nd time I figured maybe last time was a fluke. I got an iced coffee that was so weak it was almost undrinkable. There will not be a 3rd visit.
author: ELLIE S.

description: Best coffee in SF!  They respect the art of making coffee. Patience required.
author: Mike G.

description: best espresso in the city. buttery-smooth. free wi-fi if you're that attached to your laptop, and a pretty decent selection of baked goods. perfect early morning stop before hitting up garage sales in the area.
author: Jess T.

description: this weekend, in honor of my friend leah's visit from chicago, she and i visited ritual for a cup of coffee off the clover.  the guy behind the couter knew his shit, and not only made us our delicious rwanda sourced coffee on the clover, he also took a moment to chat with us about our coffee preferences and offered us a sample of the guatemalan blend from the french press.  nom nom nom.
author: emmie k.

description:
As far as coffee goes, this place is awesome. Their espresso is thick and delicious and they are superb latte artists. The baristas here really know what they are doing--I mean, they do regularly send their baristas to national competitions. The gripe about the long lines... here is the thing about Syneso and La Marzocco machines: The baristas manually dose the amount of espresso into the filter, manually pack, or tamp, the espresso, then WATCH the shots whilst making other drinks; and that's just the shots side. Places like Ritual (and Intelligentsia and Lamille in LA) don't use huge pitchers to steam milk, like Starbucks and other chains, each latte has its own little pitcher of milk. Starbucks and other chains have ingrained in people that three minutes is the max wait time for an espresso drink--but again, this ISNT starbucks. If you're in a hurry, don't come here. It's a gourmet establishment--you're getting good shit.

Ambiancewise, if you like fixed gears, Mac books, and long, greasy hair, then you'll like this place. I don't like that stuff. The times that I have been here, I have never, ever wanted to sit anywhere in the shop. 

But f!ck do they have awesome espresso.
author: Ryan C.

description: yummy coffee, great ambiance and mexican food just around the corner.
author: parker h.

description: nice space in mission! parking is a pain. like to come here often, but its a bit up and down in terms of experience. power source for laptops can be hard to find, if that matters to you. staff is non-chalant. still, i dont mind the place on a quiet sunday evening
author: Sai M.

description: super friendly and super yummy, so neccessary. no food, but it's all about the coffee here, the soy latte has me hooked!
author: Ginger R.

description: My work from home location, due to free wifi and excellent music. You can camp all day without a problem -- I just get another drink when it gets busy to not take advantage of them. Several nearby places for lunch too.
author: Travis C.

description: will increase my star when they patch things up with their old tea suppler in the east coast and bring back GINGER CARAMEL...other than that ...the sea of black-rimmed introverts starring aimlessly into the macbook is always predictable...
author: dion l.

description: gibraltars. clover machine. some tasty sidamo to buy. always a reason to stop in, but never really a reason to stay too long. one of the best roasters in the city though.
author: Jaei P.

description: berkeley has the best cafes to read in, hands down. but i'm not an undergrad anymore, and my taste in coffee has gone up as well. so i like ritual roasters. it's always a bit of a zoo but i've been lucky so far in being able to get a table. only twice have i been lucky enough to snag the side tables with the great lighting. the cappucino is tasty, the people watching is entertaining, and the artwork is always great distraction from whatever i'm supposed to read.
author: Helen K.

description: Solid french press coffee offerings.   Cool shop.   Would be 5 star if not for the unwanted attitude from the cashier.   Get over yourself.
author: m. f.

description: The coffee and espresso are consistently burnt and too strong. (It's not normal to have grinds floating in my coffee, is it?) I agree with the reviews of pretty much every other coffee place in the neighborhood -- I've been to them all a bunch -- but the reviews here are just so off.
author: N C.

description: Love this place!  The coffee is great and served in these adorable cups.  I know, I know, I love the details.  The ambience is casual, a little bohemian, with some great tunes playing on the radio.  The crowd is really diverse from Mission hipsters to relaxed students typing away on their laptops while listening to their own iPods.  And the cupcakes.  I can't forget to mention that they have these mini cupcakes that are amazing!
author: P L.

description: Ritual brews the coffee on the weak side.  I prefer Phil'z, where each cup of coffee is brewed to order.  I hear that Ritual's beans are good, but I buy my beans from Phil'z, too.
author: Sun L.

description:
if the coffee wasn't so fucking good i would pass on the hipster fashion show and mac parade.

last time i was there i watched this girl get into a fight with the barista. it was rather amusing. they don't like cell phones in line apparently.
author: parker t.

description: Great coffee and although it is always crowded, I can always find a place to sit.  Very hip, wear your white belt.
author: pauline e.

description: One word.... Yum! If you put aside the whole "place to be seen" thing, you have an amazing cup of coffee! Keep up the good work!
author: Coffee C.

description: They let us sit around forever drinking our coffee and playing scrabble.  Much better to watch all of the goings on here (busy day and night) while my opponent tries to spell something with their 7 lousy letters than staring at the walls in my home.  Perfect place on a cold SF day.
author: d l.

description: Ritual's coffee IS good, probably some of the best to be found, but the place is so unappealing.  Part of it's the employees.. in the handful of times I been there, I don't think I've ever seen one of them crack a smile and they never explain their system of picking up the drinks, so often the drink sits there getting cold while you ask if it's yours and they give you a look of contempt.  But the atmosphere is also the problem.. sterile and loud, much like being in a warehouse.  It smells good tho, especially when they are roasting up a batch.
author: Jules S.

description: Best coffee I EVER HAD so far! Excellent atmosphere, you can smell the coffee once you step into the store. Whener you order a Latte they will kindly offer you the "art of the coffee" right in front of you. This place is pack all the time; but it worth all the waits. Lucky that I lived close by so I get to have it everyday!!
author: MF M.

description: On one of my frequent walks up and down Valencia Street, I joked to a friend that there are an absurd number of coffee houses in the area whose patronage depends solely on aspiring first-time novelists that care less about the taste of the coffee the venue provides than the availability of patio seating and wireless connectivity for their iBooks. As it happens, just a few minutes later I was directed to Ritual, and lo, Madame Irony made a well-timed appearance. On my first visit, I had a regular coffee, and thankfully it lacked the burnt flavor common to the dark roasts at many chain coffee shops. The coffee was poured from a French press rather than a drip machine; thus it was brewed using the coffee aficianado's method of choice and was served hot but well south of scalding. I've since learned that the coffee is always brewed in a French press and then stored in thermal urns; rather than continuously heating the coffee in the urns, each batch is discarded and replaced with a freshly brewed one every twenty minutes. The espresso drinks I've ordered since that initial visit have been notably better than most and have had a rich, thick foam to them that puts the wispy froth one gets at other coffee joints to shame. The place is spacious, with more than three-quarters of the area dedicated to table and couch seating, and well-lit -- both traits rare to coffee houses in the vicinity. While still in its first few weeks in business, Ritual has quickly grown in popularity, and the clientele, it seems, is skewing hip and attractive, so it's on the verge of becoming a prime people-watching spot. The bottom line, though, is that you can come for the coffee with the amenities being secondary, rather than the other way around, and you won't be disappointed.
author: Eugene P.

description: I've been a daily regular at ritual for three years. valencia and 21st is my home. I would pay $1.50 for an 8 oz cup, chat with my barista and be on my way in a quick minute. you can no longer get an 8 oz cup, the prices were raised, and the coffee is not ready when you order it, taking up to 15-20 minutes to get your cup. This is fine and dandy for people from other neighborhoods that can justify spending $3 on their coffee everyday. Many people who pay rent in this neighborhood can not justify $3 for a cup. This new change in policy now supports people with more money from other neighborhoods coming into this neighborhood and spending more money than we have, further gentrifying the mission. I understand this is the reality of what is happening to valencia st. I defended ritual for years for supporting the average joe, but now i brew my own coffee. I just want people to be conscious of when they go to other neighborhoods to spend money from their higher salaries than those residents actually living in the neighborhood.
author: Veronica E.

description: good coffee. free wifi, but it's always so slow and spotty despite the fact that they run two separate access points there. it's sufficient for email and web browsing, but i can't get any real work done here. power outlets are a little hard to find. that also goes for seats most of the time. it's too bad, because i like the atmosphere, the music, and the art on display. if they would improve the wifi situation, i would spend more time here. i do give them kudos for offering spoons for stirring your coffee, instead of disposables.
author: Ben H.

description: So my coffee shop experiences so far in the short time I have lived in San Francisco are limited to Starbucks (of course ... simply for the convenience), Blue Bottle, and now Ritual Coffee Roasters.  I went early afternoon so their was no line.  I walked straight up to the register and ordered my double latte.  Sometimes going to a coffee shop and ordering for the first time can be intimidating.  Everybody uses their own coffee language!  Tall is small, flat means now foam?, skinny means nonfat or lowfat?  Simply put I ordered a double latte and no questions asked the woman at the register picked up a cup asked me for my name and that was that!  As I began to pay I noticed my all time favorite coffee, Ethiopia Harar!  I ordered a half pound ... I was so excited.  As I got home and opened up I was a little disappointed.  It wasn't roasted very dark leaving behind the full potential that exists ... that rich sweet blueberry characteristic.  Nonetheless my latte was great (made with a cute little heart atop the perfect layer of foam).  Now I can officially begin my day.
author: Mark S.

description: ok. i admit. it. i came here to use the bathroom. i have a bladder the size of a pea and though i love my bookstore trek through the mission there is never anywhere to find a clean bathroom.  however, even after discovering the (remarkably) clean bathrooms, i stayed. i am not a coffee person (i love me some samovar) but i can appreciate that their coffee is better than most. also, it's large yet cozy and slightly hipster but not in a bad way. i love places with no cell phone rules even if it means i have to go outside in the cold to take a call. my one gripe was that i could not find a trash can. anywhere. which was just weird for a coffee house. aside from that i could see coming here for more than the bathroom.
author: Rachel S.

description: excellent coffee, friendly people, awesome ambiance--my favorite cafe in San Francisco!
author: Sheila S.
